Posts.Content: Wow, what rotten luck, especially after all you've both been thru. I'd say don't worry too much about it right now until it can be investigated further. The 3mm lung nodule could be anything, but the lymph node is certainly unusually large. Has she or have you had the chance to speak with the doctor yet? (or did I miss that?) Without her doctor's input you're really just shooting in the dark. I hope it ends up being something that is either easily treatable or perhaps requires no action at all. We can always hope, right? Prayers for you both!
Posts.Title: new worries

Posts.Content: What I've read is that the length of time between RP and RT is not significant, but the PSA level at which RT is initiated is quite significant. Hence many doctors are advocating SRT as soon as an elevating pattern is established. With a rising PSA, then higher PSA also means longer time passed before starting, so they are related. I just passed the halfway point in my RT (18 more to go I think) and bowel issues started the second week... frequent urgency and loose bowels, occasional diarrhea (2X/week or more). Normally I am regular as clockwork. One cup of coffee and two minutes in the throne room. No other SE's at this time, but I hear the last couple weeks brings on fatigue that lasts for several weeks following conclusion of Tx. Good luck to you and your father. There will be some dietary restrictions (varies by RO) and the water/bladder requirement. Bowel issues if any will impact the bladder requirement. It's a bit tough, but nothing compared to what has been thru already. Showing up every day in time is imperative, but the procedure itself is not the least bit uncomfortable.

Posts.Content: Rooster, I'm right behind you dude, and have already been warned not to expect a miraculous rebound. My last six month shot was in January and my T level this month is 9. My Uro said it would take a year or two to go back up, but will probably never be what it was before (whatever that was, as no one ever tested it before). Also I'll be 68, was on it for 18 months and I only have one testicle anyway.... but looking forward to sleeping on dry sheets once again someday!

Posts.Content: CT was Monday. Pancreas is okay, but... there is a 3cm mesenteric mass of unknown origin in the small bowel. Here we go again, I guess.
Posts.Title: The waiting game... (long)

Posts.Content: Things seemed to be going well. PSA is zero, and no more Lupron injections. Nothing to do now but wait for the HT to wear off over the next couple of years and see what if anything the PSA does. So it seemed like a good time to re-attack a few older medical problems that had been back-burnered by the prostate cancer a few years ago. So grab a drink, get comfy and let me take you on a ride. I've had eye, sinus and mouth problems for a long time, and have a big scar on my neck from surgeries around 35 years ago. And just as my PSA had started out (long story) my first few stabs at getting treated were met by "oh that's nothing to be concerned about" from the medical community, or "here, take this and come back in six months". With my adjuvant radiation out of the way last fall, I had an ENT look up my nose and he said he saw a "mass" in there, and wanted a CT scan. Great, just what I needed... more radiation. So instead he ordered an MRI, which was inconclusive. He put me on megadoses of gabapentin for a few months and the pain in my throat (nose? tongue? Pharynx?) subsided. I slept a lot and put on ten pounds, which I finally managed to lose this year. But I was still having trouble breathing, so he did a septoplasty (and turbinoplasty... look it up, "turbinators", like Ahh-h-nold) ... I had broken my nose a half dozen times in high school, basically every sport they tried to make me participate in. Why don't they "force" jocks into math and science competitions? Made sense that the deviated septum was the problem. It took a couple months to heal up. But now one side of my nose is completely closed off. Not what I had hoped for. At least I'm not coughing up phlegm for the first few hours of every day. So then I have my annual eye exam with my fourth ophthalmologist and he puts me on yet another expensive eye drop (you've no doubt seen commercials for them) which worked no better than the ones that I had been on for five years before that. So I dug out the business card for yet another ophthalmologist (#5) whom I had been referred to last year when I was going thru the "AUS-and-ART" phase of my PCa treatment. So no time for yet another eye doc then, but now the time seemed right. So he pokes me in the eye and says "I've seen this before " (it's a somewhat rare condition) and started me on 60mg/day of prednisone. He wanted CT's of my brain and face. (Great, just what I needed... more radiation.) Got that about a month ago, just after seeing my ENT again for a follow-up on the septoplasty. ENT says my nasal valve is incompetent... that's an actual medical term. As he was the throat guy (who had ordered the MRI) he refers me to his nose and sinus associate to discuss putting what he called a "clip" in my cheek to hold my nose open. Turns out this is a new procedure currently undergoing clinical trials. Interesting concept. Hey, at least it's not cancer! So I say oh by the way I just happen to have this CT study of my face from the eye doctor, and he looks at it and says I have a bony deformity that is fairly common, but for most it is not a problem. We discuss the implant procedure to be included as part of surgery to remove some of the bone deformity from the base of my skull (!!!) and I schedule the surgery for next month. The scheduling nurse asks, how long you gonna be on prednisone? I dunno. Back to the eye doc, a neuro-ophthalmic and occuloplastic surgeon (fortunately he has never mentioned surgery) and he has me tapering down on the prednisone... 60-50-40, and this week 30mg/day. Apparently this is a lot of prednisone. I didn't know. So I figure I'd better get in to see my GP just so he knows all the stuff I've got going on. I'm telling all this to my GP and he kind of gives me one of those looks, like what the hell are you doing? He says my cheeks are widening and I am developing "moon face" (again, an actual medical term, look it up) and he starts poking me in the belly. Does that hurt? No, but if you poke hard enough, it will. Then he orders some bloodwork. So yesterday his nurse calls and tells me that I have pancreatitis and he wants more bloodwork, which I had this morning, and a CT scan of my abdomen. (Great, just what I need... more radiation.) So now I wait. Called the eye doc and turns out he never sent a report to my PCP. The healthcare system in Florida is overwhelmed and the patient has to follow up on literally everything. If you don't then stuff just falls thru the cracks. Nurses are constantly busy shuffling papers and answering the phone, and then don't remember if they already took care of the one in their hand so just put it on a stack, where it gets buried and ends up in the warehouse from the end of "Raiders of the Lost Ark" where it will never be seen by those "top men". So now it's Friday. I may get a call telling me to rush to the hospital... or maybe not. The prednisone has me all jittery anyway... hard to sleep. Really revved up. And now I gotta worry about something new? Maybe? All I know so far is my doc said NOT to have implant surgery while I'm on prednisone, so I called the ENT's office to cancel the surgery. I hope they got the message. No one has called back yet. So I sit and wait... tick, tock.
Posts.Title: The waiting game... (long)

Posts.Content: Ken, when have you ever complained about anything? Anywho, I actually posted the story to be entertaining, not whining or venting. Beyond some of the strange names for things, the fact that they all wanted CT's was just too coincidental. Plus the fact that some coincidences worked in my favor ("I just happen to have this CT disc done last week") and others seemed to blow up my best made plans... a pill is making me postpone the surgery that had seemed to fall into place so conveniently. MF - You've obviously had a LOT more orgasmic/biochem than me, or for most guys probably. I do remember the glucocoricoids post. And though all this is new to me (just as PCa was) I am aware of the tapering off requirement for prednisone, as both my wife and our younger son had previously been treated with it. And I had already looked up Cushing's Syndrome after my doc mentioned the moon face. For me, now, this is yet another adventure. An opportunity to experience and to learn. I am eager to get this implant done so I can move on to other matters. August is not my most favorite month. It was a year ago that I started adjuvant radiation, and it will be two years at the end of this month since my RP. Additionally this weekend marks the fourteenth anniversary of an accident that put me in a hospital bed for three months, then a wheelchair, crutches and a cane for a couple years. Yet another life changing event. The story goes on. Just thought I'd share some of it with you guys. Have a great weekend everyone! We're heading to the beach for a week.

Posts.Title: The waiting game... (long)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Some doctors are loathed to inform their patients that biopsy and MRI tests regularly generate false negatives. I have not heard of any insurance company requiring an antibiotic be used prior to approving additional biopsy or MRI. FWIW this all sounds so familiar to me, as well as Another's earlier mention of your apparent "discomfort with your doctor". I had persistent annoying burning in my urethra (but NOT when urinating) and was given longer and longer courses of Cipro... so much that my feet and toes turned purple. Meanwhile my PSA kept rising and rising. After the first biopsy "proved" that there was nothing wrong, I essentially gave up. My urologist NEVER mentioned the possibility of false negatives and in fact never mentioned the word cancer. Admittedly I was a fool. All this time I could have been doing online research, but I trusted my urologist (eventhough his attitude annoyed and frustrated me). By the time I changed doctors, my cancer had progressed to where is was almost at the point of metastasis. Thank god it was discovered just in time, and by then had become quite difficult to treat. I don't know what to say about your case. It is truly puzzling. The previous poster (ASA) has had a lot of biopsies, and another contributor here (Djin) had many more before his cancer was finally discovered. This all seems to me to be a barbaric practice... a test of wills against a system designed to keep the patient in the dark.

So, those were not enough for him to clearly see the Prostate, apparently? MRI's reveal soft tissue in greater detail than CT, and a bone scan is just that, bones.

Posts.Content: I too am on Venlafaxine, and can attest to its efficacy. It has cut the frequency, intensity and duration of hot flashes by about half. It was NOT EASY getting it prescribed. A year ago I was an emotional mess. I wrote about the saga here on Cancer Forums (OK now I'm REALLY depressed) Simply put, this stuff works. They shouldn't keep it such a secret from us guys with cancer and on hormone deprivation therapy.
Posts.Title: For those on Hormone Therapy.........

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi What dose of Venlafaxine are you guys taking? Just in case I started at 37.5 - they always start you low and taper up. Then on to the 'effective' dose of 75mg daily, in the morning. I would sometimes take an extra 37.5 later in the day if I was feeling down. Just recently I doubled again to 150mg. Been on it for nine months now and rarely have the blues these days. My family notices I am much more pleasant to be around. You have to taper back off it gradually, so it's a double edged sword. I told Lori I'd probably be on it for life. She asked why. TBH it only 'helps' the hot flashes, but does not eliminate them. They are shorter, less severe and less frequent, but tolerable. I hear it takes a year or even years to get T levels back. So as long as the Venlafaxine keeps working, I guess I'm okay. Word is in MDD circles that Effexor (venlafaxine) has good durability and works for years before it 'poops out'. I guess we'll see.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD When decreasing the number of decimal points (significant figures), a 5 or greater in the least significant place rounds to the next higher number. Thus anything from .05 to .14 would round to .1. Once it hits .15, it becomes .2. If I remember correctly, in a purely statistical environment I think a 5 is rounded up only if it would result in an even number, otherwise it is rounded down... so either 1.5 or 2.5 would be rounded to 2. Of course, it may be different when rounding PSA numbers, but in statistics, there's an even probability that the number of samples being rounded up would equal the number rounded down. In other words, you'd be rounding up half the time and rounding down half the time. Just nit picking here!
Posts.Title: One Year Result - No Man's Land Followup - Part 2

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by h60av8er Well, first post surgery post, had the catheter removed today which is nice, on the other hand, the pathology report has me at stage p3ta pN0... The doctor started out with "I got all the cancer" so that, negative margins and the Gleason staying at 3=4+7 seems good. My wife and are are at square one again and pretty pessimistic, this seems like not so good news. Actually it all sounds like pretty GREAT news, especially since he said flat out that he got ALL the cancer. As long as you are certain of that, then you have little to worry about. Although no cancer is good cancer, it sounds like yours didn't go very far. Negative margins is VERY good. pN0 means there is no lymph node involvement. And you can assume "M0" for no metathesis. Furthermore, 3+4 is better than 4+3 (assuming yours was a typo). The first number is the predominant pattern, and the second number is the secondary pattern. Nothing to be pessimistic about. My favorite reference for decoding all the symbols and numbers can be found here Prostate Cancer: Stages and Grades .... BTW congrats on surviving the Foley. Mine is back IN again, for the past week... and I HOPE it is coming out on Thursday.

Posts.Title: One Year Result - No Man's Land Followup - Part 2

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jfredfc Question, for many years ... I had been on Wellbutrin with good results. Since the surgery I feel more depressed ... Gotten to the point where I am snapping at folks and letting a lot of things worry me. I am going to see my PCP on the 19th. Anyone else had these problems. The phenomenon of an antidepressant becoming ineffective particularly after an extended period of "good results" seems to be fairly common if you read forums devoted to anxiety and depression, just as this one (cancerforums.net) is focused on cancer. Patients who had taken a certain antidepressant for some years refer to it as having "pooped out" and that they had to switch to another one. You can think of it as the treatment having a lifespan. Just as each class of antidepressants (tricyclic, SSRI, SNRI) has a specific mechanism of action, various drugs in each class seem to work for some symptoms of some patients where another similar drug may not work at all. So when a drug becomes no longer effective for the patient, the physician needs to find a different drug that works. Also there may be issues with tolerability. Wellbutrin in particular is generally well tolerated by most patients, though it may not necessarily be the most effective. Personally I am fairly new to the world of behavioral pharmacology, but as with prostate cancer, I had to become a quick study, did a lot of research and told my doctor what specific problems bothered me the most and what I felt might help. First thing is that you need to inform your doctor that the Wellbutrin (Buproprion) is no longer working for you, and that you have these specific issues that disturb you most. Do not "lead" into it by recommending a specific drug, but when further into the conversation you might ask about it. You might print out specific articles from your own research and highlight specific hot points that are similar to your own condition. Doctors don't like to be told what to do, but also they do not take hints very well. They expect to ask questions and you just answer, so when it comes your turn if he prescribes something else, ask why and oh what about this other one (you've heard of, a friend uses or recommended, etc). It seems like a convoluted way to get things done, but doctors do have an ego and respond better to input rather than suggestion.

Posts.Title: Anti-Depressants

Posts.Content: FWIW my "persistent prostatitis" was treated for two years with frequent courses of Cipro for longer and longer periods of time, because my DRE's were normal and the first biopsy was negative. The Cipro made my feet turn purple and made my fingers numb. The "prostatitis" later turned out to be high grade prostate cancer. The word "cancer" had never been mentioned by anyone until after my urologist retired. Moral of the story is that sometimes it really is cancer.

Posts.Title: What my MRI Report looks like.

Posts.Content: I read this thread early this morning (Allmo's OP and ASA's first reply, which was the only reply at the time) and decided that I did not want to start my day that way. Yes, I was a victim of the 2012 recommendations. My PSA shot up and kept rising, and my Urologist did the minimum that he was required to do. He did a biopsy and told me only that it was negative. End of story for him. Now six years later, I'm still recovering from all the treatments that were required to "undo" his negligence. Admittedly, I should have done some research of my own. But he never even mentioned anything about cancer, only mentioned prostatitis, and that my prostate was "normal". Those guys whose cancer was discovered by means of a positive DRE are the lucky ones. Fortunately mine was caught before it invaded the lymphatic system, or at least appears that way. And I REALLY feel sorry for those guys who are worse off than me. This has left a major scar on my psyche, and I'm not sure if it will ever go away. I would love to contribute something positive to this thread, but it just gets me upset. So I'll stop there.

Posts.Title: One Year Result - No Man's Land Followup - Part 2

Posts.Content: My urologist never mentioned the word "cancer" and seemed totally unconcerned, even with my double digit PSA and family history. By the time I changed doctors, my PCa had apparently progressed rapidly. An MRI indicated that the tumor was contained within the prostate, where in fact upon surgery it had penetrated in three separate areas near the bladder and had invaded the seminal vesicles. Moral of the story is you never know just what will be found in there. The surgeon had to use a "broad cut" and removed a lot of tissue, including the nerves. Everything that could have possibly gone wrong, did. However, nowadays I never hesitate to get a second opinion before proceeding with surgery. In my most recent experience, the tests run at a large cancer center were inconclusive, and I ended up having a bowel resection at a local hospital, with good results. So I'd say go ahead and go with the second clinic and if their findings are no different, then go ahead with your original surgeon. As long as all of them take you seriously, you're in good shape.

Posts.Title: 2018 US Preventative Task force recommendation on Psa screening

Posts.Content: My urologist never mentioned the word "cancer" and seemed totally unconcerned, even with my double digit PSA and family history. By the time I changed doctors, my PCa had apparently progressed rapidly. An MRI indicated that the tumor was contained within the prostate, where in fact upon surgery it had penetrated in three separate areas near the bladder and had invaded the seminal vesicles. Moral of the story is you never know just what will be found in there. The surgeon had to use a "broad cut" and removed a lot of tissue, including the nerves. Everything that could have possibly gone wrong, did. However, nowadays I never hesitate to get a second opinion before proceeding with surgery. In my most recent experience, the tests run at a large cancer center were inconclusive, and I ended up having a bowel resection at a local hospital, with good results. So I'd say go ahead and go with the second clinic and if their findings are no different, then go ahead with your original surgeon. As long as all of them take you seriously, you're in good shape.

Posts.Title: New diagnosis - High numbers - some pressure to rush treatment from urologist

Posts.Content: I read this thread early this morning (Allmo's OP and ASA's first reply, which was the only reply at the time) and decided that I did not want to start my day that way. Yes, I was a victim of the 2012 recommendations. My PSA shot up and kept rising, and my Urologist did the minimum that he was required to do. He did a biopsy and told me only that it was negative. End of story for him. Now six years later, I'm still recovering from all the treatments that were required to "undo" his negligence. Admittedly, I should have done some research of my own. But he never even mentioned anything about cancer, only mentioned prostatitis, and that my prostate was "normal". Those guys whose cancer was discovered by means of a positive DRE are the lucky ones. Fortunately mine was caught before it invaded the lymphatic system, or at least appears that way. And I REALLY feel sorry for those guys who are worse off than me. This has left a major scar on my psyche, and I'm not sure if it will ever go away. I would love to contribute something positive to this thread, but it just gets me upset. So I'll stop there.

Posts.Title: New diagnosis - High numbers - some pressure to rush treatment from urologist

Posts.Content: Things seemed to be going well. PSA is zero, and no more Lupron injections. Nothing to do now but wait for the HT to wear off over the next couple of years and see what if anything the PSA does. So it seemed like a good time to re-attack a few older medical problems that had been back-burnered by the prostate cancer a few years ago. So grab a drink, get comfy and let me take you on a ride. I've had eye, sinus and mouth problems for a long time, and have a big scar on my neck from surgeries around 35 years ago. And just as my PSA had started out (long story) my first few stabs at getting treated were met by "oh that's nothing to be concerned about" from the medical community, or "here, take this and come back in six months". With my adjuvant radiation out of the way last fall, I had an ENT look up my nose and he said he saw a "mass" in there, and wanted a CT scan. Great, just what I needed... more radiation. So instead he ordered an MRI, which was inconclusive. He put me on megadoses of gabapentin for a few months and the pain in my throat (nose? tongue? Pharynx?) subsided. I slept a lot and put on ten pounds, which I finally managed to lose this year. But I was still having trouble breathing, so he did a septoplasty (and turbinoplasty... look it up, "turbinators", like Ahh-h-nold) ... I had broken my nose a half dozen times in high school, basically every sport they tried to make me participate in. Why don't they "force" jocks into math and science competitions? Made sense that the deviated septum was the problem. It took a couple months to heal up. But now one side of my nose is completely closed off. Not what I had hoped for. At least I'm not coughing up phlegm for the first few hours of every day. So then I have my annual eye exam with my fourth ophthalmologist and he puts me on yet another expensive eye drop (you've no doubt seen commercials for them) which worked no better than the ones that I had been on for five years before that. So I dug out the business card for yet another ophthalmologist (#5) whom I had been referred to last year when I was going thru the "AUS-and-ART" phase of my PCa treatment. So no time for yet another eye doc then, but now the time seemed right. So he pokes me in the eye and says "I've seen this before " (it's a somewhat rare condition) and started me on 60mg/day of prednisone. He wanted CT's of my brain and face. (Great, just what I needed... more radiation.) Got that about a month ago, just after seeing my ENT again for a follow-up on the septoplasty. ENT says my nasal valve is incompetent... that's an actual medical term. As he was the throat guy (who had ordered the MRI) he refers me to his nose and sinus associate to discuss putting what he called a "clip" in my cheek to hold my nose open. Turns out this is a new procedure currently undergoing clinical trials. Interesting concept. Hey, at least it's not cancer! So I say oh by the way I just happen to have this CT study of my face from the eye doctor, and he looks at it and says I have a bony deformity that is fairly common, but for most it is not a problem. We discuss the implant procedure to be included as part of surgery to remove some of the bone deformity from the base of my skull (!!!) and I schedule the surgery for next month. The scheduling nurse asks, how long you gonna be on prednisone? I dunno. Back to the eye doc, a neuro-ophthalmic and occuloplastic surgeon (fortunately he has never mentioned surgery) and he has me tapering down on the prednisone... 60-50-40, and this week 30mg/day. Apparently this is a lot of prednisone. I didn't know. So I figure I'd better get in to see my GP just so he knows all the stuff I've got going on. I'm telling all this to my GP and he kind of gives me one of those looks, like what the hell are you doing? He says my cheeks are widening and I am developing "moon face" (again, an actual medical term, look it up) and he starts poking me in the belly. Does that hurt? No, but if you poke hard enough, it will. Then he orders some bloodwork. So yesterday his nurse calls and tells me that I have pancreatitis and he wants more bloodwork, which I had this morning, and a CT scan of my abdomen. (Great, just what I need... more radiation.) So now I wait. Called the eye doc and turns out he never sent a report to my PCP. The healthcare system in Florida is overwhelmed and the patient has to follow up on literally everything. If you don't then stuff just falls thru the cracks. Nurses are constantly busy shuffling papers and answering the phone, and then don't remember if they already took care of the one in their hand so just put it on a stack, where it gets buried and ends up in the warehouse from the end of "Raiders of the Lost Ark" where it will never be seen by those "top men". So now it's Friday. I may get a call telling me to rush to the hospital... or maybe not. The prednisone has me all jittery anyway... hard to sleep. Really revved up. And now I gotta worry about something new? Maybe? All I know so far is my doc said NOT to have implant surgery while I'm on prednisone, so I called the ENT's office to cancel the surgery. I hope they got the message. No one has called back yet. So I sit and wait... tick, tock.
Posts.Title: The waiting game... (long)

Posts.Content: CT was Monday. Pancreas is okay, but... there is a 3cm mesenteric mass of unknown origin in the small bowel. Here we go again, I guess.
Posts.Title: The waiting game... (long)

Posts.Content: Wow, what rotten luck, especially after all you've both been thru. I'd say don't worry too much about it right now until it can be investigated further. The 3mm lung nodule could be anything, but the lymph node is certainly unusually large. Has she or have you had the chance to speak with the doctor yet? (or did I miss that?) Without her doctor's input you're really just shooting in the dark. I hope it ends up being something that is either easily treatable or perhaps requires no action at all. We can always hope, right? Prayers for you both!

Posts.Title: The waiting game... (long)

Posts.Content: Ken, when have you ever complained about anything? Anywho, I actually posted the story to be entertaining, not whining or venting. Beyond some of the strange names for things, the fact that they all wanted CT's was just too coincidental. Plus the fact that some coincidences worked in my favor ("I just happen to have this CT disc done last week") and others seemed to blow up my best made plans... a pill is making me postpone the surgery that had seemed to fall into place so conveniently. MF - You've obviously had a LOT more orgasmic/biochem than me, or for most guys probably. I do remember the glucocoricoids post. And though all this is new to me (just as PCa was) I am aware of the tapering off requirement for prednisone, as both my wife and our younger son had previously been treated with it. And I had already looked up Cushing's Syndrome after my doc mentioned the moon face. For me, now, this is yet another adventure. An opportunity to experience and to learn. I am eager to get this implant done so I can move on to other matters. August is not my most favorite month. It was a year ago that I started adjuvant radiation, and it will be two years at the end of this month since my RP. Additionally this weekend marks the fourteenth anniversary of an accident that put me in a hospital bed for three months, then a wheelchair, crutches and a cane for a couple years. Yet another life changing event. The story goes on. Just thought I'd share some of it with you guys. Have a great weekend everyone! We're heading to the beach for a week.

Posts.Title: The waiting game... (long)

Posts.Content: What I've read is that the length of time between RP and RT is not significant, but the PSA level at which RT is initiated is quite significant. Hence many doctors are advocating SRT as soon as an elevating pattern is established. With a rising PSA, then higher PSA also means longer time passed before starting, so they are related. I just passed the halfway point in my RT (18 more to go I think) and bowel issues started the second week... frequent urgency and loose bowels, occasional diarrhea (2X/week or more). Normally I am regular as clockwork. One cup of coffee and two minutes in the throne room. No other SE's at this time, but I hear the last couple weeks brings on fatigue that lasts for several weeks following conclusion of Tx. Good luck to you and your father. There will be some dietary restrictions (varies by RO) and the water/bladder requirement. Bowel issues if any will impact the bladder requirement. It's a bit tough, but nothing compared to what has been thru already. Showing up every day in time is imperative, but the procedure itself is not the least bit uncomfortable.

Hey MF, any idea if prednisone, an oral steroid might fit into this anywhere? I've been on ~50mg/day for the past month for another medical condition. The neuro-ophthalmologist is aware that I have been treated for prostate cancer, but one cannot always trust physicians to be aware of all potential drug interactions.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Some doctors are loathed to inform their patients that biopsy and MRI tests regularly generate false negatives. I have not heard of any insurance company requiring an antibiotic be used prior to approving additional biopsy or MRI. FWIW this all sounds so familiar to me, as well as Another's earlier mention of your apparent "discomfort with your doctor". I had persistent annoying burning in my urethra (but NOT when urinating) and was given longer and longer courses of Cipro... so much that my feet and toes turned purple. Meanwhile my PSA kept rising and rising. After the first biopsy "proved" that there was nothing wrong, I essentially gave up. My urologist NEVER mentioned the possibility of false negatives and in fact never mentioned the word cancer. Admittedly I was a fool. All this time I could have been doing online research, but I trusted my urologist (eventhough his attitude annoyed and frustrated me). By the time I changed doctors, my cancer had progressed to where is was almost at the point of metastasis. Thank god it was discovered just in time, and by then had become quite difficult to treat. I don't know what to say about your case. It is truly puzzling. The previous poster (ASA) has had a lot of biopsies, and another contributor here (Djin) had many more before his cancer was finally discovered. This all seems to me to be a barbaric practice... a test of wills against a system designed to keep the patient in the dark.

Posts.Title: My PSA Result is 10

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by h60av8er Well, first post surgery post, had the catheter removed today which is nice, on the other hand, the pathology report has me at stage p3ta pN0... The doctor started out with "I got all the cancer" so that, negative margins and the Gleason staying at 3=4+7 seems good. My wife and are are at square one again and pretty pessimistic, this seems like not so good news. Actually it all sounds like pretty GREAT news, especially since he said flat out that he got ALL the cancer. As long as you are certain of that, then you have little to worry about. Although no cancer is good cancer, it sounds like yours didn't go very far. Negative margins is VERY good. pN0 means there is no lymph node involvement. And you can assume "M0" for no metathesis. Furthermore, 3+4 is better than 4+3 (assuming yours was a typo). The first number is the predominant pattern, and the second number is the secondary pattern. Nothing to be pessimistic about. My favorite reference for decoding all the symbols and numbers can be found here Prostate Cancer: Stages and Grades .... BTW congrats on surviving the Foley. Mine is back IN again, for the past week... and I HOPE it is coming out on Thursday.

Posts.Title: Not a great pathology report? Need an experienced eye please

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD When decreasing the number of decimal points (significant figures), a 5 or greater in the least significant place rounds to the next higher number. Thus anything from .05 to .14 would round to .1. Once it hits .15, it becomes .2. If I remember correctly, in a purely statistical environment I think a 5 is rounded up only if it would result in an even number, otherwise it is rounded down... so either 1.5 or 2.5 would be rounded to 2. Of course, it may be different when rounding PSA numbers, but in statistics, there's an even probability that the number of samples being rounded up would equal the number rounded down. In other words, you'd be rounding up half the time and rounding down half the time. Just nit picking here!

Posts.Content: Wow, what rotten luck, especially after all you've both been thru. I'd say don't worry too much about it right now until it can be investigated further. The 3mm lung nodule could be anything, but the lymph node is certainly unusually large. Has she or have you had the chance to speak with the doctor yet? (or did I miss that?) Without her doctor's input you're really just shooting in the dark. I hope it ends up being something that is either easily treatable or perhaps requires no action at all. We can always hope, right? Prayers for you both!

Posts.Title: The waiting game... (long)

Posts.Content: What I've read is that the length of time between RP and RT is not significant, but the PSA level at which RT is initiated is quite significant. Hence many doctors are advocating SRT as soon as an elevating pattern is established. With a rising PSA, then higher PSA also means longer time passed before starting, so they are related. I just passed the halfway point in my RT (18 more to go I think) and bowel issues started the second week... frequent urgency and loose bowels, occasional diarrhea (2X/week or more). Normally I am regular as clockwork. One cup of coffee and two minutes in the throne room. No other SE's at this time, but I hear the last couple weeks brings on fatigue that lasts for several weeks following conclusion of Tx. Good luck to you and your father. There will be some dietary restrictions (varies by RO) and the water/bladder requirement. Bowel issues if any will impact the bladder requirement. It's a bit tough, but nothing compared to what has been thru already. Showing up every day in time is imperative, but the procedure itself is not the least bit uncomfortable.

Posts.Title: Looks like dad's headed to salvage radiation. Your experiences appreciated!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Some doctors are loathed to inform their patients that biopsy and MRI tests regularly generate false negatives. I have not heard of any insurance company requiring an antibiotic be used prior to approving additional biopsy or MRI. FWIW this all sounds so familiar to me, as well as Another's earlier mention of your apparent "discomfort with your doctor". I had persistent annoying burning in my urethra (but NOT when urinating) and was given longer and longer courses of Cipro... so much that my feet and toes turned purple. Meanwhile my PSA kept rising and rising. After the first biopsy "proved" that there was nothing wrong, I essentially gave up. My urologist NEVER mentioned the possibility of false negatives and in fact never mentioned the word cancer. Admittedly I was a fool. All this time I could have been doing online research, but I trusted my urologist (eventhough his attitude annoyed and frustrated me). By the time I changed doctors, my cancer had progressed to where is was almost at the point of metastasis. Thank god it was discovered just in time, and by then had become quite difficult to treat. I don't know what to say about your case. It is truly puzzling. The previous poster (ASA) has had a lot of biopsies, and another contributor here (Djin) had many more before his cancer was finally discovered. This all seems to me to be a barbaric practice... a test of wills against a system designed to keep the patient in the dark.

Posts.Title: My PSA Result is 10

Posts.Content: I too am on Venlafaxine, and can attest to its efficacy. It has cut the frequency, intensity and duration of hot flashes by about half. It was NOT EASY getting it prescribed. A year ago I was an emotional mess. I wrote about the saga here on Cancer Forums (OK now I'm REALLY depressed) Simply put, this stuff works. They shouldn't keep it such a secret from us guys with cancer and on hormone deprivation therapy.
Posts.Title: For those on Hormone Therapy.........

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi What dose of Venlafaxine are you guys taking? Just in case I started at 37.5 - they always start you low and taper up. Then on to the 'effective' dose of 75mg daily, in the morning. I would sometimes take an extra 37.5 later in the day if I was feeling down. Just recently I doubled again to 150mg. Been on it for nine months now and rarely have the blues these days. My family notices I am much more pleasant to be around. You have to taper back off it gradually, so it's a double edged sword. I told Lori I'd probably be on it for life. She asked why. TBH it only 'helps' the hot flashes, but does not eliminate them. They are shorter, less severe and less frequent, but tolerable. I hear it takes a year or even years to get T levels back. So as long as the Venlafaxine keeps working, I guess I'm okay. Word is in MDD circles that Effexor (venlafaxine) has good durability and works for years before it 'poops out'. I guess we'll see.

Posts.Title: Update - Provenge Therapy Completed

Posts.Content: I read this thread early this morning (Allmo's OP and ASA's first reply, which was the only reply at the time) and decided that I did not want to start my day that way. Yes, I was a victim of the 2012 recommendations. My PSA shot up and kept rising, and my Urologist did the minimum that he was required to do. He did a biopsy and told me only that it was negative. End of story for him. Now six years later, I'm still recovering from all the treatments that were required to "undo" his negligence. Admittedly, I should have done some research of my own. But he never even mentioned anything about cancer, only mentioned prostatitis, and that my prostate was "normal". Those guys whose cancer was discovered by means of a positive DRE are the lucky ones. Fortunately mine was caught before it invaded the lymphatic system, or at least appears that way. And I REALLY feel sorry for those guys who are worse off than me. This has left a major scar on my psyche, and I'm not sure if it will ever go away. I would love to contribute something positive to this thread, but it just gets me upset. So I'll stop there.

Posts.Content: FWIW my "persistent prostatitis" was treated for two years with frequent courses of Cipro for longer and longer periods of time, because my DRE's were normal and the first biopsy was negative. The Cipro made my feet turn purple and made my fingers numb. The "prostatitis" later turned out to be high grade prostate cancer. The word "cancer" had never been mentioned by anyone until after my urologist retired. Moral of the story is that sometimes it really is cancer.

In other words, you'd be rounding up half the time and rounding down half the time. Just nit picking here!
Posts.Title: One Year Result - No Man's Land Followup - Part 2

Posts.Content: I read this thread early this morning (Allmo's OP and ASA's first reply, which was the only reply at the time) and decided that I did not want to start my day that way. Yes, I was a victim of the 2012 recommendations. My PSA shot up and kept rising, and my Urologist did the minimum that he was required to do. He did a biopsy and told me only that it was negative. End of story for him. Now six years later, I'm still recovering from all the treatments that were required to "undo" his negligence. Admittedly, I should have done some research of my own. But he never even mentioned anything about cancer, only mentioned prostatitis, and that my prostate was "normal". Those guys whose cancer was discovered by means of a positive DRE are the lucky ones. Fortunately mine was caught before it invaded the lymphatic system, or at least appears that way. And I REALLY feel sorry for those guys who are worse off than me. This has left a major scar on my psyche, and I'm not sure if it will ever go away. I would love to contribute something positive to this thread, but it just gets me upset. So I'll stop there.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD When decreasing the number of decimal points (significant figures), a 5 or greater in the least significant place rounds to the next higher number. Thus anything from .05 to .14 would round to .1. Once it hits .15, it becomes .2. If I remember correctly, in a purely statistical environment I think a 5 is rounded up only if it would result in an even number, otherwise it is rounded down... so either 1.5 or 2.5 would be rounded to 2. Of course, it may be different when rounding PSA numbers, but in statistics, there's an even probability that the number of samples being rounded up would equal the number rounded down. In other words, you'd be rounding up half the time and rounding down half the time. Just nit picking here!

Posts.Content: ILMF sorry about your experience with Lyme disease. I've heard several others who had to struggle with misdiagnosis and for Lyme disease in particular. I think I agree with MF that you probably don't have cancer, yet, but here have been guys who ended up having PCa despite having a low PSA, but it's rare. Thanks for the shoutout, Lori and I are doing well now. We should be wrapping this up by the end of the year, then just getting periodic checkups thereafter, I hope. Good luck going forward!
Posts.Title: PSA Dropped after 3 weeks of cipro

Posts.Content: My urologist never mentioned the word "cancer" and seemed totally unconcerned, even with my double digit PSA and family history. By the time I changed doctors, my PCa had apparently progressed rapidly. An MRI indicated that the tumor was contained within the prostate, where in fact upon surgery it had penetrated in three separate areas near the bladder and had invaded the seminal vesicles. Moral of the story is you never know just what will be found in there. The surgeon had to use a "broad cut" and removed a lot of tissue, including the nerves. Everything that could have possibly gone wrong, did. However, nowadays I never hesitate to get a second opinion before proceeding with surgery. In my most recent experience, the tests run at a large cancer center were inconclusive, and I ended up having a bowel resection at a local hospital, with good results. So I'd say go ahead and go with the second clinic and if their findings are no different, then go ahead with your original surgeon. As long as all of them take you seriously, you're in good shape.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jfredfc Question, for many years ... I had been on Wellbutrin with good results. Since the surgery I feel more depressed ... Gotten to the point where I am snapping at folks and letting a lot of things worry me. I am going to see my PCP on the 19th. Anyone else had these problems. The phenomenon of an antidepressant becoming ineffective particularly after an extended period of "good results" seems to be fairly common if you read forums devoted to anxiety and depression, just as this one (cancerforums.net) is focused on cancer. Patients who had taken a certain antidepressant for some years refer to it as having "pooped out" and that they had to switch to another one. You can think of it as the treatment having a lifespan. Just as each class of antidepressants (tricyclic, SSRI, SNRI) has a specific mechanism of action, various drugs in each class seem to work for some symptoms of some patients where another similar drug may not work at all. So when a drug becomes no longer effective for the patient, the physician needs to find a different drug that works. Also there may be issues with tolerability. Wellbutrin in particular is generally well tolerated by most patients, though it may not necessarily be the most effective. Personally I am fairly new to the world of behavioral pharmacology, but as with prostate cancer, I had to become a quick study, did a lot of research and told my doctor what specific problems bothered me the most and what I felt might help. First thing is that you need to inform your doctor that the Wellbutrin (Buproprion) is no longer working for you, and that you have these specific issues that disturb you most. Do not "lead" into it by recommending a specific drug, but when further into the conversation you might ask about it. You might print out specific articles from your own research and highlight specific hot points that are similar to your own condition. Doctors don't like to be told what to do, but also they do not take hints very well. They expect to ask questions and you just answer, so when it comes your turn if he prescribes something else, ask why and oh what about this other one (you've heard of, a friend uses or recommended, etc). It seems like a convoluted way to get things done, but doctors do have an ego and respond better to input rather than suggestion.

Posts.Title: 2018 US Preventative Task force recommendation on Psa screening

Posts.Content: I will add to or expound upon remarks in the last few replies. Yes, I believe that most of those who stick around are those who are still engaged in the fight. Either their treatment is ongoing (as with MM, Fairwind, and myself) and those who have been thru the mill (ASA, MF, Prato, Another) and realize that their fortunes could possibly change at any moment. And because there are so many newbies who are seeking information, I typically refrain from jumping into any questions or discussions regarding incontinence or ED, as I do not want to scare anyone. For some of us things have turned out better than expected, and others, far worse than was ever imagined. My diagnosis was actually a relief after more then two years of hearing "your PSA is high, but all of your tests are negative". Without a diagnosis you can't get treated for anything. Apparently according to the new guidelines an elevated PSA alone is not enough. And as long as insurance is calling the shots, you can't receive a more advanced test until after your preceding tests have given you a green light to go forward. So I tend to be envious of those who had a simple DRE from their GP, a successful biopsy was performed and their G3+3 was treated successfully with little more than some minor inconvenience. And their greatest fear going into this was a possible loss of sexual prowess, not lifelong incontinence and certainly not BR. But for a small number of us it has been more difficult than that. So often I just keep quiet..

Posts.Title: SRT completed!

Posts.Content: Mike - Thanks for taking the time to write about your experience. Sometimes what tends to end up online is some of the horror stories. Fortunately it sound like everything went by the book for you. Dry nights is typically the first sign of improvement, then reduced number of pads during the day. Most guys have it worst when on their feet (it's gravity). And most claim 6-12 months to regain full continence, though there are some superheroes who have managed even shorter. You are fortunate to have retained full erectile capability as well. Congratulations on pulling thru this with flying colors! Don't hesitate to drop by any time with a question or a progress report. It's always good to hear the positive experiences.

Posts.Title: First Time Posting

Posts.Content: Mike - Thanks for taking the time to write about your experience. Sometimes what tends to end up online is some of the horror stories. Fortunately it sound like everything went by the book for you. Dry nights is typically the first sign of improvement, then reduced number of pads during the day. Most guys have it worst when on their feet (it's gravity). And most claim 6-12 months to regain full continence, though there are some superheroes who have managed even shorter. You are fortunate to have retained full erectile capability as well. Congratulations on pulling thru this with flying colors! Don't hesitate to drop by any time with a question or a progress report. It's always good to hear the positive experiences.

Posts.Content: I see. My RO also recommends concurrent HT and RT, but started me on Lupron to allow the incontinence more time to heal before SRT. But then my Uro said that's not going to happen. So back to the RO next month to present the case for the AUS. If I had been in your shoes (PSA rising) I'd really be in deep doo-doo. So now you're 'Lupronized' for another six months?
Posts.Title: SRT completed!

Posts.Content: Congratulations! I'm sure that must be a tremendous relief to have that over with! How do you feel... worn out? That's what I've read from most guys. And that bladder thing is my biggest concern... empty bowel and full bladder every day just ain't gonna happen for me. So hopefully the Lupron can keep my PSA down long enough to have the AUS implanted, a couple months for that to heal, then a couple months of field testing before the SRT can begin. Any surgical revision would set the calendar back again. That's the old squeeze play. I can see your PSA was really taking off. Did your RO suggest trying anything else when the Lupron failed?

Posts.Title: SRT completed!

Posts.Content: To you guys who recently had biopsies... OleJoe and NCman, I hope your procedures went well and that the results were helpful. But there's one thing that you need to know, something that my doctor never told me but was hopefully discussed in your books... If your biopsy is 'negative' it does not mean that you do not have cancer. My original urologist never even mentioned the word cancer, but merely told me that all my tests were negative. He gave me the impression that my PSA rise could be treated with medicine. What no one ever told me was that about a third of initial biopsies totally miss any tumor, even when high grade cancer may exist. If the doctor does not pursue further investigation then the patient must be the one who takes the reins and pushes for more information. Doctors tend to say as little as possible. I believe that withholding information is unethical, but today it is probably a legal requirement. All this is very unfortunate but that's the way it is. Some others here have had multiple biopsies and other tests and procedures with varying outcomes. The bloody, uncomfortable process of prostate biopsy leaves a guy certainly not anxious to repeat the procedure when the outcome yields nebulous results. The 'lucky' ones are those who strike pay dirt the first time and are successfully treated without clinical upstaging in the process. It is all too easy to become discouraged in this process. Unfortunately the 'once and done' guys are the ones least likely to seek out forums like this one and others. The good news is that most guys have favorable outcomes from their PCa experience and we never hear from them. Hopefully your experiences will go well.

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum, and good luck on Monday. With your G7 pathology you stand an excellent chance of pulling thru this without any complications. I too am having surgery on Monday 5/15 to implant an artificial sphincter. Only a couple thousand of these are done annually so I'm a bit apprehensive about it, however it is necessary so that I can begin salvage radiation which was postponed from March due to incontinence. I have good control but am told that continence worsens following RT so it is best to get it in beforehand rather than try to recover later. My blog is listed at the bottom of my sig (though I haven't paid much attention to it lately). I hope everything goes well for you in the weeks ahead. If you follow the path of most of the guys here, you will be pad free in just a few months.

Posts.Title: I found this article disturbing.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F I was adding a few points to consider as to when to commence RT with the small possibility that RT may be delayed or averted until/if your PSA becomes both clinically detectable and clinically rising. From experience, I was worked up for entry into an SR clinical trial and was told by a top Urologic RO that I was a candidate for SR and should consider undergoing SR whether on not I enrolled in the clinical trial. He provided reprints of the latest published data. I challenged him and asked "how many of the successful SR recipients would have never recurred without SR?" My Primary Uro MD forbid me to consider SR until/unless my uPSA indicated BR. Most fortunately, that has not yet occurred. Had I followed the advice of this "Apex" Uro Oncologist, I would have had SR unnecessarily. Originally Posted by njstol01 The possibility of salvage radiation was mentioned, however this would hinge on PSA #, which of course have not been done yet. So I see it somewhat alarming (to me being so close to in your shoes) that you are already considering radiation even before your first PSA result. Are you and your doc being too aggressive, or is my uro being too conservative and missing something? As you both bring up the "whether or not and when to begin RT" topic, you may both be interested in this recent posting (or you may have seen it already, as it has appeared on several blogs): Conflicting messages after surgery for high-risk patients from radiation oncologists and urologists

Posts.Title: New Guy Here, Surgery on Monday

Posts.Content: Another Floridian here, Clearwater/Countryside area... I know Prato and Gary and we have all been thru this. Listen well to the words of Another... He is very wise and knows when to slap someone in the face and shout "snap out of it! ... I now refer to him as Sensei as he recognizes when someone is engaging in wishful thinking. Believe me, I made all the usual mistakes. When my PSA rose my GP sent me to a urologist. When it kept rising my urologist seemed unconcerned. When he said "your biopsy was negative" I took that as "you do not have cancer". I fully intended to take more action much sooner, but had a lot going on and never found the time. Perhaps not unlike you, I was so engaged in living life that I ignored the warning signs. But as others have mentioned, less than half of the prostate can be accessed from the rear. All my DRE's were "normal", and only much later did I learn that one in three initial biopsies are false negatives... i.e., the needle simply missed the tumor. Doctors generally don't tell you this. Now on my fourth urologist, I saw a graphic in his office detailing male anatomy and I remarked "no wonder my first urologist couldn't find my tumor" and he responded, yeah, you can never find them up there. Geez. It's like you need to already know all the answers before you know what questions to ask. That's where this board is so valuable. If I had known four years ago what I know now, I would likely have a single line in my signature below... "2012: PSA 4, MRI, biopsy, G7, RP, PSA zero". The longer you wait, the worse your condition will become. It's like tooth decay, it doesn't get better, it gets bigger!

Posts.Title: Hello from SW Florida

Posts.Content: The hospital will insert the Foley and mount the StatLock during surgery. They generally hold up for a week or so. Usually the patient need not be concerned about it. I've had Foley's off and on for some months at a time during the past 20 years or so and bought a few spares from Amazon. Yes, it is a good idea to trim, not shave the skin to improve adhesion and avoid irritation. And be sure to clean around the tip daily with mild soapy water and apply a mild ointment, for comfort. Use polysporin or bacitracin, NOT Neosporin. It is too strong.

Perhaps not unlike you, I was so engaged in living life that I ignored the warning signs. But as others have mentioned, less than half of the prostate can be accessed from the rear. All my DRE's were "normal", and only much later did I learn that one in three initial biopsies are false negatives... i.e., the needle simply missed the tumor. Doctors generally don't tell you this. Now on my fourth urologist, I saw a graphic in his office detailing male anatomy and I remarked "no wonder my first urologist couldn't find my tumor" and he responded, yeah, you can never find them up there. Geez. It's like you need to already know all the answers before you know what questions to ask. That's where this board is so valuable. If I had known four years ago what I know now, I would likely have a single line in my signature below... "2012: PSA 4, MRI, biopsy, G7, RP, PSA zero". The longer you wait, the worse your condition will become. It's like tooth decay, it doesn't get better, it gets bigger!

Posts.Title: Pelvic MRI today

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mikesimm here is my question... During the course of 39 treatments of RT, is it permitted to say do half of them, then take a 3-4 week break and then resume for the remainder of the treatments? I'm going to say no, though your RO will be the ultimate judge on this. I for one went thru "hell and high water" (literally) to get through RT. The list of events that would have caused me to delay or take a pause in treatments is lengthy and I won't repeat them here, but I'd say don't plan on getting a break in midstream. It's good to see you back here again Mike. Your lovely wife is correct... as a T3b you should use every tool in the arsenal to knock out this cancer while it's down. I think the stats are 50/50 regarding progression free survival for T3b's without ART and ADT, but you don't want to be on the wrong side of that statistic. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Hello from SW Florida

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JW57 The diagnosis has yet to completely sink in. It's such a strange feeling to know I have cancer and yet feel completely fine. I've been on a bit of a roller coaster, emotionally. Finding this Forum has been very helpful. Yes, the cancer diagnosis is certainly a shocker, and for most is their first serious medical issue of a lifetime beyond maybe a broken bone or perhaps some major surgery for something non-malignant. But learning that there is something eating away inside you - and that there is no certainty that you can or will be cured of it is truly a life altering event. In my case I knew there was something wrong... I felt certain of it, but all the tests were negative. The final diagnosis of prostate cancer at least relieved my anxiety of not knowing what was wrong and why I had been so emotional for the past couple years on top of everything else my wife and I had going on. I wish I'd had the time to seek out other opinions from other doctors and not have to rush into treatment, but given my particular situation, surgery appeared to be the best approach and I have no regrets. It sounds like you are taking this very well and approaching your treatment logically and analytically. You will get thru this. It was discovered early and the path you are now on is one that is well worn. Good luck in your recovery and don't hesitate to come back and keep us informed of your progress.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BAB In fact, my treatment went over the Thanksgiving holiday. To compensate for this day off, they had all of us who were going through radiation come in on SUNDAY. Hurricane Irma came thru last year when I was halfway thru my 39 radiation treatments, and knocked out power for most of Florida. The RO's office had us come in on Saturday before the storm hit for an extra day of treatment, then added an extra Monday at the end of my treatments last October. I also missed my closest cousin's funeral, which was held during my next to last week of RT and would have required flying back to Ohio.

Posts.Title: Pelvic MRI today

Posts.Content: There is a chance that you may eventually need both radical prostatectomy surgery plus radiation therapy if your cancer has extended beyond the prostate gland itself. The most significant fact that influenced my decision to proceed with surgery first is that if the surgery does not get everything, then radiation treatment after surgery has a high success rate. But on the other hand, if you choose radiation first and your cancer returns, surgical removal of the prostate after radiation has a low success rate.

Posts.Title: Cialis, Viagra or Sildenafil for Penile Rehabilitation

Posts.Content: I agree that you should have the biopsy. A couple things to keep in mind if you do... 1) not all insurances will pay for an initial MRI guided biopsy, and generally require an ultrasound biopsy first (stupid, given the high chance of false negative... I lost a year that way) and 2) if the biopsy is positive, there is a 6-8 week healing period required before any treatment could commence, so it's likely you'd need to postpone any treatment until around the time of the wedding anyway... and with PC it's usually not so aggressive that a few weeks delay would be significant. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: Good luck with this June, and for your husband. Often the choice between surgery and radiation as the first line treatment comes down to the patients age and general health, as well as the extend of the cancer. If your husband is over 70 or has other medical problems such as diabetes or heart disease that might interfere with his recovery, then surgery is probably not a good idea. On the other hand, if he is young (less than 60) you must consider that he would likely still live more than 20 years and some of the after effects of radiation might appear later in his life (there is disagreement on this from staunch proponents of first line radiation). Furthermore, if your husband's cancer turns out to be a higher grade than 8, which would be 9 or 10, then generally surgery is skipped and treatment goes right into hormone therapy and radiation only. One of the advantages of surgery is that the entire prostate is removed and examined in a lab and the exact nature of the cancer can be determined. Also the prostate bed can be visually examined as well as remaining lymph nodes for any residual cancer. I have heard of some cases in which surgery is begun and then halted if the extent of cancer turns out to be much more than expected. With radiation all the targeting of beams is based on scans. Also there are about a dozen varieties of radiation treatment and many of them require a commitment of daily treatments for several weeks or months. The pill your husband has started on is probably Casodex, which blocks testosterone and in a couple weeks he will probably get a shot of Lupron, which reduces the production of testosterone in order to 'starve' the cancer and limit its growth and potential spread. For most men, the hormone therapy or ADT is the least comfortable of the treatment trifecta as it usually goes on for several years. His high PSA number is probably the reason for starting HT immediately. Otherwise, the single G8 grade with a few 6's should be able to be treated successfully. The wild card is the lymph node involvement. I hope this works out well for you both.

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed (wife)

Posts.Content: The catheter will probably be attached to his thigh with a Statlock. If not you can tape the tube to his thigh to prevent tugging on his penis. Pink crud will develop around where the tube exits the penis. I rinsed it with a cotton ball, mild soap and warm water, pulled back on the penis slightly to expose the tubing and apply polysporin or bacitracin ointment (NOT neosporin) with a q-tip all the way around the tubing then let it slide back in. Stool softener starting the day after surgery is a must. If no "movement" within a couple days, add a stimulant laxative. My Uro liked Milk of Mag. I never disconnected the cath from the large overnight bag. I cut out the bottom of one pocket on a couple pairs of pajama bottoms and fed the bag and tubing thru the hole. During the day I would carry the bag around in a large empty bucket, which was also handy for carrying drinks and such when you don't have a free hand. During the night, keep the overnight bag in the big bucket by the bedside. Sometimes they do leak, and it will save a big headache. The valves on those bags can be tricky. By never allowing the bag to be level or higher than his bladder will prevent introducing infection. Make sure it is always draining down and is not kinked or clogged. Also never disconnecting the bag from the tubing also minimizes the possibility of infection... but that's just me. He will have lifting restrictions for about a month following surgery. I think it was ten pounds. It's surprising how heavy some things are, like a gallon of milk or a twelve pack of soda. If in doubt, don't exert. Getting in and out of bed will be difficult for at least a week, maybe two. That's why the recliner is very handy. Also it is difficult to put on socks and shoes, even slippers, scratch the ankles or whatever. He will likely have some odd requests for you to do things for him. Good luck getting thru this together!

Posts.Title: Cialis, Viagra or Sildenafil for Penile Rehabilitation

Posts.Content: The hospital will insert the Foley and mount the StatLock during surgery. They generally hold up for a week or so. Usually the patient need not be concerned about it. I've had Foley's off and on for some months at a time during the past 20 years or so and bought a few spares from Amazon. Yes, it is a good idea to trim, not shave the skin to improve adhesion and avoid irritation. And be sure to clean around the tip daily with mild soapy water and apply a mild ointment, for comfort. Use polysporin or bacitracin, NOT Neosporin. It is too strong.

Posts.Content: Thanks Djin.... The choice is yours. I know there is a high rate of depression among cancer patients and personally am still unsure which disease fed upon the other. Thank goodness for the forum brothers here who urged me to seek treatment. While "staying positive" may help with one's struggle, being depressed can certainly make the battle much more difficult. Good to know we help each other in any way we can!
Posts.Title: Try to stay positive

Posts.Content: I agree that you should have the biopsy. A couple things to keep in mind if you do... 1) not all insurances will pay for an initial MRI guided biopsy, and generally require an ultrasound biopsy first (stupid, given the high chance of false negative... I lost a year that way) and 2) if the biopsy is positive, there is a 6-8 week healing period required before any treatment could commence, so it's likely you'd need to postpone any treatment until around the time of the wedding anyway... and with PC it's usually not so aggressive that a few weeks delay would be significant. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: I'd say there's likely to be surgery in your near future. Your case looks a lot like mine. Just FYI here's what happened... My PSA had been slowly rising over a number of years, 2-3-4, until just after my 63rd birthday it shot up to 9.5. My Uro did a biopsy which was negative, but the PSA kept rising thru the teens and finally twenties. He suggested my symptoms could be prostatitis and I was prescribed repeated courses of Cipro. This year he retired unexpectedly and his partner took over my case and did a MRI-guided biopsy. The results were two of twelve cores 100%, several others ranging 15-40%, with the majority being negative. Bone scan was negative. Tumor appeared to be contained within the capsule. Surgery was recommended as I am "young and healthy enough" and the tumor appeared to be aggressive. So your Gleason is slightly higher and hopefully the remaining test(s) will also be negative. I'd say you have the opportunity to nip this in the bud. With a Gleason 9 but low % of total cores positive I'd say yours is also likely to be aggressive. TBH it was a relief to me when the biopsy finally came back positive as everything leading up to that for the past three years wasn't giving me any answers at all. All I could do was worry, and when the news finally came in at least I knew I could actually do something about it. With the surgery the Uro was able to examine the surrounding tissues for any signs of the cancer having spread. So far it appears only the seminary vesicles were affected. If I were five years older or had some underlying health issues (heart disease, diabetes) then some other lengthy, alternative treatments might have been more viable, but for me getting it over with was the best solution. Good luck to you in whatever may come of this. You are fortunate this was found fairly early on.

Posts.Title: Biopsy results - Not a good news

Posts.Content: I was overdue for a colonoscopy and had spent the entire previous year trying to get other medical procedures out of the way before starting ART to radiate the prostate bed following RP. My RO informed me that I would have to wait I think it was three months after a colonoscopy before starting RT. That colonoscopy was scheduled and then rescheduled several times last year, when it became apparent that it would delay the RT significantly. Three doctors told me flat out that I was "trying to do too much", so the colonoscopy got postponed until after the end of ART. Then when I completed ART my RO said that I would need to wait at least six months before getting the colonoscopy. I am anxious to get that underway as I experienced considerable bowel disruption during RT and beyond. The radiation proctitis still persists today, nearly five months after RT, and my colonoscopy is already scheduled for April. The reasoning for the healing periods is that the colon needs time to heal following a colonoscopy before hitting it with radiation, and once radiated, needs to heal before any invasive procedures that could lead to scar tissue developing as a result of radiated tissue healing improperly. All though I can't say I'm really looking forward to it, it will be a relief to finally have that out of the way.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MrEd When I had my consults with the RO he had 3 centers I could go to. He said he would not send me to the one closest because it had an older machine and they only use it to target secondary bone cancers... So I know I have to see what machine is being used... Hopefully I will not have bcr but I always wondered about this since my talk with the RO. Forgive me for asking, but why are you being referred to a radiation oncologist at this point? Reading your sig I see that practically everything was negative ("EPE -, SVI -, LVI -, LN -, PNI+, Margins -, Pathologic stage pT2 N0) and your PSA's <0.1 ... I would have LOVED to have had a pathology report like that. So what's the reasoning? Is this a "just in case" or were you given some bad news that I haven't read about? Sorry if I haven't been following your story. Good luck with whatever comes of this.

Posts.Title: Radiation question.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Question for Ed and all you RALP guys -- did any of your surgeons do intra-operative frozen sections to see whether there was EPE and, if not, continue the operation and spare both nerve bundles? I ask because Ed's sig has "Surgeon went wide on the right side and spared nerves on left." To answer your question as one of the "RALP guys", my surgeon "went wide". My wife and I had informed the him beforehand that nerve sparing was not as important as was treating the cancer. Consequently he used a broad cut. Both PNI and EPE were extensive. I was however able to achieve orgasm (quite a few actually!) post-op before starting the Lurpon... plus even a few in the early days of "Lupron flare". In my case, the tumor was located at the base of the prostate, at the opposite end from the apex where a positive surgical margin would be likely to occur. Hence no intraoperatove sections were deemed necessary. Instead my tumor was proximal to the bladder and sphincter, and so I suffered the consequences. But that's the breaks, and I dealt with it.

Posts.Title: Predictors of long-term distress in female partners of men diagnosed with PCa

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JJackson I am doing "my version" of Kegel's and walking, etc...and trying to extend times between urinating...sometimes that's a challenge. Wonder if I'll get my own probe? I had the Kegel training just two days before surgery because we were in Florida tying up some loose ends, so I didn't have much time to practice. But I had read here that Kegels beforehand are not as important as they are afterwards. When the nurse explained that it involved an anal probe I just said "sounds like fun". Then she asked if I was supposed to get "electrical stimulation" and I said "even more fun". J/K. Anyway so I had the hold-for-10-rest-for-five lessons. To be honest, ten times ten, three times a day just wears me OUT, so I don't always do them as prescribed. I do at least try to hold for five seconds five times. So I'm curious, what is "your version" of the Kegels?

Posts.Title: Radiation question.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JJackson I am doing "my version" of Kegel's and walking, etc...and trying to extend times between urinating...sometimes that's a challenge. Wonder if I'll get my own probe? I had the Kegel training just two days before surgery because we were in Florida tying up some loose ends, so I didn't have much time to practice. But I had read here that Kegels beforehand are not as important as they are afterwards. When the nurse explained that it involved an anal probe I just said "sounds like fun". Then she asked if I was supposed to get "electrical stimulation" and I said "even more fun". J/K. Anyway so I had the hold-for-10-rest-for-five lessons. To be honest, ten times ten, three times a day just wears me OUT, so I don't always do them as prescribed. I do at least try to hold for five seconds five times. So I'm curious, what is "your version" of the Kegels?

Posts.Title: Physical Therapy for incontinence

Posts.Content: There was a thread posted here several months back - when I first started posting here - by a physician who has since stopped posting, on this very topic. I think it was titled "Is now the time for MRI to become the standard" or something similar. I had looked it up and referenced it in several subsequent posts, but by now it has probably moved back too many pages to be easily found. Without the MRI my cancer and my wife's quite possibly would have never been found until they might have progressed to the point of causing extensive metastatic damage. Prowler and surely several others here have likely also had a similar experience. Granted, MRI is currently an expensive procedure, but there are no known residual side effects (such as cumulative radiation, as with CT) and is only slightly uncomfortable... who hasn't had an itch you can't scratch appear just a few minutes into a 40 minute scan? But the outcome can be life saving!
Posts.Title: How important is a 3T MRI? My experience.

Posts.Content: I agree that you should have the biopsy. A couple things to keep in mind if you do... 1) not all insurances will pay for an initial MRI guided biopsy, and generally require an ultrasound biopsy first (stupid, given the high chance of false negative... I lost a year that way) and 2) if the biopsy is positive, there is a 6-8 week healing period required before any treatment could commence, so it's likely you'd need to postpone any treatment until around the time of the wedding anyway... and with PC it's usually not so aggressive that a few weeks delay would be significant. Good luck!
