Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Question for Ed and all you RALP guys -- did any of your surgeons do intra-operative frozen sections to see whether there was EPE and, if not, continue the operation and spare both nerve bundles? I ask because Ed's sig has "Surgeon went wide on the right side and spared nerves on left." To answer your question as one of the "RALP guys", my surgeon "went wide". My wife and I had informed the him beforehand that nerve sparing was not as important as was treating the cancer. Consequently he used a broad cut. Both PNI and EPE were extensive. I was however able to achieve orgasm (quite a few actually!) post-op before starting the Lurpon... plus even a few in the early days of "Lupron flare". In my case, the tumor was located at the base of the prostate, at the opposite end from the apex where a positive surgical margin would be likely to occur. Hence no intraoperatove sections were deemed necessary. Instead my tumor was proximal to the bladder and sphincter, and so I suffered the consequences. But that's the breaks, and I dealt with it.
Posts.Title: Radiation question.

Posts.Content: You are right where I was at eight months, faced with getting the AUS. In my case, there was additional urgency added because of the necessity for ART and the looming one year post-op deadline, including approx three months dedicated to getting the AUS and allowing it to heal. It was a very tough decision. Like you, I had some semblance of normalcy thanks to the condom caths, but occasionally used diapers at 8-12 per day. Some normal continence had returned but was told I would lose some of that after RT. The scary part of this is that this decision will change the way you do something that you do all day, every day for the rest of your life! ... Plus there seemed to be no one else on this board with any experience on the subject. I felt so all alone. But then I scoured several other message boards and found a few others who'd had the implant and were satisfied. One month post activation for me now, and the ability to once again wear shorts and swimsuits has been a wonderful feeling. Plus, my RT is finally underway. Again, it is a very tough decision, but if and when you do go that way, you will be pleased with the outcome. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Incontinence I have had enough

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pottk I am curious what you mean by 1 year deadline.. the reason i ask is my first psa was <.1 with my second psa being .09. So there is a possibility of srt in my future. Not so much of a deadline but more of a milestone. There have been studies which show that RT is most effective within the first 21 months post-op. I infer from that essentially "the sooner the better". Initially, ART was scheduled to begin last March 1st and was postponed due to incontinence. Then I was put into PT with a kegel coach. When that did not yield significant improvement I had to decide whether to get the AUS, which also meant allowing at least six weeks to heal AND accommodate the 25% potential revision rate... which of course, also happened to me as well. I could have put these things off forever... and then of course blame myself somewhere down the road for allowing the cancer to get the upper hand.
Posts.Title: Incontinence I have had enough

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by G1enn During the last 18 months I've been having it checked every three months and it's hovered between 3.8-5.3. We ran a few courses of antibiotics- including one that lasted a month. My doctor has now recommended a biopsy. His initial recommendation was a MRI- but my insurance won't cover it and it would be 3500$. I have it scheduled for august 2nd. It's under local anesthesia. My concern is that even if it shows nothing that doesn't mean there is nothing there right? Is there anyway to know for sure that there's nothing there? What else could be causing my psa to be so consistently high for such a long time. My doctor said he didn't know. You are very right on that. I too had rising PSA but a negative biopsy. In fact all tests were negative. That just told me that I had to wait until it got bad enough that some doctor couldn't help but stumble over it. Well, yes there was cancer, and it did get worse. Read my sig below for the full rundown. My greatest problem was that my urologist did not share ANY information with me other than the tests being negative. Three years later, after a lot of time and research, I learned that insurance will not pay for an MRI unless there is a negative biopsy first, but other symptoms persist. Usually they prefer a positive DRE rather than 'just' rising PSA. So you may need to go thru a blind ultrasound biopsy just to get authorization for the MRI. It would be more cost effective and many more lives could be saved if they would just pay for an MRI when everything else in negative. This is what happens when the rules are made by people who have never been sick. Good luck. I hope you can get this taken care of quickly.

Posts.Title: Prostate biopsy at 32

Posts.Content: We are sorry that you must join us here and especially because this is your father's second cancer. The good news is that his PSA and his Gleason are not terribly high. The Gleason 3+4 is better than 4+3 type because it means that MOST of the cancer found in the biopsy samples is grade 3, not grade 4. Grade 3 rarely ever spreads outside the prostate, though it is possible that some of the grade 4 may have spread. Also his PSA is high for a man of his age, but is under 10 and over 10 is more dangerous. Some severe prostate cancer the PSA is in the hundreds or even thousands. You will know more after your father has had more tests. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Dad PCa recently diagnosed (data inside)

Posts.Content: Good recommendation from ASA. He has had biopsies aplenty and knows they are uncomfortable if not painful and can lead to many potential complications. Given your age and your other health problem(s), another "blind' biopsy could be counterproductive. Also your PSA is relatively low for your age. Most likely that one cancerous spot is still in there but in the subsequent biopsies, the needle just missed it. It happens. Cancer does not just go away on its own. However, if it is slow growing, which it appears to be, it is unlikely that it will grow to the stage where it might endanger your life before something else takes you, so to speak. The saying is, many men die with prostate cancer, not from cancer. The MRI fusion may indeed identify an actionable tumor in your prostate, but the procedure requires specialized training, and not every urologist will recommend it (because they are not qualified to do it themselves). There are also varying levels of detail to be revealed by different generations of MRI procedures. If you are concerned about your condition, you should investigate the MRI guided biopsy before allowing anyone to do another blind ultrasound guided biopsy. Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Do I REALLY Need Another Biopsy

Posts.Content: I'd say there's likely to be surgery in your near future. Your case looks a lot like mine. Just FYI here's what happened... My PSA had been slowly rising over a number of years, 2-3-4, until just after my 63rd birthday it shot up to 9.5. My Uro did a biopsy which was negative, but the PSA kept rising thru the teens and finally twenties. He suggested my symptoms could be prostatitis and I was prescribed repeated courses of Cipro. This year he retired unexpectedly and his partner took over my case and did a MRI-guided biopsy. The results were two of twelve cores 100%, several others ranging 15-40%, with the majority being negative. Bone scan was negative. Tumor appeared to be contained within the capsule. Surgery was recommended as I am "young and healthy enough" and the tumor appeared to be aggressive. So your Gleason is slightly higher and hopefully the remaining test(s) will also be negative. I'd say you have the opportunity to nip this in the bud. With a Gleason 9 but low % of total cores positive I'd say yours is also likely to be aggressive. TBH it was a relief to me when the biopsy finally came back positive as everything leading up to that for the past three years wasn't giving me any answers at all. All I could do was worry, and when the news finally came in at least I knew I could actually do something about it. With the surgery the Uro was able to examine the surrounding tissues for any signs of the cancer having spread. So far it appears only the seminary vesicles were affected. If I were five years older or had some underlying health issues (heart disease, diabetes) then some other lengthy, alternative treatments might have been more viable, but for me getting it over with was the best solution. Good luck to you in whatever may come of this. You are fortunate this was found fairly early on.

Posts.Title: Biopsy results - Not a good news

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TinkerbellRM27 Can you explain what impact radiation can have over urinary function? Radiation freezes the healing process. For a RP patient recovering from surgery, the urinary tissues take considerable to time to fully heal, though for some they may reach a functional state fairly quickly. For some individuals it may take over a year, and for someone with adverse pathology indicating residual cancer, there is some urgency to proceed with adjuvant or salvage radiotherapy. Radiation damages all cells, healthy cells as well as cancer cells. Healthy cells are able to recover, but cancer cells are not. The process takes some time... months. In the case of structures that are still healing from the trauma of surgery, probably even longer. I am not yet there myself, however I have spoken with others who had RP followed by RT who have stated that they were near fully continent before RT but lost some continence following the radiation. This was one of the decisions involved in the AUS process. My doctor said it is better to have the AUS implanted before radiation rather than after, and the only case of a failed AUS implant involved a man who had previously had primary radiation during which he lost some continence and the tissues were not healthy enough to accommodate the AUS. Thanks for your interest!. I present some of this info in my blog at cancercoupleblog.com

Posts.Content: Sorry you need to join our club, but the good news is your numbers are low and you caught it early. PNI is common and is not necessarily indicative of extraprostatic extension. You do have choices basically between surgery and radiation, depending on just how far past "40" you are. I'd say you have an excellent chance to shake this with minimal after effects. Good luck!

Posts.Title: New to this "Club"

Posts.Content: What I take from the article is that if I had stopped eating any form of protein and spent all my time grazing as livestock do, plus never get my PSA checked then I would have only had a one in seven chance of getting PCa. Instead after all these "treatments" I've been going thru for the past year (and will continue thru this year) I have a one in seven chance of dying from it. Unfortunately I like steak and cheese and I like soda. I can't go back and change that. Both of our sons live more like what is advocated in the article due to the eastern cultures where they live, but they have as many health issues as the next guy. I'd say the author has her own agenda and has gleaned statistics that only support her claims.
Posts.Title: Men with recurring prostate cancer not dying from prostate cancer

Posts.Content: What I take from the article is that if I had stopped eating any form of protein and spent all my time grazing as livestock do, plus never get my PSA checked then I would have only had a one in seven chance of getting PCa. Instead after all these "treatments" I've been going thru for the past year (and will continue thru this year) I have a one in seven chance of dying from it. Unfortunately I like steak and cheese and I like soda. I can't go back and change that. Both of our sons live more like what is advocated in the article due to the eastern cultures where they live, but they have as many health issues as the next guy. I'd say the author has her own agenda and has gleaned statistics that only support her claims.
Posts.Title: Men with recurring prostate cancer not dying from prostate cancer

Posts.Content: We are sorry that you must join us here and especially because this is your father's second cancer. The good news is that his PSA and his Gleason are not terribly high. The Gleason 3+4 is better than 4+3 type because it means that MOST of the cancer found in the biopsy samples is grade 3, not grade 4. Grade 3 rarely ever spreads outside the prostate, though it is possible that some of the grade 4 may have spread. Also his PSA is high for a man of his age, but is under 10 and over 10 is more dangerous. Some severe prostate cancer the PSA is in the hundreds or even thousands. You will know more after your father has had more tests. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Dad PCa recently diagnosed (data inside)

Posts.Content: Mine was supposed to be a simple 45 minute procedure. It wasn't. There wasn't supposed to be a catheter... there was, for two weeks. It was supposed to be outpatient... instead I had emergency surgery. Anything that could go wrong, did go wrong. But two months later, the device was successfully activated, and I went down to one single pad a day. Not quite everything I had been promised, but it does indeed work, almost. But it's better than wearing a leg bag. Hopefully yours goes well. For most guys it does.

Posts.Title: Aus 800

Posts.Content: Good luck to you Bob. I chose a local radiation oncologist as he was only about ten minutes away versus 45 minutes in heavy traffic to get to the big cancer center in Tampa. Your lymphatic involvement does put you in the high risk category, but at least you do not have seminal vesicle invasion. You will need to get your adjuvant RT underway as soon as possible. For me, the delay was due to persistent incontinence. Guidelines recommend ART within 12 months of surgery. JH and some Uro's use only one decimal place precision, so anything under (or slightly over) 0.1 is reported as 0.1 ... My current uro always uses the ultra sensitive testing, so when my PSA was going from .02 to .08, which would all be reported as "undetectable" by JH... so they knew it was time to start hormone therapy to halt the cancer's progression.

Posts.Title: General Questions Post Surgery . . .

Posts.Content: Yesterday I saw the surgeon for a ten day followup and he had the pathology report, which concluded that my mesenteric mass was sclerosing mesenteritis. That and Carcinoid cancer were the two most likely diagnoses that I had studied for the past few months. A good graphic of the various possible diagnoses can be found here: Peritoneal Solid Masses He said the mass was essentially "calcified fat", lobular in appearance and slightly smaller than a baseball, but much larger than expected. It is typically non-lethal but was large enough to cause some disruption. The fact that I had been told that it could not be biopsied led to the delay in treatment. I would have had the surgery a month earlier, but my gastroenterologist said that these "usually" turn out to be Carcinoid, which is the antiquated name for "neuro-endocrine tumor" or NET (more specifically GEP-NET). This led me to a crash course on NET's and becoming familiar with yet another cancer that I had previously known nothing about. This Saturday - tomorrow - Nov 10th is "NET cancer awareness day". I have the bumper decal but not the T-shirt. This is the same type of cancer that killed Steve Jobs and more recently Aretha Franklin. Look it up. No one will ever even HEAR of neuro-endocrine cancer unless you specifically look for it. It is often misdiagnosed as a number of other conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome. This type of mass is rare but not uncommon. Usually one is found upon autopsy in about 1 in 100 cases, but there are only a few hundred cases of appearance in the living... not because it is deadly, but because they usually don't look for it. It was just my good fortune that my GP suspected pancreatitis and ordered a CT which discovered the mass. The surgery itself went well. I have three new incisions added to my collection, the largest being 7" long right down the middle. I was unable to eat or take anything by mouth for several days. Saliva and ice chips alone were enough to cause tremendous reflux and discomfort, but the surgeon said the anastomosis was so close to the stomach that anything I took by mouth had nowhere to go. Finally after five days on IV nutrition I quickly transitioned to full liquids and finally some cream of wheat. Still having some discomfort and my bowels are unpredictable, but am eating normally... though in smaller portions. I see the surgeon next just before Thanksgiving. He told me it may take six months before things return to normal... whatever that is.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BAB The lowest PSA that you’ll see from their lab is 0.1. They dub that “undetectable.” ...which is like having an outdoor thermometer that always just reads "freezing" if the temperature is anywhere below 32F. It could be below zero, and you'd never know until you try to start your car. Or there could be ducks in the pond. Yeah, it's that accurate of a predictor.

Posts.Title: It's official, it's not cancer!

Posts.Content: Yesterday was surgery number 15, and I'm pleased to say that everything went well. This was a revision of the septoplasty that I'd had last April but which left me with a collapsed nasal valve. So some bone was removed from my nasal cavity and a pair of implants were placed into either side of my nose to hold it open. Everything went well. I went in at noon and was home at 4PM and slept most of the rest of the day. After several dressing changes, the bleeding had stopped by 11PM last night. My nose is crusty and tender, but it's nothing like the original surgery last April, when I was stuffed up for several weeks. Once that had cleared up it became obvious that I wasn't breathing as I should. A lot of people, when I told them I was having a septoplasty for a deviated septum, they told me oh yeah I had that and it really helped. Well, that's just me and my luck. So this revision surgery had originally been scheduled fairly soon after, but then that mass was discovered in my abdomen. Everything had to be postponed to take care of that first. So as they say, "it's another one for the record books". I'm typing without my reading glasses as they hurt my nose (I had been warned about that beforehand). There appears to be no bruising, but have some ink marks on my nose. Anyone remember "Nip Tuck"? So I'm glad at least that my nose is open now and just have to sleep with my head elevated for a few nights. Next "big" surgery will hopefully be the total knee replacement that I was supposed to get back in 2015, but got prostate cancer instead. That damn cancer just gets in the way of everything!

Posts.Title: Well, I just had another surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Positive surgical margins following radical prostatectomy The "extent" of a positive margin is usually measured in mm in your path report. It could influence a decision for adjuvant RT or early SRT. We should have a Forum contest: In 100 words or less, describe the sensation of having a Foley removed. Winner gets a helium-inflated Foley balloon. First, a question for you Djin... one that has always puzzled me. The surgeon who performed my RP stated that I had negative margins. But in the path report it stated that the largest extraprostatic extension was 6mm. My RO looking a the same path report (which I have around here somewhere) told me that there were actually three foci of EPE. I'm guessing that these were places where the cancer had broken thru the prostate capsule, but because it had not been cut away from external tissues (or something of that nature) that it was not considered a surgical margin. Note my tumor was at the base and had consumed 25% of my prostate, but not at the apex where most PSM's occur. So, is there a formal distinction between extraprostatic extension and positive surgical margin? Is PSM the invasion of extraprostatic tissue? (other than SVI I suppose) Second matter, I have only one way to describe the sensation of Foley removal: it tickled. I've had it done at least a half dozen times in my life, and can only say that it is far more scary than painful. It was not unlike hill hopping or rollercoaster airtime.

Posts.Content: Thank you for the link to an interesting article. Admittedly I immediately searched for any reference to T3B and SVI in particular, which led to one footnote linking to a brief yet highly informative article on the 5-year biochemical progression-free rate for those of us with (+)SVI yet (-)LNI and (-)margins. This dense, highly concise study could perhaps better be presented as a box chart, and I wish I were sufficiently literate in markups to present that here. But at barely three paragraphs long, this article is well worth a few minutes for anyone here with higher grade pathology following their initial RP... Prognostic stratification of pt3b disease by nodal and margin status

Posts.Title: Radical prostatectomy as monotherapy for T3 N0-N1 M0 disease

Posts.Content: Mike, everyone hates the waiting game. It seems we are always waiting for something... waiting to see a doctor, waiting for test results, waiting for improvement following treatment. Then there's the apprehension beforehand, which has its own special name, "scanxiety"... the anxiety that your next scan may show more cancer or that the cancer has returned. My fusion biopsy was a major relief, after my first biopsy proved to be a false negative. I seemed to be the only one who was concerned about it. When the MRI actually showed something, I finally had something that could be treated rather than ignored. But the fear and anxiety are always there.

Posts.Title: Pirads iv

Posts.Content: Not sure if there is actually a question in here, but here's a few things I've been able to determine: ART - adjuvant radiation is planned as part of the RP surgery, either due to adverse pathology known beforehand from the biopsy or discovered during the RP surgery. Adverse pathology is generally a very high pre-op PSA, locally advanced cancer (stage 3), seminal vesicle invasion, positive surgical margin. I am generalizing here, but the difference between adjuvant and salvage radiation is not so much based on the time lapsed between RP and RT, but on known adverse pathology which was not resolved during surgery. Generally ART is planned to be performed as soon as possible following surgery, generally 3 to 6 months post-op, or as soon as sufficient healing and continence have returned. ** SRT - salvage radiation is prompted by a rise in PSA post op in response to possible biological recurrence (BR). This is generally determined by two consecutive rises in PSA and/or PSA rising above a threshold value, formerly 0.2 but more recently 0.03 ... Often SRT would be needed if there was positive surgical margin(s) which at the time of surgery "may or may not" lead to BR, as opposed to ART which is prompted by adverse pathology which is likely to lead to rising PSA immediately following surgery without a period of low PSA between RP and RT. SRT is often required in a 2-5 year time window following RP. Sorry I do not have references or specific links to support any of this. It was not easy to glean this info from highly technical articles and personal accounts on boards like this one, so if anyone disputes these generalities, have at it. FWIW the recent NCCN classifications of high risk or adverse pathology is presented here. Again there is much discourse and dispute (nit-picking) on what on the surface appear to be hard and fast criteria. Low risk. The tumor is classified as T1a, T1b, T1c, or T2a. PSA is less than 10 ng/mL. The Gleason score is 6 or less. Intermediate risk. The tumor has 2 or more of these characteristics: Classified as T2b or T2c PSA is between 10 and 20 ng/mL Gleason score of 7 High risk. The tumor has 2 or more of these characteristics: Classified as T3a PSA level is higher than 20 ng/mL Gleason score is between 8 and 10 Very high risk. The tumor is classified as T3b or T4. The histologic grade is 5 for the main pattern of cell growth, or more than 4 biopsy cores have Gleason scores between 8 and 10. ** BTW in my case, I had been referring to my current radiation treatment as 'SRT' before I knew enough to figure out that it was actually ART. I was told immediately after surgery that I would need radiation at six months post-op due to the SVI. But at six months I was still near fully incontinent so was put on ADT to keep my PSA down until such time that continence could return. PSA rise was minimal, but the 12 month milestone was approaching. Why that was important is a different discussion. Anyway, my RT is referred to as "delayed adjuvant".

Posts.Title: Criteria for RT after RP: Adjuvant vs. Salvage

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic For Intermediate risk, did you mean G7 or G7-10? My pre-surgery PSA (correcting for Proscar by doubling) was <10. What risk group am I? Intermediate? I think I need post-surgery classification. Post-surgery one has the detailed path report and doesn't have to rely (only) on the biopsy. I'm hoping, despite the G9, my Uro will say I don't need ART and we can just monitor the PSA. The good and the bad in my case led me to ask my URO for the Decipher test. From what I've read, high G is included; that's my dilemma. DT - the table was copied directly from from the NCCN guidelines and I didn't add or subtract anything, but merely added emphasis for clarity. It is difficult to find such straightforward information now because these guidelines are currently in the process of being revised by committee (!) ... However, the 'higher' risk categories generally include "G8-10" and "primary grade 5" both of which your case meets. I can't really read any more 'into' the tables as your case is rather odd (as I'm sure you already know!) Here's a link to the complete guidance in PDF form. Pop open a beer and plan to spend the evening in your recliner. What you want is probably on pages 10-11. https://www.tri-kobe.org/nccn/guidel...h/prostate.pdf Originally Posted by rmotacek1 I was scheduled to have ART as soon as I could after RP because of my adverse pathology report (see signature). I didn't even question them because I was still kind of shell shocked from the whole cancer diagnosis. On one hand, I kind of wish I would have waited and watched my PSA levels first and maybe did more research on the pros & cons of ART. It wasn't cheap and I worry about the long term SE's. On the other hand, I think it was important to throw a one-two punch at my aggressive cancer. Anyway, I am playing the cards I was dealt. Now I just play the waiting game every six months and hope for the best. Rmotacek, you did the right thing imo. Looking at all the (+)'s in your sig, primary 4, secondary 5, 12 cores positive... if it didn't get you now, it would probably come back and bite you later. Glad to see your PSA is still dropping and your continence appears to be excellent. Well played!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BAB The lowest PSA that you’ll see from their lab is 0.1. They dub that “undetectable.” ...which is like having an outdoor thermometer that always just reads "freezing" if the temperature is anywhere below 32F. It could be below zero, and you'd never know until you try to start your car. Or there could be ducks in the pond. Yeah, it's that accurate of a predictor.
Posts.Title: General Questions Post Surgery . . .

Posts.Content: The grade and extent of your father's cancer does indeed make surgery questionable, however there are advantages to removal followed by EBRT as opposed to merely radiating the entire prostate area, especially if your father already has problems with urination. You will find, especially online, many proponents - even zealots, of radiation as monotherapy and view surgery as brutal and barbaric. Often it turns out that these individuals have had only intermediate grade cancer and/or have not dealt with long term after effects of living with a toasted prostate. I personally had RP+RT+HT over the past two years. The prostate gland and surrounding tissues were removed and thoroughly examined in a pathology lab and the extent of disease was well known once the surgeon was finished. All three forms of therapy have had lasting after effects. The surgery left me incontinent and I required a prosthetic implant to proceed on with radiation. The adjuvant radiation left me with persistent bowel problems. And the hormone therapy is a "gift that keeps on giving" as for how it has impacted my life. But my PSA is now zero, I have no problems with voiding and my gastroenterologist says my next colonoscopy will be in seven years. My current urologist stated that high risk, high grade PCa patients who undergo the trifecta treatment protocol have the lowest incidence of recurrence compared to those men who had RP or RT (of any form) alone, with or without HT. Also please be aware that of the guys with G8-10 and stage T3a-b there is a 50% possibility that they would not have needed the adjuvant radiation, however given your father's advanced condition I do not believe he would be fortunate enough to get by without it. Additionally be aware that there are limitations to the accuracy of external scans regarding their ability to identify and locate the extent of spread until the disease has progressed much further. The only way to be sure that it stopped at the SV and capsule is to actually get in there. Some surgeons will likely even be unwilling to operate on a man your dad's age and condition, and radiation oncologists will likely give highly optimistic predictions for their own particular form of RT which they practice. Don't dismiss any possible options. Your father is only a few years older than me and has a slightly worse prognosis, but for me at least for now, prostate cancer appears to now be in the past.

Posts.Title: 6 Months out of surgery robotic prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Positive surgical margins following radical prostatectomy The "extent" of a positive margin is usually measured in mm in your path report. It could influence a decision for adjuvant RT or early SRT. We should have a Forum contest: In 100 words or less, describe the sensation of having a Foley removed. Winner gets a helium-inflated Foley balloon. First, a question for you Djin... one that has always puzzled me. The surgeon who performed my RP stated that I had negative margins. But in the path report it stated that the largest extraprostatic extension was 6mm. My RO looking a the same path report (which I have around here somewhere) told me that there were actually three foci of EPE. I'm guessing that these were places where the cancer had broken thru the prostate capsule, but because it had not been cut away from external tissues (or something of that nature) that it was not considered a surgical margin. Note my tumor was at the base and had consumed 25% of my prostate, but not at the apex where most PSM's occur. So, is there a formal distinction between extraprostatic extension and positive surgical margin? Is PSM the invasion of extraprostatic tissue? (other than SVI I suppose) Second matter, I have only one way to describe the sensation of Foley removal: it tickled. I've had it done at least a half dozen times in my life, and can only say that it is far more scary than painful. It was not unlike hill hopping or rollercoaster airtime.

Posts.Title: Good bye Mr. Foley!!

Posts.Content: Denis - you know me from several other boards. I'm not sure how much you remember about me, but as I recall I was your first reply to your first question in your first forum (but please correct me if I am wrong). Some guys are lucky, or as lucky as one can be when they have cancer. Their GP refers them to a Urologist because their PSA is elevated. A DRE finds something unusual with the prostate and their first biopsy reveals a low grade tumor, a G6 or perhaps G7(3+4). They are told they have cancer and then fret over treatment for a few months, undergo either surgery or one of the myriad forms of radiation, recover and then live happily ever after, and we never hear from them. I am not that guy. My GP started this and my Urologist whom I had been seeing for more than a decade dismissed my elevated PSA and said my DRE was normal. A year later it had doubled and I consented to a biopsy, which much to my dismay came back negative. I saw my urologist many times over the next few years and all he told me was that my PSA was sky high but that "all your tests are negative" and gave me more Cipro. We were in the process of retiring and moving to Florida and I did my best to manage my symptoms throughout the chaos and mayhem of vacating our home of 33 years and downsizing to a condo a thousand miles away. When my new GP in Florida asked about my PSA I told him the story, and when I later presented his findings to my Urologist he told me that he was going to quit practicing. Why is all this relevant? Because it is the exact opposite of your case. By the time anyone took me seriously my cancer had progressed to the level of being considered 'very high risk'. I did not have months or years to ponder what to do. Our furniture and possessions were divided between two states, work was under way on both homes and contracts had been signed. A new, more competent urologist ordered tests that should have been done years earlier. I looked into several forms of radiation and each would have required time commitments that were inconvenient at best if not impossible given our present situation, and would leave me in questionable condition following treatment. The surgeon said come back in two months and we can take it out and find out exactly what's going on in there. That was something I could work with. I drove a rental truck to Florida a month later and flew back home just four days before the surgery. The surgery itself went spectacularly well. Because my wife worked at the hospital I was treated like royalty. The recovery was uneventful. Within days the surgeon called and informed me that I would need radiation in about six months. So should I have chosen radiation in the first place? Well, it turns out, no. Even trying to get ART underway at the six month mark was impossible. Shortly after our move my wife developed non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and required hospitalization followed by months of treatments. Within days of her discharge from the hospital she required emergency eye surgery and needed to be driven to all appointments. It would have been extremely difficult to commit to daily radiation given all we were going thru. As it is, I nearly lost my sanity during that period. Others on this board can attest to my frazzled mental state last winter. Rarely does cancer allow us the option of leisurely choosing between so many options. Even in my wife's case we had to chose between immediate spinal surgery or proceed with a biopsy and wait for the results. And the decision had to be made within hours. There are and were no guarantees that one path would not lead to a complete disaster or to a full recovery. As you know, on that other message board there are those who believe that surgery is a brutal form of torture that should be outlawed and that any form of radiation therapy would yield a superior outcome. I was told by my surgeon that if I had been five years older, or had some health issues, or if my cancer had progressed just a bit further, that I would not be a candidate for surgery. Again, no time to sit and wait. Furthermore I did not like the idea of having this dead organ inside of me for the rest of my life, or that I might end up like several other men I've spoken with who had been left with serious bowel issues. And as far as I knew at the time, if the radiation failed to kill the cancer there were no other options but chemo. BTW, I should mention that my father, who I loved dearly, was a radiologist, or more specifically, what is today known as a radiation oncologist. If anything, I might be biased toward radiation, not against it. It's just that in my case, radiation was not a good fit. Heck, surgery barely fit at the time. And as it is, I've ended up getting almost as much radiation as I would have if I'd gone that way in the first place. But I have the assurance of knowing that a very good doctor was actually in there, knew exactly what he had taken out and what was left behind. It was not a smooth journey by any means, and I am still to this day fighting this disease tooth and nail. Your choices will be based upon your present situation and given the constraints within which you must navigate. You are the commander of this ship and where you end up will be the result of the decisions you make within the limitations of the knowledge you have to work with. In other words, it's pretty much like the life in general, but this time the stakes are higher. I still love to hear every doctor I've seen tell me "you made the right decision". At the time, there was no way to be sure.

Posts.Title: Which Treatment????

Posts.Content: Yesterday was surgery number 15, and I'm pleased to say that everything went well. This was a revision of the septoplasty that I'd had last April but which left me with a collapsed nasal valve. So some bone was removed from my nasal cavity and a pair of implants were placed into either side of my nose to hold it open. Everything went well. I went in at noon and was home at 4PM and slept most of the rest of the day. After several dressing changes, the bleeding had stopped by 11PM last night. My nose is crusty and tender, but it's nothing like the original surgery last April, when I was stuffed up for several weeks. Once that had cleared up it became obvious that I wasn't breathing as I should. A lot of people, when I told them I was having a septoplasty for a deviated septum, they told me oh yeah I had that and it really helped. Well, that's just me and my luck. So this revision surgery had originally been scheduled fairly soon after, but then that mass was discovered in my abdomen. Everything had to be postponed to take care of that first. So as they say, "it's another one for the record books". I'm typing without my reading glasses as they hurt my nose (I had been warned about that beforehand). There appears to be no bruising, but have some ink marks on my nose. Anyone remember "Nip Tuck"? So I'm glad at least that my nose is open now and just have to sleep with my head elevated for a few nights. Next "big" surgery will hopefully be the total knee replacement that I was supposed to get back in 2015, but got prostate cancer instead. That damn cancer just gets in the way of everything!

Posts.Title: Well, I just had another surgery

Posts.Content: Frenchy, congrats on keeping the low PSA. I'm exactly one year behind you... one year since RP and presently just finishing RT. I'm surprised since you are T3b that they did not refer you immediately for ART and start you on HT. Also not using the uPSA. But it's the outcome that is important. I had to request a testosterone check at my last PSA, and will ask for one every three months now until after the HT wears off. The significance is that higher T-levels while you are undergoing treatment means the HT is not working... which I guess in your case probably doesn't apply. I've heard it said that following HT T-levels never return to their previous normal high.

Posts.Title: Which Treatment????

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DKing My husband just got Diagnosed with prostate cancer. PSA was 21.32 T3 Gleason 8 Invasive adenocarcinoma - Gleason score 8 (4,4) core 85% tissue involved- right lateral anterior ... I am more worried then my husband Your husband's numbers are very similar to mine. See my sig below. The additional bone scan is necessary to rule out distant metastasis. Surgery is typically the logical choice in these cases, as stated by others, because if there is residual cancer after surgery then radiation can still be used to treat it (the converse is not true). Posts.Title: Criteria for RT after RP: Adjuvant vs. Salvage

Posts.Content: Not sure if there is actually a question in here, but here's a few things I've been able to determine: ART - adjuvant radiation is planned as part of the RP surgery, either due to adverse pathology known beforehand from the biopsy or discovered during the RP surgery. Adverse pathology is generally a very high pre-op PSA, locally advanced cancer (stage 3), seminal vesicle invasion, positive surgical margin. I am generalizing here, but the difference between adjuvant and salvage radiation is not so much based on the time lapsed between RP and RT, but on known adverse pathology which was not resolved during surgery. Generally ART is planned to be performed as soon as possible following surgery, generally 3 to 6 months post-op, or as soon as sufficient healing and continence have returned. ** SRT - salvage radiation is prompted by a rise in PSA post op in response to possible biological recurrence (BR). This is generally determined by two consecutive rises in PSA and/or PSA rising above a threshold value, formerly 0.2 but more recently 0.03 ... Often SRT would be needed if there was positive surgical margin(s) which at the time of surgery "may or may not" lead to BR, as opposed to ART which is prompted by adverse pathology which is likely to lead to rising PSA immediately following surgery without a period of low PSA between RP and RT. SRT is often required in a 2-5 year time window following RP. Sorry I do not have references or specific links to support any of this. It was not easy to glean this info from highly technical articles and personal accounts on boards like this one, so if anyone disputes these generalities, have at it. FWIW the recent NCCN classifications of high risk or adverse pathology is presented here. Again there is much discourse and dispute (nit-picking) on what on the surface appear to be hard and fast criteria. Low risk. The tumor is classified as T1a, T1b, T1c, or T2a. PSA is less than 10 ng/mL. The Gleason score is 6 or less. Intermediate risk. The tumor has 2 or more of these characteristics: Classified as T2b or T2c PSA is between 10 and 20 ng/mL Gleason score of 7 High risk. The tumor has 2 or more of these characteristics: Classified as T3a PSA level is higher than 20 ng/mL Gleason score is between 8 and 10 Very high risk. The tumor is classified as T3b or T4. The histologic grade is 5 for the main pattern of cell growth, or more than 4 biopsy cores have Gleason scores between 8 and 10. ** BTW in my case, I had been referring to my current radiation treatment as 'SRT' before I knew enough to figure out that it was actually ART. I was told immediately after surgery that I would need radiation at six months post-op due to the SVI. But at six months I was still near fully incontinent so was put on ADT to keep my PSA down until such time that continence could return. PSA rise was minimal, but the 12 month milestone was approaching. Why that was important is a different discussion. Anyway, my RT is referred to as "delayed adjuvant".

You have a post-op followup and he would do periodic checkup's and any injections (HT) that may be deemed necessary. But your treatment would be directed by your RO. Posts.Title: 6 Months out of surgery robotic prostatectomy

Posts.Content: The grade and extent of your father's cancer does indeed make surgery questionable, however there are advantages to removal followed by EBRT as opposed to merely radiating the entire prostate area, especially if your father already has problems with urination. You will find, especially online, many proponents - even zealots, of radiation as monotherapy and view surgery as brutal and barbaric. Often it turns out that these individuals have had only intermediate grade cancer and/or have not dealt with long term after effects of living with a toasted prostate. I personally had RP+RT+HT over the past two years. The prostate gland and surrounding tissues were removed and thoroughly examined in a pathology lab and the extent of disease was well known once the surgeon was finished. All three forms of therapy have had lasting after effects. The surgery left me incontinent and I required a prosthetic implant to proceed on with radiation. The adjuvant radiation left me with persistent bowel problems. And the hormone therapy is a "gift that keeps on giving" as for how it has impacted my life. But my PSA is now zero, I have no problems with voiding and my gastroenterologist says my next colonoscopy will be in seven years. My current urologist stated that high risk, high grade PCa patients who undergo the trifecta treatment protocol have the lowest incidence of recurrence compared to those men who had RP or RT (of any form) alone, with or without HT. Also please be aware that of the guys with G8-10 and stage T3a-b there is a 50% possibility that they would not have needed the adjuvant radiation, however given your father's advanced condition I do not believe he would be fortunate enough to get by without it. Additionally be aware that there are limitations to the accuracy of external scans regarding their ability to identify and locate the extent of spread until the disease has progressed much further. The only way to be sure that it stopped at the SV and capsule is to actually get in there. Some surgeons will likely even be unwilling to operate on a man your dad's age and condition, and radiation oncologists will likely give highly optimistic predictions for their own particular form of RT which they practice. Don't dismiss any possible options. Your father is only a few years older than me and has a slightly worse prognosis, but for me at least for now, prostate cancer appears to now be in the past.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic For Intermediate risk, did you mean G7 or G7-10? My pre-surgery PSA (correcting for Proscar by doubling) was <10. What risk group am I? Intermediate? I think I need post-surgery classification. Post-surgery one has the detailed path report and doesn't have to rely (only) on the biopsy. I'm hoping, despite the G9, my Uro will say I don't need ART and we can just monitor the PSA. The good and the bad in my case led me to ask my URO for the Decipher test. From what I've read, high G is included; that's my dilemma. DT - the table was copied directly from from the NCCN guidelines and I didn't add or subtract anything, but merely added emphasis for clarity. It is difficult to find such straightforward information now because these guidelines are currently in the process of being revised by committee (!) ... However, the 'higher' risk categories generally include "G8-10" and "primary grade 5" both of which your case meets. I can't really read any more 'into' the tables as your case is rather odd (as I'm sure you already know!) Here's a link to the complete guidance in PDF form. Pop open a beer and plan to spend the evening in your recliner. What you want is probably on pages 10-11. https://www.tri-kobe.org/nccn/guidel...h/prostate.pdf Originally Posted by rmotacek1 I was scheduled to have ART as soon as I could after RP because of my adverse pathology report (see signature). I didn't even question them because I was still kind of shell shocked from the whole cancer diagnosis. On one hand, I kind of wish I would have waited and watched my PSA levels first and maybe did more research on the pros & cons of ART. It wasn't cheap and I worry about the long term SE's. On the other hand, I think it was important to throw a one-two punch at my aggressive cancer. Anyway, I am playing the cards I was dealt. Now I just play the waiting game every six months and hope for the best. Rmotacek, you did the right thing imo. Looking at all the (+)'s in your sig, primary 4, secondary 5, 12 cores positive... if it didn't get you now, it would probably come back and bite you later. Glad to see your PSA is still dropping and your continence appears to be excellent. Well played!

Posts.Title: middle of SRT and Hormone - PSA .02 = problem?

Posts.Content: IMO "should be 0" is a rather broad statement. There are a number of us on here who had RP's and had, are having, or will be having SRT, are currently on HT and have PSA's in the low >0 range. Plus, as pointed out, your SRT is still underway. Probably best to see what shakes out once that is over with. I'm guessing there's not much they can do about a little PSA once the prostate is out (it's not like they can go back in and take out the other one!) and doubtful that more RT would do any more good, especially soon after the first... other than extending HT, given that there is not already widespread systemic metastasis. How well have you handled the Lupron? I'm about 6-8 weeks in and have just had a few bouts of sweats and feel a little foggy in the brain, otherwise not much.

Posts.Title: middle of SRT and Hormone - PSA .02 = problem?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi Other than what your RO said, did you have anything else to support continuing HT? I ask because I can’t locate any citations about HT helping with the residual effects of post radiation treatment. No actual hard data, just an engineer's hunch as to how things work. The Uro who did my RP said 2-3 years was typical. Then my RO said the only relevant studies he relied upon were either six months or 24 months. Then there were the studies often referenced on HW showing little difference between 18 months and 24 months, and that 18 months was emerging as the new standard. Add to that the fact that I started Lupron eight months before starting the two months of RT, and it would last another two months afterwards (8+2+2=12) and adding another six months would bring me up to new standard of 18 months. I had already learned how to cope with the Lupron and figured I may as well go all in. I believe that starving the cancer cells an additional six months while they're dying from radiation exposure would only assist in their demise. And I suspect that if I quit HT at the first opportunity that some weakened cells might recover and come back to haunt me someday later on. And again, going off Lupron only to need to start again at some later date seemed counterproductive. As I said, throw everything at the beast while it's down for the count. There's nothing in all that I read or heard which said that I couldn't or shouldn't remain on HT for another six months, and as long as the doctor concurs, the insurance will pay for it. In other words, the decision was all mine... My fear now is, what happens when this finally wears off?
Posts.Title: Looking for opinion

Posts.Content: From what I understand, 0.02 is the lower limit of what can be detected. At least your PSA is less than what it was, so apparently the Lupron is doing its job. I wouldn't worry, but if you are then you should probably ask your RO.

Posts.Title: middle of SRT and Hormone - PSA .02 = problem?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gary e Been done with RP 2years ago... Done with radiation last month but have my 6th monthly firmagon injection coming up. I am beginning to hate firmagon as it makes me tired and gives me hot flashes. Gary, I suspect that your fatigue may be largely due to the residual affect of the SRT. Yes, HT does cause fatigue, but the last few weeks of radiation and a month or so afterwards also contributes to extreme fatigue. I'm well into my second year of HT now and the most difficult SE's have been brain fog, emotional volatility and the hot flashes/night sweats, in that order. I too take Venlafaxine (generic for Effexor) which has helped with the hot flashes and emotional instability, but the brain fox persists. No major financial blunders so far, but have done a few stupid things, can't remember names etc. Regarding the duration of adjuvant HT, I heard everything everything from nine months to three years. I could have opted to end HT a few months ago following the end of ART, but elected to go with an additional six month shot, which should start to wear off in July. My Uro says it will take a year for my testosterone to return and will never return to full level. My decision was based on current data indicating there is little difference between 18 months and 24 months of HT. But primarily it was because my RO told me that the residual effects of the adjuvant radiation would continue to kill cancer cells for an additional 8-9 months after the conclusion of RT. Doing some quick math I recognized that another six months of HT and then both the HT and RT would work together during that time. Our cases, yours and mine, are slightly different in that my ART was one year post-op and yours was two years. But neither of us reached undetectable status until after HT+RT. Yes, it's tough, and we don't get cut much slack by anyone because of it. Only those who have been on HT can appreciate it. Women think it's like menopause and we are getting testosterone shots like HRT. And most men don't realize just how dependent they are on testosterone for much of their drive and motivation. As you are looking for opinions, mine would be to throw everything at the beast now while you still can. Possibly having to go back on HT in the future may not be nearly as effective as it would be to just continue with it now. In the long run, it's only a few more months.

Posts.Title: Looking for opinion

Posts.Content: It's sad to hear that this disease has hit someone as young as you, but you are fortunate to have an understanding wife to support you. Medicine is not exact and sometimes unplanned stuff happens. Cancer itself can affect your emotional state, and depression is not uncommon. If you have had prior experience with other diseases or surgeries then you already know this. I have found that visiting forums such as this and seeing what others have been thru can help one realize that things always could have been a lot worse. You are fortunate that your disease was discovered early and was readily treatable. Maybe it wasn't perfect, but you are alive and most likely have a good prognosis for the future. I don't really know what else to say, but I do fully understand what you are feeling, and hope you are able to pull out of it. Many others here have been thru this also.

Posts.Content: Indeed PO you are fortunate to still be with us, and we are fortunate to have you with us. We are celebrating a quiet, relatively normal Christmas this year, for a change... Last year on December 5th, an MRI had identified a tumor on my wife's spine. Her pain was so severe that I took her to the ER on Dec 15th, where she was admitted and diagnosed with primary bone lymphoma. She began chemo and radiation and was finally discharged the night of Dec 23rd, just the night before Christmas Eve. Then on December 28th she was rushed into emergency surgery. Quite the Christmas to remember! 2017 was a year full of treatments for both of us, following an even more eventful 2016. Here's hoping for a peaceful and HEALTHY 2018 for us all!

Posts.Title: Viadur (leuprolide acetate implant)

Posts.Content: At the apex the tissues blend together and it becomes difficult for the surgeon to separate the prostate from the surrounding tissue, hence there is a greater likelihood of cancerous tissue being left behind as a "positive surgical margin". The upside is that tumors located at the apex are more easily diagnosed being closer to the rectum. Tumors at the base are more difficult to locate because they sit directly beneath the bladder and away from the rectum. They cannot be felt by DRE and are more difficult to biopsy. There is a greater likelihood of bladder neck involvement and seminal vesicle invasion, but rarely (I think) leave a PSM as the tissues are distinct.

Posts.Title: Apex, Base and a discussion on positive margins

Posts.Content: In the Gleason score, the pathologist examines tissue samples from the prostate biopsy and identifies the most prevalent and predominant types of cancer cells in the samples and the second most predominant or in some cases the "worst type" but less predominant cells and adds the two numbers together. The cells are graded on a scale of one to five, with five being the worst. Grade 3 cells are the lowest grade that are considered to be cancerous. Grade 1 and 2 are not cancerous. Thus the most common cancers found in men who do have prostate cancer are: G6 (3+3), G7(3+4) also known as favorable G7, a worse G7 with the grade 4 more prevalent (4+3) or unfavorable, next is G8 which is usually (4+4) and G9 or G10 which have grade 5 cells as either the most predominant or next most or both... so 4+5, 5+4, and 5+5. Sounds confusing, but it is not really. A newer method of grading PCa still uses the Gleason grades, but combines the various Gleason scores into grade groups, from least to most severe... Grade Group 1: (3+3) Grade Group 2: (3+4) Grade Group 3: (4+3) Grade Group 4: (4+4) Grade Group 5: (4+5) and above.

Posts.Title: Metastatic Stage 4 continues

Posts.Content: Personally I don't think you have much to worry about. Your numbers are low and this was caught early. Read through the bio's of some of the guys who post here and you will see +perineural invasion noted often. There are many other possible findings that are worse then PNI, but typically are associated with higher Gleason scores. There is a possibility that the final pathology may elevate your Gleason from 7 to either 8 or 9, and that does happen, but then some even have theirs lowered once the prostate has been removed and examined under a microscope. Your surgeon should tell you what you should be prepared for. Your greatest concerns now should be about the day of surgery and the week or two that follow. 99.99% the guys pull thru this without any complications. The soreness and immobility and the catheter are inconvenient and uncomfortable, but not very painful. If you've had major surgery before you may rank the RP fairly low on the scale, so to speak. Your surgeon has probably done this procedure many hundreds or possibly thousands of times and is likely well equipped to handle anything that may come up. You should have every reason to be confident of the outcome. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Fort post-meeting with surgeon tomorrow

Posts.Content: Consult, don't start to worry YET. The horses have just left the gate and are not yet even at the first turn. A lot of nerve tissue was severed during your surgery and it will take time to recover both sensation and control. Be aware that there is such a thing as too much Kegeling which can tire the muscles and lead to more leakage. Time is a better healer than any amount of exercise, and every doctor I've spoken with agrees that most healing will have occurred by nine months, but can continue thru 12-18 months post-op. For most men, it is between 3 and 6 months. As others have said, you will first have dry nights. Of course, getting up from those dry nights can be annoying. Also as was my case, standing was the worst. I was okay getting up, but when on my feet 'doing other stuff' and not having my mind focused on 'holding it' was when I would flow like a garden hose, and be totally unaware of it. My Uro put me into Kegel training PT at three months, primarily because I had this deadline of getting adjuvant radiation underway at six months, due to adverse pathology. You should note that I am not your typical case, and AFAIK am the only one in this forum to have an artificial sphincter implant after all else failed. And even with that device implanted, I still squirt a little on occasion... but one pad lasts for several days. Even now I can tell that my natural continence is still improving more than one full year post-op. With your pathology, I'd say if you have any continence issues it will not have anything to do with your prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: Fort post-meeting with surgeon tomorrow

Posts.Content: Consult, don't start to worry YET. The horses have just left the gate and are not yet even at the first turn. A lot of nerve tissue was severed during your surgery and it will take time to recover both sensation and control. Be aware that there is such a thing as too much Kegeling which can tire the muscles and lead to more leakage. Time is a better healer than any amount of exercise, and every doctor I've spoken with agrees that most healing will have occurred by nine months, but can continue thru 12-18 months post-op. For most men, it is between 3 and 6 months. As others have said, you will first have dry nights. Of course, getting up from those dry nights can be annoying. Also as was my case, standing was the worst. I was okay getting up, but when on my feet 'doing other stuff' and not having my mind focused on 'holding it' was when I would flow like a garden hose, and be totally unaware of it. My Uro put me into Kegel training PT at three months, primarily because I had this deadline of getting adjuvant radiation underway at six months, due to adverse pathology. You should note that I am not your typical case, and AFAIK am the only one in this forum to have an artificial sphincter implant after all else failed. And even with that device implanted, I still squirt a little on occasion... but one pad lasts for several days. Even now I can tell that my natural continence is still improving more than one full year post-op. With your pathology, I'd say if you have any continence issues it will not have anything to do with your prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman And I may be wrong, but isn't it possible that eligard could be effective for more than 2 years? Eventually cancer cells become "castration resistant". It takes years, but happens eventually ... I think around three years. Sometimes guys are put on intermittent HT. It gives them a break now and then, and the Ca cells get "re-tenderized" again. But then, of course, I could be wrong
Posts.Title: Stage 3 progression??

Posts.Content: When you say stage 3, I assume you mean you were either T3a or T3b. Hopefully the eight weeks of radiation cleaned up whatever cancer may have remained following your RP. That's what it was supposed to do anyway, not necessarily the Eligard. The HT is intended to keep your PSA down between RP and SRT (or at least, that's how I understand it's supposed to work). Also tenderize the cancer cells so to speak.. it starves them of that tasty testosterone they love so much. It's a bit disappointing that some of the more knowledgeable guys haven't replied yet. Hopefully they will soon. If you could provide your exact pathology... margins, LNI, SVI or whatever, that might help.

Posts.Title: Metastatic Stage 4 continues

Posts.Content: Personally I don't think you have much to worry about. Your numbers are low and this was caught early. Read through the bio's of some of the guys who post here and you will see +perineural invasion noted often. There are many other possible findings that are worse then PNI, but typically are associated with higher Gleason scores. There is a possibility that the final pathology may elevate your Gleason from 7 to either 8 or 9, and that does happen, but then some even have theirs lowered once the prostate has been removed and examined under a microscope. Your surgeon should tell you what you should be prepared for. Your greatest concerns now should be about the day of surgery and the week or two that follow. 99.99% the guys pull thru this without any complications. The soreness and immobility and the catheter are inconvenient and uncomfortable, but not very painful. If you've had major surgery before you may rank the RP fairly low on the scale, so to speak. Your surgeon has probably done this procedure many hundreds or possibly thousands of times and is likely well equipped to handle anything that may come up. You should have every reason to be confident of the outcome. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Membership renewal

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi Other than what your RO said, did you have anything else to support continuing HT? I ask because I can’t locate any citations about HT helping with the residual effects of post radiation treatment. No actual hard data, just an engineer's hunch as to how things work. The Uro who did my RP said 2-3 years was typical. Then my RO said the only relevant studies he relied upon were either six months or 24 months. Then there were the studies often referenced on HW showing little difference between 18 months and 24 months, and that 18 months was emerging as the new standard. Add to that the fact that I started Lupron eight months before starting the two months of RT, and it would last another two months afterwards (8+2+2=12) and adding another six months would bring me up to new standard of 18 months. I had already learned how to cope with the Lupron and figured I may as well go all in. I believe that starving the cancer cells an additional six months while they're dying from radiation exposure would only assist in their demise. And I suspect that if I quit HT at the first opportunity that some weakened cells might recover and come back to haunt me someday later on. And again, going off Lupron only to need to start again at some later date seemed counterproductive. As I said, throw everything at the beast while it's down for the count. There's nothing in all that I read or heard which said that I couldn't or shouldn't remain on HT for another six months, and as long as the doctor concurs, the insurance will pay for it. In other words, the decision was all mine... My fear now is, what happens when this finally wears off?

Posts.Title: Fort post-meeting with surgeon tomorrow

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gary e Been done with RP 2years ago... Done with radiation last month but have my 6th monthly firmagon injection coming up. I am beginning to hate firmagon as it makes me tired and gives me hot flashes. Gary, I suspect that your fatigue may be largely due to the residual affect of the SRT. Yes, HT does cause fatigue, but the last few weeks of radiation and a month or so afterwards also contributes to extreme fatigue. I'm well into my second year of HT now and the most difficult SE's have been brain fog, emotional volatility and the hot flashes/night sweats, in that order. I too take Venlafaxine (generic for Effexor) which has helped with the hot flashes and emotional instability, but the brain fox persists. No major financial blunders so far, but have done a few stupid things, can't remember names etc. Regarding the duration of adjuvant HT, I heard everything everything from nine months to three years. I could have opted to end HT a few months ago following the end of ART, but elected to go with an additional six month shot, which should start to wear off in July. My Uro says it will take a year for my testosterone to return and will never return to full level. My decision was based on current data indicating there is little difference between 18 months and 24 months of HT. But primarily it was because my RO told me that the residual effects of the adjuvant radiation would continue to kill cancer cells for an additional 8-9 months after the conclusion of RT. Doing some quick math I recognized that another six months of HT and then both the HT and RT would work together during that time. Our cases, yours and mine, are slightly different in that my ART was one year post-op and yours was two years. But neither of us reached undetectable status until after HT+RT. Yes, it's tough, and we don't get cut much slack by anyone because of it. Only those who have been on HT can appreciate it. Women think it's like menopause and we are getting testosterone shots like HRT. And most men don't realize just how dependent they are on testosterone for much of their drive and motivation. As you are looking for opinions, mine would be to throw everything at the beast now while you still can. Possibly having to go back on HT in the future may not be nearly as effective as it would be to just continue with it now. In the long run, it's only a few more months.

Posts.Content: Thanks Mike. After wading thru the gobbledygook, the following quite might be most significant for those guys who may be grappling with the decision whether or not to proceed with radiation after RP or waiting to see just what shakes out... When this literature is examined as a whole, it appears that ART patients generally have better outcomes compared to SRT patients. For example, ART study arms generally report lower rates of biochemical recurrence and metastatic recurrence than do SRT study arms at similar post-RP follow-up durations.

Posts.Title: Adjuvant and Salvage Radiotherapy after Prostatectomy: ASTRO/AUA Guideline

Posts.Content: A lot would depend on your age and the number of positive cores from the biopsy, as well as the percentage of those cores. Your Gleason could put you into either active surveillance or treatment, but your PSA is relatively high and the thing to watch would be the doubling time. If it goes above 10 then you do need to act and I'd say that surgery is the appropriate choice, assuming your age and general health allow (and assuming they do since you're already scheduled). Most guys make it thru surgery just fine. You'll need to make preparations for a period of incontinence, which should heal up generally within six months. The thing about getting the prostate out is that it will be examined in a pathology lab and you will get a report of EXACTLY what was in there. Often a biopsy only reveals a small amount of a low grade tumor, but it is later discovered that there were higher grade tumors lurking in the shadows. Some others will promote various forms of radiation, which can do the trick but without the pathology. RT is administered based upon external scans which don't always show the whole picture, and is something like shooting in the dark. And bear in mind that EVERY form of treatment carries with some risk of side effects. Good luck to you, and your family!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind 30% of the time, surgery reveals a higher grade cancer than the biopsy discovered.. Fairwind ... You're another one who had normal DRE's and negative biopsies, only to be shot down when pathology revealed a far worse condition than the earlier tests had indicated. Now I know you're pretty much boxed in. I'm sorry to say it, but reading your story makes me realize just how fortunate I truly am. If there's a silver lining, that's it. Your ability to maintain a positive outlook throughout your journey is to be admired.
Posts.Title: Did I make the right choice.

Posts.Content: Welcome to your sixties, our "Golden years" lol. I had been planning our retirement for years. There was a powerful urge to start taking SS at 62. Plus there were, and still are, people urging my wife to take it early saying "do the math, you're throwing money away" rather than listening to informed financial experts who say delay it as long as possible. Two responses I always use are "that's not math, that's arithmetic" (those who say do the math don't know the difference between the two) and I ask my wife if she would rather have $2000 a month now or $3000 a month in a few years. That usually makes sense to most sensible people. So the fact that we both have had cancer sort of altered our perceptions, but did not change the plan. Things got complicated though. The first biopsy (false negative, but my doc didn't share that info) was on my wife's insurance. Probably just as well. I turned 64 later that year and the plan began to solidify. We planned when to move our furniture to Florida and when to put our house on the market. The process took several years. I filed for SSRI three months before my 65th birthday, as it takes 90 days to process. The objective was for medicare premiums to come directly out of the SSA as that simplifies everything. If you do not already have an online acct at SSA.gov do so now. It will give you your projected payout for future years, and you can interpolate for the years in between. She and I both had to let our employers know in advance. For me that involved finding and training a replacement, as I was sort of a one man band where I worked. I started on that four years in advance. We knew what my wife would get on her pension and what our investments were/would be worth. I'm sure you have all that figured out as well. Once my medicare started things kicked into high gear. I had a new doctor in Florida who caused me to question my urologist's approach. Coincidentally he announced his retirement at our next and last meeting. I quickly had the MRI and fusion biopsy, bone scan, all that. Medicare paid for everything. We drove our last truckload of stuff to Florida, made arrangements for renovations to our new place and flew back north for my prostatectomy. Six weeks later our place sold and we drove our second car and most of the last of our stuff back to Florida. As I was on medicare and she is two years younger than me she went on Obamacare for a year, which was cheap but meant paying a HUGE deductible when she was diagnosed just a couple months later. Fortunately we had just sold a house. The delays with her chemo and my AUS and radiation caused for my Excel spreadsheet ("the plan") to grow extensively. Medical expenses grew much more than we had planned, but has worked out okay. Now she gets about the same monthly amount from her pension that I do from SSRI. Since our income is now very low, she is drawing down her taxable IRA as we delay starting her SSRI, which is still a couple years off (we've compromised on 68 rather than 70) but the plan is still working. Being in your line of work I'm sure you have a lot of this figured out already. Medicare is awesome. Now she has been on it for a year already but has not much needed it. OTOH I've had all this weird medical problems. I hate to be a burden on society, but then people like you and me and my wife have paid into it for most of our lives so it is "supposed" to be our money anyway, right? As you approach medicare age, you will get all kinds of junk mail from insurance companies. Do your research and choose wisely. Occasionally my wife will some back from one of her activities and tell me that someone told her that she should be taking spousal benefit from MY SSRI. All stuff I've already looked into, and I have to convince her to have faith in the plan. It's like a chronic backache. You recognize it when it pops back up again and know how to deal with it, but it's still annoying anyway. Good luck in the coming years. I've been meaning to call you and see how your AUS is working out. I won't bother trying to call anyone today, as I realize that it is a very special day for a lot of guys. Take care and TTYL.

Posts.Title: social security and health issues

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD There is more to it than just the amount you get at what age. How long do you expect to live? There's your gamble. You will have to do this calculation for your situation and decide what is best for you. The final gamble is how long will you live. True. That's why I said our cancers changed our perspective but not our plan. The plan was created before either of us had cancer. We were retired and had moved. What would we do differently at that point? There are those who say to take the money now and spend it before you die. I still plan to live into my eighties and her into her nineties. And there will still be inflation during all those years. That's where $3000/mo looks a lot better than $2000. If one of us relapses and die within the 5-10 year window instead of the 10-20 year window, we're going to wish we'd taken our SS earlier? Perhaps. More likely we'll be thankful for the time we had together and glad that the survivor has an extra $1000 every month. And yeah, I've heard the "take it now and invest it", but there are not many investments that can guarantee 6.7%. And in most cases, you spend whatever you make. So if we can afford to live on a little less and still be happy, then we feel comfortable having the added cushion for our survivor.

Posts.Title: Did I make the right choice.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Chico Dave This summer, my PSA went up from 1.6 to 3.7. DRE was negative for any lumps... if I need a biopsy I would like to do what I can to assure it is as accurate as possible. My hunch is that Dr. Karpman's plan is a standard twelve core biopsy done in the office. I wish I had pursued my elevated PSA more aggressively four years ago. It was not until I retired and got a new primary care physician that he found two bumps during a DRE. I had been getting DRE's from my Uro for several years, plus what I understood to be a random biopsy which was 100% negative. My new PCP asked if I'd had an MRI associated with the biopsy and I said no. Returning to my Uro he said those bumps were "concretions". Note that all this time my PSA was going thru the roof. He recommended that I should be sure to drink plenty of water. It was not until he retired and his partner picked up my case that an MRI fusion biopsy was performed (like ten weeks ago) and everything accelerated rapidly from there. I suspect that if I had pursued treatment more aggressively when my PSA hit 9 that perhaps the PC might not have spread to the seminal vesicles and I might not be facing possible radiation treatment six months from now. Maybe I would have instead heard "we got it all, you are cancer free". So like I said, don't just take the word of your hot shot Hollywood uro. Shop around and ask LOTS of questions.

Posts.Title: social security and health issues

Posts.Content: Thomas, it sounds like you truly have your head in the right place. Congratulations on your earlier battle with colon cancer and also on your recent prostatectomy. As you said, it appears "clean", though your prostate was quite large (I think our moderator Chuck still holds the record though). Admittedly, cancer becomes easier to face after the first time around. My wife and I are survivors and I have faced a couple other possible cancers... one scare about a year ago and another pending surgery right now. I too never read Gary's lengthy self pity post, though I must say that around 18 months ago I was deeply upset and in the pit of despair... and seem to be thru that now. For those so affected, it is very difficult to deal with. Seeing so many people affected by cancer it is hard to believe that only a relatively small percentage of people either have it or have had it. I think it's either 15% or 15 million... Lupron brain makes it hard to keep figures straight, and also makes me not really care anyway. But enough about me. Anyway, It appears that this one is for all intents and purposes behind you, other than the usual post-op stuff... regaining continence and dealing with what is usually a lengthy period of ED. You haven't mentioned nerve sparing, but one would assume that your surgeon was able to retain most of your nerve tissue. Good luck to you in the months and years ahead!
