Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gunrun I'm going for an MRI without contrast this Saturday is that normal? Dunno. My MRI was with contrast, but I had previously had a negative biopsy. You are 20 years younger than me. It is possible your status is what mine may have been a few years ago.... a small, nearly undetectable tumor causing slowly rising PSA levels and worth watching but probably not justifying surgery... yet. Posts.Title: My update

Posts.Content: I still use the buttoned diapers. Easy to change. Just unbutton the front, drop it down a little and slide a new one in. Pull the old one out and button up the new one. No need to drop trou any further than the knees. Then I roll up the old one and stuff it into a one quart zipper baggie. Each baggie can hold two. I carry the fresh diaper along with the extra pair of straps in the baggie until the first change. The brand I use is called Prevail. They are identical to the CVS generics but cost about 30% less from Amazon. I use the diaper once or twice a week to give myself a break from the cath and leg bag, as I am able to hold a full bladder as long as I am sitting or laying down (or sleeping). Usually about 8 diapers per day as they do not hold a lot. As far as the pad/briefs combo, yeah, I still have a closet shelf full of them. The trick is to tear off just the bottom of the strip of paper that covers the adhesive strip on the pad, then stick it to the bottom of the brief, then it doesn't tear off so much of the liner inside the brief. I've found you can get 3-4 pad changes before going with just the brief, padless. Briefs require that eventually you need to remove the trousers, which generally means removing the shoes as well. Major operation for a typical bathroom stall. Main problem I had with the briefs is perspiration. If I may mention it, Forum Brother Jamie developed jock itch from wearing briefs too long each day using the pad replacement approach. In the end I gave up entirely on the pad/brief approach as my leakage while on my feet is too voluminous for any absorbency product to accommodate. Even the belted diapers don't hold much. They appear to be made more for women (the blue strip is between your legs, not up front) even though the package claims that they are "unisex".

Posts.Title: Depends pads and briefs?

Posts.Content: A lot would depend on your age and the number of positive cores from the biopsy, as well as the percentage of those cores. Your Gleason could put you into either active surveillance or treatment, but your PSA is relatively high and the thing to watch would be the doubling time. If it goes above 10 then you do need to act and I'd say that surgery is the appropriate choice, assuming your age and general health allow (and assuming they do since you're already scheduled). Most guys make it thru surgery just fine. You'll need to make preparations for a period of incontinence, which should heal up generally within six months. The thing about getting the prostate out is that it will be examined in a pathology lab and you will get a report of EXACTLY what was in there. Often a biopsy only reveals a small amount of a low grade tumor, but it is later discovered that there were higher grade tumors lurking in the shadows. Some others will promote various forms of radiation, which can do the trick but without the pathology. RT is administered based upon external scans which don't always show the whole picture, and is something like shooting in the dark. And bear in mind that EVERY form of treatment carries with some risk of side effects. Good luck to you, and your family!

Posts.Title: Did I make the right choice.

Posts.Content: Thomas, it sounds like you truly have your head in the right place. Congratulations on your earlier battle with colon cancer and also on your recent prostatectomy. As you said, it appears "clean", though your prostate was quite large (I think our moderator Chuck still holds the record though). Admittedly, cancer becomes easier to face after the first time around. My wife and I are survivors and I have faced a couple other possible cancers... one scare about a year ago and another pending surgery right now. I too never read Gary's lengthy self pity post, though I must say that around 18 months ago I was deeply upset and in the pit of despair... and seem to be thru that now. For those so affected, it is very difficult to deal with. Seeing so many people affected by cancer it is hard to believe that only a relatively small percentage of people either have it or have had it. I think it's either 15% or 15 million... Lupron brain makes it hard to keep figures straight, and also makes me not really care anyway. But enough about me. Anyway, It appears that this one is for all intents and purposes behind you, other than the usual post-op stuff... regaining continence and dealing with what is usually a lengthy period of ED. You haven't mentioned nerve sparing, but one would assume that your surgeon was able to retain most of your nerve tissue. Good luck to you in the months and years ahead!
Posts.Title: Well, Now What?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind 30% of the time, surgery reveals a higher grade cancer than the biopsy discovered.. Fairwind ... You're another one who had normal DRE's and negative biopsies, only to be shot down when pathology revealed a far worse condition than the earlier tests had indicated. Now I know you're pretty much boxed in. I'm sorry to say it, but reading your story makes me realize just how fortunate I truly am. If there's a silver lining, that's it. Your ability to maintain a positive outlook throughout your journey is to be admired.
Posts.Title: Did I make the right choice.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nick P Prostate removed 9/16 but PSA was 0.6 afterwards rising to 1.0 over the next year. Had salvage radiation in late '17 with Lupron injections every 3 months(had the third about a month ago). Just had my PSA done and it's too low to measure. Doctor wants me to stay on Lupron for another year, then we'll ween me and see what happens. I know Lupron can drive PSA numbers down but can Lupron alone make the PSA too low to measure? I suppose it can, but it primarily depends on what they're calling undetectable. Welcome back Nick, by the way. I had RP and RT right around the same time as yours (August 2016 and 2017). In between those two I was on Lupron only. Initially my PSA was called undetectable, but I went to the lab's website where they defined the lower limit as .02 ... Initially I was "<.02" then it was .02, then <.03 and then .03 ... I suppose at some point in there it came out from under the veil of undetectabiliity so to speak. Now they're telling me it is undetectable but I have to ask, is it zero, and then they say yes it's zero. Now I realize that after eighteen months on Lupron that the PSA is still being artificially suppressed, but by how much? And for how long?. Hence I always just tell people I won't know until sometime in 2020. With these drugs that stay in our systems for so long there's no way to know for sure just what you're seeing. You're reading was pretty high post-op so there must have been a substantial amount of local spread. I don't remember what your sig used to look like, but when all this is over we should have a big celebration!

Posts.Title: Salvage radiation treatment followup

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Chico Dave This summer, my PSA went up from 1.6 to 3.7. DRE was negative for any lumps... if I need a biopsy I would like to do what I can to assure it is as accurate as possible. My hunch is that Dr. Karpman's plan is a standard twelve core biopsy done in the office. I wish I had pursued my elevated PSA more aggressively four years ago. It was not until I retired and got a new primary care physician that he found two bumps during a DRE. I had been getting DRE's from my Uro for several years, plus what I understood to be a random biopsy which was 100% negative. My new PCP asked if I'd had an MRI associated with the biopsy and I said no. Returning to my Uro he said those bumps were "concretions". Note that all this time my PSA was going thru the roof. He recommended that I should be sure to drink plenty of water. It was not until he retired and his partner picked up my case that an MRI fusion biopsy was performed (like ten weeks ago) and everything accelerated rapidly from there. I suspect that if I had pursued treatment more aggressively when my PSA hit 9 that perhaps the PC might not have spread to the seminal vesicles and I might not be facing possible radiation treatment six months from now. Maybe I would have instead heard "we got it all, you are cancer free". So like I said, don't just take the word of your hot shot Hollywood uro. Shop around and ask LOTS of questions.

Posts.Title: Salvage radiation treatment followup

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD There is more to it than just the amount you get at what age. How long do you expect to live? There's your gamble. You will have to do this calculation for your situation and decide what is best for you. The final gamble is how long will you live. True. That's why I said our cancers changed our perspective but not our plan. The plan was created before either of us had cancer. We were retired and had moved. What would we do differently at that point? There are those who say to take the money now and spend it before you die. I still plan to live into my eighties and her into her nineties. And there will still be inflation during all those years. That's where $3000/mo looks a lot better than $2000. If one of us relapses and die within the 5-10 year window instead of the 10-20 year window, we're going to wish we'd taken our SS earlier? Perhaps. More likely we'll be thankful for the time we had together and glad that the survivor has an extra $1000 every month. And yeah, I've heard the "take it now and invest it", but there are not many investments that can guarantee 6.7%. And in most cases, you spend whatever you make. So if we can afford to live on a little less and still be happy, then we feel comfortable having the added cushion for our survivor.

Posts.Title: My update

Posts.Content: Cpro, I had IMRT a year after RP. Actually I was told right after surgery that I would need adjuvant radiation in about six months but I had problems with continence. They usually prefer to allow 3-6 months before starting RT for everything to heal, as RT will also affect continence. Proton was available locally but as Southsider said is expensive and my insurance would not cover it. The machine used for my IMRT was the Varian Rapidarc. Details are in my sig below. Did your urologist mention anything about hormone therapy? And do you yet know your post-op PSA? These will be important factors. Studies have shown that ART (adjuvant radiation) administered within the first 21 months following surgery (yes, nearly two years) is more effective than waiting for PSA to cross some threshold, known as salvage radiation. The threshold for SRT was formerly 0.2 but more recently they have been using 0.03, though I believe they still use .02 as the threshold for BCR or biochemical recurrence. There are differing opinions over the need for ART in T3a cases with PSM and T3b with SVI. Some studies show as many as half might have comparable overall survival with or without post-op radiation, or something like that. Again, studies differ. I've never heard of proton therapy being used or even recommended for ART or SRT. In my case the IMRT left some persistent bowel disruption which will suposedly improve over the next year or two. But I am approaching two years since RP and my PSA is 0.00, though it is still artificially suppressed by ADT. I won't know for sure until sometime in 2020. Several other guys here have gone thru the same trifecta or RP, RT and HT and in some cases did not fare as well as I did. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Depends pads and briefs?

Posts.Content: You will need to see an upward trend, such as "<.03, .03, <.04) for three consecutive PSA's, otherwise don't worry about it. Generally the ultra sensitive PSA have a bit of wobble, but if it keeps going up then you might consider adjuvant therapy.

Posts.Title: Well, Now What?

Posts.Content: I was in the same situation, and was told right after the RP that I would need radiation in about six months. My wife and I had a lot going on at the time, as my diagnosis occurred the summer that we had retired and were moving out of our house of 33 years and into a condo in Florida, a thousand miles away. I was going thru 10-12 pads a day. My new Uro in FL set me up with a kegel coach (therapist) and trained with an anal plug and monitoring equipment. She had me doing more and more kegels, but some others here and elsewhere say it is possible to over exert and actually strain the muscles involved. And as soon as we moved, my wife was diagnosed with lymphoma and needed to go thru six months of chemo. I was her driver and caregiver for that time. My RO put me on Lupron to halt progression of the cancer. He told me that most healing of incontinence occurs within 9 months of surgery. So at seven months I had to make a decision, for as you know, radiation requires that you hold a quart or so of water for a couple of hours. It was a very stressful time. I knew that getting the AUS would change something that I do all day, every day, for the rest of my life. I did extensive research, and questioned the surgeon about lifespan and revisions etc. He assured me that everything would be okay. The big day came and everything was a disaster. He had to replace it two weeks later. My carefully planned schedule was thrown way off. But ultimately I was able to get thru the two months of daily RT, despite numerous hurdles thrown before me. Please note that at that time, there was no one else here on this message board who'd had an AUS. I was in uncharted territory. But since then, I have corresponded with several other implant recipients and they all had the quick and uncomplicated procedure that I had been promised. So I guess it's just me that everything seems to go wrong for. I started a group on FB for AUS patients but so far there's only two of us there. But I can give you some resources if you are interested, you can PM me here. Good luck to you!

Yeah, we're great because your PSA and tumor location seems to be exactly like mine! I'll tell you, those two years when mine went from PSA=9 to 25 were years I would NOT want to re-live! Others are right... at your age (you are my late older brother's age) surgery is probably not recommended, however some radiation therapy could add years to your life. Given that your G7 breaks down as 3+4 indicates that there is grade 4 PCa growing in there (grade 3 already established). Yes, you have some time on your side, for now. I'd say go ahead and get this treated, and live long enough to die from something else. You do NOT want metastatic bone disease in your old age!

Posts.Title: SBRT, Gleason 4+3, unfavorable. Concerned!

Posts.Content: Typically when there is adverse pathology identified during RP then RT is recommended at the six month mark to allow for adequate healing, or regaining sufficient continence to hold a full bladder, which is a requirement of RT. The apex of the prostate is more prone to result in positive surgical margins, as is the case with yours. If you are ready to go ahead with RT then I would say go for it. In my case it took a whole year of anguish and additional surgeries just to get to the point where I could do the RT. Men I've known who had +SM and SRT have done very well years later. You're right, sex isn't as important as is your own longevity. As I understand it, studies have shown that the PSA level before starting SRT is the most significant factor in affecting the outcome. It would make sense that starting RT before detectable PSA appears would be even better. If your PSA is still undetectable then it is unlikely that you would require hormone therapy.

Posts.Content: I would say you are right, but there's probably nothing that can be done, yet. His doctor cannot really do anything until a pattern is established. True, 0.2 is the threshold for BR but without a mets site to treat little can be done at this point. He probably had some adverse pathology (SVI, +SM) at the time of his prostatectomy, hence the radiation. But RT can fail. Your friend is probably looking at some form of treatment down the road... HT, maybe chemo. Not sure. This is what all of us survivors fear most!

Posts.Title: A friend

Posts.Content: Greetings, Gentlemen. I learned of my PC just two months ago from my second biopsy in two years, but this was my first MRI biopsy. My PSA had risen from 4 to 9 then teens and finally 25, Gleason 8 (4+4), two cores 100% plus two 4+3 some lesser value but all localized to the lower right lobe... all others negative. Elected surgery as that would allow examination of surrounding tissue and at 65 I am relatively young and healthy. I just got home yesterday and fell asleep in the recliner, then had a fairly good night's sleep in my bed last night. Still a little loopy from the anesthesia and morphine. Just started passing gas this morning but still waiting for the big poo (yeah, I'm really full of it) and avoiding the percocet for that reason. Pathology report is due next Tuesday after the holiday, but I am optimistic as bone scan and blood work were negative. Fortunately I had joined this forum a month ago and read a few posts here, and they have been a big help. I bought one of those big orange Home Depot buckets and keep the overnight bag hooked in there with a few other accessories. This morning I experienced some leakage around the foley but the nurse confirmed by phone that this is likely due to a bladder spasm. Fortunately my wife of 35 years was a rehab nurse and has lots of catheter experience so I haven't had to do much hands on myself except emptying the bag this morning. Initially I had intended to post here pre-op but we've had a lot going on lately, as we both recently retired and are in the process of moving to Florida. We just got back last weekend for this surgery and put the house on the market. We left Florida just days before Hurricane Hermine. My Urologist had also retired in the meantime but his partner has done thousands of DaVinci's and so far everything has gone well. Everyone at the hospital was friendly and cheerful, and as some of the staff recognized my wife it seemed they had put me in the executive suite, so the first night was as quiet and restful as could be expected. Well that's about all I know for now. I will figure out this signature thing later. I hope everyone who lives here stateside has fun this Labor Day weekend. See you later!

Posts.Title: Couple Of Questions Re: Salvage Radiation & Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: You will definitely need to find a radiological oncologist, preferably one who specialized in prostate cancer exclusively. The urologist should be able to refer you to one. Your husband's travel schedule will likely be a problem as radiation is typically administered daily over a period of many weeks in a row. The RO may recommend hormone therapy as well. Your husband's diagnosis is indeed unfortunate, particularly such an advanced case... but in the vast majority of cases this is not a death sentence. You have obviously already done a good deal of homework and are familiar with much of the terminology. The surgical report and the final pathology report after the prostate has been examined under a microscope will provide invaluable information necessary to plan his treatment. Though I am not familiar with this particular variety of PCa (signet cell), I suspect that even with his high numbers he still has a good chance of surviving his prostate cancer, though it will be a very long road. Certainly there will soon be a number of additional replies to this thread from others, perhaps some who had a similar case. Good luck to both you and your husband!

Posts.Title: Chemohormonal Treatment, PC Stage 4 D2

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jack1954 ... lymp nodes and seminal V involvement. My gleason is now 10 as well. I was quite shocked with the outcomes however I have to accept the reality. Shocking news indeed. We don't see a lot of G10's here. Not to sound glib, but I thought I had it bad, until I read about you. But I am curious... You have likely had this growing in you for some time now... certainly longer than your first urinary issues were addressed just one year ago. Did you have any suspicions that there was something wrong? Maybe hoping it might go away, or too afraid to find out for sure? In my case, the trouble started three years ago, but all the preliminary tests were negative. Because there was a lot going on in my life during the second year - and a very poor emotional state (perhaps because there was an unknown cancer eating away inside me) I did nothing when it probably would have been the best time to pursue further investigation aggressively, and before it began to spread. Unfortunately, that is not how it happened, and now it has. I wish you luck. Admittedly this does not look good. But the good news is you are doing something about it now. This is going to be a tough road ahead, but you are over the first hurdle. There are a few other guys here who have had, or who like us are facing post op RT and/or HT. We are all in the same boat - a boat we'd rather not be in, but a boat that floats and is better than being in the water. And we are in it together. We are praying for you, Jack.

Posts.Title: New here, just had DaVinci, day 2

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon Like you I spend 6 months in Florida, albeit I believe you live there 12 months/year. I prefer the golf temperatures in Ontario in the summer. Allen Last winter was our first in Florida. We moved our furniture down in the fall, then returned north in spring to empty our house... 33 years of accumulated junk. Then we drove a truck back to Fla this summer and returned last weekend for the surgery. Eventually we will be Florida residents., but for now leaving many things open ended. Originally Posted by Rich2.0 Hi Rob, It sounds like you're progressing well after surgery. I'm one week out and I was also very worried about constipation (still am). I found that two extra strength Tylenol were enough for me after the first day or so getting back home. Hang in there and don't forget to try to move around. That should also help with the gas and constipation as well. My back gets sore if I stay in one position too long so I have a built in reminder to get my butt up on a regular basis! Thanks for the tips. I tend to fall asleep easily for now, but I do get up and walk around the house, to the kitchen, bathroom etc. I notice you are quite young for PC - late forties? That's my nephew's age. I'm sorry you had to experience this at your age, but it is good that it was caught early! Originally Posted by PDV Hi Rob and Rich That constipation can be a real serious problem. Two or three weeks post surgery in 2011 my brother's bowels stopped working totally.There's a name for it but I can't recalled what it is--something like illyis. He was in incredible pain and his neighbor rushed him to the hospital. He was readmitted for eight days and fed intravenously. The only thing he was allowed to eat was ice chips. He was bored out of his mind. They had him walking up and down the aisles. Finally after eight days he farted and they sent him home. Knowing that, when I had the surgery last year I ate the stool softener and laxatives like candy. Good luck. Probably Ileitis. He may have already had an inflammatory bowel disease which became aggravated. Thanks for the reply.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jack1954 ... lymp nodes and seminal V involvement. My gleason is now 10 as well. I was quite shocked with the outcomes however I have to accept the reality. Shocking news indeed. We don't see a lot of G10's here. Not to sound glib, but I thought I had it bad, until I read about you. But I am curious... You have likely had this growing in you for some time now... certainly longer than your first urinary issues were addressed just one year ago. Did you have any suspicions that there was something wrong? Maybe hoping it might go away, or too afraid to find out for sure? In my case, the trouble started three years ago, but all the preliminary tests were negative. Because there was a lot going on in my life during the second year - and a very poor emotional state (perhaps because there was an unknown cancer eating away inside me) I did nothing when it probably would have been the best time to pursue further investigation aggressively, and before it began to spread. Unfortunately, that is not how it happened, and now it has. I wish you luck. Admittedly this does not look good. But the good news is you are doing something about it now. This is going to be a tough road ahead, but you are over the first hurdle. There are a few other guys here who have had, or who like us are facing post op RT and/or HT. We are all in the same boat - a boat we'd rather not be in, but a boat that floats and is better than being in the water. And we are in it together. We are praying for you, Jack.

Posts.Title: New here, just had DaVinci, day 2

Posts.Content: Greetings, Gentlemen. I learned of my PC just two months ago from my second biopsy in two years, but this was my first MRI biopsy. My PSA had risen from 4 to 9 then teens and finally 25, Gleason 8 (4+4), two cores 100% plus two 4+3 some lesser value but all localized to the lower right lobe... all others negative. Elected surgery as that would allow examination of surrounding tissue and at 65 I am relatively young and healthy. I just got home yesterday and fell asleep in the recliner, then had a fairly good night's sleep in my bed last night. Still a little loopy from the anesthesia and morphine. Just started passing gas this morning but still waiting for the big poo (yeah, I'm really full of it) and avoiding the percocet for that reason. Pathology report is due next Tuesday after the holiday, but I am optimistic as bone scan and blood work were negative. Fortunately I had joined this forum a month ago and read a few posts here, and they have been a big help. I bought one of those big orange Home Depot buckets and keep the overnight bag hooked in there with a few other accessories. This morning I experienced some leakage around the foley but the nurse confirmed by phone that this is likely due to a bladder spasm. Fortunately my wife of 35 years was a rehab nurse and has lots of catheter experience so I haven't had to do much hands on myself except emptying the bag this morning. Initially I had intended to post here pre-op but we've had a lot going on lately, as we both recently retired and are in the process of moving to Florida. We just got back last weekend for this surgery and put the house on the market. We left Florida just days before Hurricane Hermine. My Urologist had also retired in the meantime but his partner has done thousands of DaVinci's and so far everything has gone well. Everyone at the hospital was friendly and cheerful, and as some of the staff recognized my wife it seemed they had put me in the executive suite, so the first night was as quiet and restful as could be expected. Well that's about all I know for now. I will figure out this signature thing later. I hope everyone who lives here stateside has fun this Labor Day weekend. See you later!
Posts.Title: New here, just had DaVinci, day 2

Posts.Content: I would say you are right, but there's probably nothing that can be done, yet. His doctor cannot really do anything until a pattern is established. True, 0.2 is the threshold for BR but without a mets site to treat little can be done at this point. He probably had some adverse pathology (SVI, +SM) at the time of his prostatectomy, hence the radiation. But RT can fail. Your friend is probably looking at some form of treatment down the road... HT, maybe chemo. Not sure. This is what all of us survivors fear most!

Posts.Title: Chemohormonal Treatment, PC Stage 4 D2

Posts.Content: A couple of factors to consider, based upon my own experience... 1) A TRUS biopsy has some risks associated with it. It involves the blind, random, unguided poking of needles thru your rectum and into your prostate in the hopes that one of the needles might bump into some portion of a tumor. Only about one third of the prostate can be sampled in this way... the bottom half up to almost halfway up to the bladder. A relatively large number of initial TRUS biopsies come back negative, even though there is cancer present in the prostate. In other words, the needles totally missed any of the tumors. 2) Most insurance companies require a negative TRUS biopsy before they will authorize a MRI, which is a safe, non-invasive and relatively inexpensive procedure. Such an MRI is able to pinpoint any tumors that may exist in prostate that are large enough to differentiate from normal healthy prostate tissue. If the MRI finds any problem areas, the image can be fused with the ultrasound in order to biopsy the tumors directly. Therefore a larger number of the samples would be likely to have cancerous tissue and fewer of the samples would come back negative. Why the insurance industry insists on subjecting men to a blind biopsy which carries with it a significant risk of introducing infection into the prostate before they will allow a safe and generally effective external scan is beyond me. I have questioned this practice here in this forum and in others at length in the past. Yet the practice persists. Furthermore, you seem to be in a better position to have your case taken seriously by a urologist than I was, because your DRE is suspicious... even though your PSA is very low. On the other hand, I had a steadily rising PSA plus persistent physical symptoms that were disrupting my sleep and such. Yet my urologist allowed my cancer to grow for several years without action, because my DRE's were in his words normal and the TRUS biopsy was negative. The blind TRUS biopsy is IMO useless... even if it comes back with cancerous tissue from that one-third of the prostate, it is quite possible that it retrieved one of the lower grade tumors and other high grade tumors were missed. I don't mean to scare you, but I believe there are more men walking around with untreated prostate cancer today because of the hysteria regarded reported "overtreatment" of men with low grade cancers during a period around ten years ago. Therefore urologists are reluctant to treat PCa's until there is overwhelming evidence that the cancer is spreading... which in many cases means it is already too late. I had trusted my urologist and had been seeing him for over a decade. He took my right testicle from me years earlier, which fortunately was benign. But when it came to my prostate, his unwillingness to act allowed me to postpone more aggressive pursuit of my condition... finding other doctors or investigating other procedures, such as you are doing now. If you are able to cancel this idiotic TRUS for now and look into other LEGITIMATE treatments (not alternative treatments) then please do so. This disease is potentially far more deadly than most in the general public are even able to comprehend. And good luck to you!

Posts.Title: New here, just had DaVinci, day 2

Posts.Content: You will definitely need to find a radiological oncologist, preferably one who specialized in prostate cancer exclusively. The urologist should be able to refer you to one. Your husband's travel schedule will likely be a problem as radiation is typically administered daily over a period of many weeks in a row. The RO may recommend hormone therapy as well. Your husband's diagnosis is indeed unfortunate, particularly such an advanced case... but in the vast majority of cases this is not a death sentence. You have obviously already done a good deal of homework and are familiar with much of the terminology. The surgical report and the final pathology report after the prostate has been examined under a microscope will provide invaluable information necessary to plan his treatment. Though I am not familiar with this particular variety of PCa (signet cell), I suspect that even with his high numbers he still has a good chance of surviving his prostate cancer, though it will be a very long road. Certainly there will soon be a number of additional replies to this thread from others, perhaps some who had a similar case. Good luck to both you and your husband!

Posts.Title: Gleason 10 / robotic prostectomy 6 days ago

Posts.Content: A couple of factors to consider, based upon my own experience... 1) A TRUS biopsy has some risks associated with it. It involves the blind, random, unguided poking of needles thru your rectum and into your prostate in the hopes that one of the needles might bump into some portion of a tumor. Only about one third of the prostate can be sampled in this way... the bottom half up to almost halfway up to the bladder. A relatively large number of initial TRUS biopsies come back negative, even though there is cancer present in the prostate. In other words, the needles totally missed any of the tumors. 2) Most insurance companies require a negative TRUS biopsy before they will authorize a MRI, which is a safe, non-invasive and relatively inexpensive procedure. Such an MRI is able to pinpoint any tumors that may exist in prostate that are large enough to differentiate from normal healthy prostate tissue. If the MRI finds any problem areas, the image can be fused with the ultrasound in order to biopsy the tumors directly. Therefore a larger number of the samples would be likely to have cancerous tissue and fewer of the samples would come back negative. Why the insurance industry insists on subjecting men to a blind biopsy which carries with it a significant risk of introducing infection into the prostate before they will allow a safe and generally effective external scan is beyond me. I have questioned this practice here in this forum and in others at length in the past. Yet the practice persists. Furthermore, you seem to be in a better position to have your case taken seriously by a urologist than I was, because your DRE is suspicious... even though your PSA is very low. On the other hand, I had a steadily rising PSA plus persistent physical symptoms that were disrupting my sleep and such. Yet my urologist allowed my cancer to grow for several years without action, because my DRE's were in his words normal and the TRUS biopsy was negative. The blind TRUS biopsy is IMO useless... even if it comes back with cancerous tissue from that one-third of the prostate, it is quite possible that it retrieved one of the lower grade tumors and other high grade tumors were missed. I don't mean to scare you, but I believe there are more men walking around with untreated prostate cancer today because of the hysteria regarded reported "overtreatment" of men with low grade cancers during a period around ten years ago. Therefore urologists are reluctant to treat PCa's until there is overwhelming evidence that the cancer is spreading... which in many cases means it is already too late. I had trusted my urologist and had been seeing him for over a decade. He took my right testicle from me years earlier, which fortunately was benign. But when it came to my prostate, his unwillingness to act allowed me to postpone more aggressive pursuit of my condition... finding other doctors or investigating other procedures, such as you are doing now. If you are able to cancel this idiotic TRUS for now and look into other LEGITIMATE treatments (not alternative treatments) then please do so. This disease is potentially far more deadly than most in the general public are even able to comprehend. And good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Chemohormonal Treatment, PC Stage 4 D2

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster22 As others have posted, you should discuss these problems with the radiation doctor. I had 8 weeks of radiation, 5 days a week, and saw my radiation doctor once a week for discussion and updates. I am guessing this is standard practice... Originally Posted by rooster22 Doctor prescribed Venlafaxine ER 37.5MG capsules to lessen the hot flashes caused by Eligard/Lupron. It is actually a drug for treatment of depression. That Rx helps quite a bit. Reduces hot flashes intensity by about 50%. Same here. Eight weeks of daily RT completed one month ago. Venlafaxine reduced the frequency, intensity and duration of hot flashes by about half. I was recently prescribed Gabapentin 1800mg daily for another condition and it seems to have eliminated the remaining 50% of hot flashes. Why don't they do this on a routine basis? I had to BEG for help. BTW for the OP - I began to experience frequent diarrhea and bowel disruptions starting my second week of RT and it persisted throughout the course. RO only recommended Activia. Didn't help that much, but who am I to say? Things are "nearly" back to normal down there now, a month after the conclusion of RT. RO seemed unconcerned about the loose bowels, only stated that some disruption is to be expected. Again, why don't they tell you about this beforehand? Geez. All I can recommend is "never trust a fart". That has saved me many potentially embarrassing situation.

Posts.Title: 2 weeks into 6 week round of Radiation

Posts.Content: I'll try to tell you what I can, but understand that this is only speculation based on what you have presented here, and is not intended as any form of medical advice. The biopsy is the ONLY way to know if (!) it is cancer, and if so how bad. But the very high PSA level and the appearance of either lymph node involvement or bone involvement makes it not look good. There is a slight possibility that his cancer is still contained in the area of his pelvis, which is good for possible radiation treatment. Prostate cancer - even aggressive PCa, is very slow growing and generally chemotherapy is not the first line approach, because the prostate has very little blood supply and the chemo just isn't delivered effectively. Perhaps the chemo mentioned is actually hormone therapy... an injection and/or pills that are very commonly used for advanced PCa. If indeed it has spread to his bones, whether to his spine or pelvis, he will probably be on hormone therapy (ADT) for the rest of his life. If he is a candidate for radiation he may be on HT for a couple months beforehand to weaken the cancer, and then once the radiation is complete, then the chemotherapy (likely docetaxel) is started to deliver the final blow to the cancer. That's pretty much it as far as first line treatments are involved. There are newer forms of HT that can be administered in addition to or as follow up to first line HT, and some additional therapies for those who have not responded well to the first line. He is likely not a candidate for surgery, so if the biopsy is inconclusive there won't be much to work with. I am not telling you this from experience, but I personally came very close to going down the path of your husband. My PSA rose and my cancer progressed for four years before I changed doctors and finally was given an MRI which found my tumor... which was hidden away up under my bladder. I was staged at 3B, which is just before stage 4 which involves metastasis and lymphatic involvement. There are various "grades" of advanced prostate cancer, such as he may be "T3bN1" if it is still in his prostate bed, has invaded some lymph nodes but has not metastasized into his bones. From there it only gets worse. I don't mean to be the deliverer of doom and gloom, but you should probably be prepared for some tough times ahead. My wife and I both went thru cancer treatments over the past two years and it will require a lot of patience on your part and bravery on the part of your husband. If you have, uh, personal problems when dealing with all of this do not hesitate to write about it here. Many of us have been thru it ourselves and will help in any way we can. Of course, there is the possibility that his situation may turn out to be not so bad after all. It does happen. There are miracles and there are surprises. But do not ever, ever get duped into alternative cures. Herbs and diets have not ever been proven to cure cancer, if indeed that is what he has. There are no "short cuts". Good luck to you both!

Posts.Content: A couple months back I asked here in this forum the difference between adjuvant and salvage therapy. Today I stumbled upon the answer... Adjuvant treatment is defined as RT or HT given within 90 days after RP while salvage treatment is given post-operatively after 90 days. This according to an article on the ncbi.nlm.nih.gov website. The full article can be read here: Role of Surgery in locally advanced prostate cancer. The article targets patients who were what I will refer to as "RP candidates"... typically those whose Gleason was high enough to justify surgery but less than G9/10 whose clinical stage proscribed RP due to its potential to spread the disease. In general this would be those who were not elevated from a G6/7 by post-op pathology, and extending to those with extraprostatic extension but short of lymphatic involvement. Locally advanced prostate cancer is the one extending beyond the prostate capsule with invasion of peri-capsular tissue, apex, bladder neck or seminal vesicles but without any lymph node involvement or distant metastasis (i.e. T3-T4, N0, M0 disease). Nearly 20-25% of cases present as locally advanced disease. These patients are at increased risk of prostate specific antigen (PSA) failure, metastatic progression and cancer specific death. This definition can be interchangeably used with the high risk prostate cancer. The article is dated 2015 and is from the Pakistan Journal of Medical Science. There is a lot of good information here regarding adjuvant and salvage therapies, which would be of specific interest to those who are or might eventually be in a situation similar to my own. There is still so much that I am learning "by the seat of my pants" so to speak, but just this morning I remarked to my wife about just how extensively our vocabularies have expanded in only four months, from a time when we had never even heard of RCHOP or Lupron.

Posts.Title: Overload of info, trying to understand

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nicole8 Hi, I am writing to get some advice about my father. He is 83 and a retired dr. Nicole - I cannot answer regarding the practicality of a biopsy while on HT, but I understand as Southsider mentioned that HT affects the prostate cells and causes them to shrink. I am wondering how much of his story you know first hand or is this only what your father has told you. You may be hearing only partial facts and some fabrication to save face. Doctors tend to be very secretive and even deceptive about their own health. My father was also a physician and never told anyone in my family about his illnesses and apparently was self medicating until his death. The only thing he told us was that he did not want to die in a hospital. He did in fact pass away at home in his own bed. If I may say, what I suspect is that your father wants to leave this world gracefully. At 83 he might have another decade at most, and a decade possibly filled with pain and suffering. With a PSA of 32 there is a good chance that his prostate cancer has at least become locally advanced (stage 3) and possibly on the verge of lymphatic involvement or bone metastasis. Within the "secret society" of physicians, doctors can be brutally honest with one another, and understanding how similar cases may progress, decide to allow himself to succumb to this disease rather than survive long enough only to battle some other possibly less dignified condition. Regarding scans, if there is distant metastasis, there is a minimum size that can be detected by even the most sensitive scans. And if there are distant mets, then what? Chemo? And how much time would that buy for him? Of course you love your father, and you do not want him to go. Please forgive me for being blunt or insensitive here, but he may be telling you only a cover story to spare himself some pain and spare you and the rest of his family from enduring watching him suffer. The six month HT shot may be enough to relieve some of his own symptoms, which he may be hiding from you, and preventing the cancer from progressing further until he can prepare himself and you for his inevitable departure.

Posts.Title: Hormone therapy before biopsy

Posts.Content: Infection is indeed a serious possible side effect of TRUS biopsies. I think it happens to one in twenty patients. But your PSA is above 10, which is the level where you should be concerned. It would probably be a good idea to get an MRI if possible to see if there are any abnormalities in your prostate. Waiting for your PSA to double would not be wise, but if you have it checked again in a few weeks it may have not risen any further or perhaps only slightly. I was hesitant to go for a second "blind" biopsy after my experience with the first one. My GP requested an MRI and I was fortunate that it found my tumor. My experience has also been that DRE's are unreliable in detecting PCa.

Posts.Title: Should I have another biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rmotacek1 Add to all of this the medical bills and depression that I have been experiencing lately and anxiety every time I get ready for another PSA check. Just never thought I would be dealing with this kind of stuff at the age of 52. I knew all of these risks were part of the deal, but it still sucks. Sorry for venting. Vent on! And thanks for chiming in. Misery loves company. It is indeed sad to see young guys like yourself struck down in their prime by this old man's disease. Depression and anxiety seem to go hand in hand with PCa. I'm working up the courage to ask my PCP for some "help", after my RO (who was the one who put me on lupron, making matters even worse) then only seemed to pull away the life preserver. As much as I love to hear the occasional "fairy tale" PCa story, where a fellow gets routine bloodwork as part of an annual physical and his PSA is "elevated", then a DRE confirms something suspicious. Finally the initial biopsy somehow manages to identify the tumor on the first try, and it is treated by RP or RT and everyone lives happily ever after. Such stories are truly refreshing. But I need to hear the blood and guts stories now and then, so I don't feel so lonely. When I need cheering up I read a few posts by the stage 4 guys. We don't hear from you very often, rmotacek. Don't be a stranger.
Posts.Title: Were your PCa treatment results what you expected?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Fortunate that my PCP observed a 50% rise in PSA in 2 years following an annual physical exam. ... He excised fairly large additional segments of tissue(s) in the region of a (+) margin on the left side. I'm confident that this additional step has spared me from SR - so far. - Fortunate that Dr Tully repositions the bladder and tacks it to the pelvic floor with a "male Burch stitch" which somehow results in better continence. Overall, I've been most fortunate and have fared extremely well! Good to hear! You are the poster boy for "doing things right". Thanks for your reply!
Posts.Title: Were your PCa treatment results what you expected?

Posts.Content: I'm just throwing this out there, but you may actually have another condition, and possibly cancer, which is NOT prostate cancer. My wife had severe back, neck and hip pains and it was only discovered by an MRI that there is a tumor on her spine. Further scans revealed tumors in her pelvis and skull. Her diagnosis of lymphoma could only be confirmed by taking a biopsy from one of the tumors and several days of lab analysis. I don't mean to scare you, but there are so many things that could cause the symptoms you've described that nothing can truly be ruled out without extensive testing, which often means one or more biopsies (I get biopsies for another condition every two years. just to determine that it has not progressed). If your pain is severe enough to affect your quality of life, do not give up until you have discovered the cause. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Aches and Pains and Prostates

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 ... the last thing I want to do is come across as complaining or whining... Oh, come on John. Everyone here knows you never complain about anything... honest! If there truly is a silver lining here at cancer forums, it has to be you. This disease has forever changed my life. Honestly, it's been quite depressing. And here all this time I thought that I was the only one! I wish I would have never had the surgery. I would have been much better off with RT and ADT... It has been a unmitigated disaster. I'm not knowledgeable on RT, but it seems to me to be a shotgun approach. Just irradiate everything and hope to fry the tumor. Plus there's no post-op dissection. I see it as little more than educated guesswork. Then of course, there are no do-overs. And when guys come back years later with rising PSA's after RT, what is there left to do? No, I never second guess the RP decision. There's a lot of things I would do differently, but given that my (our) PCa was already growing by leaps and bounds, it was either cut it out or "watchfully wait" until it spread to the bones. Besides, once it's done, it's done. Can't go back and change it anyway. Maybe just use what we have learned to give guidance to others who come after us who may be in a similar situation.

Posts.Title: Were your PCa treatment results what you expected?

Posts.Content: It was just about one year ago that the ball got rolling on my PCa treatment (see my sig) and now one year later the results are in. All of us... you, me, and the other guy - all made decisions and choices based on possible risks and likely outcomes. Whether or not we may have actually realized it throughout that process, short of any outright disaster, we all faced three possible "likely" risks: 1) didn't get all the cancer ("salvage"), 2) partial or permanent incontinence, and 3) diminished sexual ability (ED or impotence). Little did I suspect that I'd end up with all three. Show of hands, if you care to answer, how did you fare?

Posts.Content: A different treatment for BPH ... Yesterday in the waiting room at my Uro's office there was an information video playing on their TV screen showing an animation of a non-invasive surgical treatment for enlarged prostate that basically involved putting two pairs of "clips" thru the prostate on either side of the urethra. I don't recall the name, but these clips look like those annoying little plastic T's that hold the price tag on you new clothes. The T's squeeze the walls of the prostate together, thereby widening the opening for the urethra.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 ... the last thing I want to do is come across as complaining or whining... Oh, come on John. Everyone here knows you never complain about anything... honest! If there truly is a silver lining here at cancer forums, it has to be you. This disease has forever changed my life. Honestly, it's been quite depressing. And here all this time I thought that I was the only one! I wish I would have never had the surgery. I would have been much better off with RT and ADT... It has been a unmitigated disaster. I'm not knowledgeable on RT, but it seems to me to be a shotgun approach. Just irradiate everything and hope to fry the tumor. Plus there's no post-op dissection. I see it as little more than educated guesswork. Then of course, there are no do-overs. And when guys come back years later with rising PSA's after RT, what is there left to do? No, I never second guess the RP decision. There's a lot of things I would do differently, but given that my (our) PCa was already growing by leaps and bounds, it was either cut it out or "watchfully wait" until it spread to the bones. Besides, once it's done, it's done. Can't go back and change it anyway. Maybe just use what we have learned to give guidance to others who come after us who may be in a similar situation.
Posts.Title: Were your PCa treatment results what you expected?

Posts.Content: It was just about one year ago that the ball got rolling on my PCa treatment (see my sig) and now one year later the results are in. Whether or not we may have actually realized it throughout that process, short of any outright disaster, we all faced three possible "likely" risks: 1) didn't get all the cancer ("salvage"), 2) partial or permanent incontinence, and 3) diminished sexual ability (ED or impotence). Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rmotacek1 Add to all of this the medical bills and depression that I have been experiencing lately and anxiety every time I get ready for another PSA check. Just never thought I would be dealing with this kind of stuff at the age of 52. I knew all of these risks were part of the deal, but it still sucks. Sorry for venting. Vent on! And thanks for chiming in. Misery loves company. It is indeed sad to see young guys like yourself struck down in their prime by this old man's disease. Depression and anxiety seem to go hand in hand with PCa. I'm working up the courage to ask my PCP for some "help", after my RO (who was the one who put me on lupron, making matters even worse) then only seemed to pull away the life preserver. As much as I love to hear the occasional "fairy tale" PCa story, where a fellow gets routine bloodwork as part of an annual physical and his PSA is "elevated", then a DRE confirms something suspicious. Finally the initial biopsy somehow manages to identify the tumor on the first try, and it is treated by RP or RT and everyone lives happily ever after. Such stories are truly refreshing. But I need to hear the blood and guts stories now and then, so I don't feel so lonely. When I need cheering up I read a few posts by the stage 4 guys. We don't hear from you very often, rmotacek. Don't be a stranger.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another There are other forms of arthirtitis that cause pain, psoriatic arthiritis is one. Sometimes the joint problems begin before the skin lessions or the lesions are mild and diagnosised as eczema or dry skin such as cracked heels. Psoriatic arthritis typically begins at a much, much younger age.

Posts.Content: I'm just throwing this out there, but you may actually have another condition, and possibly cancer, which is NOT prostate cancer. My wife had severe back, neck and hip pains and it was only discovered by an MRI that there is a tumor on her spine. Further scans revealed tumors in her pelvis and skull. Her diagnosis of lymphoma could only be confirmed by taking a biopsy from one of the tumors and several days of lab analysis. I don't mean to scare you, but there are so many things that could cause the symptoms you've described that nothing can truly be ruled out without extensive testing, which often means one or more biopsies (I get biopsies for another condition every two years. just to determine that it has not progressed). If your pain is severe enough to affect your quality of life, do not give up until you have discovered the cause. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi You just can't catch a break. What is your next step? Thanks Gary... still just putting one foot in front of the other. July we are back to our "Cancer Couple" grind. Lori sees her eye doctor (she'd had emergency surgery immediately after her discharge last December) and then her Hemo-Oncologist for a three month blood workup. I'm having a colonoscopy two years early, as radiation will change the texture of any abdominal tissues... so getting that out of the way now. Then I get my next six month Lupron shot, and the artificial sphincter will be activated - "turned on". The tissues surrounding the implant must be fully healed before the device is allowed to operate. Then I see my RO near the end of July to setup our radiation schedule. He goes on vacation in early August, so we are taking a week at the beach Aug 6-12 before starting SRT the following week, assuming the AUS functions properly in the interim. Hopefully RT will all be done by mid October, then Lori is due for her next CT scan. The Lupron will stay with me thru the end of this year. I need to ask the RO if he will want me to continue on it into and throughout next year as well. Then the "big wait" to see where the PSA stabilizes (hopefully). PS - as I was typing this the doorbell rang. It was UPS delivering the case of diapers. BTW good luck with your RALP this month. When is the big day?
Posts.Title: Slipping back into total incontinence

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pat m At my yearly physical my psa went from 2 to 13. I had a biopsy 3 weeks ago showing 2out of 16 with a Gleason 4+5 =9 Bone and CT negative. My doctor is great but seems to think there'll be more treatment after surgery. I asked about an MRI but it'll put treatment off for a couple of months. Appreciate any advice. Pat- You appear to have a high risk case IMO. G9 is serious (though yours is better than 5+4 would be). An MRI would help identify the location and nature of the tumor, but your biopsy has already done that. Note that you will be required to wait another month (about) before your surgery. Typically Uro's like 6-8 weeks healing between BX and RP. Don't delay any longer than is necessary. Your G9 and PSA >10 could indicate extraprostatic extension is already present (cannot be confirmed until after surgery) which would call for post surgical radiation and possibly hormone therapy. I'd say you caught this just in time.

Posts.Title: Prostate surgery??

Posts.Content: I just noticed this thread this morning. Guess I must have been busy that day. My choice of surgery was primarily made due to my particular set of circumstances. We were selling our Ohio home and had for the most part already moved to Florida. Contracts had been signed. Winter was coming. In the end I had surgery plus two months of radiation (and HT to boot). How does that fit into the FB groups? Sorry, I only keep a FB account so a few people can contact me, nothing more. It's cute but it all seems to be a waste of time and terribly complicated for someone who already has Lupron brain. I suppose the one thing that "gets me" most is that in radiation groups, people refer to HT plus two types of radiation as the triple play. I guess those of us who have had a "true" triple play are stuck with the term trifecta. Another is the guys who proclaim that it's time to make a decision, or a choice... and what they're deciding is which form of radiation. Granted, I realize that for some guys, surgery is already out due to age or health. It's sort of like "your choice of desserts" really means what kind of pie do you want. In a way I am a bit envious of the guys who actually had the luxury of time to make a leisurely choice between a variety of options... even "maybe I'll get treated, and maybe I won't". We are all of us in different situations and there are a variety of external as well as internal factors that influence our decisions. I've worked directly with a number of CEO's and COO, and they have the gift of making quick decisions and just going with them. I think the choices over which I agonized the most were those where I had months to consider what to do, and still ended up later recognizing that I could have done something differently. But isn't that just life?

Posts.Title: Sweating bullets

Posts.Content: I used saw palmetto for many years, and my urologist urged me to continue using it. It did seem to improve my flow, reduce urgency and reduce irritation. I didn't notice any change in libido. Actually SP is a weak estrogen and if anything should cause you to put on a little weight. For a while I used the whole herb form, but eventually moved on to the extract combined with Pygeum extract. Now that I no longer have a prostate I of course stopped taking all that, and now take vitamins that include iron and also stopped all zinc and flax supplements. Swanson sells an excellent combo SP/Pygeum gelcap that worked well for many years. That Uro who recommended the SP ended up doing me no favors. Who knows how long I actually had prostate cancer.

Swanson sells an excellent combo SP/Pygeum gelcap that worked well for many years. That Uro who recommended the SP ended up doing me no favors. Who knows how long I actually had prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: The waiting game - or is there something I can do?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pat m At my yearly physical my psa went from 2 to 13. I had a biopsy 3 weeks ago showing 2out of 16 with a Gleason 4+5 =9 Bone and CT negative. My doctor is great but seems to think there'll be more treatment after surgery. I asked about an MRI but it'll put treatment off for a couple of months. Appreciate any advice. Pat- You appear to have a high risk case IMO. G9 is serious (though yours is better than 5+4 would be). An MRI would help identify the location and nature of the tumor, but your biopsy has already done that. Note that you will be required to wait another month (about) before your surgery. Typically Uro's like 6-8 weeks healing between BX and RP. Don't delay any longer than is necessary. Your G9 and PSA >10 could indicate extraprostatic extension is already present (cannot be confirmed until after surgery) which would call for post surgical radiation and possibly hormone therapy. I'd say you caught this just in time.

Posts.Title: Prostate surgery??

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 ... the last thing I want to do is come across as complaining or whining... Oh, come on John. Everyone here knows you never complain about anything... honest! If there truly is a silver lining here at cancer forums, it has to be you. This disease has forever changed my life. Honestly, it's been quite depressing. And here all this time I thought that I was the only one! I wish I would have never had the surgery. I would have been much better off with RT and ADT... It has been a unmitigated disaster. I'm not knowledgeable on RT, but it seems to me to be a shotgun approach. Just irradiate everything and hope to fry the tumor. Plus there's no post-op dissection. I see it as little more than educated guesswork. Then of course, there are no do-overs. And when guys come back years later with rising PSA's after RT, what is there left to do? No, I never second guess the RP decision. There's a lot of things I would do differently, but given that my (our) PCa was already growing by leaps and bounds, it was either cut it out or "watchfully wait" until it spread to the bones. Besides, once it's done, it's done. Can't go back and change it anyway. Maybe just use what we have learned to give guidance to others who come after us who may be in a similar situation.

Posts.Title: Prostate surgery??

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F What are your thoughts about heading up to Tampa to Moffitt Cancer Center? It is an NCI Designated Cancer Center. You will have the option of being in their expert care ... I spent a week at Moffitt last month (not inpatient, but was there every day) and it is a well run operation. Everyone was very friendly and efficient from the start, willing to listen and informed me what was going on. Ultimately the tests provided no new information other than confirming that whatever it is growing in me it has to come out. When I asked if there would be any advantage to having the surgery there, the doctor said that if I have a surgeon whom I trust that I should have it done locally (which I am, next Monday). If I had this to do all over again, I'm not sure I would start there, but would at least have them involved, as I did this time. Given that it is less than an hour away from us it was worth the drive... but we did stay in a nearby motel for a couple of nights, for our convenience and to avoid morning rush hour traffic for those NPO early morning tests. Good luck to you Gene!

Posts.Title: starting to feel the burn

Posts.Content: My two cents, I think that you do have reason to be concerned... but it is unlikely that anything could be done now, at this point. Your PSA is definitely rising. If this continues, it will eventually cross some arbitrary tipping point. For me, it was PSA=4. My GP sent me to see a Uro after my PSA went from 2 - 2.5 - 3 - 3.5 and eventually 4.0 over a number of years... and I do mean years, like between from 50 to 60. My Uro, whom I had been seeing for prostate infections and such for probably 20 years, said he is not alarmed by rising PSA, but by any sudden spike in PSA. He did a digital (which as much as it is the brunt of many jokes, isn't really all that bad if your Dr is gentle). All was normal. Fast forward one year later, my PSA jumped to 9.5 ... I was put on Cipro but it kept rising. Then I underwent the biopsy. It was negative. When asked what do we do next, my Uro said another biopsy. Now, the problem with a series of negative tests is that it leads one to believe that there is nothing wrong. But I kept experiencing what lets call "symptoms". I was not anxious to undergo another biopsy. Other issues/life problems took priority and that second biopsy got put off until two years later, when it was discovered that yes it is cancer and it has spread. I guess my point is, whatever happens, don't be mislead into believing that your rising PSA means nothing. If it continues to rise, and your Dr seems to dismiss it, get someone else involved. Be concerned. Be aggressive. BTW I agree with the remark by forum brother 'Another' that a younger urologist will have the advantage of still being alive when you will probably need him the most.

Posts.Title: New beginnings in prostate awareness

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DanATX Just feeling thankful that I moved quickly to surgery. Doc said with the grade 5 hidden in there, waiting would have been, in retrospect, not as positive an approach. Said the tumor was much more advanced and aggressive looking than the pre-surgical numbers/biopsy would have suggested. Might have taken multiple biopsies to catch the aggressive stuff due in part to the long, skinny shape it had. We all like to have our decisions validated, so I'm taking that as a big positive for me. Congrats on pulling thru the surgery and getting past that BP problem. I chose RP over radiation for expediency (we were right in the middle of moving 1000 miles away) but the results afterwards reassured me that it was the right decision. Like you, my tumor was somewhat "hidden" and what appeared on the MRI to be close to the capsule turned out to be thru the wall and into the nerves and vesicles. Also a couple of lesser cores were elevated to true G8. A couple doctors since have reassured me that RP was the right decision. Of course, every case is different, and given a different set of circumstances, the choice may have been different. I hope your recovery goes well and you are spared any further surprises.

Posts.Title: Hello from the Other Side (of Surgery)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sabertex36 LVI is positive. LVI is indeed serious, so is bladder neck invasion. Maybe MM will chime in here on LVI. Waiting six months post-op for healing is customary. My PSA was tested by uPSA every five weeks during that period. Adjuvant RT was recommended as soon as my path report came in, and my RO started ADT after four months. By seven months post-op I was faced with the decision whether or not to get an artificial sphincter implant - two more surgeries which required additional healing - so that I could proceed with radiation. Before RT my PSA rose from a tiny <.02 to .03 (no "<"). Small as that may seem, it was enough to indicate a rise and therefore the presence of residual prostate cells. With .03 being the "new" cutoff for BCR, I am glad the HT was started before the rise was confirmed. My point being that you want to hit the cancer with everything you can as early as you can. You won't get a chance to go back for a do-over. Many of us who end up in a forum such as this do so because we did not end up being the fortunate ones who got it all the first time. We tend to be the more complicated cases... those who did not get the lucky breaks or for whom things didn't go quite as well as might have been expected. Good luck going forward!

Posts.Title: Final path - Next steps?

Posts.Content: Well the vacation is almost over. Following the first implant surgery I couldn't pee for two weeks. I had a Foley the whole time, which made it difficult to sleep (most of us have been there). Then one week ago I had emergency surgery to revise the AUS. Following that surgery I was surprised to find that my diaper was usually dry. I had lost some bladder capacity during the two weeks with the Foley, but at least I could feel the urge and could hold it long enough to make it to the bathroom. Usually the inside of my diaper was maybe just a little moist from perspiration, or sometimes a little discoloration up front. I mentioned this to the urologist and he said this newfound continence was probably just due to swelling from the surgery. I said let me enjoy it while I can. Then a couple nights ago I noticed I dripped a few times after getting out of the shower. Starting today my pad is routinely soaked, so I ordered another case of diapers. Soon the swelling will have subsided enough that I will be able to back to the condom caths and leg bag. Well, it was fun while it lasted.

Posts.Title: Slipping back into total incontinence

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman I don't understand, though, isn't it expected that you'll be incontinent until the sling is activated? Yes. The AUS implant surgery must be fully healed before the device is turned on.** Until that time, I will remain incontinent. I had a brief period this past week of "fake" continence because swelling from the surgery was squeezing my urethra, making it difficult to urinate. BTW the Sling and AUS are different devices, though both are made by the same company. The Sling is a mesh cradle for the bladder that relieves pressure from the natural sphincter. The AUS is actually a tiny hydraulic system with a pump, fluid reservoir and expandable cuff. ** I think I posted on that other message board under "AUS saga continues" that the day of the initial implant surgery, when I was unable to urinate, the surgeon had to manipulate my swollen scrotum while I was awake to check that the device had not been accidentally activated. That was an "8" on the pain scale!

Posts.Title: New beginnings in prostate awareness

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum Shanis and it is good to see that you have agreed to throw everything possible at your cancer. I've heard that early docetaxel is far more effective as opposed to reserving it as a last resort, which used to be the norm. And congratulations on your rapid decline in PSA. But most likely it is not yet due solely to the Lupron. Stats I've seen indicate that it takes four weeks for the Lupron depot to reduce testosterone to the <50 level required for maximum effectiveness. Starting you on Casodex in advance was also a wise move. Has spot radiation been mentioned for your mets and nodes? To facilitate other responses here you may want to complete your "signature" page as outlined in one of the sticky posts at the top of the forum page. Basically you go into "settings" at the top of your screen and click on "signature" on the left. Then simply enter your dates and values regarding your diagnosis and treatment so far. And good luck to you going forward!

Posts.Title: PSA 268 / Gleason 8 / Bone Mets

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DanATX Just feeling thankful that I moved quickly to surgery. Doc said with the grade 5 hidden in there, waiting would have been, in retrospect, not as positive an approach. Said the tumor was much more advanced and aggressive looking than the pre-surgical numbers/biopsy would have suggested. Might have taken multiple biopsies to catch the aggressive stuff due in part to the long, skinny shape it had. We all like to have our decisions validated, so I'm taking that as a big positive for me. Congrats on pulling thru the surgery and getting past that BP problem. I chose RP over radiation for expediency (we were right in the middle of moving 1000 miles away) but the results afterwards reassured me that it was the right decision. Like you, my tumor was somewhat "hidden" and what appeared on the MRI to be close to the capsule turned out to be thru the wall and into the nerves and vesicles. Also a couple of lesser cores were elevated to true G8. A couple doctors since have reassured me that RP was the right decision. Of course, every case is different, and given a different set of circumstances, the choice may have been different. I hope your recovery goes well and you are spared any further surprises.

Posts.Title: Statlock Catheter Stabilization Device Foley 2 -way

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I never understood the overtreatment mantra. I think it is linked to the other myth you will die of something else before you die of PC. As life expectancy increases and the cancer expands to more and younger men and more aggressive forms public perception will change. I think social stigma also plays a role. Men are reluctant to accept the responsibility for the disease, will not discuss it, and practice denial and delay which feeds complaint and bitterness over the natural outcome of delayed detection and treatment. The denial and delay syndrome is driven by men themselves not stepping up and taking responsibility for their health. It's easy to "blame the victim. My treatment was delayed because my urologist downplayed the significance of my steadily rising PSA, and seemed to be unaware of my family history. Yes, he told me that my PSA was high, but my GP has always told me that my LDL and triglycerides are high. Neither of these last two have tried to kill me, yet. My urologist never even mentioned the word cancer. How was I to know? I expected him to be the expert on the subject. When I went along with the biopsy... no minor procedure... he only told me that it was negative. He just gave me more and more antibiotics. It is hard for me to not feel resentful of the way I was treated... or more precisely, NOT treated. And it makes my blood boil every time I read someone talking about "overtreatment". Yes, I understand what happened, to SOME men. But that's no reason to throw out the baby with the bathwater. It wasn't until I changed doctors and asked my Uro several very pointed questions that he dropped me like a hot potato. I only wish it had happened two years earlier. The "lucky" men who received treatment when their cancer was only a G6 or G7 should consider themselves very fortunate. The alternative could have been to end up with an artificial sphincter and pelvic radiation disease, all because some gov't panel scared a doctor into downplaying PSA screening. Yes, it is so much easier to simply blame the patient for trusting his doctor.

Posts.Title: Maybe nothing but its of concern to me and Uro PSA inching

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F There is little doubt that you will need to take interventional action at some point in time. You will need to decide the "When" & "What." The questions to consider is: "Will this violate the capsule and when?" & "What happens if the capsule is violated?" Probably more a matter of when rather than if. Granted, 7 is borderline intervention stage, but my experience is the Gleason tends to be elevated with time rather than lowered. If there is a tumor it will spread. The question is, when is a good time to stop it in its tracks? It won't get better on its own.

Posts.Title: 2nd Opinion - thoughts on AS

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate We all have different experiences, RobLee, and mine does not align with yours... It's worth taking the time to make sure he won't regret his choice for the rest of his life. I was merely seconding points made by Michael, that most likely, something will eventually need to be done someday. Winter is still a young man... some 22 years younger than you, so granted he certainly has time to pursue other options. In my case however, an "aggressive, high grade" tumor appeared suddenly and over a period of less than four years went from undetectable to the point where it had begun to spread. But I was also told by my doctor that if I were five years older, I would have had fewer options. So sometimes the window may not be as wide as we might like it to be. You are two months younger than my late older brother. He's been gone six years now.

Posts.Title: 2nd Opinion - thoughts on AS

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by redbelly7 I will be meeting w/ radiology on the 30th and will probably start radiation mid Sept. Right now, I am incontinent. I can hold some, but if I walk, bend, etc, I leak. The Dr gave me a foam clamp to wear during radiation, so I can keep something in my bladder to protect it. I am planning to start PT for kegels soon. Since I've already had a RP, is there anything that I can do to protect my colon and rectum? What should I be looking for during the process? I'm planning on having radiation and go back to work. Uh, this is something your RO should be doing for you! I started RT a week ago (for SVI) and have jumped thru all kinds of hoops since January getting ready for this. Two of the most common methods to minimize bowel and bladder toxicity are a rectal balloon and a requirement to hold a full bladder. I asked my RO twice about the balloon and he says half of RO's use it, and half do not. He does not. But he does require that patients be able to hold a full quart of water (32 oz) while under the zapper. Also be aware that what little continence you may have now will likely be diminished after RT. I've heard this from several guys. They had decent continence going into RT but came out with little remaining. In my case, it required an AUS implant, which ideally should be implanted before radiation begins. Like many other surgical procedures, it becomes more complicated when performed on irradiated tissues. I would suggest that you ask your RO about these topics, and I suspect that other bro's here would say the same. Good luck, especially with that clamp. I tried it, didn't work for me.
