Posts.Title: Radiation starting soon, what is best way to protect other parts

Posts.Content: Mike - Your T3B/SVI automatically qualifies your for ART. I had 70Gy IMRT using the Varian RapidArc like Chester, but as MF points out, your PSA is essentially undetectable. However, your primary grade 4 component of your G7 plus the bladder neck involvement tips the scale back toward ART. The fact that you seem to be fully continent is another green flag. I'd say talk with a RO who is not promoting Proton. PB is a high priced option that I believe is aimed at intermediate risk patients. It is more accurate at delivering targeted primary radiation to known tumors. You should probably have your entire prostate bed flooded with radiation to wipe out any escaped cancer cells in the area of the SV and bladder neck before they take advantage of the opportunity for systemic spread. It's a bit of a crap shoot. I think the stats show it's 50/50 whether you would ever have BCR without having ART. But it is my belief to zap everything while it's still localized. There are some drawbacks to getting radiation, but if there's a chance you might need it later on, you'd be better of getting it now. Good luck, and best regards to your lovely wife.

Posts.Title: Radiation Opinions Sought and Be Your Own Advocate

Posts.Content: Surgery was Monday. It was a terrible day. We arrived at 10AM for a procedure that was supposed to take less than an hour. Around noon we were told the surgeon would be delayed about an hour, so I sent my wife home. I remember they finally wheeled me into the OR at 2PM. Next thing I remember was being wheeled into a room where my wife was waiting at 6PM. The day finally ended after 8PM with the Dr inserting a Foley cath. What happened in the meantime? I suspect that I was "out" much longer than expected. I do remember someone telling me "you don't remember because of the drugs we gave you". Well if such drugs exist then I want some NOW because my head keeps going back to that day. Today I had my first followup. The Foley was out briefly, then went back in for another week. I'm still pretty beat up but am gradually returning to normal. I have to keep reminding myself that I am doing this not to be pad free but so I can start radiation before the cancer spreads any further. Looking forward to rejoining the group here...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by chiguy I can't seem to be able to edit my signature to include them or my current PSA. There is a limit to the length of sigs here, and on most boards. I keep bumping into it myself. The settings screen flashes a message about 1000 characters, but I don't believe my sig is longer than that. I've had to remove a lot of bold highlighting and eliminate some duplicate stats to fit in the important new developments. It looks like you use a lot of bolding as well as duplication of terminology such as %free PSAD and spelling out months. With a few tricks you should be able to fit it what need to convey here. It's curious, I see some sigs here that take up a full page. I wonder how they got around the character limit.

Posts.Title: AUS is in

Posts.Content: I do know of the Duet catheter. It has an upper balloon to prevent the tip from poking the top of the bladder. It is new, so I suspect that crusty old doctors who are set in their ways may have never run across it. On the other hand, as there are two balloons, I suspect that it may also fill more space inside the bladder and possibly produce even MORE of the sensation that you are now experiencing... that you have to pee. I had one in for two weeks recently and that sensation was quite bothersome. Removal of the Foley is a bit more complicated than you thought. DO NOT pull it out, or you can do some damage. Removal required a 10ml syringe to extract the saline solution that fills the balloon. Once drained, it is fairly easy and quite painless to pull out... it even tickles a little. In some countries with socialized medicine patients are expected to remove their own. In the US it is generally done by a medical professional, typically a nurse.

Posts.Title: New AAJC 8th Edition

Posts.Content: I've heard everything from six months to three years. My RO said it is important to be on HT before and after RT. Initially that was supposed to be just six months, then my SRT was postponed by five months. The Uro who did my RP said it would be three years. When I asked about two he said two or three years is typical. (As a movie buff this reminded me of Mr & Mrs Smith). Then my RO most recently said just one year. Since my SRT starts next month, then that satisfies the before and after requirement. I know that the guys with stage 4 and metastatic PCa are typically on it for three years and even longer, but it typically becomes ineffective after several years... which leads to the intermittent HT protocol (xx months on, xx months off).

Posts.Title: How long should I be on ADT (hormone therapy)?

Posts.Content: Flying all over the country and staying in motels was nothing that I could ever afford. My GP had been monitoring my PSA and recommended consulting a urologist when it hit 4. My mistake was trusting the wrong doctor. My urologist only told me three things between 2012 and when I was finally diagnosed in 2016 after he retired: 1) your PSA is nothing to be concerned about, 2) your biopsy was negative, and 3) your prostate is normal. I am certain that if he had ever mentioned the word "cancer" then I might have been motivated to look further. Now, today, when a doctor tells me that I might have cancer, I make sure to get additional testing. Lesson learned from my urology experience. Had I been a wealthy person it might have been a fun getaway to maybe drive up to Cleveland Clinic for a second opinion. After all, I drove to Cedar Point in Sandusky many times. But making the four hour drive up there just to see if there might be a doctor there who could tell me something different from what my local Uro told me was not a priority. Never even occurred to me.

Posts.Title: Does your economic status influence your treatment choice..

Posts.Content: Hopefully not striking additional fear into you, but my wife had worsening pain in her back and pelvis for nearly a year and it was dismissed by the doctors. Eventually we paid $700 cash for an MRI and she was finally diagnosed with lymphoma. Not sure if that's any better than prostate cancer, but she was treated and is in remission. We were told that the form she had is very rare.

Posts.Title: Age 26

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Currently, at least one TRUS biopsy is in most men's future before an insurance company will provide a MRI guided biopsy. TRUS biopsy is 50% false negative so it may not be definitive... My prognosis is good, and could have been better with a more aggressive and persistent diagnostic phase. This disease will most likely catch up to most men. Stay ahead of it as long as you can. The first happened to me, and I wish the latter had been the case. I lost another full year between biopsies due to other life issues; during that time the cancer began to spread, and now requires more extensive treatment. This is very good advice, to stay on top of it.

Posts.Title: Options aside from a biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I never understood the overtreatment mantra. I think it is linked to the other myth you will die of something else before you die of PC. As life expectancy increases and the cancer expands to more and younger men and more aggressive forms public perception will change. I think social stigma also plays a role. Men are reluctant to accept the responsibility for the disease, will not discuss it, and practice denial and delay which feeds complaint and bitterness over the natural outcome of delayed detection and treatment. The denial and delay syndrome is driven by men themselves not stepping up and taking responsibility for their health. It's easy to "blame the victim. My treatment was delayed because my urologist downplayed the significance of my steadily rising PSA, and seemed to be unaware of my family history. Yes, he told me that my PSA was high, but my GP has always told me that my LDL and triglycerides are high. Neither of these last two have tried to kill me, yet. My urologist never even mentioned the word cancer. How was I to know? I expected him to be the expert on the subject. When I went along with the biopsy... no minor procedure... he only told me that it was negative. He just gave me more and more antibiotics. It is hard for me to not feel resentful of the way I was treated... or more precisely, NOT treated. And it makes my blood boil every time I read someone talking about "overtreatment". Yes, I understand what happened, to SOME men. But that's no reason to throw out the baby with the bathwater. It wasn't until I changed doctors and asked my Uro several very pointed questions that he dropped me like a hot potato. I only wish it had happened two years earlier. The "lucky" men who received treatment when their cancer was only a G6 or G7 should consider themselves very fortunate. The alternative could have been to end up with an artificial sphincter and pelvic radiation disease, all because some gov't panel scared a doctor into downplaying PSA screening. Yes, it is so much easier to simply blame the patient for trusting his doctor.

Posts.Title: USPSTF Backtracks, Now Says PSA Test Is 'Individual Decision'

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F There is little doubt that you will need to take interventional action at some point in time. You will need to decide the "When" & "What." The questions to consider is: "Will this violate the capsule and when?" & "What happens if the capsule is violated?" Probably more a matter of when rather than if. Granted, 7 is borderline intervention stage, but my experience is the Gleason tends to be elevated with time rather than lowered. If there is a tumor it will spread. The question is, when is a good time to stop it in its tracks? It won't get better on its own.

Posts.Title: 2nd Opinion - thoughts on AS

Posts.Content: Mike - Your T3B/SVI automatically qualifies your for ART. I had 70Gy IMRT using the Varian RapidArc like Chester, but as MF points out, your PSA is essentially undetectable. However, your primary grade 4 component of your G7 plus the bladder neck involvement tips the scale back toward ART. The fact that you seem to be fully continent is another green flag. I'd say talk with a RO who is not promoting Proton. PB is a high priced option that I believe is aimed at intermediate risk patients. It is more accurate at delivering targeted primary radiation to known tumors. You should probably have your entire prostate bed flooded with radiation to wipe out any escaped cancer cells in the area of the SV and bladder neck before they take advantage of the opportunity for systemic spread. It's a bit of a crap shoot. I think the stats show it's 50/50 whether you would ever have BCR without having ART. But it is my belief to zap everything while it's still localized. There are some drawbacks to getting radiation, but if there's a chance you might need it later on, you'd be better of getting it now. Good luck, and best regards to your lovely wife.

Posts.Title: Gone backwards last 2 days

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by redbelly7 I will be meeting w/ radiology on the 30th and will probably start radiation mid Sept. Right now, I am incontinent. I can hold some, but if I walk, bend, etc, I leak. The Dr gave me a foam clamp to wear during radiation, so I can keep something in my bladder to protect it. I am planning to start PT for kegels soon. Since I've already had a RP, is there anything that I can do to protect my colon and rectum? What should I be looking for during the process? I'm planning on having radiation and go back to work. Uh, this is something your RO should be doing for you! I started RT a week ago (for SVI) and have jumped thru all kinds of hoops since January getting ready for this. Two of the most common methods to minimize bowel and bladder toxicity are a rectal balloon and a requirement to hold a full bladder. I asked my RO twice about the balloon and he says half of RO's use it, and half do not. He does not. But he does require that patients be able to hold a full quart of water (32 oz) while under the zapper. Also be aware that what little continence you may have now will likely be diminished after RT. I've heard this from several guys. They had decent continence going into RT but came out with little remaining. In my case, it required an AUS implant, which ideally should be implanted before radiation begins. Like many other surgical procedures, it becomes more complicated when performed on irradiated tissues. I would suggest that you ask your RO about these topics, and I suspect that other bro's here would say the same. Good luck, especially with that clamp. I tried it, didn't work for me.

Posts.Title: Radiation starting soon, what is best way to protect other parts

Posts.Content: Welcome, Jim! JJ, Rich and I are the PC "three Caballeros"... we always seem to be posting together, as all three of us just had DaVinci surgery in the past few weeks and are recently liberated from the cath... currently day four cathless for me, and going thru an awful lot of pads - probably ten a day. I haven't experienced split stream since the surgery, but knew it well over the previous years of prostate infections. In my case, my concern is that the full length of my urethra is still sore and the tip of the penis tender from the catheter. I have good control most of the time but experience frequent "squirts" throughout the day... bending over, getting up from a chair or passing gas are most common. I am going to say that most likely - unless a doctor or nurse says it is unusual - that all these things we experience are probably normal and will pass eventually.

Posts.Title: March 4th in SW Florida - Conference for Patients

Posts.Content: You may wish to read THIS THREAD from late last year. Lots of guys contributed to it. Personally I never had much luck with the clamp, or with pads for that matter. They didn't hold enough and my shaft had the tendency to flop off to one side or the other and miss the pad altogether. I came to rely primarily on external catheters and have written extensively on several different forums on the subject. My favorite, most comfortable and most reliable was the Freedom silicone with aloe, about $1.25 ea on Az, leg bag by Rusch about $2 ea also from Az. I would try to go a day or two each week w/o the CC and would use Prevail belted shields, which are also sold at CVS as their own brand. I think we discussed this in an earlier thread, so maybe you tried these and they did not work for you. Different strokes, as they say. Several ppl had suggested to me to place a pad inside a Depends brief, with only a small portion of the adhesive exposed. That way you can change the pad without changing the brief. I found it all to be way too bulky... but then I am slender and wear snug fitting trousers, so it definitely looked like I was wearing a diaper. Today I wear only a Tena moderate absorbent pad, the "3 drops" package.

Posts.Title: Incontinence suggestions for returning to work after Prostate Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I never understood the overtreatment mantra. I think it is linked to the other myth you will die of something else before you die of PC. As life expectancy increases and the cancer expands to more and younger men and more aggressive forms public perception will change. I think social stigma also plays a role. Men are reluctant to accept the responsibility for the disease, will not discuss it, and practice denial and delay which feeds complaint and bitterness over the natural outcome of delayed detection and treatment. The denial and delay syndrome is driven by men themselves not stepping up and taking responsibility for their health. It's easy to "blame the victim. My treatment was delayed because my urologist downplayed the significance of my steadily rising PSA, and seemed to be unaware of my family history. Yes, he told me that my PSA was high, but my GP has always told me that my LDL and triglycerides are high. Neither of these last two have tried to kill me, yet. My urologist never even mentioned the word cancer. How was I to know? I expected him to be the expert on the subject. When I went along with the biopsy... no minor procedure... he only told me that it was negative. He just gave me more and more antibiotics. It is hard for me to not feel resentful of the way I was treated... or more precisely, NOT treated. And it makes my blood boil every time I read someone talking about "overtreatment". Yes, I understand what happened, to SOME men. But that's no reason to throw out the baby with the bathwater. It wasn't until I changed doctors and asked my Uro several very pointed questions that he dropped me like a hot potato. I only wish it had happened two years earlier. The "lucky" men who received treatment when their cancer was only a G6 or G7 should consider themselves very fortunate. The alternative could have been to end up with an artificial sphincter and pelvic radiation disease, all because some gov't panel scared a doctor into downplaying PSA screening. Yes, it is so much easier to simply blame the patient for trusting his doctor.

Posts.Title: Ensuring eligibility for surgery

Posts.Content: Flying all over the country and staying in motels was nothing that I could ever afford. My GP had been monitoring my PSA and recommended consulting a urologist when it hit 4. My mistake was trusting the wrong doctor. My urologist only told me three things between 2012 and when I was finally diagnosed in 2016 after he retired: 1) your PSA is nothing to be concerned about, 2) your biopsy was negative, and 3) your prostate is normal. I am certain that if he had ever mentioned the word "cancer" then I might have been motivated to look further. Now, today, when a doctor tells me that I might have cancer, I make sure to get additional testing. Lesson learned from my urology experience. Had I been a wealthy person it might have been a fun getaway to maybe drive up to Cleveland Clinic for a second opinion. After all, I drove to Cedar Point in Sandusky many times. But making the four hour drive up there just to see if there might be a doctor there who could tell me something different from what my local Uro told me was not a priority. Never even occurred to me.

Posts.Title: Good news, I guess... how's everyone doing?

Posts.Content: I just got my second PSA results, now six months after completing adjuvant radiation and fifteen months into my 18 months of Lupron alone. There was some difficulty getting the results as my Uro's office is undergoing some management changes and I cannot log into their web portal, but a phone call to his nurse (again, confounded by techno issues with their phone system) and got the results verbally. PSA is "undetectable".. I don't know the actual value due to glitch above but I asked the nurse, is it 0.00? and she said yes. I asked about testosterone and she said 23.2, or was it 27.2? Anyway she said it's normal for Lupron. And this whole cognitive impairment thing where I can't remember what the heck I'm doing is also "normal for Lupron". So I know there are lots of guys here who are on ADT and I was wondering how you guys are doing? I try read all of your posts (MichiganMan, my "joined at the pelvis" bro) and everyone else who has finished the aggressive treatment and are on the long slow, slide back to normalcy (hopefully) and trying to live life partially impaired and limping along with no other goals right now other then waiting for the next PSA test and hoping it hasn't moved in the wrong direction. Sorry I don't remember everyone's name, but I recognize you when scanning the thread list and always read whatever you guys have to say. Two years into this (or four or six, depending on how you count) I don't read every thread, and only respond where it seems my input may be more valuable than it would be demoralizing... so forgive me if this has been discussed here before. I was reading on that other message board about testosterone recovery following ADT, which concurred with something MM mentioned earlier about a six months half life after the end of the therapeutic period of the last last shot (ie, six months after the last six month shot). So I realize that after I DO NOT get another six month shot in July, three months from now, that by next January 2019 I will have about half as much of the LNRH or whatever it is in my system and should see recovery of testosterone during that year, 2019. My Uro said for it to take about a year for the Lupron to wear off and start getting accurate PSA tests. But what I'm probably more interested in now is testosterone recovery. In fact I'm a little bit worried about what "life after Lupron" will be like. My T level was never tested before starting HT so I have no idea what my baseline would be. But I've read that two factors affect testosterone recovery... age of the patient and length of time on ADT. The thread I found on that other website suggests that early on into one's PCa journey, T levels actually decline, as the cancer is actually consuming testosteron as it grows. And in my case, as my cancer has apparently been around for quite a long while before it was clinically detectable, I'm thinking I was probably hypogonadal or low-T even before that first biopsy. Granted, I was able to keep my very sexy wife satisfied before things started going south, and did father two very healthy sons. But after that period of time I did lose a testicle and recall that more than four years ago (or twenty years ago, depending on how one counts) I was experiencing hot flashes and severe mood swings, and wondering if my baseline T level was lower than most guys anyway. I've never been an athlete, exercise enthusiast or even a sports fan. OK, enough of my usual rambling. But a final thought. I just told my wife about this and she just said, why don't the doctors tell people about any of this? To which I could only say, doctors don't want an informed patient, they just want to call all the shots, and the less they say, the less they can be held to. Have a happy 4/20 everyone! I'll be on the table with a scope up my butt for my first post-RT colo.

Posts.Title: Good news, I guess... how's everyone doing?

Posts.Content: Surgery was Monday. It was a terrible day. We arrived at 10AM for a procedure that was supposed to take less than an hour. Around noon we were told the surgeon would be delayed about an hour, so I sent my wife home. I remember they finally wheeled me into the OR at 2PM. Next thing I remember was being wheeled into a room where my wife was waiting at 6PM. The day finally ended after 8PM with the Dr inserting a Foley cath. What happened in the meantime? I suspect that I was "out" much longer than expected. I do remember someone telling me "you don't remember because of the drugs we gave you". Well if such drugs exist then I want some NOW because my head keeps going back to that day. Today I had my first followup. The Foley was out briefly, then went back in for another week. I'm still pretty beat up but am gradually returning to normal. I have to keep reminding myself that I am doing this not to be pad free but so I can start radiation before the cancer spreads any further. Looking forward to rejoining the group here...

Posts.Title: AUS is in

Posts.Content: I tried another brand of belted shield that has velcro and they were not as good as the CVS/Prevail. I still have most of that pack left. Problem I had was the elastic belts were too tight and tend to curl. I buttoned two straps back to back on both sides (the buttons at either the front of back are then reversed). If you are mechanically inclined you can figure it out. I think the shields are intended primarily for women hence the shortcomings but are marketed as unisex. As for the CC's, different manufacturers have staked out different sizes along the scale. The Freedoms are at 28, 31, 34 etc. Another brand has 29, 32, 35 and so on. I liked the silicon freedoms w/aloe for all they were, though once the Lupron started they were a bit too large (but next size down was too tight). There was one brand, Coveen I think, that had 30mm which seemed to be the best fit, but were a different animal... had like an accordion flex point at the end. Each variety has their pluses and minuses. Apply them smoothly then squeeze all around to make the adhesive stick. There seem to be no good tutorials available on this. Presumably anything on youtube would be banned unless using a fake phallus, which is actually not very realistic.
Posts.Title: Incontinence suggestions for returning to work after Prostate Surgery

Posts.Content: Within a few months post-RP I was dry most nights but had very little control during the day. The situation never improved. My Uro sent me to PT with a Kegel coach but my continence was never reliable. I would leak often enough that I had to wear some form of protection 24 hours a day. Even now, with the AUS implant I sometimes drip during the night. And as Rooster stated, my bladder seems to hold less now than it did previously and I get up several times during the night to pee. I now go thru 1-2 pads daily and at night I sleep with a dry washcloth in my crotch covering my penis and scrotum. I bought a supply of yellow or beige washcloths so my wife doesn't use them to wash her face (ehwww). The leaking isn't always a problem but I can feel even just a few drops on my thigh and it wakes me up. And there's still the occasional wet spot on the sheets. It doesn't seem to matter what I drink or when, it just happens. It's the new normal.

Posts.Title: Radiation question

Posts.Content: Mike - Your T3B/SVI automatically qualifies your for ART. I had 70Gy IMRT using the Varian RapidArc like Chester, but as MF points out, your PSA is essentially undetectable. However, your primary grade 4 component of your G7 plus the bladder neck involvement tips the scale back toward ART. The fact that you seem to be fully continent is another green flag. I'd say talk with a RO who is not promoting Proton. PB is a high priced option that I believe is aimed at intermediate risk patients. It is more accurate at delivering targeted primary radiation to known tumors. You should probably have your entire prostate bed flooded with radiation to wipe out any escaped cancer cells in the area of the SV and bladder neck before they take advantage of the opportunity for systemic spread. It's a bit of a crap shoot. I think the stats show it's 50/50 whether you would ever have BCR without having ART. But it is my belief to zap everything while it's still localized. There are some drawbacks to getting radiation, but if there's a chance you might need it later on, you'd be better of getting it now. Good luck, and best regards to your lovely wife.

Posts.Title: Radiation Opinions Sought and Be Your Own Advocate

Posts.Content: Flying all over the country and staying in motels was nothing that I could ever afford. My GP had been monitoring my PSA and recommended consulting a urologist when it hit 4. My mistake was trusting the wrong doctor. My urologist only told me three things between 2012 and when I was finally diagnosed in 2016 after he retired: 1) your PSA is nothing to be concerned about, 2) your biopsy was negative, and 3) your prostate is normal. I am certain that if he had ever mentioned the word "cancer" then I might have been motivated to look further. Now, today, when a doctor tells me that I might have cancer, I make sure to get additional testing. Lesson learned from my urology experience. Had I been a wealthy person it might have been a fun getaway to maybe drive up to Cleveland Clinic for a second opinion. After all, I drove to Cedar Point in Sandusky many times. But making the four hour drive up there just to see if there might be a doctor there who could tell me something different from what my local Uro told me was not a priority. Never even occurred to me.

Posts.Title: Good news, I guess... how's everyone doing?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TinkerbellRM27 What steps did your doctor go through in order to ensure you were eligible for surgery? From the perspective of the scans - which did your doctor have done to ensure it has not spread? -I am concerned bc my dad's current urologist had a bone scan and pelvic MRI done. A different uro we saw last week recommended he also have a Prostate MRI and a Cat Scan of his mid section to ensure no spread. From the perspective of other surgery suitability, did your uro have you see a cardio doc? get a physical? meet with an anesthesiologist? Sounds like your Dad has already had more tests than I did. In my case, an MRI first identified the location of my tumor, then my new Uro ordered some blood work and a nuclear bone scan. That's all. No CT. The hospital required a routine physical exam by my GP (I had recently had an annual physical within the past three months, which I think included EKG and chest x-ray). Then I met with the pre-op team at the hospital who were all very good, explained what to do when and provided Sage wipes and Impact nourishment supplement beforehand. No anesthesiologist until the day of surgery. All in all, the RRP was the best surgical experience I have ever had, ever.

Posts.Title: Ensuring eligibility for surgery

Posts.Content: I tried another brand of belted shield that has velcro and they were not as good as the CVS/Prevail. I still have most of that pack left. Problem I had was the elastic belts were too tight and tend to curl. I buttoned two straps back to back on both sides (the buttons at either the front of back are then reversed). If you are mechanically inclined you can figure it out. I think the shields are intended primarily for women hence the shortcomings but are marketed as unisex. As for the CC's, different manufacturers have staked out different sizes along the scale. The Freedoms are at 28, 31, 34 etc. Another brand has 29, 32, 35 and so on. I liked the silicon freedoms w/aloe for all they were, though once the Lupron started they were a bit too large (but next size down was too tight). There was one brand, Coveen I think, that had 30mm which seemed to be the best fit, but were a different animal... had like an accordion flex point at the end. Each variety has their pluses and minuses. Apply them smoothly then squeeze all around to make the adhesive stick. There seem to be no good tutorials available on this. Presumably anything on youtube would be banned unless using a fake phallus, which is actually not very realistic.

Posts.Title: Incontinence suggestions for returning to work after Prostate Surgery

Posts.Content: Practically every man here started his prostate cancer journey with a TRUS (transrectal ultrasound guided biopsy). The urologist will insert a small probe into your rectum and a needle will punch out a dozen or so core samples. Usually the patient is sedated for this, though some docs seem to go cheap and just use Novocaine. If you are awake you may just feel a little sting. You will probably be required to take an enema or two the morning of the procedure. You should be given an antibiotic, as there is a risk of passing fecal material into the prostate. Afterwards, your urine will be bloody for several days. I experienced some passing of clots that restricted urine flow, but that was the worst of it. Semen will be dark red then brown for several weeks afterwards, perhaps as long as a month or more. Then it will clear up. Good luck with your procedure. Sometimes the TRUS will yield false negative results, meaning that there may actually be cancer in there, but the needle missed it. In that case you should request or demand an MRI before another biopsy. That is important (I was never offered that option). Following the biopsy, any further procedures such as prostatectomy, further biopsy or colonoscopy must be postponed by 6-8 weeks while the prostate and surrounding tisue heals.

Posts.Title: Ultrasound guided prostate biopsy (looking for what to expect)

Posts.Content: You may wish to read THIS THREAD from late last year. Lots of guys contributed to it. Personally I never had much luck with the clamp, or with pads for that matter. They didn't hold enough and my shaft had the tendency to flop off to one side or the other and miss the pad altogether. I came to rely primarily on external catheters and have written extensively on several different forums on the subject. My favorite, most comfortable and most reliable was the Freedom silicone with aloe, about $1.25 ea on Az, leg bag by Rusch about $2 ea also from Az. I would try to go a day or two each week w/o the CC and would use Prevail belted shields, which are also sold at CVS as their own brand. I think we discussed this in an earlier thread, so maybe you tried these and they did not work for you. Different strokes, as they say. Several ppl had suggested to me to place a pad inside a Depends brief, with only a small portion of the adhesive exposed. That way you can change the pad without changing the brief. I found it all to be way too bulky... but then I am slender and wear snug fitting trousers, so it definitely looked like I was wearing a diaper. Today I wear only a Tena moderate absorbent pad, the "3 drops" package.

Posts.Title: Incontinence suggestions for returning to work after Prostate Surgery

Posts.Content: Congrats Red, I hope your procedure went well. Unfortunately you'll need to wait another month before you can play with it. My swelling and bruising was pretty bad... I looked like an eggplant down there. Hopefully you iced your goods off and on for the first few days. I read other guys say they were instructed to pull down on the pump twice a day to keep it from retracting upward into the abdomen. I didn't have to as the pump was placed where my right testicle used to be. I don't know the particulars about the retraction, but have heard about it so it must be important. I'm trying to get an AUS support group going on FB if either of you guys might be interested. But of course, most guys don't have any problems with their AUS, so it's been kind of lonely. It won't take long to get used to your new hardware. In the meantime, good luck!

Posts.Title: AUS 800 dr installed.

Posts.Content: I've heard everything from six months to three years. My RO said it is important to be on HT before and after RT. Initially that was supposed to be just six months, then my SRT was postponed by five months. The Uro who did my RP said it would be three years. When I asked about two he said two or three years is typical. (As a movie buff this reminded me of Mr & Mrs Smith). Then my RO most recently said just one year. Since my SRT starts next month, then that satisfies the before and after requirement. I know that the guys with stage 4 and metastatic PCa are typically on it for three years and even longer, but it typically becomes ineffective after several years... which leads to the intermittent HT protocol (xx months on, xx months off).

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by chiguy In my case they found 2 previously unseen lesions, which likely explain my high PSA and G6 history to that point. The 'new' lesions were in the base, which I understand is a more difficult area to read. I have not yet had a fusion biopsy to confirm all this... My PSA rose steadily for four years, but because DRE's were normal and initial biopsy was negative, nothing was done until a fusion biopsy two years ago found a G8 tumor at the base. Yes, a difficult area to read. My new Uro simply said "you can never find them up there". I wish my original Uro had been more open to following up with additional tests, and I wish I had known a lot more at the time.

Posts.Title: Incontinence suggestions for returning to work after Prostate Surgery

Posts.Content: Within a few months post-RP I was dry most nights but had very little control during the day. The situation never improved. My Uro sent me to PT with a Kegel coach but my continence was never reliable. I would leak often enough that I had to wear some form of protection 24 hours a day. Even now, with the AUS implant I sometimes drip during the night. And as Rooster stated, my bladder seems to hold less now than it did previously and I get up several times during the night to pee. I now go thru 1-2 pads daily and at night I sleep with a dry washcloth in my crotch covering my penis and scrotum. I bought a supply of yellow or beige washcloths so my wife doesn't use them to wash her face (ehwww). The leaking isn't always a problem but I can feel even just a few drops on my thigh and it wakes me up. And there's still the occasional wet spot on the sheets. It doesn't seem to matter what I drink or when, it just happens. It's the new normal.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by IceStationZebra But it sounds like there is nothing that will ever rule out that I have cancer, it looks like we’re just delaying it until we hit a ringer and some test finds something. Something that another doctor told me around 35 years ago was "we can rule it in, but not out". I wish my urologist had told me the same thing, about two years earlier. My cancer might not have progressed as it did, while he led me believe that my prostate was normal. As you've been at this for six months (?) ... I don't see any stats other than your PSA, I'm guessing that you are in the same boat I was in four years ago... consistently rising PSA but all tests "negative" so far. If my urologist had offered me a prostatectomy back then I might have taken him up on it, rather than fumbling around with false negative biopsies which were doomed to failure unless a different approach was taken. Of course, standards of care wouldn't permit that. Whatever loop you find yourself currently caught up in, I hope you can find an exit soon!

Posts.Title: AUS 800 dr installed.

Posts.Content: Hey Nick, I remember that you and I joined CFN around the same time. For me it was July 2016, just a couple weeks after the biopsy confirmed my G8. We also had surgery and radiation around the same time, last day of August for me, and RT was a year later Aug-Oct 2017. Like MM, I don't remember your stats exactly, but it sounds like we've been on a similar path. My final Lupron shot was a year ago. I'm guessing you must be getting the three month shots, not the six month shots. The worst SE's for me have been hot flashes, brain fog and mood swings... I think, not sure I can remember everything. Duh. I don't miss the body hair at all. Fortunately no man boobs, but there was a spike in blood work (lipids, A1C, BP) for a year or so. Two of my three shots were rather painful, so not sure how you were so lucky lol. Thing is, I just had PSA and T tested and my testosterone is still in the pits. It measures only 11 now, and my doc says it may take 12-18 months to bounce back. It's great that you have an excellent doctor who keeps you informed. Mine doesn't tell me much. I was starting to wonder if that was all urologists (I've had four). Well anyway, your 50-60% chance honestly doesn't sound that great, so I'm guessing maybe you had lymphatic involvement? Without a sig it's hard to tell why your odds aren't higher. My doc just tells me that my PSA may go up "a little" once the HT wears off. Maybe another year from now. I won't believe the good news until it's been clear for five years. Just thinking out loud. Thanks for checking in. I hope everything continues to go well for you!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by chiguy In my case they found 2 previously unseen lesions, which likely explain my high PSA and G6 history to that point. The 'new' lesions were in the base, which I understand is a more difficult area to read. I have not yet had a fusion biopsy to confirm all this... My PSA rose steadily for four years, but because DRE's were normal and initial biopsy was negative, nothing was done until a fusion biopsy two years ago found a G8 tumor at the base. Yes, a difficult area to read. My new Uro simply said "you can never find them up there". I wish my original Uro had been more open to following up with additional tests, and I wish I had known a lot more at the time.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy Rob, Are you talking so-called 'whitie-tighties or a real thong? I'm at the end of my rope trying to find something that I can use with a pad and will stay up around my hips when they begin to get heavy. The thong reference really was intended as a joke. Do they still make those? Anyway, I use snug fitting low cut bikini style briefs that are made of stretch polyester rather than cotton. Cotton stretches out too much and does sag when the pad gets heavy. And the bikini briefs (which I bought at Target) have more of a pronounced pouch up front for the junk, and the pad. Only problem was the tight waistband, which as I mentioned earlier, can be stretched out before wearing. Good luck finding something that works well for you!
Posts.Title: What is your choice

Posts.Content: Welcome to the board Mauricio. My initial impression is that RT this early is overkill, especially given your low numbers and no adverse pathology. However, as you have already started RT I would recommend that you proceed with HT and throw everything at it while it is still early. Of course, in my case I did have adverse pathology and took this approach, starting HT soon after surgery. Also I had a pretty rough time with RT. Presumably your HT would be a short course (3-6 months) and you should not be concerned about castrate resistance. Most guys with T3a and negative SM would wait for a pronounced and continual PSA rise before initiating further treatment. However, once you have started you should likely do as much possible now. You only get one first chance at this. Good luck!

Posts.Title: 18 Months on Lupron update

Posts.Content: Diminished appetite and subsequent weight loss are the things that will get a doctor's attention, once you get past flu season and any likelihood of everything being blamed on that (even though you didn't have it). When you are "congratulated" on your weight loss, say you haven't been able to eat much. Then bring up the headaches. I have no idea what the problem could be, but there are probably a thousand possibilities. But I do know doctors and how they work. They only go by what they can physically see and measure, THEN will ask questions about how you feel. Their first approach is that there's nothing wrong and all they need to do is convince the patient of that. Good luck with this.
Posts.Title: Help requested.

Posts.Content: One year ago today... or more accurately 52 weeks ago, as August 31st was on Wednesday last year, was my prostatectomy. And what a year it has been. Also, as of today's treatment I am now one-third of the way thru with adjuvant radiation. It was a lo-o-o-ong struggle just to get to this point. I've been fighting this disease for over three years now. Finally there is light at the end of the tunnel. Thanks everyone here who has been there for me.

Posts.Title: Big milestone today!

Posts.Content: My T is also 11, just tested and one year after Lupron. I've never had my estrogen tested. Lord knows it was hard enough just to get my testosterone tested. Is there a chance of developing breast cancer? Yes, but very unlikely. There are about 2,000 cases of male breast cancer every year. But think of all the women with estrogen levels much higher than yours, and still "only" about 1 in 6 will ever in their lifetimes develop BC. Is there something that has you concerned about it? Say, a lump in your breast or elsewhere? Or are you just in need of something else to worry about.

Posts.Title: Embarrassing ?

Posts.Content: I'm wondering if anyone here has had the AMS800 artificial urinary sphincter implant or if anyone here has had their level of incontinence described as "intrinsic sphincter deficiency", as opposed to stress urinary incontinence or the other one, the urgency thing (which I don't have). Anyway, my six month anniversary of my RP was last week and I had already been told that I am not a candidate for the "sling". But up until this point, I had pretty much been led to believe that I could still expect some improvement in control up until around ten months... at least that's what I was told by my RO. But today I was seen by the prosthetic urologist who said, yes he's seen healing up to nine months, but from where I am now, no way that's going to happen. So basically I'm scheduled for surgery in around ten weeks from now. By then my wife's chemo should be wrapped up and we will even have time for another little getaway before I go back under the knife. I had hoped to postpone the AUS until my PSA began to rise again. Reason being is as soon as the device goes in, the deterioration begins. The inflatable cuff causes the urethra to erode and so it needs to be surgically relocated every 8-10 years (paraphrasing here) and as it "eats" about 2cm of urethra each time, they can move it twice. So I can expect maybe thirty years out of it. (BTW usually they just replace the device rather than simply move it, as after ten years or so the risk of mechanical failure increases). I told him that I have been fortunate so far with a similar ticking time bomb, namely my left leg, which I was told twelve years ago that I could expect around ten years before needing a TKR. And I was hoping to do the same thing here, postpone the AUS until the cancer reappears. He basically said the real ticking time bomb is delaying the radiation, that the Lupron will keep it in check for a while but it's not a cure, and I really should proceed with the SRT as soon as possible... and they prefer that the AUS goes in before the radiation begins. Plus there's a six week window afterwards for tissue healing before the RT essentially freezes the recovery process. Now, I realize that the doctors are basically selling something, and I felt that I could at least get by for a while before being once again carved up. The big "ah-hah" moment came when I considered just how much time I could possibly hope to save... sort of a "how long can you tread water" question. Is it worth jeopardizing recurrence of the cancer just to save a few months in the lifespan of a mechanical device? Then the answer became obvious. I've read as much as I can from users on other forums who have had experience with this device, and was wondering if anyone here might have some thoughts on the matter. Thanks.

Posts.Title: AMS800 AUS & intrinsic sphincter deficiency

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 What was your level of continence at the six month mark? By the 4-5 month mark, I was about a 9 on the scale of 10. Then I had SRT/HT, and I went back a bit to where I am now, about 7/8. One pad a day... First, thanks for your kind words for what Lori & I have been thru. I remember you are T3b and I know you have been thru a lot yourself. As far as continence, I am right now at six months, and continence is I'd guess 50% at best. Nights are dry, and I am fine sitting or lying down. And I can "hold it" as long as I need to when I get up. But at some point in the day, I must direct my attention to other things in daily life. That's when whatever I am wearing just fills up and I leak like a faucet. As far as "pads per day" (they always ask that question) I only say that pads can't hold enough. I wear diapers, and they hold about a half pound each. When I use an external cath and leg bag I dump out about a half liter several times a day. I think what the Dr meant was that I'm simply not going to go from 50% to 80-90% in just a few more months. He said if I was using "only" 2 or 3 pads a day then I could go ahead with the RT. But since I use 8-10 even 12 diapers a day, then I basically have no control at all, at least for most of the day. Yes, it settles down at night, but during the day, my condition is described as intrinsic sphincter deficiency.

Posts.Title: AMS800 AUS & intrinsic sphincter deficiency

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 By the 4-5 month mark, I was about a 9 on the scale of 10. Then I had SRT/HT, and I went back a bit to where I am now, about 7/8. So if I understand correctly, your continence actually worsened following (or during) your salvage radiation. And I assume this may not be uncommon. So I am going to guess that even if I were to improve (say from 50% to 80%) in the next couple months before SRT begins, then it is quite possible that my continence would get knocked back down again by the radiation treatments. So that's a reason to go ahead and proceed with the AMS800.
Posts.Title: AMS800 AUS & intrinsic sphincter deficiency

Posts.Content: Welcome to the board Mauricio. My initial impression is that RT this early is overkill, especially given your low numbers and no adverse pathology. However, as you have already started RT I would recommend that you proceed with HT and throw everything at it while it is still early. Of course, in my case I did have adverse pathology and took this approach, starting HT soon after surgery. Also I had a pretty rough time with RT. Presumably your HT would be a short course (3-6 months) and you should not be concerned about castrate resistance. Most guys with T3a and negative SM would wait for a pronounced and continual PSA rise before initiating further treatment. However, once you have started you should likely do as much possible now. You only get one first chance at this. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Combined ADT + RT after Surgery

Posts.Content: Diminished appetite and subsequent weight loss are the things that will get a doctor's attention, once you get past flu season and any likelihood of everything being blamed on that (even though you didn't have it). When you are "congratulated" on your weight loss, say you haven't been able to eat much. Then bring up the headaches. I have no idea what the problem could be, but there are probably a thousand possibilities. But I do know doctors and how they work. They only go by what they can physically see and measure, THEN will ask questions about how you feel. Their first approach is that there's nothing wrong and all they need to do is convince the patient of that. Good luck with this.
Posts.Title: Help requested.

Posts.Content: One word... thong. Okay, J/K. Anyway, I've been a boxer brief kind of guy for over a decade, but after the RP healed up I went to wearing snug briefs. Some sag as bad as boxer briefs but the bikini style is more snug fitting. But I don't like the waistband that is usually made too tight on that style, so I stretch out the waistband overnight around the mouth of a bucket or trash can before wearing.

Posts.Title: CCF calculator question

Posts.Content: Today's colonoscopy went well. Came home, ate soup and slept the rest of the day. The good news is no polyps. I have previous pathology with several adenomas removed a decade ago, and colonoscopies every 2-3 years since. More good news, next colo in seven years! I guess he felt I was in good shape in that department. The not so good news, I do have radiation colitis. He says that's why I'm still experiencing frequent urgency and diarrhea six months after the conclusion of IMRT. I'm going to avoid consulting Dr Google on this one. Doc says he took a biopsy and if it comes back negative then the RC should ease gradually over the coming years. We don't hear much about RC as a result of prostate treatment. Anyone else have knowledge on the matter?

Posts.Title: Good news on ED meds

Posts.Content: Rob - no personal experience, but the most common adverse effect I've heard mentioned is peripheral neuropathy. If the infusion staff does not offer you cold packs for your hands and feet, you should request them. This will reduce the blood flow to your extremities (where there are presumably no mets) and thereby reduce the damaging effects of the Docetaxel to your peripheral nerves. Good luck, another Rob

Posts.Title: Those on hormone therapy (ADT) may want to learn more about ADT

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by po18guy Here is a doctor/researcher oriented video on the difficulties of T-Cell Lymphomas. Give it a brief watch and maybe ask her to watch with you. Look at the extreme depth of knowledge and the desire to control or eliminate these rare lymphomas. The jargon is very technical, but shows the profound efforts made by medical science in the effort to spare human life. These researchers hate cancer and live in the micro-cellular world in man's best attempt to eradicate it. http://www.oncologytube.com/video/ne...homas/10001079 Thanks, but first off I gotta say (and I'm sure you'll fix it) the video link is wrong... the text is correct if you copy and paste, but clicking on the link brings up a reply window. With that out of the way, I want to welcome you to the prostate forum. I know you've been here before as I've seen your replies to a few other posts. And of course I know you as moderator of the HL/NHL forum here. Interesting video. I enjoyed watching it as I have a deep appreciation for the seriousness and difficulty of the fight against cancer. I'm afraid if I show it to my wife the best I can hope is that it might make her feel fortunate to not have T-cell lymphoma. Worst case, well, she is one who feels that everything can be remedied with herbs and prayers, diet and exercise, essential oils, Reiki... I've seen it all. I have ordered the book and hope (and pray) that she will read it and maybe take it to heart. It says there is a Ken Burns documentary... I am slightly dyslexic and choose audio books if possible (it takes me forever to compose a post or reply here). Thanks for the reply and the links. I'm trying to work thru this.
Posts.Title: Nowhere to turn

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Respectfully, support groups may be of help but, frankly, my thoughts turn to a leaking roof. If you have one, you would call a roofer because he is the one most trained to repair the damage. With that in mind, you may want to seek professional therapeutic help to ease your emotional pain. Depression can fester, if left untreated. Thanks Jim. I've considered that, and I know that mental state can affect one's health. I knew about your wife, but not your son. Very sad. We have two adult sons who are terrific (and I have told them so!) and feel so fortunate that neither of them ever associated with the drug crowd... never even had a tattoo or piercing. We feel so blessed! Surely that must have been very difficult to learn how to cope with, and now living with your wife's hemi behavior. I'm sure you two have been together so long that either one of you would be lost without the other, so you value the time you have left together.

Don't give up on yourself, your wife/ relationship, or your treatments. Whenever things got rocky at times over the past 35+ married years I always ask myself "is this worse than being alone?" and the answer is always no. Thanks, John. You're always there, for everyone. You're the one that I just knew would reply.

Posts.Content: I agree with Fairwind. Such was my case. Same age at time of surgery. I chose surgery for expediency and the surgeon had an excellent track record (I am still very pleased with his work). However I ended up needing SRT anyway for SVI. Given that your cancer includes the apex, you may need RT+HT as well, as most positive margins occur at the apex. BTW I just learned yesterday that my HT will be one full year and probably no more. And BTW my father received his radiologic training at Loyola. Good choice!

Posts.Title: Tough Decision - I'd like to hear your thoughts

Posts.Content: For the record, I have never been depressed, and still believe I am not. Certainly not 'clinically' depressed nor profound. Yes, I get mad sometimes, I get anxious, I get stressed. I composed that post and emailed it to every living relative I have, as they have all witnessed me going over the edge. We all live near the edge, but some are better at pulling back when they feel themselves being pushed forward. I had to accept the diagnosis because I couldn't convince my doctor that the side effects of the Lupron have been too much for me. Yes, I could just grin and bear it. But there are medications that can help. When I talk with my doctor about it, it just goes over his head. I once told him "everyone I know who's on Lupron is also on antidepressants" and he just said that would just make me feel weird. That didn't help either. MM, I feel a greater kinship with you than I think any other guy here. We have similar diagnoses, yours a bit worse, and you are further along. And yes I am pissed that I got this disease, but I am MOST pissed that I couldn't get it treated sooner. My Uro dismissed all the signs (that can happen) but then just when I had caught my breath and was ready to go back and fight the good fight, my wife did something that sent me over the edge. Way over. It was innocent but thoughtless, and because I was in a terrible emotional state I could only think about getting out of the well, not about getting yet another biopsy. You see, when you mention depression, everybody starts treating you differently... and not necessarily better. It's more like "be careful around him". It's happening already. But again, I am not "depressed", I'm just experiencing the kind of deep mood swings that are TYPICAL for the disease and medications that we are all experiencing. I do not for one minute believe that the new meds will make me any more happy than I already am. I am a happy person. However, if they can reduce the frequency and severity of hot flashes and LET ME SLEEP, if they can help stabilize some of the deep mood swings THAT EVERYONE ON LUPRON REPORTS, and if it can at the same time make it a little easier to avoid going over the edge, then it is entirely worth it to be called "depressed".
Posts.Title: OK, now I'm REALLY depressed

Posts.Content: No, I don't mean I'm extremely depressed... no, I mean I am now OFFICIALLY depressed. After much anguish I finally swallowed my pride and accepted an unpleasant medical diagnosis in order to get the medications I need. There is so much stigma associated with having "major depressive disorder" on one's medical record, but my wife finally convinced me that I need not be so concerned... after all, it's not like I'm going to be applying for a job or anything like that. Believe me, the view from the bottom of the well is a LOT different from how it looks up top. Most days I can walk past "the well", even approach the edge and look down into the well and think "gee, that doesn't look so bad... that shouldn't be so hard to climb out of". But I never know just when I'm going to fall in, or when I do, how long I'll be down there. And as I'm flailing about down there, screaming for help, I can look up and see all the people standing around the edge looking down and thinking "that doesn't look so bad". And once I finally manage to get out, then I have to apologize to everyone that I may have offended when I was down there.... which doesn't make me feel any better. And some of them may have actually given me a little shove, granted it's never intentional, just some little thing that pushed me over the edge. According to the American Cancer Society, 15 to 35% of cancer patients experience depression. That means either one out of three or one out of seven. That's a huge gap. I suppose it's actually 1 in 3 that are depressed but only 1 in 7 report it, or feel they need to do something about it. Thinking back, I remember at least a half dozen times I've visited doctors and described what should be classic symptoms... endless crying fits, tightness in the chest, unable to breath, feeling a need to escape (how many times in the past three years since my prostate cancer symptoms first appeared have I left the room rather than engage in an uncomfortable discussion). As I describe to my doctor(s) what I feel are serious problems I just see this blank look on his face, like all he's thinking is "what's the least I can do to get this guy out of my office". I was amazed at the difference in medical care between what my wife has had compared to what I get. I've sat with her thru her many doctors visits. Her doctor asks are you in pain, and how is your emotional state? She even looked at each of us and said "you have cancer, and YOU have cancer, this is going to be difficult... you will need to be sure that you do not let it affect your mental state". My doctor just says "I'm putting you on hormone therapy... there will be some side effects". My wife finally told me "doctors don't take hints, you need to come right out and tell him what you need". I had this sense of pride a couple weeks ago getting a routine endoscopy when asked if I had ever been treated for anxiety or depression and I immediately said no. I guess in reality it's just another question, like have you ever had headaches. And since I no longer need to be concerned with background checks and security clearances, there's really no reason to be so obstinate about it. So the plan is I'll be going on Cymbalta and Gabapentin once my surgery is out of the way. First step was getting off the narcotics I've been on for the past decade since my leg injury... that's been rough. I tried cutting back by half every two days. Five of the last six nights have largely been sleepless. It's tough knowing you have a drawer full of pills that could end the fits and sweats, but if I take one then I'll just have to start all over again. But there's some sort of interaction between SRNI's like Cymbalta and opiate derivatives. For now I'm taking Lyrica for the OA pain... man, that stuff is expensive! And it wear off quickly. Once the AUS surgery is out of the way, much of the therapeutic effects of the new meds is "off label"... the Gabapentin is often prescribed for hot flashes, Cymbalta for osteoarthritis. But my Dr says he can't prescribe off label and expect to be reimbursed. So after all the discussion we had, I logged into my chart online and saw this HUGE (or so it seemed) "F32.9 - major depressive disorder". My sig has been updated accordingly.

Posts.Title: CCF calculator question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by zaldamo ... my step dad is very stubborn, angry and not communicating very well right now. He has prostate cancer, verified via biopsy. He had an MRI last week and confirmed it had metastasized into his bones. I don't know which ones. He said they would try to give him "a few years" and he's getting a shot of some kind at the urologist in 10 days. That's all I know... Assuming I can get him to communicate, can anyone give some general tips about how to proceed? I want him to go to a the local teaching university, or even The James in Columbus or The Cleveland Clinic. (We live in Cincinnati.) What questions should he ask? Second opinion? Should he not be seeing an oncologist or a uro who specializes in cancer? He is angry and grumpy because he is in pain. At least he had the biopsy and MRI and has shared enough that he will be getting "a few more years" probably from the shot of Lupron (or similar androgen deprivation therapy) which will lower his PSA until the cancer becomes castrate resistant, which is usually several years but sometimes never gets that far. He may also get Prolia or Xgeva injection to keep his bones as strong as possible. Bone metastasis is typically end stage. Sorry to be blunt. Sometimes men live for a decade or more after reaching stage 4. I think I read the average is four or five years (average meaning some live more than ten and some maybe only months). There is generally no cure. A last resort injection would be radium 223 but I don't think that's what he'll be getting. Sometimes prostate cancer is not detected until it is already too late. People think cutting it out cures everything. They are not informed. You can try to get him to go to another facility if he is willing. They may only be able to subject him to more tests and painful treatments and yet be unable to give him any better news. I know the urology business in Cincinnati is pretty much monopolized by the Urology Group (on Sanger Blvd in Norwood, with some satellite offices) and once you're in there you don't have much choice, especially in the area of urologic oncology. If I could go back four or five years I would have camped out at Cleveland Clinic. I don't know what's available in Cols. My cousin has kidney cancer and was at James for several months. They saved his life, but there again were basically delaying the inevitable. If you really want to help him you need to talk with him about getting access to his medical records and be ready to make a LOT of phone calls and do a lot of driving. More than anything, do what you can to make him comfortable. If the situation is truly as you have presented it, then don't try to believe in miracle cures or lift his spirits with we can beat this pep talks. There is a small possibility that it could happen, but the odds are more likely against him. Don't fight it, but don't let him give up just yet. Be prepared for an emotional struggle. And remember to take care of yourself too.

Posts.Content: I am one year behind you and have not abused my body anywhere near as bad as you have. But I am fighting my prostate cancer with everything available. I've had two surgeries since the prostatectomy, and that is not going well. I was originally scheduled for salvage radiation three months ago, and now am hoping that I will be able to get SRT underway before I hit the one year mark. The only reason my PSA is not skyrocketing now is due to the Lupron, which has been difficult to say the least. You have a choice. Think of the men who do not have a choice. If and when your PCa has metastasized beyond the point where it could be treated, do you want to say you gave up all hope, or do you want to say you went down fighting to your last breath? It is after all your choice. Talk to some guys who are already there, and see what they say.

Posts.Title: Thinking of passing on salvage radiation.

Posts.Content: Your confusion is understandable... the same thing happened to me - rising PSA but negative DRE and negative biopsy. I had been seeing the same urologist for twenty years, and when asked what to do next he said another biopsy. It seemed pointless to me. Then I heard about the MRI fusion biopsy. My uro said that required special training and his partner took over and yes it was cancer. My understanding is that the MRI fusion biopsy is fairly new and some insurance will not pay for it unless there has already been another previous biopsy (which you had). The traditional ultrasound guided biopsy uses ultrasound to locate the prostate but does not indicate varied densities within the prostate gland, which might suggest a tumor. With the MRI guided biopsy the surgeon can be guided directly to a suspicious region of the gland. In my case, only the lower right lobe was affected, but with an aggressive tumor. I don't want to frighten you, but this could possibly be your case as well. There are other ways your PSA could be elevated without the presence of a tumor, and it sounds like your uro is pursuing those. Getting another opinion from a different urologist is a good idea, though he may not find anything different. I lost a year between biopsies during which time the tumor spread, but fortunately not too far. In your case you say you have no other symptoms. In mine it was subtle. Up once every night around 4AM to pee which is not unusual at our age. I had reduced ejaculate but also thought maybe age. Just because the tests so far are negative doesn't necessarily mean there is nothing wrong. I guess all I can really say is you may become discouraged but don't give up. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Confused

Posts.Content: No, I don't mean I'm extremely depressed... no, I mean I am now OFFICIALLY depressed. After much anguish I finally swallowed my pride and accepted an unpleasant medical diagnosis in order to get the medications I need. There is so much stigma associated with having "major depressive disorder" on one's medical record, but my wife finally convinced me that I need not be so concerned... after all, it's not like I'm going to be applying for a job or anything like that. Believe me, the view from the bottom of the well is a LOT different from how it looks up top. Most days I can walk past "the well", even approach the edge and look down into the well and think "gee, that doesn't look so bad... that shouldn't be so hard to climb out of". But I never know just when I'm going to fall in, or when I do, how long I'll be down there. And as I'm flailing about down there, screaming for help, I can look up and see all the people standing around the edge looking down and thinking "that doesn't look so bad". And once I finally manage to get out, then I have to apologize to everyone that I may have offended when I was down there.... which doesn't make me feel any better. And some of them may have actually given me a little shove, granted it's never intentional, just some little thing that pushed me over the edge. According to the American Cancer Society, 15 to 35% of cancer patients experience depression. That means either one out of three or one out of seven. That's a huge gap. I suppose it's actually 1 in 3 that are depressed but only 1 in 7 report it, or feel they need to do something about it. Thinking back, I remember at least a half dozen times I've visited doctors and described what should be classic symptoms... endless crying fits, tightness in the chest, unable to breath, feeling a need to escape (how many times in the past three years since my prostate cancer symptoms first appeared have I left the room rather than engage in an uncomfortable discussion). As I describe to my doctor(s) what I feel are serious problems I just see this blank look on his face, like all he's thinking is "what's the least I can do to get this guy out of my office". I was amazed at the difference in medical care between what my wife has had compared to what I get. I've sat with her thru her many doctors visits. Her doctor asks are you in pain, and how is your emotional state? She even looked at each of us and said "you have cancer, and YOU have cancer, this is going to be difficult... you will need to be sure that you do not let it affect your mental state". My doctor just says "I'm putting you on hormone therapy... there will be some side effects". My wife finally told me "doctors don't take hints, you need to come right out and tell him what you need". I had this sense of pride a couple weeks ago getting a routine endoscopy when asked if I had ever been treated for anxiety or depression and I immediately said no. I guess in reality it's just another question, like have you ever had headaches. And since I no longer need to be concerned with background checks and security clearances, there's really no reason to be so obstinate about it. So the plan is I'll be going on Cymbalta and Gabapentin once my surgery is out of the way. First step was getting off the narcotics I've been on for the past decade since my leg injury... that's been rough. I tried cutting back by half every two days. Five of the last six nights have largely been sleepless. It's tough knowing you have a drawer full of pills that could end the fits and sweats, but if I take one then I'll just have to start all over again. But there's some sort of interaction between SRNI's like Cymbalta and opiate derivatives. For now I'm taking Lyrica for the OA pain... man, that stuff is expensive! And it wear off quickly. Once the AUS surgery is out of the way, much of the therapeutic effects of the new meds is "off label"... the Gabapentin is often prescribed for hot flashes, Cymbalta for osteoarthritis. But my Dr says he can't prescribe off label and expect to be reimbursed. So after all the discussion we had, I logged into my chart online and saw this HUGE (or so it seemed) "F32.9 - major depressive disorder". My sig has been updated accordingly.

You need a realistic timeline to map out your years ahead.

Posts.Title: Thinking of passing on salvage radiation.

Posts.Content: For the record, I have never been depressed, and still believe I am not. Certainly not 'clinically' depressed nor profound. Yes, I get mad sometimes, I get anxious, I get stressed. I composed that post and emailed it to every living relative I have, as they have all witnessed me going over the edge. We all live near the edge, but some are better at pulling back when they feel themselves being pushed forward. I had to accept the diagnosis because I couldn't convince my doctor that the side effects of the Lupron have been too much for me. Yes, I could just grin and bear it. But there are medications that can help. When I talk with my doctor about it, it just goes over his head. I once told him "everyone I know who's on Lupron is also on antidepressants" and he just said that would just make me feel weird. That didn't help either. MM, I feel a greater kinship with you than I think any other guy here. We have similar diagnoses, yours a bit worse, and you are further along. And yes I am pissed that I got this disease, but I am MOST pissed that I couldn't get it treated sooner. My Uro dismissed all the signs (that can happen) but then just when I had caught my breath and was ready to go back and fight the good fight, my wife did something that sent me over the edge. Way over. It was innocent but thoughtless, and because I was in a terrible emotional state I could only think about getting out of the well, not about getting yet another biopsy. You see, when you mention depression, everybody starts treating you differently... and not necessarily better. It's more like "be careful around him". It's happening already. But again, I am not "depressed", I'm just experiencing the kind of deep mood swings that are TYPICAL for the disease and medications that we are all experiencing. I do not for one minute believe that the new meds will make me any more happy than I already am. I am a happy person. However, if they can reduce the frequency and severity of hot flashes and LET ME SLEEP, if they can help stabilize some of the deep mood swings THAT EVERYONE ON LUPRON REPORTS, and if it can at the same time make it a little easier to avoid going over the edge, then it is entirely worth it to be called "depressed".
Posts.Title: OK, now I'm REALLY depressed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rmotacek1 ... he said "you may experience some ED". I just had to laugh! That made me laugh too!
Posts.Title: OK, now I'm REALLY depressed

Posts.Content: Your confusion is understandable... the same thing happened to me - rising PSA but negative DRE and negative biopsy. I had been seeing the same urologist for twenty years, and when asked what to do next he said another biopsy. It seemed pointless to me. Then I heard about the MRI fusion biopsy. My uro said that required special training and his partner took over and yes it was cancer. My understanding is that the MRI fusion biopsy is fairly new and some insurance will not pay for it unless there has already been another previous biopsy (which you had). The traditional ultrasound guided biopsy uses ultrasound to locate the prostate but does not indicate varied densities within the prostate gland, which might suggest a tumor. With the MRI guided biopsy the surgeon can be guided directly to a suspicious region of the gland. In my case, only the lower right lobe was affected, but with an aggressive tumor. I don't want to frighten you, but this could possibly be your case as well. There are other ways your PSA could be elevated without the presence of a tumor, and it sounds like your uro is pursuing those. Getting another opinion from a different urologist is a good idea, though he may not find anything different. I lost a year between biopsies during which time the tumor spread, but fortunately not too far. In your case you say you have no other symptoms. In mine it was subtle. Up once every night around 4AM to pee which is not unusual at our age. I had reduced ejaculate but also thought maybe age. Just because the tests so far are negative doesn't necessarily mean there is nothing wrong. I guess all I can really say is you may become discouraged but don't give up. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Confused

Posts.Content: Gleason 6 is borderline. Most docs would probably not do surgery at this stage (I'd guess). PSA is a little high. If it goes into double digits then you may need to take action. The thing is, at your age the clock is running out. Assuming you have no other significant health problems (heart or liver disease) then you are - as I was - "young and healthy enough" for surgery. After age 70, or if other health problems are present then surgery may no longer be an option. You do know that if you have surgery first then you can always have radiation (and or HT) later... not necessarily the other way around. That was the clincher for me. But my cancer was G8 and PSA 25, higher than yours, so taking action was more urgent in my case. You have time to consider options, but I'd say you're probably looking at your case becoming more complicated in a few years. Just my two cents. Good luck with whatever comes out of this.
