Posts.Title: Researchers might of found a way to stop the spread of cancer

Posts.Content: I need to vent and have no one to talk to. It's becoming more difficult to remain upbeat about everything. I may never post this or may delete it. Sometimes it seems the only friends I have are here. My wife has been reading books which I thought were about living with cancer, but instead are spreading a conspiracy theory about how big pharma and the cancer "industry" have been suppressing information about miracle cures (please see my earlier post: Toxic online videos This morning she tells me that Lupron doesn't really reduce PSA but just "readjusts the scale so it looks like you're losing weight". Meanwhile I have genuine concerns about my future treatment. About the Lupron my biggest concern is bone loss (known osteopenia, severe leg injury 2005, partial disability). The Lupron doesn't bother me much. But I think it makes me moody. I get used to the sweats. I know I still have cancer in me but SRT can't begin until my continence gets under control. Right now it looks like that means getting an implant and waiting a few months for that to heal - if it doesn't require revision surgery (25% chance). Then maybe the SRT will get everything, which hopefully is isolated to the area of the seminal vesicle bed. I've posted a couple times here about the AUS and no one - NO ONE replied. There are a few guys on the Cancer Survivors Network who have been thru this, but it is a difficult board to navigate. I feel more at home here, but it seems like I'm the only one who missed the continence bandwagon. I am really scared about this. There are a lot of moving parts and a lot that can go wrong. In a way I feel that my wife got the easy cancer. It sounds more scary "Lymphoma", but really her treatment was pretty much by the book. She keeps telling me she met a guy who "had the surgery (RP) and he's fine". And I tell her I met a guy who had lymphoma and he's fine, BUT THIS IS NOT A COMPETITION. There is a lot I have learned about my cancer and about hers that I have never told her about because I don't want to escalate the situation. I've been with her thru everything. I drive her to all of her appointments and stay with her all day. I told her today after this book discussion "you have no idea who is really on your side". I know if I forward something to her from Quackwatch.org that it will just end up meaning more anguish and more tears for me. I've looked into a couple support groups but there seem to be two types: 1) the "really weird" cancer people who only want to talk about theirs (weird cancer, not weird people.. .they really are good) and 2) prostate guys who are 90% all into their ED. I've PM'd a few guys here who "get it"... when you're over 60 (or for some other reason have a limited amount of time left) that ED really isn't such a big deal. My wife really is a beautiful, caring person. She bought me a book "Constructive Wallowing" about allowing yourself to feel emotions. Yeah, I've got enough of that. Everyone asks about her, how she's doing. She has no hair, so it's like a badge of honor. Meanwhile I have to drag this "ball and chain" (leg bag and condom catheter) everywhere I go... even sleep with it, or I piss all over. I think it's starting to get to me. Sorry for venting. I know I'll probably get a few replies from the same guys, and thanks guys for that.

Posts.Title: Nowhere to turn

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Respectfully, support groups may be of help but, frankly, my thoughts turn to a leaking roof. If you have one, you would call a roofer because he is the one most trained to repair the damage. With that in mind, you may want to seek professional therapeutic help to ease your emotional pain. Depression can fester, if left untreated. Thanks Jim. I've considered that, and I know that mental state can affect one's health. I knew about your wife, but not your son. Very sad. We have two adult sons who are terrific (and I have told them so!) and feel so fortunate that neither of them ever associated with the drug crowd... never even had a tattoo or piercing. We feel so blessed! Surely that must have been very difficult to learn how to cope with, and now living with your wife's hemi behavior. I'm sure you two have been together so long that either one of you would be lost without the other, so you value the time you have left together.

Posts.Title: Nowhere to turn

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by po18guy Here is a doctor/researcher oriented video on the difficulties of T-Cell Lymphomas. Give it a brief watch and maybe ask her to watch with you. Look at the extreme depth of knowledge and the desire to control or eliminate these rare lymphomas. The jargon is very technical, but shows the profound efforts made by medical science in the effort to spare human life. These researchers hate cancer and live in the micro-cellular world in man's best attempt to eradicate it. http://www.oncologytube.com/video/ne...homas/10001079 Thanks, but first off I gotta say (and I'm sure you'll fix it) the video link is wrong... the text is correct if you copy and paste, but clicking on the link brings up a reply window. With that out of the way, I want to welcome you to the prostate forum. I know you've been here before as I've seen your replies to a few other posts. And of course I know you as moderator of the HL/NHL forum here. Interesting video. I enjoyed watching it as I have a deep appreciation for the seriousness and difficulty of the fight against cancer. I'm afraid if I show it to my wife the best I can hope is that it might make her feel fortunate to not have T-cell lymphoma. Worst case, well, she is one who feels that everything can be remedied with herbs and prayers, diet and exercise, essential oils, Reiki... I've seen it all. I have ordered the book and hope (and pray) that she will read it and maybe take it to heart. It says there is a Ken Burns documentary... I am slightly dyslexic and choose audio books if possible (it takes me forever to compose a post or reply here). Thanks for the reply and the links. I'm trying to work thru this.
Posts.Title: Nowhere to turn

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 Example for radiation. University of Chicago and Dana Farber for SRT use a dosage of 68.4 GY, and a boost of 1.8 GY. At other big name cancer centers, it's 70-72 GY. Maybe that's why I am on ADT longer, to make up for the smaller dosage. MM - I posted about my RO visit yesterday on that other forum, but was going to wait until after tomorrow when I will have more info before posting here. My RO apparently plans on 68.4 Gy but no boost mentioned. Also learned that I will only be on Lupron thru the end of this year. Big relief. Next (and hopefully last) Lupron shot tomorrow, along with AUS activation. Will post more later.

Posts.Content: Age 65 at RP. Dry nights at one month per norm. Never regained full continence (sorry, I know there are those who do not want to hear that..... I debated whether to respond at all). Gave up on pads altogether. Three months physical therapy (Kegel training). Relied mostly on condom catheters and leg bag, occasional full briefs. Salvage radiation postponed due to incontinence. Artificial sphincter implanted 5/15/17, revised 5/30, to be activated tomorrow (7/21). Rebuilding bladder capacity to 500-800ml. SRT to commence approx one month from now.

Posts.Content: I agree with Fairwind. Such was my case. Same age at time of surgery. I chose surgery for expediency and the surgeon had an excellent track record (I am still very pleased with his work). However I ended up needing SRT anyway for SVI. Given that your cancer includes the apex, you may need RT+HT as well, as most positive margins occur at the apex. BTW I just learned yesterday that my HT will be one full year and probably no more. And BTW my father received his radiologic training at Loyola. Good choice!

Posts.Title: Post RP incontinence survey

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ANWANK ... he needs to go to urologist. His psa was 4.04. I started researching and thought that was not really high but we went earlier this week. Dr does another psa, dre and schedules a biopsy. DRE negative again and psa 4.1. He also said that his psa should not be over 2.5 at his age and typically should be about 0.7 or so. He recommended genetic testing. He stated that if his biopsy comes back negative he will submit to his insurance for an MRI guided biopsy. I guess I am slightly confused. I understand his family history plays a factor but with two negative dre,no symptoms, and slightly elevated psa, why does this urologist seem pretty confident that there is cancer? Has anyone here had a similar experience? Your doctor and the urologist are indeed doing a good job, and you are also fortunate that they are keeping you informed. Yes, I had somewhat of a similar experience, however my urologist kept me in the dark for a couple of years. Doctors are restricted in what they can do at various stages of diagnosis and treatment by standards of practice and even moreso by what the insurance companies will pay. Several years ago a gov't panel decided that PSA tests were resulting in too many men being "over treated". When my GP noted that my PSA was high for my age, he recommended that I see a urologist. The uro did a DRE which was "normal". In fact, every DRE was normal right up until the day four years later when my prostate was removed. You are fortunate that your doctor is recommending genetic testing and has informed you of the steps your fiance will go thru to be diagnosed and treated. I must also point out to you that if at any time you disagree with anything the doctor says then you always have the option of seeing another doctor (though may need insurance approval). Also he has the right to refuse ANY treatment he does not approve of. And of course, do your best to do your own research and educate yourself as much as you can, which apparently you are doing now. Good luck to you and your fiance, and hopefully in your lives together.

Posts.Title: Prostate biopsy this month

Posts.Content: John - I have not had that specific surgery, but have been advised that I may need an artificial sphincter - a different surgery. I am only five months post op and my RO says he has seen improvement up to ten months, so I am only halfway there. Problem is I have no urgency... I leak when I sneeze or pass gas, otherwise my urine just runs out of me and I am totally unaware of it... so much that pads or diapers are very impractical, and I tend to rely on an external or condom cath and leg bag. I see my Uro again in about ten days and hope to discuss options with him, as the therapist just keep saying more kegels, more kegels. I will ask my Uro if the sling is an option (honestly I haven't looked into it). The artificial sphincter would be a good fit in my case as I only have one testicle and the inflator bulb would take the place of the other one. I'll be watching this thread to see how you progress! As a former scout leader myself, I fully understand your concerns.

Posts.Title: Started Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate RobLee, Your case may fall into the category of constant inflammation increasing your odds of eventually getting significant prostate cancer. http://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/news/...rostate_cancer This is not unique to the prostate. It seems that wherever there is constant irritation, the chances for developing cancer are higher. Thank you ASA. I had considered that long term inflammation of the prostate probably contributed to or possibly brought about my PCa. I had been having difficulty urinating for several years and my Urologist had recommended saw palmetto, which I did use for many years. It did seem to help. So I cannot be certain just when it actually became prostate cancer, but I chose the point in time when my PSA shot up from 4 to 9.5, though I know that BPH can also cause an increase in PSA. From the first 9.5 in early 2014 onward it continued to climb steadily, so I have assumed that was when it became cancerous.
Posts.Title: A pain in the Prostate :(

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Respectfully, support groups may be of help but, frankly, my thoughts turn to a leaking roof. If you have one, you would call a roofer because he is the one most trained to repair the damage. With that in mind, you may want to seek professional therapeutic help to ease your emotional pain. Depression can fester, if left untreated. Thanks Jim. I've considered that, and I know that mental state can affect one's health. I knew about your wife, but not your son. Very sad. We have two adult sons who are terrific (and I have told them so!) and feel so fortunate that neither of them ever associated with the drug crowd... never even had a tattoo or piercing. We feel so blessed! Surely that must have been very difficult to learn how to cope with, and now living with your wife's hemi behavior. I'm sure you two have been together so long that either one of you would be lost without the other, so you value the time you have left together.
Posts.Title: Nowhere to turn

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Thomasj Negitive biopsies? Thats sounds strang to me ... My first biopsy was negative and so I was hesitant to have a second. Fortunately the 2nd MRI fusion biopsy was far more accurate. With only four of fifteen cores positive and two of them 100%, it's no wonder that the first random biopsy failed to hit the tumor which was isolated to the lower right lobe. It's like swatting a fly in a barn in the dark.

Posts.Title: Over treatment

Posts.Content: I just gotta say, as everyone's saying that non-metastatic prostate cancer does not cause any pain, I had "discomfort" that went on for several years. While not like what the OP has described, I frequently had a constant burning sensation in my urethra. The only time it didn't burn was while I was urinating, so I knew it was probably not a venereal disease. My urologist put me on Cipro and that took care of it. He explained the burning and the elevated PSA as likely due to prostatitis. The burning would eventually return and require longer and longer courses of Cipro to yield relief. Turns out eventually that it was indeed prostate cancer. I can't entirely blame him though. I was content to know that it certainly appeared that I did not have cancer. I would have rather known up front, but everything was pointing to something else... other than the steadily escalating PSA. Fate finally intervened when my Uro retired and his partner took over my case. By then I just wanted to get it over with. So he long and short of it is, at least in my case, there can be physical symptoms of PCa. And looking back to when my PSA began to rise and remembering how crummy I was feeling both physically and emotionally, I can tell now that there were more than just a few warning signs.

Posts.Title: A pain in the Prostate :(

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy Hi Rob, If you don't mind my asking, how long have you been on Lupron and why are you stopping it? It's been one full year, and originally it was only supposed to be one shot for six months to boost my adjuvant radiation... two months before, two months during, and two months after. But because of my incontinence and the requirement of holding a full bladder during RT, I had to make a tough decision on getting the AUS... then that required a revision surgery two weeks later, and all that had to heal a couple months before starting RT. Long story short, I wasn't able to start RT until about a year after the RALP, and my RO kept me on Lupron the whole time in order to hold my PSA down. Upon completion of the radiation, there was still two months left on the last six month Lupron shot, so it sounded like perfect timing. Then my RO told me that the radiation would continue to kill cancer cells for another 8-9 months afterwards. I had been reading a lot about various studies on how HT improves the effectiveness of RT by making the cancer cells more sensitive to destruction. That was the RO's original purpose in starting me on Lupron in the first place (reread first sentence of first paragraph). He said there were two studies, one with HT lasting for six months and one for two years, which concluded this added benefit. And the surgeon who did my RALP had told me that I would likely be on HT for three years! There is much discussion on another forum that I frequent about the optimal timing for HT. Many agree that the new standard is eighteen months. Sooo... by now I had heard everything from six months, to one year, 18 months, two years, and even three years. My RO was ready to stop the HT at one year, which is now this month. But as he had said the radiation would still be working for another six months from now, I "volunteered" to extend the HT by getting another six month shot this month. That way, both the radiation and the Lupron will be wearing off around the same time. My rationale was that I would rather throw everything I could at this cancer, rather than end treatment now and then find out later on down the road that I might need to go back on HT due to BCR. And because I've already had the maximum dose of radiation, there's no more rounds in the clip, so to speak. The cancer cells dying from the radiation will cause my PSA to bounce around until midway thru this year, and the Lupron shot I get next week will be effective until July, then will also take a while for it to exit my system. For that reason, I tell people that I won't know whether or not all this has worked until probably another year (2019 at the earliest). I have not discussed extending the Lupron any further with any of my doctors. Frankly, if it hasn't done its job at eighteen months, then I'm potentially risking the cancer becoming castrate resistant. I'd like to avoid that. At some point, I have to stop the treatments and see which way the PSA is going to go on its own, up or down. Sorry for the long story, and I hope it helps with the decisions you must make.

Posts.Content: The AMS800 seems like a good solution, and once in place, repair or replacement is an hour long outpatient procedure. I'm facing the same "life span" limitations with my knee (workers comp injury). I understand your father-in-law... when you get to an age, there's so much that needs fixin' you just take care of the most critical first, and just live with what you can. I've measured my urine and weighed my pads (about 1/2 lb each) and go thru 8-12 a day. As I said, not very practical. The kegels just wear me out and I don't see much improvement. We also have two sons, around 30 now and both are great guys... maybe because of a good role model Sorry you have to deal with this at your age. Good luck with whatever happens.
Posts.Title: Male sling incontinence surgery

Posts.Content: Personally I don't know if there's any difference if nerve sparing was exercised in surgery, but where you are right now is typical for six weeks out... dry at night but leaking when on your feet. It's gravity. Most guys get down to 1-3 pads per day in 6-12 months. Check out other guys' stories in the "Continence Concerns" thread.

Posts.Title: Nerve sparing surgery and incontinence

Posts.Content: Your confusion is understandable... the same thing happened to me - rising PSA but negative DRE and negative biopsy. I had been seeing the same urologist for twenty years, and when asked what to do next he said another biopsy. It seemed pointless to me. Then I heard about the MRI fusion biopsy. My uro said that required special training and his partner took over and yes it was cancer. My understanding is that the MRI fusion biopsy is fairly new and some insurance will not pay for it unless there has already been another previous biopsy (which you had). The traditional ultrasound guided biopsy uses ultrasound to locate the prostate but does not indicate varied densities within the prostate gland, which might suggest a tumor. With the MRI guided biopsy the surgeon can be guided directly to a suspicious region of the gland. In my case, only the lower right lobe was affected, but with an aggressive tumor. I don't want to frighten you, but this could possibly be your case as well. There are other ways your PSA could be elevated without the presence of a tumor, and it sounds like your uro is pursuing those. Getting another opinion from a different urologist is a good idea, though he may not find anything different. I lost a year between biopsies during which time the tumor spread, but fortunately not too far. In your case you say you have no other symptoms. In mine it was subtle. Up once every night around 4AM to pee which is not unusual at our age. I had reduced ejaculate but also thought maybe age. Just because the tests so far are negative doesn't necessarily mean there is nothing wrong. I guess all I can really say is you may become discouraged but don't give up. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Confused

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ANWANK ... he needs to go to urologist. His psa was 4.04. I started researching and thought that was not really high but we went earlier this week. Dr does another psa, dre and schedules a biopsy. DRE negative again and psa 4.1. He also said that his psa should not be over 2.5 at his age and typically should be about 0.7 or so. He recommended genetic testing. He stated that if his biopsy comes back negative he will submit to his insurance for an MRI guided biopsy. I guess I am slightly confused. I understand his family history plays a factor but with two negative dre,no symptoms, and slightly elevated psa, why does this urologist seem pretty confident that there is cancer? Has anyone here had a similar experience? Your doctor and the urologist are indeed doing a good job, and you are also fortunate that they are keeping you informed. Yes, I had somewhat of a similar experience, however my urologist kept me in the dark for a couple of years. Doctors are restricted in what they can do at various stages of diagnosis and treatment by standards of practice and even moreso by what the insurance companies will pay. Several years ago a gov't panel decided that PSA tests were resulting in too many men being "over treated". When my GP noted that my PSA was high for my age, he recommended that I see a urologist. The uro did a DRE which was "normal". In fact, every DRE was normal right up until the day four years later when my prostate was removed. You are fortunate that your doctor is recommending genetic testing and has informed you of the steps your fiance will go thru to be diagnosed and treated. I must also point out to you that if at any time you disagree with anything the doctor says then you always have the option of seeing another doctor (though may need insurance approval). Also he has the right to refuse ANY treatment he does not approve of. And of course, do your best to do your own research and educate yourself as much as you can, which apparently you are doing now. Good luck to you and your fiance, and hopefully in your lives together.

Posts.Title: Prostate biopsy this month

Posts.Content: Your confusion is understandable... the same thing happened to me - rising PSA but negative DRE and negative biopsy. I had been seeing the same urologist for twenty years, and when asked what to do next he said another biopsy. It seemed pointless to me. Then I heard about the MRI fusion biopsy. My uro said that required special training and his partner took over and yes it was cancer. My understanding is that the MRI fusion biopsy is fairly new and some insurance will not pay for it unless there has already been another previous biopsy (which you had). The traditional ultrasound guided biopsy uses ultrasound to locate the prostate but does not indicate varied densities within the prostate gland, which might suggest a tumor. With the MRI guided biopsy the surgeon can be guided directly to a suspicious region of the gland. In my case, only the lower right lobe was affected, but with an aggressive tumor. I don't want to frighten you, but this could possibly be your case as well. There are other ways your PSA could be elevated without the presence of a tumor, and it sounds like your uro is pursuing those. Getting another opinion from a different urologist is a good idea, though he may not find anything different. I lost a year between biopsies during which time the tumor spread, but fortunately not too far. In your case you say you have no other symptoms. In mine it was subtle. Up once every night around 4AM to pee which is not unusual at our age. I had reduced ejaculate but also thought maybe age. Just because the tests so far are negative doesn't necessarily mean there is nothing wrong. I guess all I can really say is you may become discouraged but don't give up. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Confused

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by po18guy Here is a doctor/researcher oriented video on the difficulties of T-Cell Lymphomas. Give it a brief watch and maybe ask her to watch with you. Look at the extreme depth of knowledge and the desire to control or eliminate these rare lymphomas. The jargon is very technical, but shows the profound efforts made by medical science in the effort to spare human life. These researchers hate cancer and live in the micro-cellular world in man's best attempt to eradicate it. http://www.oncologytube.com/video/ne...homas/10001079 Thanks, but first off I gotta say (and I'm sure you'll fix it) the video link is wrong... the text is correct if you copy and paste, but clicking on the link brings up a reply window. With that out of the way, I want to welcome you to the prostate forum. I know you've been here before as I've seen your replies to a few other posts. And of course I know you as moderator of the HL/NHL forum here. Interesting video. I enjoyed watching it as I have a deep appreciation for the seriousness and difficulty of the fight against cancer. I'm afraid if I show it to my wife the best I can hope is that it might make her feel fortunate to not have T-cell lymphoma. Worst case, well, she is one who feels that everything can be remedied with herbs and prayers, diet and exercise, essential oils, Reiki... I've seen it all. I have ordered the book and hope (and pray) that she will read it and maybe take it to heart. It says there is a Ken Burns documentary... I am slightly dyslexic and choose audio books if possible (it takes me forever to compose a post or reply here). Thanks for the reply and the links. I'm trying to work thru this.

Posts.Title: Saying "Hi" to all And A General Update

Posts.Content: John - It's good to hear that you survived the surgery and here's hoping the sling does for you what you need. I remember that fish hook sensation from some testicular surgery I had mentioned earlier. Good thing, for me anyway, was that it wasn't there all the time. But when it hit, man, did it make itself known! As I recall, I used a bag of frozen veggies on my scrotum, rotating on and off every 15 minutes. That seemed to help more than anything else. Not sure if your doc said anything about that. Also slept on the recliner a lot. About the AMS800, I got the "official" word a couple weeks ago that I am definitely NOT a candidate for the sling, and it looks like the AUS is definitely in my future. I've posted a couple times here in the PCa forum and got zero replies. I guess most of the other bros here haven't had to deal with these issues (or at least not among currently active members). I've been spending some time on the American Cancer Society Cancer Survivors Network as there seem to be more guys who have had surgeries related to incontinence. Main problems there are the board is not as easy to navigate as this one (cancerforums.net) and a lot of the posts are several years old. I post comments and no one ever replies (I guess there's a lot of that about). Regarding the comments by Jeb above (I hope you're doing okay if you're reading Jeb) I had the opportunity to "play" with an AMS800 and speak with a mfr's rep. The device is a lot smaller than I expected. Jeb's comment about two replacements in a lifetime is actually due to tissue erosion rather than mechanical failure. Also there is a 25% revision rate, mostly due to replacement and sizing issues, again rather than mechanical failure. The cuff "eats" 2cm of urethra over a decade, and generally they can relocate the cuff twice before running out of urethra. While they're in there, they just replace the unit anyway, as a ten year old device is more likely to actually fail. You mentioned in your first post above that the sling would likely take you back to the level of urgency you had prior to your RP. As I've never had the urgency (I can hold as long as I need to, just not forever!) I am trying to think of what that would be like. I guess you will still wear a pad in case you don't "make it?" Oh well, I suppose only time will tell. Do not ever look back and question your decision to have the surgery... that will only drive you crazy. You had to do something, and it's done, over. Good luck in your continued recovery! Be sure to come back and tell us how things have worked out.

Posts.Title: Male sling incontinence surgery

Posts.Content: Age 65 at RP. Dry nights at one month per norm. Never regained full continence (sorry, I know there are those who do not want to hear that..... I debated whether to respond at all). Gave up on pads altogether. Three months physical therapy (Kegel training). Relied mostly on condom catheters and leg bag, occasional full briefs. Salvage radiation postponed due to incontinence. Artificial sphincter implanted 5/15/17, revised 5/30, to be activated tomorrow (7/21). Rebuilding bladder capacity to 500-800ml. SRT to commence approx one month from now.

Posts.Title: Post RP incontinence survey

Posts.Content: Mike, congrats on the ultra-low PSA. I'm guessing you are not on any form of HT? If not then you are indeed fortunate! After my prostatectomy it was pretty much a given that I would need adjuvant radiation, and everything that followed was aimed at getting that underway... even though my PSA was low ("undetectable" by some measures, and .02-.03 by others). The T3B was what was always cited as justification. From what I've read it's 50/50 as to whether ART is actually necessary in such cases. I just wanted to get it over with. Since your PSA is so low I suppose the ball is up in the air. Good luck in your meeting with the doc next month. Mine was not very informative, but I just did what I was advised. I didn't do any shopping around, but did consider some alternatives and went with offices that were close to home rather than driving a couple hours a day in order to go to a "center of excellence" or whatever. I think it probably comes down to what you are comfortable with.

Posts.Title: Sor Far, So Good

Posts.Content: I just gotta say, as everyone's saying that non-metastatic prostate cancer does not cause any pain, I had "discomfort" that went on for several years. While not like what the OP has described, I frequently had a constant burning sensation in my urethra. The only time it didn't burn was while I was urinating, so I knew it was probably not a venereal disease. My urologist put me on Cipro and that took care of it. He explained the burning and the elevated PSA as likely due to prostatitis. The burning would eventually return and require longer and longer courses of Cipro to yield relief. Turns out eventually that it was indeed prostate cancer. I can't entirely blame him though. I was content to know that it certainly appeared that I did not have cancer. I would have rather known up front, but everything was pointing to something else... other than the steadily escalating PSA. Fate finally intervened when my Uro retired and his partner took over my case. By then I just wanted to get it over with. So he long and short of it is, at least in my case, there can be physical symptoms of PCa. And looking back to when my PSA began to rise and remembering how crummy I was feeling both physically and emotionally, I can tell now that there were more than just a few warning signs.

Posts.Title: Post RP incontinence survey

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate ... RP would likely be left for only the more "difficult" cases." During a recent conversation with another RP(+HT+ART) survivor, the topic of Cyberknife came up and my wife reminded me that I was not a candidate for CK. I'm glad she remembered hearing that as my "second set of ears". CK also has its ardent proponents, who tend to believe that it is "the only way to go". During ART I met and got to know several other guys who were undergoing EBRT/SBRT as primary therapy. Bowel disruption was a big problem for some, and even more so for me, who had fewer treatments than them, but experienced disturbing SE's throughout the course. I'm guessing that the "HDR/BT" which seems to be the current rage is probably also not without side effects. I would suspect that these are typically downplayed before going into treatment and quickly forgotten afterwards, especially by those who had it and advocate it for everyone without regard to individual pathology. Not everyone goes into this with a G(3+3).

Posts.Title: For Denis and Others trying to Decide on which Treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by IceStationZebra I had shoulder surgery once and they gave me something called Versed while I was waiting—not sure why—but I don’t remember anything from that point on despite having conversations with anesthesiologists and others. That is the purpose of administering Versed (usually with Fentanyl) pre-op is it blocks the formation of memories. So stuff happens, but you don't remember it... mainly, the pain. Been there many times myself. As for the TRUS biopsy and insurance... if it weren't for that, my cancer would have likely been discovered much sooner, and probably with a much better prognosis. Unfortunately, my urologist also never mentioned anything about this. Makes me mad just thinking about it. It seems to be so "penny wise and pound foolish". If they had been willing to pay for an inexpensive and painless MRI before my first prostate biopsy five years ago (this month!) then a simple RP probably would have eliminated the cancer before it had spread. But instead, there was much "adjuvant" therapy necessitated, at a high cost both to the healthcare system and to me in the way of lasting complications. It's just senseless. Especially since my latest Uro commented that it is nearly impossible to find tumors up near the bladder without an MRI.

Posts.Title: Why a TRUS biopsy is often NOT completely random

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ANWANK ... he needs to go to urologist. His psa was 4.04. I started researching and thought that was not really high but we went earlier this week. Dr does another psa, dre and schedules a biopsy. DRE negative again and psa 4.1. He also said that his psa should not be over 2.5 at his age and typically should be about 0.7 or so. He recommended genetic testing. He stated that if his biopsy comes back negative he will submit to his insurance for an MRI guided biopsy. I guess I am slightly confused. I understand his family history plays a factor but with two negative dre,no symptoms, and slightly elevated psa, why does this urologist seem pretty confident that there is cancer? Has anyone here had a similar experience? Your doctor and the urologist are indeed doing a good job, and you are also fortunate that they are keeping you informed. Yes, I had somewhat of a similar experience, however my urologist kept me in the dark for a couple of years. Doctors are restricted in what they can do at various stages of diagnosis and treatment by standards of practice and even moreso by what the insurance companies will pay. Several years ago a gov't panel decided that PSA tests were resulting in too many men being "over treated". When my GP noted that my PSA was high for my age, he recommended that I see a urologist. The uro did a DRE which was "normal". In fact, every DRE was normal right up until the day four years later when my prostate was removed. You are fortunate that your doctor is recommending genetic testing and has informed you of the steps your fiance will go thru to be diagnosed and treated. I must also point out to you that if at any time you disagree with anything the doctor says then you always have the option of seeing another doctor (though may need insurance approval). Also he has the right to refuse ANY treatment he does not approve of. And of course, do your best to do your own research and educate yourself as much as you can, which apparently you are doing now. Good luck to you and your fiance, and hopefully in your lives together.

Posts.Title: Lupron and libido

Posts.Content: John - I have not had that specific surgery, but have been advised that I may need an artificial sphincter - a different surgery. I am only five months post op and my RO says he has seen improvement up to ten months, so I am only halfway there. Problem is I have no urgency... I leak when I sneeze or pass gas, otherwise my urine just runs out of me and I am totally unaware of it... so much that pads or diapers are very impractical, and I tend to rely on an external or condom cath and leg bag. I see my Uro again in about ten days and hope to discuss options with him, as the therapist just keep saying more kegels, more kegels. I will ask my Uro if the sling is an option (honestly I haven't looked into it). The artificial sphincter would be a good fit in my case as I only have one testicle and the inflator bulb would take the place of the other one. I'll be watching this thread to see how you progress! As a former scout leader myself, I fully understand your concerns.

Posts.Title: Male sling incontinence surgery

Posts.Content: The AMS800 seems like a good solution, and once in place, repair or replacement is an hour long outpatient procedure. I'm facing the same "life span" limitations with my knee (workers comp injury). I understand your father-in-law... when you get to an age, there's so much that needs fixin' you just take care of the most critical first, and just live with what you can. I've measured my urine and weighed my pads (about 1/2 lb each) and go thru 8-12 a day. As I said, not very practical. The kegels just wear me out and I don't see much improvement. We also have two sons, around 30 now and both are great guys... maybe because of a good role model Sorry you have to deal with this at your age. Good luck with whatever happens.
Posts.Title: Male sling incontinence surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ANWANK ... he needs to go to urologist. His psa was 4.04. I started researching and thought that was not really high but we went earlier this week. Dr does another psa, dre and schedules a biopsy. DRE negative again and psa 4.1. He also said that his psa should not be over 2.5 at his age and typically should be about 0.7 or so. He recommended genetic testing. He stated that if his biopsy comes back negative he will submit to his insurance for an MRI guided biopsy. I guess I am slightly confused. I understand his family history plays a factor but with two negative dre,no symptoms, and slightly elevated psa, why does this urologist seem pretty confident that there is cancer? Has anyone here had a similar experience? Your doctor and the urologist are indeed doing a good job, and you are also fortunate that they are keeping you informed. Yes, I had somewhat of a similar experience, however my urologist kept me in the dark for a couple of years. Doctors are restricted in what they can do at various stages of diagnosis and treatment by standards of practice and even moreso by what the insurance companies will pay. Several years ago a gov't panel decided that PSA tests were resulting in too many men being "over treated". When my GP noted that my PSA was high for my age, he recommended that I see a urologist. The uro did a DRE which was "normal". In fact, every DRE was normal right up until the day four years later when my prostate was removed. You are fortunate that your doctor is recommending genetic testing and has informed you of the steps your fiance will go thru to be diagnosed and treated. I must also point out to you that if at any time you disagree with anything the doctor says then you always have the option of seeing another doctor (though may need insurance approval). Also he has the right to refuse ANY treatment he does not approve of. And of course, do your best to do your own research and educate yourself as much as you can, which apparently you are doing now. Good luck to you and your fiance, and hopefully in your lives together.

Posts.Title: Prostate biopsy this month

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate ... RP would likely be left for only the more "difficult" cases." During a recent conversation with another RP(+HT+ART) survivor, the topic of Cyberknife came up and my wife reminded me that I was not a candidate for CK. I'm glad she remembered hearing that as my "second set of ears". CK also has its ardent proponents, who tend to believe that it is "the only way to go". During ART I met and got to know several other guys who were undergoing EBRT/SBRT as primary therapy. Bowel disruption was a big problem for some, and even more so for me, who had fewer treatments than them, but experienced disturbing SE's throughout the course. I'm guessing that the "HDR/BT" which seems to be the current rage is probably also not without side effects. I would suspect that these are typically downplayed before going into treatment and quickly forgotten afterwards, especially by those who had it and advocate it for everyone without regard to individual pathology. Not everyone goes into this with a G(3+3).

Posts.Title: For Denis and Others trying to Decide on which Treatment

Posts.Content: HT with ART/SRT has become standard procedure nowadays, whether or not clinical recommendations are yet to be published. There have been enough studies to show that there is an advantage to concomitant HT with RT. What varies is the actual protocol. In a moderate risk situation such as your own, most likely it will be Lupron only for six months... two months before starting RT, two months during RT and two months afterwards. This is easily accomplished with a single six month depot shot. In cases of higher grade PCa or active mets, oral Casodex is administered for two weeks prior to the injection to minimize the Lupron "flare" which can exacerbate existing tumors. Also in higher grade cancers the HT may be extended to a total of 18 months. Prior standards went to 2 or 3 years, but recent evidence shows that 18 months is equally effective. Also, the radiation will continue to kill cancer cells for 8-9 months after treatment ends. If you do end up in the HT/RT boat, there are a number of us here who have been down the same path. So don't hesitate to ask questions. We've probably already been through it before you. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Looking for advice from any who have been through salvage radiation

Posts.Content: John - It's good to hear that you survived the surgery and here's hoping the sling does for you what you need. I remember that fish hook sensation from some testicular surgery I had mentioned earlier. Good thing, for me anyway, was that it wasn't there all the time. But when it hit, man, did it make itself known! As I recall, I used a bag of frozen veggies on my scrotum, rotating on and off every 15 minutes. That seemed to help more than anything else. Not sure if your doc said anything about that. Also slept on the recliner a lot. About the AMS800, I got the "official" word a couple weeks ago that I am definitely NOT a candidate for the sling, and it looks like the AUS is definitely in my future. I've posted a couple times here in the PCa forum and got zero replies. I guess most of the other bros here haven't had to deal with these issues (or at least not among currently active members). I've been spending some time on the American Cancer Society Cancer Survivors Network as there seem to be more guys who have had surgeries related to incontinence. Main problems there are the board is not as easy to navigate as this one (cancerforums.net) and a lot of the posts are several years old. I post comments and no one ever replies (I guess there's a lot of that about). Regarding the comments by Jeb above (I hope you're doing okay if you're reading Jeb) I had the opportunity to "play" with an AMS800 and speak with a mfr's rep. The device is a lot smaller than I expected. Jeb's comment about two replacements in a lifetime is actually due to tissue erosion rather than mechanical failure. Also there is a 25% revision rate, mostly due to replacement and sizing issues, again rather than mechanical failure. The cuff "eats" 2cm of urethra over a decade, and generally they can relocate the cuff twice before running out of urethra. While they're in there, they just replace the unit anyway, as a ten year old device is more likely to actually fail. You mentioned in your first post above that the sling would likely take you back to the level of urgency you had prior to your RP. As I've never had the urgency (I can hold as long as I need to, just not forever!) I am trying to think of what that would be like. I guess you will still wear a pad in case you don't "make it?" Oh well, I suppose only time will tell. Do not ever look back and question your decision to have the surgery... that will only drive you crazy. You had to do something, and it's done, over. Good luck in your continued recovery! Be sure to come back and tell us how things have worked out.

Posts.Content: I've been in Club Barrett's for a decade now, having endoscopies every two years. Always thought that it would be EC that would get me eventually, not PC. One year anniversary of RP at the end of this month. Had an early endoscopy a cpl months ago, as I start RT in ten days. Tried to fit in a colonoscopy also but all my docs said I was trying to do too much. Taking Nexium every morning since back when it was Rx. Fortunately one of only a few meds I take regularly. I've been told one in five cases of Barrett's becomes cancerous.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD I was diagnosed with Barrets 3 years ago and a month before my RP in May had a recheck. It was healed. I took pantoprazole for those 3 years. When I was diagnosed 3 years ago my doc told me only about 2-3% of Barrets becomes cancer. Looks like I was given some erroneous information. Wikipedia says: "The study found that every year, 0.12 percent of the Barrett's patients — or about one in 860 people — go on to develop cancer of the esophagus, a disease that is particularly lethal. The figure was much lower than the estimate of 0.5 percent stemming from earlier studies. The 0.5 figure was probably misread by the doctor who told me one in five. Dave - no side effects from long term use of Protonix? Of course, three years is a little different from ten years. Still, I'm wondering why my doctor had me on Prevacid and then Nexium, when Protonix might have worked better. It was never mentioned.

Posts.Title: Got the news yesterday, what now?

Posts.Content: Mike - Welcome back, and it has been a while! Looking back on your last posts and it was just after we got the all clear from my wife's oncologist and just before my AUS surgery, which didn't work out very well. Long story. Anyway, today the AUS was NOT activated, which was supposed to be the "big day". Long and short of it is, I'm still waiting to schedule my SRT, but hopefully it will still be within the 12 month window post-RP. So good luck with your own SRT. Do you have a target date yet? What I know about RT is just what I've read here, but I'm hoping to get some pointers from the RO at our next meeting in about a month. Isn't it a bite in the arse when you come out of surgery and are told, "great news! We got MOST of the cancer."

Posts.Title: Mike A Update

Posts.Content: Nothing is actually 100%. The advantage of surgery is that the prostate, seminal vesicles, lymph nodes and surrounding tissues can be removed (or sampled) and examined in a laboratory after the surgery to determine if the cancer has spread and if so to what extent. Gleason 9 indicates that one or more of the biopsy samples contained extensively deformed cells and very few normal cells. Such a cancer is likely quite aggressive and could easily spread, if it has not yet done so already. The cancer typically spreads 1) within the prostate capsule, 2) the surrounding tissues, 3) bone and finally 4) distant organs. Of course I am not by any means a professional. This is just from reading up on the topic. Like everyone here, we are all new to this. If you wish to know more your best authority is your doctor.

Posts.Content: They say that caregivers are angels but minus the wings. You are indeed a saint for what you have been thru and have certainly earned your halo. And yes, please do not forget to take care of yourself as well. Hang in there.
Posts.Title: Time, and then, always, progression.

Posts.Content: Greetings from another T3B'er. Medical marijuana is now legal where we live, but finding it is not easy. My wife recently overcame lymphoma and asked her Hemoncologist about CBD and MMJ. He advised against buying 'street' drugs because you don't know what else might be in it and it could interfere with her chemo. He said that he was not licensed to prescribe MMJ. We found a 'doctor' who does but never paid him a visit. It looked like it was going to be expensive and of course not covered by insurance (our co-pay last year was $10,000). We have purchased several bottles of CBD oil. I did not like the taste and it did nothing for me, but she used it for some time, then stopped. As far as pain relief, perhaps if I had bone mets I might think differently about it. Since I've had three abdominal surgeries in the past nine months and she had spinal, pelvic and cranial tumors, we both have a large collection of narcotics, anti-spasmotics, mood stabilizers and so on that are far more effective. She likes to get high sometimes now that she is done with chemo, and even though I spent probably a third of my life getting high, I no longer enjoy it. Occasionally someone in chat will ask about CBD oil and I refer them to the manufacturers website. We do have a lot of information between my wife and I on alternative treatments. But I strongly believe in traditional medicine. Her doctors have explained the importance of empirical evidence to us and I believe them. There is none that support any claims of efficacy for MMJ or CBD oil other than the relief of nausea and a perceived reduction of pain.

Posts.Title: PSA Recurrence & CBD Oil

Posts.Content: Well, you definitely have cancer, and you are fortunate that it was found on the first biopsy (though unfortunate that it struck you at a fairly young age). Good news is that if your pathology remains 3+4 then it has just recently begun to progress. Now is the time to strike, while it is in its infancy, so to speak. For someone still young, and assuming in good health, surgical prostatectomy is generally suggested as you have an excellent chance of full recovery, plus the prostate gland once removed can be dissected and thoroughly examined in a lab to determine the true extent of the cancer. If it perhaps may have begun to spread, which is unlikely for grade 3 but possible for grade 4, then you will still have the option of radiation treatment "down the road". If radiation is chosen as the first line treatment, that is generally no longer an option. Still you should speak with several specialists before making your decision. Good luck in you treatment and your recovery!

Posts.Title: Is TomoTherapy the same as Proton Therapy, Just Different Name?

Posts.Content: HT with ART/SRT has become standard procedure nowadays, whether or not clinical recommendations are yet to be published. There have been enough studies to show that there is an advantage to concomitant HT with RT. What varies is the actual protocol. In a moderate risk situation such as your own, most likely it will be Lupron only for six months... two months before starting RT, two months during RT and two months afterwards. This is easily accomplished with a single six month depot shot. In cases of higher grade PCa or active mets, oral Casodex is administered for two weeks prior to the injection to minimize the Lupron "flare" which can exacerbate existing tumors. Also in higher grade cancers the HT may be extended to a total of 18 months. Prior standards went to 2 or 3 years, but recent evidence shows that 18 months is equally effective. Also, the radiation will continue to kill cancer cells for 8-9 months after treatment ends. If you do end up in the HT/RT boat, there are a number of us here who have been down the same path. So don't hesitate to ask questions. We've probably already been through it before you. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Doc says time to do something.

Posts.Content: First let me extend an unwanted welcome to the cancer forums network. A few things that may not be immediately apparent. Yes, Gleason 8 is serious, and considered to be very high risk. And I do have a lot of personal experience with it. Because of the positive seminal vesicle invasion, your husband is at stage 3B, which is the last stage before stage 4 or distant metastasis. You were fortunate to have caught it when you did. The bone scan will hopefully rule out bone metastasis and the CT/PET scan any organ involvement. If that is the case, then his cancer remains very treatable. Of the three treatments mentioned above, I am currently in phase three (first surgery, then hormone therapy, and currently radiation). It will admittedly be difficult. Looking back, if I had to do this over again I would have investigated everything there is to learn about PCa (as you are doing now) and second, headed straight to a major cancer center, such as JH. But we don't get any do-overs. But I should reassure you that even though there is nothing wrong with changing to another doctor or treatment facility, your husband probably has every likelihood of being successfully treated locally. The doctor's cavalier attitude and remark about discussing the results over a drink were not to downplay the seriousness of this diagnosis, but to put you both at ease so that you can CALMLY make this very important decision. Your doctor sees this every day. On the other hand, this is your first (and hopefully only) cancer diagnosis, or at least prostate cancer. The urologist can be calm about it and speak of unemotionally, and he would prefer that you not make any decision in haste. And as Michael mentioned above, there is a necessary cooling off period following a biopsy before treatment can begin. Take a deep breath. Study as much as you can. Prepare a list of questions. Talk with others... you will be amazed at how many men in their sixties have or had prostate cancer.This is not to diminish your fear and anxiety, but please realize that many MANY men have been thru this. Some are even worse off, and many more had it much easier. In your husband's case, there will be many unknowns ahead of you, because G8 is not the best, but neither is it the worst. Good luck with everything!

Posts.Title: Signing off

Posts.Content: I would say that you have good reason to be concerned. It may indeed be nothing to be alarmed about, but as you said, it may become an entirely different situation a few years from now. Your PSA is rising rapidly, but urologists tend to be unconcerned about PSA alone. I suspect there was something left behind that your surgeon isn't going to own up to, so to speak. As Djin and Fairwind stated, you need to be speaking with a radiation oncologist now. Your urologists job is done, other than maybe checking your PSA now and then to measure your progress. Generally recurrence is declared when PSA reaches 0.2, though more recently they have been using 0.03 as the threshold. You are well beyond that now. And you are correct that scans will likely not detect anything at your low levels. In general, various types of scans have a minimum threshold PSA level necessary for detection: PET-PSMA = 0.6 ng/ml PET-F18 Flurocholine = 1.8 ng/ml PET- F18 (Axumin) = 2.0 MRI-Feraheme = 2.5 MRI-C11/F18 = 2.5 MRI-Ga = 10.0 Traditional CT = 20.0 Nuclear Bone scan = 30.0 As you can see, you would need a PSA of 2.0 for the majority of these, and your pre-op scan was probably the same nuclear bone scan that most of us had. Statistics show that radiation initiated within the first two years following RP usually has a better outcome than waiting to cross a BCR threshold.

Posts.Title: Not looking good one year on from RP

Posts.Content: Nothing is actually 100%. The advantage of surgery is that the prostate, seminal vesicles, lymph nodes and surrounding tissues can be removed (or sampled) and examined in a laboratory after the surgery to determine if the cancer has spread and if so to what extent. Gleason 9 indicates that one or more of the biopsy samples contained extensively deformed cells and very few normal cells. Such a cancer is likely quite aggressive and could easily spread, if it has not yet done so already. The cancer typically spreads 1) within the prostate capsule, 2) the surrounding tissues, 3) bone and finally 4) distant organs. Of course I am not by any means a professional. This is just from reading up on the topic. Like everyone here, we are all new to this. If you wish to know more your best authority is your doctor.

Posts.Title: Surgery success for Gleason 9

Posts.Content: There are two types of sutures, dissolving and permanent. Typically permanent suture is black and temporary is clear, like fishing line. They use permanent suture for heart surgery (valves and such). Dissolving suture is used for most other applications. I don't know which would be used for the urethra bladder union. Eventually scar tissue grows over the sutures.

Posts.Title: 2 months after DaVinci, back on Foley catheter again

Posts.Content: There are two types of sutures, dissolving and permanent. Typically permanent suture is black and temporary is clear, like fishing line. They use permanent suture for heart surgery (valves and such). Dissolving suture is used for most other applications. I don't know which would be used for the urethra bladder union. Eventually scar tissue grows over the sutures.

Posts.Title: 2 months after DaVinci, back on Foley catheter again

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by maxphunn I know my 6 weeks post-op PSA of 0.53 was bad enough, but was expecting the 10 week post-op PSA to be somewhat lower. It's not. My PSA is now 0.65! Now I don't know what to think. In all the books I read, have not seen anything about PSA this high and rising this soon after surgery. I know radiation is in my future and have an appointment next week with a radiation oncologist that specializes in PC. I like to be prepared for these meetings and have an understanding of what's happening with my PC and a list of questions before the meeting. But now I just don't know what I am in for. Can somebody give me an idea of what is happening please? This is the stage 3 part, and is likely the result of your positive margins noted in your sig. It's all there... "Staging is pT3/pN0 Extraprostatic extension present, nonfocal (established, extensive), right side Apical resection margin is bilaterally involved by invasive carcinoma Right and left seminal vesicles not involved by adenocarcinoma" As I understand it, the "extensive extraprostatic extension" part means that the cancer had spread outside your prostate capsule. Fortunately your lymph nodes and seminal vesicles were apparently not involved. I don't know how that actually causes your body to produce the PSA, but apparently it does. Here is a good article on extraprostatic extension http://www.harvardprostateknowledge....-prostatectomy ... The author states that 10-20% of RP patients have positive margins. I think you're handling it pretty well. You knew there would be radiation afterwards, and this is why. Similar situation for me. I too see my RO next week, and I have been afraid that my PSA might start to climb but have been lucky so far. You will pull thru this just fine. There are a few of us T3 guys here and they're all still posting. Keep your spirits up and remember that none of this is abnormal. If anything, the fact that your PSA has already begun to rise will likely mean that you will probably need to begin radiation sooner rather than later. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Time, and then, always, progression.

Posts.Content: Your friend should definitely have the cystoscopy. I'm guessing that there was excessive scar tissue at the remaining sphincter and the Foley was removed too early. Most guys do not have this problem following RALP, but I get the impression that his surgeon is blowing him off and not taking his condition seriously.
Posts.Title: Post RALP Inability to Urinate

Posts.Content: You sound upbeat and one would think that the Welbutrin would keep your moods stable. But I found out the hard way that cancer itself can affect your mood. For two years I was tired and irritable all the time. I'm curious, has your PSA been tested since your surgery? Could there be any residual cancer that may have escaped the prostate? Also, who prescribed the Welbutrin, and for what? Perhaps your meds need to be adjusted. Just having cancer can cause depression. I believe that if you believe there may be something wrong, then that is reason enough to have it investigated.

Posts.Title: Happy New Year, and some ED experiences

Posts.Content: I would say that you have good reason to be concerned. It may indeed be nothing to be alarmed about, but as you said, it may become an entirely different situation a few years from now. Your PSA is rising rapidly, but urologists tend to be unconcerned about PSA alone. I suspect there was something left behind that your surgeon isn't going to own up to, so to speak. As Djin and Fairwind stated, you need to be speaking with a radiation oncologist now. Your urologists job is done, other than maybe checking your PSA now and then to measure your progress. Generally recurrence is declared when PSA reaches 0.2, though more recently they have been using 0.03 as the threshold. You are well beyond that now. And you are correct that scans will likely not detect anything at your low levels. In general, various types of scans have a minimum threshold PSA level necessary for detection: PET-PSMA = 0.6 ng/ml PET-F18 Flurocholine = 1.8 ng/ml PET- F18 (Axumin) = 2.0 MRI-Feraheme = 2.5 MRI-C11/F18 = 2.5 MRI-Ga = 10.0 Traditional CT = 20.0 Nuclear Bone scan = 30.0 As you can see, you would need a PSA of 2.0 for the majority of these, and your pre-op scan was probably the same nuclear bone scan that most of us had. Statistics show that radiation initiated within the first two years following RP usually has a better outcome than waiting to cross a BCR threshold.

Posts.Title: First post, Just got the news......

Posts.Content: Yes, Tena does offer a trial pack with one each of three different absorbances at http://www.tena.us/mens-products/Men,en_US,sc.html The moderate absorbency ("three drops") guards are the most popular and for some reason are the cheapest at $10 per 48 count pack. The light "shields" (one drop) cost around a dollar each, which I don't understand why that is. I've never tried the heaviest or the ultra light. I tried Tena because a nurse when I had my prostatectomy said her husband uses them because they are the quietest ones and do not make swishing sounds when you walk. I had tried Depends and found they were way too bulky. Ultimately I landed upon maternity nursing pads from Amazon. They are $10 for a pack of 120, are highly absorbent and stick right where you want them in your shorts without creating a bulge in your pants, and they do not become lumpy.

Posts.Content: The bulb that keeps the catheter in holds a few ounces, therefore fills part of your bladder with fluid... so it feels like your bladder is a little full. The natural urge is to try to expel it. I remember going into the bathroom and standing in front of the toilet and thinking "okay, now what?". There's really nothing you can do about it. Caffeine and/or alcohol may make it feel worse. Just FYI... it seems to be all normal.

Posts.Content: Ron, thanks for checking in. It sounds like things are moving along about as well as can be expected, though I'm sure the met and nodes will always be a concern. Will you be continuing the Lupron after that last shot in December? You and I came here around the same time. My biopsy was a week before yours and I too just passed the two year mark. This past week was my first time NOT getting another six month shot, and I am anxiously waiting for the stuff to finally wear off over the next couple of years. I'm guessing you still have the option of SRT in the future if things go south, but hopefully you won't be needing that. God bless.

Posts.Title: 2 long years

Posts.Content: OTS - if I may, I suspect one of your "problems" is that you have entirely too much information! Granted, data collection and analysis is an important important step in any project, but in my experience, this is not just another project. My employers, and in most cases I worked directly for the CEO, COO or CFO, they relied upon my instinct and intuition... hunches, gut feelings, even more than my analytical skills. Among the best executives I worked with were those who were able to make quick decisions based upon limited information, and deal with the fallout later. And I suppose that's how it went with my cancer. I knew very little going in (as has been my entire life, it seems). I knew my PSA was high at 25, after a couple years of frequent testing. It was finally suggested that I should get an MRI. The uro interpreted the radiology report, suggesting that my PCa was contained but was near the capsule. I knew I only had months to act, and that I might need radiation after surgery. That's about it. Turns out the tumor had already invaded the capsule. Did that occur during the two months between biopsy and surgery? I don't know. In the months following surgery I learned quite a lot. I'm not sure that ANY of it would have altered my course of treatment. When I read of other guys who had PHI's and deciphers and pirads and all this other "information" to work with, it burns me up that my original Uro never offered anything other than Cipro. And even though my tumor consumed 25% of my prostate, he managed to miss it entirely. Makes me mad just thinking about it. But I did by necessity need to act swiftly. In addition, we had put our house on the market. Contracts had been signed. We were renovating our retirement condo a thousand miles away. My entire PCa debacle was but another annoyance that I had to deal with, and deal with quickly. Those who have the luxury of time often spend too much of it trying to calculate the odds in a game where you have little control and absolutely no foreknowledge of on which side of the coin you will ultimately land. From my post-op pathology it was shown that my greatest "tumor contact length" (though it wasn't called that) was 6mm. Yet the CA had invaded both seminal vesicles. Presumably had I waited much longer it would have been on its way to the lymphatic system, and the story would likely have an entirely different outcome. Sometimes you just gotta fly with the seat of your pants.

Be happy having confirmation every year that your PCa hasn't returned. Next month will be my first PSA test in six months - my first six month span in a long time. I was getting them every three months for something like five years before now. I am hoping to change Uro's eventually but once I'm clear I'll probably ask my GP to include PSA's in my annual exams, when they draw blood for everything else anyway.

Posts.Title: PSA forever post RALP?

Posts.Content: MM & mjimsr, your cases are different but have one thing big thing in common... you are considering elective surgery that will make a major change in something that you do all day, every day for the rest of your life. I am not trying to talk anyone out of getting the AUS, as I understand that the majority of recipients are totally satisfied with their implant, and I wish I were one of them. There are a number of guys with the AMS800 who post in other forums. Only a few had any problems. I thoroughly researched the AMS800 before having the surgery. It was a time of great anxiety. MM, I had forgotten about the radiation thing, but now I do remember my Uro informing me that it is better to have the device implanted before radiation rather than after. This was about 7 months after my RP and I was trying to schedule my adjuvant RT, and due to my severe incontinence, I needed the AUS in order to proceed with my next phase of treatment. I have spoken with several other guys who had the implant and one guy who'd had radiation before the surgery had his removed immediately. I think he said he would try again after further time to heal from the RT. Another guy told me his was not installed properly. That's pretty much what happened on my first attempt. He never tried again and now wears pads. Most others seems happy. Let's say you decide you are going to buy a pickup truck to drive to work (I've always owned a sedan or small wagon). I've never owned one but I'm guessing there are some tradeoffs that maybe you never thought of before making that decision, like where you can park it and how many passengers and how much luggage you can transport. And you can't magically turn it into a six passenger sedan when you need to. So with the AUS, you can't pee without squeezing the pump in your scrotum. Sounds simple, but this is EVERY TIME you have to pee. There's no way without doing that. Mjimsr, this is for you. I understand your need, but you're thinking of the horse and not the wagon. Plus there is a lot of discomfort involved. Simply sitting down becomes a different matter. When the cuff makes contact with a hard seat such as a bench, it causes a little squirt. Plus such seats become painful quickly. You end up squirming in your seat and ppl winder what's going on. My scrotum was tender for about the first year and finding a "numb" spot to squeeze became a challenge. Plus, in my case, when the surgeon replaced the original AUS with a new one, he somehow damaged a nerve, which causes some pain even sitting in some cushioned seats. And now, as some surgeons do, he seems to want nothing to do with me now, or at least not acknowledge in any way that his treatment was less than optimal. So I'm just saying that "it can happen". You MAY be buying a lemon, so to speak. The device itself is reliable, and the reason for having it routinely replaced is because the cuff eventually erodes the urethra, which requires another surgery, and while they're in there they just replace all the hardware. This is every 5-10 years, and each surgery carries its own risks. Mine just happened sooner than most. And eventually you run out of a viable space on your urethra to place the cuff. I'd love to write more and more, but there's a lot more material to cover than I can express here. This forum in particular, CFN, has no other AUS recipients that I know of. That's one reason why I was so stressed last year when I was making my decision. I found a few other forums with guys who have the AUS, and as I said, most are happy with theirs. So you probably stand to gain everything you hope for, but it won't be "cheap" in the form of physical, bodily costs. So not trying to discourage either of you, but just to make you aware that it's not a panacea. It's like anything else you buy... beforehand it seems like it will do everything you hoped for. But once you own it, you discover the flaws. I'm sure we'll be writing more about this in the future. Good luck, guys!

Good luck with the Zytiga, and as you say, keep the faith brother.

Posts.Title: Stage 4 now castration resistant

Posts.Content: MM, presumably by now you are in the doc's office or back from there. I did not want to present any "bad news" when you have your hopes up, but... You already know how well my AUS went, and I blame it all on choosing a younger surgeon rather than going with the older, arrogant, and likely more experienced guy. I had pressed my would-be surgeon for a number of how many of these he had done, but he evaded the question twice. That should have been a red flag, but I wanted to stay with his practice because their facilities are nearby and they might still be around when I'm 80. I was promised a 45 minute procedure, home that afternoon, and no catheter. Well, it was nothing like that. But eventually it did work, and I got my adjuvant radiation done. The AUS leaks and I must wear a pad at all times, and I sleep with a dry washcloth in my crotch... even when I need to get up in the middle of the night. If I don't, then sure enough, I either drip or sometimes even squirt. But, it is still better than going thru 8-10 wet pads every day. If I had it to do over again, I would still do it, but would do it differently. As for the implant, the whole things seems to me to be very bulky and awkward. If sex is REALLY important to you, then I guess you could put up with it. My wife is a nurse and says some of her patients had one and it was heavy and whenever the patient turned in bed it was like having a tail. I say "no way". I have enough hardware to manage already. The AUS's fittings sometimes pinch in my shorts.. I couldn't imagine having even more mechanical parts to deal with. I know you are a younger man, and in my case the testosterone is taking it's time coming back. I still don't feel a damn thing and wonder if and when I ever will again. With my wife and I both having had to deal with multiple cancers, we just consider ourselves fortunate to be alive and mobile. We still have great memories of the great sex we had for several decades, but life is telling us it's time to move beyond that. As I understand it, both implants can be done during the same surgery. But remembering how bruised up I was after the AUS and the residual nerve damage that I still have from that procedure, I'm glad I never considered an additional implant. Be sure you talk to other guys who have the pump up penis and get their take on it. I've heard they work well, but I'm sure there is a price to pay in the form of discomfort when you're NOT using it. Good luck John.

Posts.Title: Ultrasound guided prostate biopsy medicare coverage?

Posts.Content: Yes, Tena does offer a trial pack with one each of three different absorbances at http://www.tena.us/mens-products/Men,en_US,sc.html The moderate absorbency ("three drops") guards are the most popular and for some reason are the cheapest at $10 per 48 count pack. The light "shields" (one drop) cost around a dollar each, which I don't understand why that is. I've never tried the heaviest or the ultra light. I tried Tena because a nurse when I had my prostatectomy said her husband uses them because they are the quietest ones and do not make swishing sounds when you walk. I had tried Depends and found they were way too bulky. Ultimately I landed upon maternity nursing pads from Amazon. They are $10 for a pack of 120, are highly absorbent and stick right where you want them in your shorts without creating a bulge in your pants, and they do not become lumpy.

Posts.Title: Dribbling has increased

Posts.Content: The MRI is probably very important. My first biopsy also was negative. After two years my GP questioned me about the negative biopsy and I presented those questions to my Uro. My Uro then informed me that the MRI guided biopsy requires specialized training. Once my case was turned over to to another Uro, I was given the MRI and a fusion biopsy which identified the tumor in my prostate. I wish this had been done two years earlier, as I am certain I could have avoided a lot of complications from the cancer having spread and requiring more aggressive treatment. The fact that your Uro is willing to order additional tests is a good sign that he/they are taking your case seriously. I feel as though my Uro just blew off my case and left me up the creek. As for your login difficulties, many browsers today will as if you want it to store your login information. If you accept, then it will store this information and log you in automatically and even provide a means of looking up your username and password if the website has changed. I use this feature in Firefox routinely, but of course not for financial information (banking and credit cards). For that, there are various password keeping apps available for a small price... and well worth it!

Posts.Title: Dribbling has increased

Posts.Content: As has been mentioned, I think the perceived discrepancy in statistics can be attributed to just how big is the yardstick being used. The figure I've heard most is that one in twenty or 5% will have not regained continence within one year, with the average being six months... some enjoying immediate continence but more realistically three months, and most healing having occurred by 9-10 months. So just what is full continence? The guy who wears a pad because he may leak once a week probably balances out the guy who DOESN'T wear a pad because he only leaks once a week. Does the guy who has a headache or indigestion a couple times a month have a chronic condition, or is that just life? It's like trying to "grade your pain level" at the clinic... for some people everything is a 10. When my leg was crushed by a truck I called it a 4. There's a big difference in how continence statistics are reported as it is all subjective and anecdotal. And of course, the hysteria over incontinence and "overtreatment" that sent everyone running to radiation has guys disregarding the real risks (including incontinence) of RT, with the RO's downplaying or even refuting some serious SE's by merely stating that "some bowel disruption is the be expected". Unfortunately I've had a lot of experience with incontinence, but for anyone dropping in on this thread you should realize that my situation is not typical. Most guys who get RP seem to recover just fine. If you were like me, your ability to pee wasn't all that terrific before having RP, or RT for that matter. But I was in a bit of a time crunch and my treatments had to progress on to the next phase without a lot of time to enjoy a full recovery in between crises.
