Posts.Title: New QOL study has much higher RP incontinence percentages than I find elsewhere

Posts.Content: MM & mjimsr, your cases are different but have one thing big thing in common... you are considering elective surgery that will make a major change in something that you do all day, every day for the rest of your life. I am not trying to talk anyone out of getting the AUS, as I understand that the majority of recipients are totally satisfied with their implant, and I wish I were one of them. There are a number of guys with the AMS800 who post in other forums. Only a few had any problems. I thoroughly researched the AMS800 before having the surgery. It was a time of great anxiety. MM, I had forgotten about the radiation thing, but now I do remember my Uro informing me that it is better to have the device implanted before radiation rather than after. This was about 7 months after my RP and I was trying to schedule my adjuvant RT, and due to my severe incontinence, I needed the AUS in order to proceed with my next phase of treatment. I have spoken with several other guys who had the implant and one guy who'd had radiation before the surgery had his removed immediately. I think he said he would try again after further time to heal from the RT. Another guy told me his was not installed properly. That's pretty much what happened on my first attempt. He never tried again and now wears pads. Most others seems happy. Let's say you decide you are going to buy a pickup truck to drive to work (I've always owned a sedan or small wagon). I've never owned one but I'm guessing there are some tradeoffs that maybe you never thought of before making that decision, like where you can park it and how many passengers and how much luggage you can transport. And you can't magically turn it into a six passenger sedan when you need to. So with the AUS, you can't pee without squeezing the pump in your scrotum. Sounds simple, but this is EVERY TIME you have to pee. There's no way without doing that. Mjimsr, this is for you. I understand your need, but you're thinking of the horse and not the wagon. Plus there is a lot of discomfort involved. Simply sitting down becomes a different matter. When the cuff makes contact with a hard seat such as a bench, it causes a little squirt. Plus such seats become painful quickly. You end up squirming in your seat and ppl winder what's going on. My scrotum was tender for about the first year and finding a "numb" spot to squeeze became a challenge. Plus, in my case, when the surgeon replaced the original AUS with a new one, he somehow damaged a nerve, which causes some pain even sitting in some cushioned seats. And now, as some surgeons do, he seems to want nothing to do with me now, or at least not acknowledge in any way that his treatment was less than optimal. So I'm just saying that "it can happen". You MAY be buying a lemon, so to speak. The device itself is reliable, and the reason for having it routinely replaced is because the cuff eventually erodes the urethra, which requires another surgery, and while they're in there they just replace all the hardware. This is every 5-10 years, and each surgery carries its own risks. Mine just happened sooner than most. And eventually you run out of a viable space on your urethra to place the cuff. I'd love to write more and more, but there's a lot more material to cover than I can express here. This forum in particular, CFN, has no other AUS recipients that I know of. That's one reason why I was so stressed last year when I was making my decision. I found a few other forums with guys who have the AUS, and as I said, most are happy with theirs. So you probably stand to gain everything you hope for, but it won't be "cheap" in the form of physical, bodily costs. So not trying to discourage either of you, but just to make you aware that it's not a panacea. It's like anything else you buy... beforehand it seems like it will do everything you hoped for. But once you own it, you discover the flaws. I'm sure we'll be writing more about this in the future. Good luck, guys!

Posts.Title: Ultrasound guided prostate biopsy medicare coverage?

Posts.Content: I don't know under what conditions Medicare may pay for an MRI guided biopsy. Most commercial insurance requires an ultrasound biopsy first before paying for an MRI. Stupid, I know, but that's the way it is. In my case that policy allowed my cancer to grow to the point where it required much more aggressive - and expensive, treatment, much more than it would have been if they had allowed it to have been found sooner. And I am probably not the only case.

Posts.Title: 18 Month Milestone

Posts.Content: MM, presumably by now you are in the doc's office or back from there. I did not want to present any "bad news" when you have your hopes up, but... You already know how well my AUS went, and I blame it all on choosing a younger surgeon rather than going with the older, arrogant, and likely more experienced guy. I had pressed my would-be surgeon for a number of how many of these he had done, but he evaded the question twice. That should have been a red flag, but I wanted to stay with his practice because their facilities are nearby and they might still be around when I'm 80. I was promised a 45 minute procedure, home that afternoon, and no catheter. Well, it was nothing like that. But eventually it did work, and I got my adjuvant radiation done. The AUS leaks and I must wear a pad at all times, and I sleep with a dry washcloth in my crotch... even when I need to get up in the middle of the night. If I don't, then sure enough, I either drip or sometimes even squirt. But, it is still better than going thru 8-10 wet pads every day. If I had it to do over again, I would still do it, but would do it differently. As for the implant, the whole things seems to me to be very bulky and awkward. If sex is REALLY important to you, then I guess you could put up with it. My wife is a nurse and says some of her patients had one and it was heavy and whenever the patient turned in bed it was like having a tail. I say "no way". I have enough hardware to manage already. The AUS's fittings sometimes pinch in my shorts.. I couldn't imagine having even more mechanical parts to deal with. I know you are a younger man, and in my case the testosterone is taking it's time coming back. I still don't feel a damn thing and wonder if and when I ever will again. With my wife and I both having had to deal with multiple cancers, we just consider ourselves fortunate to be alive and mobile. We still have great memories of the great sex we had for several decades, but life is telling us it's time to move beyond that. As I understand it, both implants can be done during the same surgery. But remembering how bruised up I was after the AUS and the residual nerve damage that I still have from that procedure, I'm glad I never considered an additional implant. Be sure you talk to other guys who have the pump up penis and get their take on it. I've heard they work well, but I'm sure there is a price to pay in the form of discomfort when you're NOT using it. Good luck John.

Posts.Title: Continence and penile implant Appt

Posts.Content: David, welcome to CFN, and good luck with your remaining RT treatments! You may be pleased to know that I just had my third post-trifecta checkup with my Uro (RP+HT+RT) and he informed me that T3B's who undergo the trifecta are the least likely to ever experience future recurrence, compared to those who go with RP or RT+HT alone. I know it is not an easy decision deciding which way to go, but it was my choice to throw everything at the beast and it appears at least for now that I have won. I am assuming that you regained continence quickly as you went into RT in just four months post-op. And I'm curious if you are also on HT. Many RO's now include HT with adjuvant radiation. Be sure to read the sticky in the blue area at the top of the main page on "what to expect from EBRT". There are potential side effects but many can be controlled thru using a modified diet (and no, it's NOT all veggies!) Good luck to you going forward and we're all hoping you can soon join me here in the 0.0 PSA club.

Posts.Title: 9 month post-surgery update

Posts.Content: Thirty minutes with a doctor is a lot. I'm lucky to get ten. I tend to NOT take my wife anymore because she wastes a lot of time asking questions about his family and such. She sees it as being friendly and caring. I see it as wasting valuable time. My GP sent me to a Uro when my PSA hit 4 at age 61. The Uro dismissed it as insignificant. But he did eventually become concerned when it was 9.5 one year later, did a biopsy, then told me all my tests were negative. So I'd say your GP did nothing wrong.

Posts.Title: Psa rising hormone therapy not working very concerned

Posts.Content: Yesterday was my 35th ART treatments using the RapidArc, and also had my final meeting with my RO. I now have only four more treatments to go! We discussed how long I should remain on Lupron and between the two of us concluded 18 months total. I asked if 2 years would be preferable and he said no, that it could reduce the efficacy of HT in the event of a future recurrence. He also said we could stop at one year if I was not tolerating it well, and I said I can do another six months okay. Note this is just Lupron, no Casodex. My only other meds are Venlafaxine and Gabapentin for the hot flashes and mood swings. Additionally he informed me that the radiation will continue to kill cancer cells for about another nine more months after RT ends, so another nine months of HT (when my next shot will wear off) will nicely cross over with the curve of the RT's effective life. It seems like a good plan. Also he said that my testosterone should return around nine months after the Lupron wears off. Also we will not know for sure whether or not all this has worked until after three consecutive PSA tests after everything has ended, worn off, and stabilized... so we're looking at 2019 (yes, 2019) before we know for sure. It's going to be a long 18 months, which will bring my struggle to a total of five years since my first biopsy. We will be glad when all this is over with. BTW Lori has her first six month CT in a couple of weeks, and she is currently in the throes of 'scanxiety'. We still discuss which of us might outlive the other. It is a necessary discussion, to keep things real. But after dealing with two cancers, a hurricane, a bat infestation and renovating two homes, I think I can handle another 18 months of watchful waiting. We're just looking forward to a time when we might go an entire month without one of us undergoing some form of treatment.

Posts.Title: Psa rising hormone therapy not working very concerned

Posts.Content: I'm just about five years behind you, Jim.... 66 years old, prostate removed last year, and was originally supposed to begin salvage radiation next month because the cancer had already begun to spread beyond the prostate. However, I still have very little bladder control PLUS I need to drive my wife to all-day chemo four times a month. The radiation will halt any continence healing and requires treatment every day for two months (essentially). So the SRT has been postponed for now until 1) I get some bladder control and 2) my wife ends her chemo. I've had one meeting with the radiation oncologist and will see him in a couple weeks. As I understand, you (or I) need to show up every weekday with an empty bowel and full bladder. I'm guessing the empty bowel part is what requires the 'prep' mentioned above. And without bladder control, mine won't be full upon arrival. As far as side effects, the only one I've heard others mention is fatigue. Some who had treatment in earlier years experienced bowel changes, but that may have been before the procedure had improved. Once you've seen your RO and I have seen mine, maybe we can compare notes. Mine says it is best to get started on RT before the PSA begins to rise. He also says hormone therapy administered along with RT has demonstrated superior results, so he started me on that last month to prevent the PSA from rising. My next PSA is in about ten days. So far it has remained low. At your age, I don't know to say. I do know a guy now 82 who underwent RP plus SRT when he was around my age and says everything went well. I'm sure other guys with more experience under their belt will chime in here. Good luck, Jim!

Posts.Title: Psa rising hormone therapy not working very concerned

Posts.Content: Ouch! LN invasion is bad, anything near a major artery is especially worrisome. I'm guessing your were stage T3a and may have had a (R1) positive margin. You might want to confirm that. It's surprising that none of this was picked up post-op, as it's only been 14 months now. I would think that since your PSA was rising... granted slowly, but consistently, that your Uro should have had you consult a RO sooner. If your situation is as bad as it sounds, you will likely be dealing exclusively with the MO and not the RO. Just my guess. What a terrible thing to happen with such favorable post-op pathology. Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Bad news today

Posts.Content: OTS - if I may, I suspect one of your "problems" is that you have entirely too much information! Granted, data collection and analysis is an important important step in any project, but in my experience, this is not just another project. My employers, and in most cases I worked directly for the CEO, COO or CFO, they relied upon my instinct and intuition... hunches, gut feelings, even more than my analytical skills. Among the best executives I worked with were those who were able to make quick decisions based upon limited information, and deal with the fallout later. And I suppose that's how it went with my cancer. I knew very little going in (as has been my entire life, it seems). I knew my PSA was high at 25, after a couple years of frequent testing. It was finally suggested that I should get an MRI. The uro interpreted the radiology report, suggesting that my PCa was contained but was near the capsule. I knew I only had months to act, and that I might need radiation after surgery. That's about it. Turns out the tumor had already invaded the capsule. Did that occur during the two months between biopsy and surgery? I don't know. In the months following surgery I learned quite a lot. I'm not sure that ANY of it would have altered my course of treatment. When I read of other guys who had PHI's and deciphers and pirads and all this other "information" to work with, it burns me up that my original Uro never offered anything other than Cipro. And even though my tumor consumed 25% of my prostate, he managed to miss it entirely. Makes me mad just thinking about it. But I did by necessity need to act swiftly. In addition, we had put our house on the market. Contracts had been signed. We were renovating our retirement condo a thousand miles away. My entire PCa debacle was but another annoyance that I had to deal with, and deal with quickly. Those who have the luxury of time often spend too much of it trying to calculate the odds in a game where you have little control and absolutely no foreknowledge of on which side of the coin you will ultimately land. From my post-op pathology it was shown that my greatest "tumor contact length" (though it wasn't called that) was 6mm. Yet the CA had invaded both seminal vesicles. Presumably had I waited much longer it would have been on its way to the lymphatic system, and the story would likely have an entirely different outcome. Sometimes you just gotta fly with the seat of your pants.

Posts.Title: Biopsy 2nd opinion and Extra Capsular Extension

Posts.Content: Just a couple quick notes... PNI is frequently found in the lab following gland removal, so it is not at all uncommon. Sometimes it is discovered upon biopsy if one of the needle pokes happens to hit one of the nerves. It's like everything else involved in the initial TRUS biopsy... you're lucky if the needle happens to hit one of the tumors, even luckier if it happens to be one of the higher grade tumors. Worst case is the needle totally misses everything and your doctor tells you that your biopsy was negative. Then you spend the next year or two believing that you do not have cancer. Which brings me to the second point. One of his samples had a primary grade 4 component. This is far worse then a G7 that was (3+4), with the grade 4 component being secondary. Grade 4 is the type of cancer that spreads outside of the prostate into the pelvic cavity. Generally it is not as bad as grade 5 which quickly progresses beyond the prostate area and spreads into the lymphatic system or metastasizes into bones. So you are fortunate that it is "only" 4, but you are right to act soon. It is not "urgent", but if treatment is delayed while you "research other options" it can quickly escalate to a higher level. If he does have surgery, the prostate will be thoroughly examined by a pathologist and the true extent of the disease will be well known. If there is residual cancer, then follow-up or adjuvant treatment is warranted... hormone deprivation therapy and adjuvant radiation. Several of us here have been thru that. The combination is a difficult course to get thru, but generally results in the least likelihood of recurrence in later years. It is important to consider other treatments, but choosing radiation first introduces additional complications. Primary radiation has its strong advocates, even zealots. They will no doubt tell you how superior it is to having surgery, while downplaying any of the side effects. Just be aware. And good luck!

Posts.Title: 9 month post-surgery update

Posts.Content: Ouch! LN invasion is bad, anything near a major artery is especially worrisome. I'm guessing your were stage T3a and may have had a (R1) positive margin. You might want to confirm that. It's surprising that none of this was picked up post-op, as it's only been 14 months now. I would think that since your PSA was rising... granted slowly, but consistently, that your Uro should have had you consult a RO sooner. If your situation is as bad as it sounds, you will likely be dealing exclusively with the MO and not the RO. Just my guess. What a terrible thing to happen with such favorable post-op pathology. Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: 9 month post-surgery update

Posts.Content: David, welcome to CFN, and good luck with your remaining RT treatments! You may be pleased to know that I just had my third post-trifecta checkup with my Uro (RP+HT+RT) and he informed me that T3B's who undergo the trifecta are the least likely to ever experience future recurrence, compared to those who go with RP or RT+HT alone. I know it is not an easy decision deciding which way to go, but it was my choice to throw everything at the beast and it appears at least for now that I have won. I am assuming that you regained continence quickly as you went into RT in just four months post-op. And I'm curious if you are also on HT. Many RO's now include HT with adjuvant radiation. Be sure to read the sticky in the blue area at the top of the main page on "what to expect from EBRT". There are potential side effects but many can be controlled thru using a modified diet (and no, it's NOT all veggies!) Good luck to you going forward and we're all hoping you can soon join me here in the 0.0 PSA club.

Posts.Title: 8 month post surgery, still in the zero club

Posts.Content: Yup, you made the decision, now just go with it. I'll be watching for your updates in THIS THREAD. I know what you mean about the feeling of detachment. That happens with big institutions. Regarding supplements, I stopped anything with high levels of antioxidants and began taking Walmart's generic version of Centrum silver. It is my understanding (from reading forums) that the "free radicals" are what kills the cancer cells, and antioxidants would counteract that. Just to be safe. My RO said the radiation would continue to work for three months after the completion of RT, so I stayed off the expensive supplements during that period. When I tried to go back to my usual Twinlab vitamins, they made me feel weird. I may try again after my current bottle of generics runs out. But oddly, I have not felt any worse without the high priced vitamins. The greatest problem I encountered with RT was dietary. I chronicled this for a while in the EBRT sticky here on CFN. I still have problems with onions, which I had never had a problem with before. Also I still have to limit my intake of fruits and veggies... limit them to single servings. Never a problem before RT, but now I think this may all may be due to the carcinoid tumor that was discovered in my small bowel last month. BTW I have two days of 90 minute scans this week (ugh!). Surgery had been scheduled for next Monday, but I cancelled that for the time being, to let Moffitt do their thing. Hopefully when you are through with your thing and I am through with mine, we may get together sometime when you are down here. Good luck with your treatments!

Posts.Title: Jeff's post op thread.

Posts.Content: The T3a simply means that the cancer has spread outside the prostate (your positive margins and extracapsular extension). Typically this is treated with eight weeks of daily radiation starting a few months after surgery. This is why many guys choose surgery first over radiation first, because then post op radiation is still an option. The fly in the ointment is that radiation halts all healing process and therefore there would be no further improvement in both ED or incontinence once it starts. In my case, I was supposed to start radiation next month (six months post op) but the RO has delayed that because I still have little bladder control and have not had an erection of any form since the surgery (sorry for the bad news). Instead he has started me on hormone therapy until I hit ten months. He said typically there is little improvement in continence after ten months, so that is when I will begin RT. Good thing, because I have to drive my wife to two all day chemos twice a month, and she should be done with that before my rad starts. Good luck working on the incontinence. It is a slow process. You will probably start having dry nights, if you haven't already. For me, nights are better than before the surgery. Most guys only have leaking when standing. It is annoying but just be prepared for it to go on for a while. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Last winter I was merrily winding my way thru this maze of prostate cancer treatment and terminology when my wife's nagging back pain finally came to a head. After much persistence and a lot of rejectionism, we finally paid cash for a couple MRI's that revealed a spinal tumor. The doctor's said they could see her next month. Another week passed and I finally drove her to the ER. That was another "night of terror". Some of you who have been reading my postings may remember what I was going thru at the time. The Lupron didn't help that either. Rather than repeat everything here, I've posted a brief wrap-up of her prognosis and what's next for us in the Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma Forum here: Chemo-is-over-final-LP-is-done! Thanks everyone for putting up with me. I fell like a tremendous weight has been lifted from us, and now it's time for my wife and I to enjoy each other's company for a while.

Posts.Content: Just a couple quick notes... PNI is frequently found in the lab following gland removal, so it is not at all uncommon. Sometimes it is discovered upon biopsy if one of the needle pokes happens to hit one of the nerves. It's like everything else involved in the initial TRUS biopsy... you're lucky if the needle happens to hit one of the tumors, even luckier if it happens to be one of the higher grade tumors. Worst case is the needle totally misses everything and your doctor tells you that your biopsy was negative. Then you spend the next year or two believing that you do not have cancer. Which brings me to the second point. One of his samples had a primary grade 4 component. This is far worse then a G7 that was (3+4), with the grade 4 component being secondary. Grade 4 is the type of cancer that spreads outside of the prostate into the pelvic cavity. Generally it is not as bad as grade 5 which quickly progresses beyond the prostate area and spreads into the lymphatic system or metastasizes into bones. So you are fortunate that it is "only" 4, but you are right to act soon. It is not "urgent", but if treatment is delayed while you "research other options" it can quickly escalate to a higher level. If he does have surgery, the prostate will be thoroughly examined by a pathologist and the true extent of the disease will be well known. If there is residual cancer, then follow-up or adjuvant treatment is warranted... hormone deprivation therapy and adjuvant radiation. Several of us here have been thru that. The combination is a difficult course to get thru, but generally results in the least likelihood of recurrence in later years. It is important to consider other treatments, but choosing radiation first introduces additional complications. Primary radiation has its strong advocates, even zealots. They will no doubt tell you how superior it is to having surgery, while downplaying any of the side effects. Just be aware. And good luck!

Posts.Title: Pretty Amazed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wbigs When I was talking to my urologist about surgery options he noticed from my record that I have had previous hernia surgery and kind of grimaced and asked if there was a bunch of mesh in there. I asked if that would be a problem and he brushed if off and said that it can just be a bit more tricky. Has anybody else heard this or had any experience with it? Its been something that been stuck in my head for the last couple of days. I had a hernia repair over thirty years ago on the same side as the prostate cancer, plus a bowel resection some time later and the Urologist noticed the two scars (which form an inverted arrow head on my abdomen). He made no mention of them when he examined my belly, only stated that he had to make sure there was a "way in". And both surgeries are prominent in my chart as the pre-op staff verified them during my admission. I was concerned after the RP because of the six new incisions, only one was painful and still is, and it is midway between my two previous scars. And the pain is very similar to the pain that led me to seek treatment back circa 1980. Today at my cath removal visit I mentioned to the Urologist about the pain of that one incision and he stated that "that one will pull more than the others". I briefly told him of my earlier experience and he just re-stated the pull more than others line. I'm guessing either that the prior surgeries presented no additional obstacles to his surgery, or at least nothing he was not prepared to address at the time. I still have concerns about the pain on my right side, as I cannot turn onto my right side and when I try to bend over only the right side hurts. But this is only like nine days post-op so I'll give my body more time to heal before I really start to worry. But yeah, stuff like that can get stuck in your head. Remember that your Uro is a professional and has trained to deal with numerous various scenarios. Have faith and hopefully everything will go perfectly for you.

Posts.Content: Thirty minutes with a doctor is a lot. I'm lucky to get ten. I tend to NOT take my wife anymore because she wastes a lot of time asking questions about his family and such. She sees it as being friendly and caring. I see it as wasting valuable time. My GP sent me to a Uro when my PSA hit 4 at age 61. The Uro dismissed it as insignificant. But he did eventually become concerned when it was 9.5 one year later, did a biopsy, then told me all my tests were negative. So I'd say your GP did nothing wrong.

Posts.Content: Yup, you made the decision, now just go with it. I'll be watching for your updates in THIS THREAD. I know what you mean about the feeling of detachment. That happens with big institutions. Regarding supplements, I stopped anything with high levels of antioxidants and began taking Walmart's generic version of Centrum silver. It is my understanding (from reading forums) that the "free radicals" are what kills the cancer cells, and antioxidants would counteract that. Just to be safe. My RO said the radiation would continue to work for three months after the completion of RT, so I stayed off the expensive supplements during that period. When I tried to go back to my usual Twinlab vitamins, they made me feel weird. I may try again after my current bottle of generics runs out. But oddly, I have not felt any worse without the high priced vitamins. The greatest problem I encountered with RT was dietary. I chronicled this for a while in the EBRT sticky here on CFN. I still have problems with onions, which I had never had a problem with before. Also I still have to limit my intake of fruits and veggies... limit them to single servings. Never a problem before RT, but now I think this may all may be due to the carcinoid tumor that was discovered in my small bowel last month. BTW I have two days of 90 minute scans this week (ugh!). Surgery had been scheduled for next Monday, but I cancelled that for the time being, to let Moffitt do their thing. Hopefully when you are through with your thing and I am through with mine, we may get together sometime when you are down here. Good luck with your treatments!

Posts.Content: Tink - I was trying to compose a response in my head, then headed over to CSN and saw your same post there. Vasco has given you some extremely valuable information there. Personally I would still be inclined toward surgery, which will most likely then lead to more HT plus some form of adjuvant RT. Your Dad has already been thru the urinary issues, and at his age ED likely not a concern. Surgery will allow a thorough examination of the prostate and surrounding tissues to determine exactly what is going on in there. All this assuming he is physically fit for surgery, and the current HT has not made the RP too difficult. As far as which doctor, there is a definite quandary here. An arrogant surgeon with a terrible bedside manner seems scary, but may be the best available choice... unless you want to go shopping for another Uro. You do want a highly experienced and confident surgeon. His presumptions going in (stage 4, 5 years, etc) will basically be irrelevant once his hands get onto or into your father. He becomes just a professional doing the job put before him. Once the surgeon is done, the RO's job begins. Choices regarding HT and RT can be determined once your Dad has recovered from the surgery. If his cancer is indeed as advanced as some feel it may be now, then concerns over incontinence and ED become irrelevant, and a medical oncologist should take over. As regards to Moffitt... I dunno. I called them to see how soon they could fit me in just in case things here in Clearwater went south. They were very professional, but for me that would be an hour each way, and I stayed with the local guy. One patient in my group (our time slot under the zapper) drives over from Winter Haven, which is over near Orlando, just to see this guy, so I figure he must be pretty good. But then you already have RO's to choose from. My wife's hemo-oncologist was from Moffitt and did a good job but even her treatment was not without hiccups as well. One never knows going into these things.

Posts.Title: 4 opinions and still unsure

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by CrystalSnow -Biopsy: Prostate, right: Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4 + 3 = 7 (Gleason grade group 3), involving 3 core fragments and approximately 5% of submitted tissue. Prostate, left: Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4 + 3 = 7 (Gleason grade group 3), involving 5 core fragments and approximately 65% of submitted tissue... 3) Any thoughts on why prostate cancer with a Gleason score of only 7 (and incomplete involvement) has already metastasized so far throughout his body? From what I understand, this seems unusual, and might be further cause for fighting to see a top specialist who 'has seen it all.' The G7 as Chuck pointed out is predominantly grade 4 of the biopsy tissues. Only about one third of the prostate is visible to biopsy, so there is a strong possibility (especially given the high PSA) that there are additional tissues harboring more grade 4 and possibly even grade 5 tumors... for example 4+5. Additionally the higher grade tumor(s) may be located near the capsule border and evidently have already penetrated. The biopsy allows only a peek into the nature of the prostate tissues. In a less severe case, the patient... especially one as young as your step father, might opt for prostatectomy, in which case the entire prostate would then be dissected and analyzed in a pathology lab, revealing the true extent of the cancer.

Posts.Title: Recent Stage IV Diagnosis

Posts.Content: This past week saw the first anniversary of the fusion biopsy that found my tumor and the phone call I got on July 5th informing me that I have cancer... the first time that word had ever been mentioned to me. And it was also the ten month anniversary of my RP. We had planned to fly back to Ohio and rent a van to finally drive back the stuff we had left in a storage locker when we moved. Actually that was originally supposed to happen last December, but that ended up being the week that my wife had the MRI that revealed her spinal tumor, which led to her lymphoma diagnosis. This time the AUS surgery required revision, which set the entire calendar back (seems it's always something) so we just flew up and back, staying with my sister for a week, and had a nice family reunion... what's left of it anyway. So I decided that would be a good opportunity to visit the surgeon who did my biopsy and RP and fill him in on what has happened... tell him about Lori's lymphoma as they used to work together, and get his take on the AUS. He examined it and said everything seemed good. About the pain in my leg he said maybe a nerve got snagged while my feet were in the stirrups. About the revision and my surgeon's remark that it had never happened to him before, he said if a surgeon does enough of those that eventually it will happen. And about the incontinence he stated that is always a risk when using the "broad cut", saying that a lot of nerve tissue had been removed and re-emphasized that I had negative nodes and negative margins. I told him I felt he had done a great job and I wish he were still my doctor. I asked him for more info about my SVI, as I have read that there are different forms, referred to as direct vs distal or "mucosal" and he said he didn't know about that, but that my seminal vesicles were definitely involved. Finally I gave him my upcoming schedule regarding AUS activation, starting SRT and my next Lupron shot. Then he dropped the bombshell that I would likely be on Lupron for three years! I had always assumed that I would be on HT possibly for a year after SRT, but not two. I do see my RO next week to hopefully set up our SRT schedule so I will definitely ask him about that. For those who have been thru SRT, what were you told? Or were you? So big month ahead... RO visit #3, Lupron shot #2, AUS activation and Lori's three month in-remission checkup with her hemoncologist. Hoping for the best, as they say.

Posts.Title: Hi all First post

Posts.Content: Ditto on what MichiganMan said. If you're T3b with SVI that puts you into the very high risk category. The first link provided by Djin leads to a discussion from just a few months ago... actually my post right after Djin's is where we get into the risk categories. This is one treatment protocol that I did not question at all. In fact I spent the first year post RP preparing for ART. Immediately following my RP I was informed that I would need ART, and my RO was quite insistent that it was very important. Also, my PSA a month after RP was declared "undetectable", which to my surgeon's standards meant that it was <.1 ... That wasn't good enough for me, nor for my Uro. Subsequent PSA's were run using ultrasensitive and was always .02 - .03 for the subsequent months, including the time while on HT. It turned out that this lab used <.02 as the cutoff for undetectable, so I kind of get the feeling that the term undetectable doesn't mean much anymore. Nor does the term "zero". My latest PSA is 0.00, and I'm still a bit skeptical. I want to know if it was somewhere between 0.001 and 0.005 and was rounded down to "zero". I think what I've read is that 50% of T3b's may be overtreated, meaning they didn't really need RT. But how can you be sure that you fall into that 50% or the other 50% that ultimately would have required treatment. All studies point to earlier radiation is better than waiting for a PSA threshold. Regarding SRT without prior adverse pathology, even the "three consecutive rises" in PSA is useless if they don't test at least every three months.

Posts.Title: Zero Club Membership Renewed - SRT Question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Livinit I had Da Vinci prostatectomy in 2008. All ok but for the incontinence. Glad to hear all is okay since your RP. I assume that means consistently low PSA's over the past ten years... that's pretty awesome. Big congratulations are in order. I too went with Tena. They were recommended by a nurse at the hospital following my RP. She said her husband uses them because they are quieter and less bulky than Depends. I gave away all my Depends and CVS pads and get the Tena from Amazon for around the same price as those Walmart pads, though I may give those a try. Thanks for the link. Finding the right pad is not easy. Too light and I need to change too often, too bulky and they bulge out and stay wet. The selection on store shelves is limited. My pad usage has been steadily increasing. The AUS seems to be getting looser and I need to discuss this with my Uro... not looking forward to that, as he had to replace it once already.

Posts.Content: Hopefully not striking additional fear into you, but my wife had worsening pain in her back and pelvis for nearly a year and it was dismissed by the doctors. Eventually we paid $700 cash for an MRI and she was finally diagnosed with lymphoma. Not sure if that's any better than prostate cancer, but she was treated and is in remission. We were told that the form she had is very rare.

Posts.Title: Two Year Update

Posts.Content: Hi, and welcome to the "horses have left the barn" club. Our cases are not dissimilar, as you can tell by my sig below. I had radiation a full year after RP and was told I would be on HT for one to three years. Research I did showed a 50/50 chance of recurrence if I declined adjuvant Tx and an 85% likelihood of 10 year survival if I went thru with it. There were complications that delayed my treatment, but in the end it appears to have all worked out. I know another man who is now 82 and had RP+RT fifteen years ago, when he was my age, and his PSA is still zero. So if you go ahead with the recommended post-op treatments, you will most likely live to die of something else (okay, I know that's not comforting). BTW the new "standard" duration for adjuvant HT is 18 months. Living with ADT is tough, but not devastating. Metastasis is devastating, so I chose to throw everything possible at my PCa. Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: This past week saw the first anniversary of the fusion biopsy that found my tumor and the phone call I got on July 5th informing me that I have cancer... the first time that word had ever been mentioned to me. And it was also the ten month anniversary of my RP. We had planned to fly back to Ohio and rent a van to finally drive back the stuff we had left in a storage locker when we moved. Actually that was originally supposed to happen last December, but that ended up being the week that my wife had the MRI that revealed her spinal tumor, which led to her lymphoma diagnosis. This time the AUS surgery required revision, which set the entire calendar back (seems it's always something) so we just flew up and back, staying with my sister for a week, and had a nice family reunion... what's left of it anyway. So I decided that would be a good opportunity to visit the surgeon who did my biopsy and RP and fill him in on what has happened... tell him about Lori's lymphoma as they used to work together, and get his take on the AUS. He examined it and said everything seemed good. About the pain in my leg he said maybe a nerve got snagged while my feet were in the stirrups. About the revision and my surgeon's remark that it had never happened to him before, he said if a surgeon does enough of those that eventually it will happen. Finally I gave him my upcoming schedule regarding AUS activation, starting SRT and my next Lupron shot. Then he dropped the bombshell that I would likely be on Lupron for three years! I had always assumed that I would be on HT possibly for a year after SRT, but not two. I do see my RO next week to hopefully set up our SRT schedule so I will definitely ask him about that. For those who have been thru SRT, what were you told? Or were you? So big month ahead... RO visit #3, Lupron shot #2, AUS activation and Lori's three month in-remission checkup with her hemoncologist. Hoping for the best, as they say.

Posts.Title: 10/12 month anniversary & update

Posts.Content: Hey Jim, welcome to the "club that no one wants to join". It sounds like your treatment is following the "normal" path for someone of your age and period of time within which your PSA was detected. A little background information... 8-10 years ago (as I understand it) some urologists were removing prostates of older men who had fairly low grade cancers. This was apparently a ploy for financial gain, and a govt panel (USPSTF or 'the task force') "suggested" that GP's stop testing PSA's as it was causing too many unnecessary surgeries. The results were that urologists were less likely to intervene when there was 'only' a higher than usual PSA and as in my case, a family history. The sad thing is that a positive DRE would get you treated immediately, where a combination of other factors would get you shown the door. Recently the same panel woke up to the realization that the outcome now, six years later, is that many more men now have advanced high risk prostate cancer, because their cases were not seen as justifying treatment. Personally, my path was not unlike yours, except that I am five years younger and was told that had I been five years older I would not have been eligible for surgery. Also due to the advanced nature of my case I was ineligible for some of the more recent innovations in radiation. But otherwise, followed a similar path... was put on several longer and longer courses of Cipro in an attempt to knock out this infection that was causing my PSA to skyrocket. Eventually diagnosed following an MRI and bone scans were negative... had RP surgery and still required hormone therapy and 39 treatments of radiation about a year later. It sounds like you are receiving excellent care now, other than the 'fits and starts' several years ago when doctors were reluctant to treat anything but the most obvious cases of prostate cancer for fear of risking lawsuits. Good luck to you in completing your EBRT and your time on HT. If you haven't done so already, you should read the sticky's at the top of the thread list on EBRT and HT. Lots of valuable information in there. Hopefully your recovery will proceed well and you will not have more than a just a few months on HT.

Posts.Title: First step of the journey

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gary e Hi roblee. I was always curious about the AUS. Did you have jitters having it installed the first time. My Uro doc said one Con he fears is that I will not know when to pee which may risk bladder infection. So what is it like if you don't mind telling Thx Gary e Certainly, glad to help in any way I can. I felt it might be better to start a new thread in case anyone else might be interested. The thread is here: https://www.cancerforums.net/threads/54694-Incontinence-and-AUS-experience?p=360369#post360369 ... The first two paragraphs are duplicated here: Not knowing your condition, I'd say that your doctor's concern should not be a problem, unless there is some reason such as a neurological condition that might cause you to not be able to feel when your bladder is full. Bladder sensations are normal with the AUS, in fact, my natural sphincter still works to some extent but is unreliable. I can tell when my bladder needs to be emptied, and when in front of the urinal or toilet must remember to both manually release the AUS as well as tell my natural sphincter to open up. There is sometimes some pressure buildup and it squirts at first, so it's a bit tricky getting everything right. Regarding the jitters, yes, this was probably one of the most difficult decisions of my life. I was extremely stressed at the time. I knew immediately following the prostatectomy that I would require salvage radiation (called adjuvant radiation) within six months, and that the RT would require holding a full bladder every day long enough for the radiation treatment, about two hours. As mentioned, my sphincter worked but I had little control and would leak copiously at times. Furthermore getting the AUS would change the way I would have to do something that I do all day every day for the rest of my life!

Posts.Title: 10/12 month anniversary & update

Posts.Content: If and when you have the biopsy, it would save you some anguish and grief if you ascertain that there is a MRI beforehand or at the time of the biopsy. Without the MRI biopsies are random, and in my case was negative despite an aggressive tumor being present because it was "missed" by the random biopsy. Fortunately I had heard of MRI guided biopsies on TV and when my family doctor asked about an MRI I knew what he was talking about. There is an excellent recent post here somewhere in the PC forum titled "need your opinion" or something like that, with a response from a doctor who I believe is a radiologist. He explains the various types of biopsies and their advantages. In light of what happened to me, I can't understand why there are still random biopsies. Edit: found the link... http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...l=1#post317143

Posts.Title: Comments on recent press release

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by redbelly7 I have read that putting in an artificial sphincter is tougher to do after radiation, is that true? Can it be done? I'm fairly confident that I will not gain continence after radiation. You will in all likelihood actually lose continence as a result of radiation. RT does a real number on abdominal tissues. Consequently any pelvic procedure such as an AUS implant or even a routine colonoscopy becomes a complicated procedure... hence the "fact" that salvage postatectomy following primary radiation generally just isn't done. The only case I know of of a totally failed AUS implant was a man who'd had primary radiation for PCa and the AUS had to be taken back out almost immediately. BTW AFAIK I am the ONLY forum member here who has had the AUS implant. It was a VERY difficult decision and no one here was able to provide any guidance. If interested you can read about my AUS journey in the link CancerCoupleBlog.com below.

Posts.Title: artificial sphincter

Posts.Content: Welcome to the AUS club Pottk! For me it was a difficult decision, as it changes the way you have to do something that you do all day, every day for the rest of your life. My point was that there was no one in this forum at the time who could share their experiences with me on the AUS. Another forum elsewhere had several guys who have one and they all had nothing but glowing reports. Yet another site only had a few with mixed results. None had my experience. I hope you had, and will continue to have, the kind of results that I had been promised by the surgeon. My primary reason for getting the AUS was so that I could start adjuvant radiation, which had already been delayed by several months due to my own incontinence as well as my duties as caregiver to my wife. Then the AUS itself caused additional delays. Much of this is detailed in my blog at CancerCoupleBlog.com or in my personal page at the American Cancer Societies' Cancer Survivors Network Rooster - I had twice requested the balloon as you had recommended, but my RO refused. I do understand why. As for the colonoscopy, I had hoped to get one in before starting ART. My RO said that the colonoscopy had to heal for ten weeks (two and a half months) before I could start ART, which had already been delayed. In fact, the colonoscopy had been scheduled and then rescheduled twice before all three docs (PCP, RO, GI) all told me that I was trying to do too much... then later my RO told me that I should not have a colonoscopy until six months have elapsed following the conclusion of RT. You may have read something different elsewhere, but I was just acting on what my doctor had instructed.

Posts.Title: artificial sphincter

Posts.Content: Jennifer, bumping this to the top so maybe tonite someone with Keytruda experience might see it and respond. Originally Posted by Jennifer2 Does anyone else have any experience with Keytruda? He takes Xtandi as well along with many pain meds/antidepresents/anti anxiety medication and now blood thinners (14 medicines total)... They now say that his bladder only holds a couple of ounces and that the walls have thickened and gotten tough therefore it has shrunk in size. Has anyone heard of this? Yes, bladder shrinkage is not uncommon, especially if he has had a lot of treatments or has been incontinent for a while. I was amazed that after nearly a year of incontinence and a month or so with a Foley cath that I feel like I can only hold about half as much as before starting treatment. Radiation had some effect also. And antidepressants tend do go along with cancer. It is estimated that one in three cancer patients suffer from depression.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster22 Don't be surprised if Radiation Oncologist will want you to use a rectal balloon during radiation. It is somewhat uncomfortable having it inserted, but once inside, it doesn't feel bad. It really helps push a good portion of the colon out of the path of the radiation beam to keep the colon from being radiated. A good radiation machine is the Varian Rapid Arc. Hope you get treated by one of those. I had asked my RO about the balloon back in April and he said he does not use them. I brought it up again this past week and he said 50% of RO's use it and 50% do not. This guy has an excellent track record so I trust him... though I would not be averse to the balloon if offered. And BTW I will be treated with the RapidArc.

Posts.Title: Tampa/Pinellas Uro/RO recommendations?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jbs71616 I just found out that my 70 year old dad has prostate cancer. The good news is that it has not spread far if at all (according to the bone scan which was clear although I understand it cannot detect anything less than 1cm?). He has a Gleason of 9(4+5), PSA 13.12, 1 positive core and 12 negative cores from biopsy, staged T1c. He has started hormone therapy (a shot plus pills). We are trying to decide between radiation and surgery and I'm having a hard time understanding why we wouldn't do surgery and then add radiation and hormone therapy... I also don't understand if he is technically "high risk" just because of his Gleason score alone since his PSA is less than 20? Some of the things I am reading say that to be high risk you must have a Gleason score of 8-10 PLUS a PSA of greater than 20. Generally if your dad is not over the age of 70 then he is a possible candidate for surgery UNLESS he already in poor health or has certain comorbities. It's all about how likely he is to survive the surgery plus whether or not he is likely to die from something other than prostate cancer before the side effects of radiation would appear. There is a very vocal group of radiation advocates who proclaim that today's radiation therapy is not the same as it was 10-20 years ago, however I would counter that there are not many living examples of men who have lived more than 20 years having undergone treatment using 10-20 year old technology. The choice is still yours, or more precisely, your father's. The primary advantage(s) of surgery over radiation are 1) that a physician is actually able to examine the prostate gland and its surrounds and treat accordingly, and 2) if surgery fails, there is always radiation. Be sure to consult with a radiation oncologist before deciding, but be sure to ask the RO what are the available options should the radiation fail. Note that without post-op pathology it is difficult to categorize your father as high risk. What you have cited it nearly correct. Te criteria are as follows: High risk: The tumor has 2 or more of these characteristics: Classified as T3a PSA level is higher than 20 ng/mL Gleason score is between 8 and 10 Very high risk: The tumor is classified as T3b or T4. The histologic grade is 5 for the main pattern of cell growth, or more than 4 biopsy cores have Gleason scores between 8 and 10. Based upon a single having a secondary grade 5 core definitely keeps him out of the VHR category. However, biopsies are known to also miss significant tumors, so there are likely more grade 4 or 5 cells in his prostate. Removal of the prostate and pathological dissection is the only way to know for sure. Radiation is a lot less messy for sure, but IMO the radiologist is essentially shooting in the dark, guided only by external imaging (scans). Additionally surgery will have immediately known and apparent side effects, while radiation has more indefinite side effects which may not appear until many years later.

Posts.Title: Dad has aggressive prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Yes, most of us are here on this forum because we were at one point in the same situation. Your 8.8 (nine-ish) is somewhat high. At that point I was sent for a biopsy as well... this was even though the digital exam was negative. When the biopsy came back negative, I asked my Uro what should we do next and he said another biopsy. If there was one thing I would change, it would be to have had that second biopsy a year earlier. It wasn't until my regular doctor said I had two lumps on my prostate that I returned to the Uro, who dismissed the lumps. Fortunately I was able to see another Uro who did an MRI guided biopsy right away. All I can say to you is do what the doctor tells you to so. If you are not satisfied with what he says, find another doctor. I suspect you will sooner or later end up with RP surgery or maybe radiation, depending on your age, or go under "surveillance"... and hope that *IF* there is indeed cancer in there, that it is treated before it begins to spread. I don't mean to scare you, but it is easy to put off treatment, whether on your part or your doctor's. Sometimes an elevated PSA can be caused by an infection, and a lump does not necessarily mean there is cancer... so you may just end up on Cipro or something... but you probably will end up with prostate treatment at some point in your life. It happens to about half of all men eventually. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Can anyone advise me

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gary e 2 years after my RP, a year after 7 weeks RT... has anyone skip the next 6 month lupron shot and just hang in their with survalence Similar situation here... RP two years ago and RT one year ago. I could have stopped HT after finishing RT last year if I wanted to but elected to stick with it for what has now become the recommended eighteen months. Considering that my Uro who did my RP said I'd probably be on HT for three years, I figure I'm doing okay. And my last 3 PSA's have been undetectable. Of course, the Lupron is still sticking with me. I figure I won't know for sure if the PCa is really gone until a few more years have passed. I sleep well now and rarely get the blues anymore. And the hot flashes are a nuisance but I've learned how to live with them. I figure if I'd dropped out of HT at the one year mark and something came back later on, then I'd probably regret not sticking with it.

Posts.Title: 3 month post op PSA test results are in

Posts.Content: Yesterday I learned that I will definitely need post-op radiation therapy next spring because my cancer had metastasized into the seminary vesicles. Those of you who read my posts know that I am in the process of moving to Clearwater Florida. I already have a primary care physician there, and will seek his recommendations for a urologist to take over my case. But I am curious if any of my R/P brothers here have had radiation treatment in the Tampa/St Pete area and if you could recommend what is a good group to go with for a urologist and a radiation oncologist. I am close to Morton Plant and also know of the Moffitt cancer center. Here at my home in Ohio there are several large groups that control everything. Even in my urology group my original Uro was okay but missed my cancer. His partner who took over my case is a super guy so I realize that sometimes it is hit and miss. We are moving to Florida at the end of this month (long after Matthew has passed) and I kind of just want to know what I'm getting into. Another forum member Michael F has made some suggestions in another thread here: http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...l=1#post319573 Thanks everyone!

However, biopsies are known to also miss significant tumors, so there are likely more grade 4 or 5 cells in his prostate. Removal of the prostate and pathological dissection is the only way to know for sure. Radiation is a lot less messy for sure, but IMO the radiologist is essentially shooting in the dark, guided only by external imaging (scans). Additionally surgery will have immediately known and apparent side effects, while radiation has more indefinite side effects which may not appear until many years later.

Posts.Title: Dad has aggressive prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jbs71616 I just found out that my 70 year old dad has prostate cancer. The good news is that it has not spread far if at all (according to the bone scan which was clear although I understand it cannot detect anything less than 1cm?). He has a Gleason of 9(4+5), PSA 13.12, 1 positive core and 12 negative cores from biopsy, staged T1c. He has started hormone therapy (a shot plus pills). We are trying to decide between radiation and surgery and I'm having a hard time understanding why we wouldn't do surgery and then add radiation and hormone therapy... I also don't understand if he is technically "high risk" just because of his Gleason score alone since his PSA is less than 20? Some of the things I am reading say that to be high risk you must have a Gleason score of 8-10 PLUS a PSA of greater than 20. Generally if your dad is not over the age of 70 then he is a possible candidate for surgery UNLESS he already in poor health or has certain comorbities. It's all about how likely he is to survive the surgery plus whether or not he is likely to die from something other than prostate cancer before the side effects of radiation would appear. There is a very vocal group of radiation advocates who proclaim that today's radiation therapy is not the same as it was 10-20 years ago, however I would counter that there are not many living examples of men who have lived more than 20 years having undergone treatment using 10-20 year old technology. The choice is still yours, or more precisely, your father's. The primary advantage(s) of surgery over radiation are 1) that a physician is actually able to examine the prostate gland and its surrounds and treat accordingly, and 2) if surgery fails, there is always radiation. Be sure to consult with a radiation oncologist before deciding, but be sure to ask the RO what are the available options should the radiation fail. Note that without post-op pathology it is difficult to categorize your father as high risk. What you have cited it nearly correct. Te criteria are as follows: High risk: The tumor has 2 or more of these characteristics: Classified as T3a PSA level is higher than 20 ng/mL Gleason score is between 8 and 10 Very high risk: The tumor is classified as T3b or T4. The histologic grade is 5 for the main pattern of cell growth, or more than 4 biopsy cores have Gleason scores between 8 and 10. Based upon a single having a secondary grade 5 core definitely keeps him out of the VHR category. However, biopsies are known to also miss significant tumors, so there are likely more grade 4 or 5 cells in his prostate. Removal of the prostate and pathological dissection is the only way to know for sure. Radiation is a lot less messy for sure, but IMO the radiologist is essentially shooting in the dark, guided only by external imaging (scans). Additionally surgery will have immediately known and apparent side effects, while radiation has more indefinite side effects which may not appear until many years later.

Posts.Title: Dad has aggressive prostate cancer

Posts.Content: If and when you have the biopsy, it would save you some anguish and grief if you ascertain that there is a MRI beforehand or at the time of the biopsy. Without the MRI biopsies are random, and in my case was negative despite an aggressive tumor being present because it was "missed" by the random biopsy. Fortunately I had heard of MRI guided biopsies on TV and when my family doctor asked about an MRI I knew what he was talking about. There is an excellent recent post here somewhere in the PC forum titled "need your opinion" or something like that, with a response from a doctor who I believe is a radiologist. He explains the various types of biopsies and their advantages. In light of what happened to me, I can't understand why there are still random biopsies. Edit: found the link... http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...l=1#post317143

Posts.Title: New Poster

Posts.Content: Yes, most of us are here on this forum because we were at one point in the same situation. Your 8.8 (nine-ish) is somewhat high. At that point I was sent for a biopsy as well... this was even though the digital exam was negative. When the biopsy came back negative, I asked my Uro what should we do next and he said another biopsy. If there was one thing I would change, it would be to have had that second biopsy a year earlier. It wasn't until my regular doctor said I had two lumps on my prostate that I returned to the Uro, who dismissed the lumps. Fortunately I was able to see another Uro who did an MRI guided biopsy right away. All I can say to you is do what the doctor tells you to so. If you are not satisfied with what he says, find another doctor. I suspect you will sooner or later end up with RP surgery or maybe radiation, depending on your age, or go under "surveillance"... and hope that *IF* there is indeed cancer in there, that it is treated before it begins to spread. I don't mean to scare you, but it is easy to put off treatment, whether on your part or your doctor's. Sometimes an elevated PSA can be caused by an infection, and a lump does not necessarily mean there is cancer... so you may just end up on Cipro or something... but you probably will end up with prostate treatment at some point in your life. It happens to about half of all men eventually. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Six weeks since Di Vinci, now a problem

Posts.Content: The tattoos are just a dot, one on each hip and one just above the pubic bone. In the treatment room there are lasers aimed at the treatment table. Every day when you are put on the table the tech will position you so that the lasers are pointing at each dot, to make sure that you are in the exact same position each time. They don't really aim at the dots, they are just to verify that they are aiming at the same place every day.

Posts.Content: I am proud to say that I totally missed whatever happened here. I had read Denis's post, saw that the thread had been locked, and went directly to Chuck's final post. I don't even want to know what was said in between. People being people indeed. Whenever I witness an online dispute, I always liken the internet to the movie "Sphere". In that movie, a space ship returns to earth with an unknown object, a glowing sphere, in the cargo bay. The researchers begin to experience horrifying events. It turns out that the sphere was a gift from an alien race. It was a device able to make dreams come true. Instead the crew brought their nightmares to reality. As others have said above, this is the best prostate cancer forum on the internet. Several others forums here that I've touched upon also seem to be equally well attended and managed. I once had an issue here, and it turned out the problem was all in my head. I am glad that we are usually able to work things out between ourselves and get on with the important things in life.
Posts.Title: I'am outta here....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dand Rob her Chemo treatment did not require a port as it was given at the hospital intravenously in a vein in her arm. Was not a problem in the beginning then accessing the vein became harder with bruising. My wife wishes she had gotten the port a month earlier. It seems to be working much better as lab, ct imaging & chemo can all use the port. Talking with my wife, she says that her oncologist was the proponent of the power port. He said she can swim with it and everything. They put it in on her last morning in the hospital and removed her PICC line later that afternoon. I think they only used the PICC for one round of chemo, and the rest will use the port.
Posts.Title: Long Term Survivor my Prostate Cancer Story 1st Prostate Forum Post

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Discuss with the Urologist about having an MP 3T MRI that can be later "fused" with a TRUS Biopsy. I'm not sure about health insurance coverage for the MRI. If it will cover it, then definitely go with it. If your current Uro does not do these, then find one who does. These are two very important points... unfortunately, in my case, my cancer had an additional year to grow and spread because initial tests were all negative. It wasn't until after my Uro, whom I had been seeing for twenty years, retired and meanwhile I retired and went on Medicare, that the fusion biopsy was done by his partner and identified the cancer. An unfortunate coincidence. He did not "do" fusion and my insurance at the time would not have covered it anyway. There was a thread here about six months ago started by a doctor on this board titled "is it time for MRI fusion biopsy to be the standard" (I don't remember the title exactly) but that was the point of the post, as it is far more accurate at identifying and localizing PCa, rather than fusion being reserved for use only after a random biopsy has turned up negative... and also therefore requiring further delay between procedures while the tissues heal.

Posts.Title: Confused and scared

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gary e 2 years after my RP, a year after 7 weeks RT... has anyone skip the next 6 month lupron shot and just hang in their with survalence Similar situation here... RP two years ago and RT one year ago. I could have stopped HT after finishing RT last year if I wanted to but elected to stick with it for what has now become the recommended eighteen months. Considering that my Uro who did my RP said I'd probably be on HT for three years, I figure I'm doing okay. And my last 3 PSA's have been undetectable. Of course, the Lupron is still sticking with me. I figure I won't know for sure if the PCa is really gone until a few more years have passed. I sleep well now and rarely get the blues anymore. And the hot flashes are a nuisance but I've learned how to live with them. I figure if I'd dropped out of HT at the one year mark and something came back later on, then I'd probably regret not sticking with it.

Posts.Title: Walking/Exercise Post Surgery

Posts.Content: It is difficult to tell exactly when the end will be. From the information you presented, it seems he has not been on any form of hormone deprivation therapy (ADT or HT) that might have arrested the progression of his bone mets. Or he may have been on HT as part of the radiation... But I am guessing that the radiation was spot treatment to his bone mets to reduce his pain. Traditionally, chemo had been reserved as a "last resort" but more recently is administered following radiation in order to take out micromets. It sounds like your husband was probably already beyond that before his treatment started. He will continue to hve good days and bad days, as both the cancer and its treatments saps all stamina from its victims. You can't necessarily blame it on doing too much on a good day. It is unfortunate that no one here was able to provide you with more information, but this particular message board is generally frequented by guys (and their wives or children) who have been recently diagnosed and/or currently undergoing treatment for a cure. Your husband's case is far beyond that. There are two other message boards where you will find men with more advanced cases... stage 4, metastatic cancer.

I've had a Foley I think six times for a few days to over a week, and never developed a UTI with it. Posts.Title: Cancered Out

Posts.Content: To reiterate what ASA has mentioned above, and hopefully as some reassurance to you, PSA's immediately following radiation as primary therapy are of little value, as the cancer cells spew out PSA as they are dying from the radiation, and this process takes many months afterwards before PSA levels stabilize. Unlike surgery, where PSA is measured frequently afterwards in order to determine whether or not any cancerous tissue remains, PSA's following radiation rarely or never go down to zero and rather is charted to determine a downward trend until it reaches a nadir or low point, then stabilizes. So it sounds like everything is progressing normally... even the insurance nightmare that seems to be unavoidable these days.
Posts.Title: Psa confusion update

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Speaking about DREs, just this morning I came across a study that looked at DREs for prostate screening and, remarkably, concluded that they were not necessary. If we eliminate the DRE and frown upon PSA screening, as some do, what is the symptom docs should use to wake up, bone pain from mets??? Originally Posted by MrEd I had no symptoms and DRE and ultrasound showed nothing. I guess if you don't use PSA's to trigger further investigation you can push the treatment to a later time and let the Medicare system take care of the costs. Originally Posted by DjinTonic You mean the cost of my funeral? There is still research in support of, and a push toward, not doing PSA screening for PCa. The problem is that early PCa has only signs and rarely symptoms. If docs are told not to check for the signs, where does that leave us? With a load of patients who are told out of the blue they have advanced, perhaps metastatic, prostate cancer. Don't get me started!!! For years, my DRE's were always "normal" and my PSA was "elevated", so I was told it was "nothing to be concerned about." Thank goodness I changed doctors following my retirement. When my new Urologist showed me on a graphic where my tumor was located, high up behind the pubic bone and just below the bladder, I said no wonder my DRE's were always normal... to which he replied, yeah, you can never find those without an MRI. So when my wife's persistent back pain was repeatedly dismissed as a muscle strain, we paid CASH for an MRI. That was sixteen months ago, and she just passed the one year mark from completing chemo. We just received a letter from her insurance company rejecting payment for the MRI. Where the @#$%#& do they find these people???!!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MDeckert RobLee (Sir) Can I ask what your PSA levels were after the DaVinci? I have had both removal and radation. Radiation after surgery came quickly because of the PSA . Informed yesterday that PSA still shows rise (each 3 months) since surgery and then after radiation . Next week is the Lupron discussion. Now have as of yesterday PSA .190 Regards..... My first PSA post op was "<.1" and the second "<.02", then I was put on Lupron. They have been "<.03" ever since. That may mean going on HT possibly for years.

Your story has stuck in my head, and now you are faced with what is essentially a failure of treatment... after all that you have been thru. For those just now tuning in, I am going to completely hijack this thread and post a link to one of the more pertinent posts in your earlier thread. BTW thank you for your advocacy on the balloon - I will definitely ask my RO if he even has the capacity to do that. His facility is literally around the corner from where I live, so changing RO's would probably be totally impractical. Michael and Rooster - good luck for your time ahead - years, on HT. It's been four months for me now and will likely be the rest of this year at least. I am actually getting used to it. My RO basically shot me down when I asked for help with the SE's. I worked with my PCP for some Rx and still working on that - trying different stuff, and I will definitely be posting at some point just how that worked out. Again, best of luck to you both. Cancer doesn't just stay overnight, it sets up housekeeping and resists eviction.
Posts.Title: hormone therapy side effects after 2 years

Posts.Content: Both my biopsies were under anesthesia, thank goodness, and the second one was an MRI guided fusion biopsy. As I understand this is a specialized procedure that requires training and experience. Be sure if you proceed with a second biopsy that it is a FUSION biopsy. Recovery from my first biopsy was what caused me to delay getting the second one. I bled a lot and had difficulty urinating. No catheter though. The second biopsy was totally without after effects. Again, no catheter, but no bleeding and no problem urinating... and it is the one that probably saved my life. I'm thinking the usual biopsy they just randomly poke around at your prostate and hope they hit something, possibly puncturing the urethra in the process. That's the only thing I can think of that would cause the bleeding. If you need surgery and proceed with a prostatectomy then you will definitely have a catheter for 7-10 days afterward. It is uncomfortable and terribly inconvenient, but that's all. It is NOT painful. Removing it is actually ticklish. I know what you mean about the waiting lists in Florida. My wife developed what (likely) turned out to be lymphoma. She couldn't see a doctor for a month. Fortunately a nurse practitioner ordered a MRI two weeks ago and she is now being treated, after much struggle and fighting with the system. I don't blame snowbirds... we were one briefly before moving to the Tampa bay area. Good luck with whatever you end up doing. Do not let fear keep you from getting treatment. You must be your own advocate.

Posts.Title: New Poster

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rmotacek1 I had my RALP in December 2015 and then because of my high gleason score I had 40 rounds of radiation in May. The radiation was really no problem except for some fatigue near the end. I am hoping that the combination of the surgery and radiation has knocked the cancer out. I just want to let you know that the radiation was very easy and not to worry about it. Originally Posted by Replicant I had salvage radiation .... Best of all, the treatment worked. Six months is the same timeline that my Urologist laid out for me (DaVinci three months ago and RT to start three months from now). The more I read about it the more apprehensive I become about it. Several guys have said it was no big deal, and everyone I've spoken with about it say it worked and there were no ill affects. But I'm still hoping that maybe I won't need to go thru with it. My PSA's have been <0.02 and categorized as undetectable. Still, the RT is recommended because my cancer had spread into both seminary vesicles. I really don't know if there's any way to determine whether or not it has or will spread beyond that. Eight weeks of daily RT seems like a tremendous risk as well as inconvenience just because there "might be" some residual cancer. My greatest concern is in regard to incontinence. Like several other guys here who had surgery around the same time as myself, I still have very little control over leaking urine. Everything I've read says to expect 6-12 months for full continence to return, but if I have RT at six months, then any progress (or lack thereof) comes to a complete halt. That is probably the scariest part.

Posts.Title: Questions on upcoming salvage radiation

Posts.Content: Thanks, Rich, for the excellent list. Kozmic - yes, AZ is Amazon (I was trying to avoid advertising... but then they don't really need it, do they?) I saw Depends shields for $15 at CVS. The same package was $12 at Target and $10 from Amazon. Moral of the story: shop around. BTW one of my nurses said her husband prefers Tena as they are not as "noisy" as Depends. I also tried Depends Flex Fit briefs, but they have so much elastic that disposal becomes a problem. They fill the trash can too fast. For pad/shield/diaper disposal I use quart size zipper plastic bags. $6 for a box of 100, and I can fit two pads in each baggie. Keeps the bath/bedroom from smelling like urine. Personally I do not like shields, at least not at this point in my recovery. I haven't found one with enough of a "pouch" in front. Most of them are flat or nearly flat and tend to squish my poor penis too much. And for the first few days after cath removal, rubbing against the pads was too irritating. I've found that I like "belted shields". These are unisex pads that button in front and back. They come with a pair of elastic straps with a button on each end. They ride low on the hips and do not irritate my incision sites as they do not have a waist band. Initially I bought them at CVS because my wife had a 30% off extra care coupon, but I found the same shields available on AZ under the name Prevail.
