Posts.Title: Cancered Out

Posts.Content: It's time to address the elephant in the room. What elephant? Post-op incontinence following prostatectomy. Some of us who are in our first month post-op have been posting remarks about leakage, Kegels, and other such matters in JJackson's "Post-op Day 10" thread... read it here: (http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...Post-op-Day-10 Jamie, Rich and I ("the three caballeros") are all in our first month post-op and struggling with these issues. There has already been a lot of info put forward in that thread, but he/we discussed starting a properly titled thread on the topic. So here it is. I just wanted to get this up and running so we can add our thoughts and experiences here rather than there (as Day 10 has long passed!) Personally I have been experimenting with various pads, shields, diapers (ok, I'm going to call them that) as well as some "external plumbing" devices. I hope to post my thoughts and opinions here on various products in the days ahead. AZ has been a terrific resource, offering testimonials as well as decent prices, better than you might find in a drug store or superstore. For any newbies (and yes, we are all newbies at this, if not now, we were only recently) what I've read and been told is that typically we should not expect to have much control for the first two months, with full control over urinary continence being attained between six and twelve months. As usual, your mileage may vary. Some report better control early on and others still having accidents more than a year out. So don't worry if you don't fit some standard. There is none. Good luck everyone! We've already taken the greatest step on this journey.

Posts.Content: My maternal grandfather had prostate cancer when he died in 1964 at the ripe old age of 84. I propose that any male living to the age of 84 might have had PC, especially given the state of medical science a half century ago. Neither my brother nor any of my cousins on my mother's side have had prostate cancer, so I believe that I was just as statistically likely to have PC as the next guy and not due to any hereditary factors.

Posts.Title: Radiation Days

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Hammer2016 After having surgery in July 2016 my PSA tests started to elevate... a hormone shot in preparation for radiation therapy. February to April 2017 I had 35 sessions of IMRT... June, September and January are all <0.010ng/ml. The days leading up to my recent PSA were nerve racking. I feel so blessed to remain in the zero club. Hey Hammer, we were on the same timeline. My RP was in Aug 2016 and I was supposed to start RT last March 2017. Congrats on the <.01 PSA !!! Originally Posted by rmotacek1 Congrats on the "zero club". I just hit it too yesterday! Same here rmotacek! Yesterday I looked up my labs online and found my PSA was 0.00 ... Frankly I'm in a bit of shock and disbelief. I see my doc on Wednesday, but I guess it's safe to say that I am now a cancer survivor! And congrats to you too!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FishSpear DRE: normal PSA history: 2016  1.50 ng/ml 2017  2.24 ng/ml 2018  3.69 ng/ml 3T mpMRI, December 2018 Found one PI-RADS 4 lesion, well contained in the prostate. Fusion TRUS biopsy, February 2019. ... I fired my first urologist for refusing to give me an mpMRI. He was adamant about doing a TRUS biopsy (blind biopsy). I wanted a better outcome and found it with my second urologist. So Im currently considering RP for the following reasons: 1) Im early stage so there is a better chance at getting it all out (a cure). 2) I can take a major surgery now a lot better than I can five or ten years from now. 3) Im currently working and have reasonable healthcare. 4) Incontinence and ED suck, but not as much as prostate cancer and Im willing to make that trade off. Ive read that if youve had radiation you are no longer able to have a RP? Is that correct and does that also apply to a CyberKnife treatment? Ive also read that once youre over 70 years old youre not considered a good candidate for RP? If this is true then its another reason to just get it done now. You have done your research well, and your decisions are sound. Even your assumptions have full merit. And you are to be commended in particular for dumping your first urologist early on. Mine would have done blind biopsies til the cows came home. And my current uro mentioned that my primary tumor would have NEVER been found that way. You have also been conscientious with regard to dismissing fashionable and trendy treatment forms. Be sure to actually SPEAK with several individuals who have been thru such treatments. Many have a very short track record. I have yet to meet a man who was treated with a product that is still less than ten years old, yet has lived another 20... without a time machine. The well worn path is RP for young healthy men, with HT and SRT if there are any complications. My surgeon told me that if I had been five years older then his recommendations would have been different. And as it was, at my advanced stage (by the time I finally confronted my original uro about his methods) then I only had a one in 20 chance of being incontinent. And with my luck, I was the one. At your age and early stage you probably have a 99% chance of being one of the once-and-done RP patients whom we never even hear from on message boards like this one. And speaking of message boards, if you had perchance visited another popular prostate cancer message board, one which I shall not name, your decisions would have been met with DOZENS of responses to the effect of "why are you even thinking of surgery, you should have Hi Def Brachy". I get tired of fighting them off. Hold your ground. RP has a long track record. If you prefer to wait til after a few more biopsies that's probably okay. And finally, I am curious what prompted you to seek treatment with such low stats as you've listed above? My GP first sent me to a urologist when my PSA hit 4.0 ... The uro was unconcerned. Had he ever even mentioned the word cancer then I likely would have done some research as you did. As far as I knew, he was treating me for prostatitis. Once again, congratulations on a job well done, and I wish you good fortune on the path ahead of you.

Posts.Title: Hi, I'm a new member

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jls85 Truthfully, we didn't even know that this could happen - we were prepared for incontinence and ED, but had no idea that he could become obstructed like that and have to be re-cathed. You should probably contact your Uro ASAP. Just about anything is possible, but most likely this is clotting where the urethra was sutured to the bladder. It appears from your post-op post that the Foley was in for less than a week and what you are dealing with is scar tissue... A cystoscopy should be able to reveal what's going on.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ready2Fight We had to get the standard 12 core first because insurance would not pay for the MRI biopsy if we did not go through that step first I think that kind of stinks but we had no choice I would rather have just gotten the MRI biopsy right from the get-go. Amen! Originally Posted by Another A note about the antibiotic drill for elevated PSA. Imo, it is bad medicine. The over use of antibiotics for elevated PSA, particularly short term, is a serious issue that can later result in complications during the biopsy and surgery. And Hallelujah! Just read the first few lines of my bio for "living proof" of the pitfalls of relying on antibiotics and blind biopsies rather than MRI's.

Posts.Title: Recovering now from my surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Speaking about DREs, just this morning I came across a study that looked at DREs for prostate screening and, remarkably, concluded that they were not necessary. If we eliminate the DRE and frown upon PSA screening, as some do, what is the symptom docs should use to wake up, bone pain from mets??? Originally Posted by MrEd I had no symptoms and DRE and ultrasound showed nothing. I guess if you don't use PSA's to trigger further investigation you can push the treatment to a later time and let the Medicare system take care of the costs. Originally Posted by DjinTonic You mean the cost of my funeral? There is still research in support of, and a push toward, not doing PSA screening for PCa. The problem is that early PCa has only signs and rarely symptoms. If docs are told not to check for the signs, where does that leave us? With a load of patients who are told out of the blue they have advanced, perhaps metastatic, prostate cancer. Don't get me started!!! For years, my DRE's were always "normal" and my PSA was "elevated", so I was told it was "nothing to be concerned about." Thank goodness I changed doctors following my retirement. When my new Urologist showed me on a graphic where my tumor was located, high up behind the pubic bone and just below the bladder, I said no wonder my DRE's were always normal... to which he replied, yeah, you can never find those without an MRI. So when my wife's persistent back pain was repeatedly dismissed as a muscle strain, we paid CASH for an MRI. That was sixteen months ago, and she just passed the one year mark from completing chemo. We just received a letter from her insurance company rejecting payment for the MRI. Where the @#$%#& do they find these people???!!

Posts.Title: Urinary retention post-op?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another The majority of PC is 3+3 and 3+4. You have 4+3. It is not slow growing and it is not like 3+4. To underscore this, 3+3 is grade group 1, 3+4 jumps to group 2, and 4+3 is group 3. Put into a list: 3+3=1 3+4=2 4+3=3 4+4=4 4+5 or 5+4 = group 5, essentially terminal You do not want to be halfway up the totem pole. That's how narrow the dividing line really is. Originally Posted by Another Worst case scenario is that of a good friend of mine with 4+3 and 57. Surgery missed a significant portion. The suspicion is they were to go wide on the right and went wide on the left instead. Follow up radiation was not very effective, and he is now looking at hormone therapy from this point forward. All side effects are present. Not a happy camper. Sorry about your friend, Ano. FWIW my surgeon used a broad cut, and in his words, removed a lot of tissue. Hence the permanent ED and as you know, persistent incontinence. Now we won't know the true outcome until after RT ends and HT wears off, but I would much rather be in my shoes than your friend's. Again, to the OP, that's how fine a line we walk with this disease.
Posts.Title: New and trying to come up with a plan

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jsceash My PSA dropped after 60 days to 2.4 but after 120 days it has not changed and remains at 2.4. Do i have any other options? Clinical trials will most likely be your next option and possibly Radium 223 for bone mets, but as your PSA is stable "for now" you may want to pause until a pattern is established. If it remains at 2.4 or rises only gradually you may have already done all you can without further trauma to your system. Presumably the lymph nodes in your chest were all irradiated or removed (?) I'm sure you realize that your PSA will probably never again be anywhere near zero, but keeping it under 10 is something of an accomplishment, at least until further treatable malignancies can be identified. Take some time off and enjoy the holidays. No one wants to have to drive to treatments in the northeast in the middle of winter anyway. Good luck going forward! Originally Posted by caddy2507 ... it sounds to me like you would more likely need an oncology radiologist. Caddy, just FYI the OP has already had EBRT so is already beyond the radiation stage and likely being treated my a MO.

Posts.Title: How concerned should I be?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jsceash My PSA dropped after 60 days to 2.4 but after 120 days it has not changed and remains at 2.4. Do i have any other options? Clinical trials will most likely be your next option and possibly Radium 223 for bone mets, but as your PSA is stable "for now" you may want to pause until a pattern is established. If it remains at 2.4 or rises only gradually you may have already done all you can without further trauma to your system. Presumably the lymph nodes in your chest were all irradiated or removed (?) I'm sure you realize that your PSA will probably never again be anywhere near zero, but keeping it under 10 is something of an accomplishment, at least until further treatable malignancies can be identified. Take some time off and enjoy the holidays. No one wants to have to drive to treatments in the northeast in the middle of winter anyway. Good luck going forward! Originally Posted by caddy2507 ... it sounds to me like you would more likely need an oncology radiologist. Caddy, just FYI the OP has already had EBRT so is already beyond the radiation stage and likely being treated my a MO.

Posts.Title: How concerned should I be?

Posts.Content: It takes a few weeks at least. Around one month you should experience dry nights. Most gain continence between 3 and 6 months, with additional improvement up to a full year. Be patient, and good luck!

Posts.Title: Incontinence after catheter removal

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rmotacek1 I had my RALP in December 2015 and then because of my high gleason score I had 40 rounds of radiation in May. The radiation was really no problem except for some fatigue near the end. I am hoping that the combination of the surgery and radiation has knocked the cancer out. I just want to let you know that the radiation was very easy and not to worry about it. Originally Posted by Replicant I had salvage radiation .... Best of all, the treatment worked. Six months is the same timeline that my Urologist laid out for me (DaVinci three months ago and RT to start three months from now). The more I read about it the more apprehensive I become about it. Several guys have said it was no big deal, and everyone I've spoken with about it say it worked and there were no ill affects. But I'm still hoping that maybe I won't need to go thru with it. My PSA's have been <0.02 and categorized as undetectable. Still, the RT is recommended because my cancer had spread into both seminary vesicles. I really don't know if there's any way to determine whether or not it has or will spread beyond that. Eight weeks of daily RT seems like a tremendous risk as well as inconvenience just because there "might be" some residual cancer. My greatest concern is in regard to incontinence. Like several other guys here who had surgery around the same time as myself, I still have very little control over leaking urine. Everything I've read says to expect 6-12 months for full continence to return, but if I have RT at six months, then any progress (or lack thereof) comes to a complete halt. That is probably the scariest part.

Posts.Title: Questions on upcoming salvage radiation

Posts.Content: It's time to address the elephant in the room. What elephant? Post-op incontinence following prostatectomy. Some of us who are in our first month post-op have been posting remarks about leakage, Kegels, and other such matters in JJackson's "Post-op Day 10" thread... read it here: (http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...Post-op-Day-10 Jamie, Rich and I ("the three caballeros") are all in our first month post-op and struggling with these issues. There has already been a lot of info put forward in that thread, but he/we discussed starting a properly titled thread on the topic. So here it is. I just wanted to get this up and running so we can add our thoughts and experiences here rather than there (as Day 10 has long passed!) Personally I have been experimenting with various pads, shields, diapers (ok, I'm going to call them that) as well as some "external plumbing" devices. I hope to post my thoughts and opinions here on various products in the days ahead. AZ has been a terrific resource, offering testimonials as well as decent prices, better than you might find in a drug store or superstore. For any newbies (and yes, we are all newbies at this, if not now, we were only recently) what I've read and been told is that typically we should not expect to have much control for the first two months, with full control over urinary continence being attained between six and twelve months. As usual, your mileage may vary. Some report better control early on and others still having accidents more than a year out. So don't worry if you don't fit some standard. There is none. Good luck everyone! We've already taken the greatest step on this journey.

Posts.Title: Post-op Continence Concerns & Suggestions

Posts.Content: Thanks, Rich, for the excellent list. Kozmic - yes, AZ is Amazon (I was trying to avoid advertising... but then they don't really need it, do they?) I saw Depends shields for $15 at CVS. The same package was $12 at Target and $10 from Amazon. Moral of the story: shop around. BTW one of my nurses said her husband prefers Tena as they are not as "noisy" as Depends. I also tried Depends Flex Fit briefs, but they have so much elastic that disposal becomes a problem. They fill the trash can too fast. For pad/shield/diaper disposal I use quart size zipper plastic bags. $6 for a box of 100, and I can fit two pads in each baggie. Keeps the bath/bedroom from smelling like urine. Personally I do not like shields, at least not at this point in my recovery. I haven't found one with enough of a "pouch" in front. Most of them are flat or nearly flat and tend to squish my poor penis too much. And for the first few days after cath removal, rubbing against the pads was too irritating. I've found that I like "belted shields". These are unisex pads that button in front and back. They come with a pair of elastic straps with a button on each end. They ride low on the hips and do not irritate my incision sites as they do not have a waist band. Initially I bought them at CVS because my wife had a 30% off extra care coupon, but I found the same shields available on AZ under the name Prevail.

Posts.Title: Post-op Continence Concerns & Suggestions

Posts.Content: It's time to address the elephant in the room. What elephant? Post-op incontinence following prostatectomy. Some of us who are in our first month post-op have been posting remarks about leakage, Kegels, and other such matters in JJackson's "Post-op Day 10" thread... read it here: (http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...Post-op-Day-10 Jamie, Rich and I ("the three caballeros") are all in our first month post-op and struggling with these issues. There has already been a lot of info put forward in that thread, but he/we discussed starting a properly titled thread on the topic. So here it is. I just wanted to get this up and running so we can add our thoughts and experiences here rather than there (as Day 10 has long passed!) Personally I have been experimenting with various pads, shields, diapers (ok, I'm going to call them that) as well as some "external plumbing" devices. I hope to post my thoughts and opinions here on various products in the days ahead. AZ has been a terrific resource, offering testimonials as well as decent prices, better than you might find in a drug store or superstore. For any newbies (and yes, we are all newbies at this, if not now, we were only recently) what I've read and been told is that typically we should not expect to have much control for the first two months, with full control over urinary continence being attained between six and twelve months. As usual, your mileage may vary. Some report better control early on and others still having accidents more than a year out. So don't worry if you don't fit some standard. There is none. Good luck everyone! We've already taken the greatest step on this journey.

Posts.Title: Post-op Continence Concerns & Suggestions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JJackson I had a Robotic Assisted Radical Prostatectomy on 9/26. My surgery was pretty uneventful. I was released to home the following day. Of course with a Foley cath, 5 puncture wounds (subcuticular stitches covered with Dermabond) and no JP or any other drain. I share the majority of experiences Ive read hereno issues with the catherter really, very sore lower abdomen and pain in the shoulders. But the discomfort lessened each and by Post Op Day 4 all was fine. I had my catherter removed Sept 2nd. My anxiety over the removal was much worse than the act itselfminimal discomfort that was over, done and gone in a few seconds. My cath was removed in my Surgeons office. He was able to spare both nerves and said the lymph nodes were clear. Originally Posted by Rich2.0 Hi Jamie, It looks like we both had our surgery on the same day! I am a bit behind schedule on the catheter removal. I'm scheduled to have mine removed first thing tomorrow morning. I know I'm going to leak like a sieve the first day but getting rid of this ball and chain will be quite liberating. I don't have any pearls of wisdom to share at this point -just some words of encouragement. Hang in there and please post back often. I will be following this thread closely. Hello guys - I'm just a week behind you two, so I will be referring back to this thread often to check on your progress. Unfortunately I did not have much time to practice Kegels pre-op, but have also read that it has limited value until afterwards. My surgery was pretty much uneventful, much like JJackson's. My cath comes out in two days. Others I have spoken with mention six months as most common time to regain full control over continence. Good luck everyone!

Posts.Title: Post op Day 10

Posts.Content: Thanks, Rich, for the excellent list. Kozmic - yes, AZ is Amazon (I was trying to avoid advertising... but then they don't really need it, do they?) I saw Depends shields for $15 at CVS. The same package was $12 at Target and $10 from Amazon. Moral of the story: shop around. BTW one of my nurses said her husband prefers Tena as they are not as "noisy" as Depends. I also tried Depends Flex Fit briefs, but they have so much elastic that disposal becomes a problem. They fill the trash can too fast. For pad/shield/diaper disposal I use quart size zipper plastic bags. $6 for a box of 100, and I can fit two pads in each baggie. Keeps the bath/bedroom from smelling like urine. Personally I do not like shields, at least not at this point in my recovery. I haven't found one with enough of a "pouch" in front. Most of them are flat or nearly flat and tend to squish my poor penis too much. And for the first few days after cath removal, rubbing against the pads was too irritating. I've found that I like "belted shields". These are unisex pads that button in front and back. They come with a pair of elastic straps with a button on each end. They ride low on the hips and do not irritate my incision sites as they do not have a waist band. Initially I bought them at CVS because my wife had a 30% off extra care coupon, but I found the same shields available on AZ under the name Prevail.

Posts.Title: Post-op Continence Concerns & Suggestions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ready2Fight We had to get the standard 12 core first because insurance would not pay for the MRI biopsy if we did not go through that step first I think that kind of stinks but we had no choice I would rather have just gotten the MRI biopsy right from the get-go. Amen! Originally Posted by Another A note about the antibiotic drill for elevated PSA. Imo, it is bad medicine. The over use of antibiotics for elevated PSA, particularly short term, is a serious issue that can later result in complications during the biopsy and surgery. And Hallelujah! Just read the first few lines of my bio for "living proof" of the pitfalls of relying on antibiotics and blind biopsies rather than MRI's.

I hope to post my thoughts and opinions here on various products in the days ahead. AZ has been a terrific resource, offering testimonials as well as decent prices, better than you might find in a drug store or superstore. For any newbies (and yes, we are all newbies at this, if not now, we were only recently) what I've read and been told is that typically we should not expect to have much control for the first two months, with full control over urinary continence being attained between six and twelve months. As usual, your mileage may vary. Some report better control early on and others still having accidents more than a year out. So don't worry if you don't fit some standard. There is none. Good luck everyone! We've already taken the greatest step on this journey.

Posts.Content: Thanks, Rich, for the excellent list. Kozmic - yes, AZ is Amazon (I was trying to avoid advertising... but then they don't really need it, do they?) I saw Depends shields for $15 at CVS. The same package was $12 at Target and $10 from Amazon. Moral of the story: shop around. BTW one of my nurses said her husband prefers Tena as they are not as "noisy" as Depends. I also tried Depends Flex Fit briefs, but they have so much elastic that disposal becomes a problem. They fill the trash can too fast. For pad/shield/diaper disposal I use quart size zipper plastic bags. $6 for a box of 100, and I can fit two pads in each baggie. Keeps the bath/bedroom from smelling like urine. Personally I do not like shields, at least not at this point in my recovery. I haven't found one with enough of a "pouch" in front. Most of them are flat or nearly flat and tend to squish my poor penis too much. And for the first few days after cath removal, rubbing against the pads was too irritating. I've found that I like "belted shields". These are unisex pads that button in front and back. They come with a pair of elastic straps with a button on each end. They ride low on the hips and do not irritate my incision sites as they do not have a waist band. Initially I bought them at CVS because my wife had a 30% off extra care coupon, but I found the same shields available on AZ under the name Prevail.

Posts.Title: Post-op Continence Concerns & Suggestions

Posts.Content: Very interesting thread... VERY interesting, probably one of the best I've found here. ASA, nice clear stratification of treatment choices vs Gleason score. Denis, I've watched your decision process on multiple forums from the very beginning. James, you hit the nail on the head... salvage radiation vs salvage surgery sealed the deal. Plus a bit of input from Ed and Another... not to omit anyone else (sorry). My brain is a bit foggy from a year on Lupron, so please bear with me. I started having serious problems right around the same time that my wife and I were planning our retirements and ultimate move to Florida... literally the same month. It was just an annoyance. I had been seeing my Urologist for twenty years. He never mentioned the C word. He did a biopsy, which was negative. DRE's were always 'normal'. He frequently told me that my PSA was high, but he never told me what that meant. So I went about with my life... retirement and relocation. When he ultimately retired and I had to find a new doctor, it was a relief when I was finally told that I have cancer. By this time, it was just one more thing I had to deal with (read my blog for more insight). It appeared surgery would the quickest and most efficient means of accomplishing an end. Some radiation options required too much time, others I was not even eligible for due to pathology. The issue of possible salvage sealed the deal. I was told following surgery that I would require radiation. And now I've had both. With surgery I pretty much knew what might happen and when... and in most cases, it did. I can accept that. After radiation, I have no idea what's next. I'm still dealing with bowel issues since the second week of radiation. It was a surprise and it is scary. When I mention it in forums some guys say, yeah, that can happen. Why was I not told about this beforehand? So with regard to surgery, I knew the risks going in and a year later I know which ones became an issue and which ones have not. But with radiation, I just don't know. My final meeting with the RO he told me that I wouldn't know for at least a year whether or not it worked. I would be very concerned if I had chosen primary radiation monotherapy and have no idea whether or not it had cured me, and that I had no further options. And I should add, what other surprises are in store? Will I someday hear that I have colorectal cancer and wonder whether or not it was caused by the radiation? I already have to wait another four months before I can even have a colonoscopy, because of the radiation. Again, it's all a big unknown. I'm just rolling with the punches here. Life throws me a curve ball and I deal with it the best I can.

Posts.Title: One year post Lupron, T = 11

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JJackson I had a Robotic Assisted Radical Prostatectomy on 9/26. My surgery was pretty uneventful. I was released to home the following day. Of course with a Foley cath, 5 puncture wounds (subcuticular stitches covered with Dermabond) and no JP or any other drain. I share the majority of experiences Ive read hereno issues with the catherter really, very sore lower abdomen and pain in the shoulders. But the discomfort lessened each and by Post Op Day 4 all was fine. I had my catherter removed Sept 2nd. My anxiety over the removal was much worse than the act itselfminimal discomfort that was over, done and gone in a few seconds. My cath was removed in my Surgeons office. He was able to spare both nerves and said the lymph nodes were clear. Originally Posted by Rich2.0 Hi Jamie, It looks like we both had our surgery on the same day! I am a bit behind schedule on the catheter removal. I'm scheduled to have mine removed first thing tomorrow morning. I know I'm going to leak like a sieve the first day but getting rid of this ball and chain will be quite liberating. I don't have any pearls of wisdom to share at this point -just some words of encouragement. Hang in there and please post back often. I will be following this thread closely. Hello guys - I'm just a week behind you two, so I will be referring back to this thread often to check on your progress. Unfortunately I did not have much time to practice Kegels pre-op, but have also read that it has limited value until afterwards. My surgery was pretty much uneventful, much like JJackson's. My cath comes out in two days. Others I have spoken with mention six months as most common time to regain full control over continence. Good luck everyone!

Posts.Title: Post op Day 10

Posts.Content: OTS - I chose to have adjuvant RT at a local urology practice in Clearwater that was just around the corner from home. I had contacted Moffitt but decided not to drive an hour or three to and from every day. My RO is now retired, but there were guys there who drove from all over to see him. One guy was from Winter Haven and he and his wife drove here in their RV on Mondays and returned on Fridays, for nine weeks. I bet if you look around you can find someone if not in Ft Myers at least maybe Sarasota that isn't too far away.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 RobLee, while his PSA is not 3 digits, if it is indeed 40, that to me is a cause for concern. I was not being critical of u, I have great respect for your opinions, and the amount of time you give to others. No disrespect intended. Best to all, MM Thanks, MM... and no offense taken. Again, the PSA 40 is quite high, but not near the highs that some have reported. I was alarmed when my PSA hit 25, but my Uro/RO says he's seen PSA's around 1000... I did not even know that was possible.
Posts.Title: Just got diagnosis

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 Brother RobLee even called it moderate. Is your PSA 40 as listed in your post, or am I missing something? FWIW MM, please consider my remark in context. I was referring to his PSA as being in line with a G8 and possible T3 pathology, rather than the triple digit PSA's associated with stage 4 G9/10 guys here. Perhaps "moderately high" would have been more accurate, but my intent was to allay any fears that he might need to undergo chemo. Originally Posted by RobLee If you're thinking traditional chemotherapy, that is unlikely for PCa at your stage. Typically that is reserved for G9 or G10, where the cancer has already left the prostate bed and spread throughout the body.... that is, assuming your scans don't reveal something worse then your G8 rating and moderate PSA level would indicate.

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosis

Posts.Content: Unless you have other health problems that may shorten your life, I would recommend ART as soon as your continence and erectile function reach an acceptable level of healing (6 mos). Your SVI plus primary grade 4 pathology puts you in the very high risk category, just as I was. In fact, my first year post-op was chaos as I tried to get adjuvant RT underway within twelve months. During that time, my PSA was checked monthly and it crept up ever so slightly from <.02 to .02 to <.03 and so on. Even though I've read that men with such adverse pathologies stand a 50/50 chance of getting by without ART, I didn't want to wait for BCR to get a foot hold. If there is residual cancer left in your abdomen, you definitely want to zap it before it moves on to greener pastures. But again, this is assuming otherwise good health on your part, or at least as good as one can expect. Good luck to you!

Your SVI plus primary grade 4 pathology puts you in the very high risk category, just as I was. In fact, my first year post-op was chaos as I tried to get adjuvant RT underway within twelve months. During that time, my PSA was checked monthly and it crept up ever so slightly from <.02 to .02 to <.03 and so on. Even though I've read that men with such adverse pathologies stand a 50/50 chance of getting by without ART, I didn't want to wait for BCR to get a foot hold. If there is residual cancer left in your abdomen, you definitely want to zap it before it moves on to greener pastures. But again, this is assuming otherwise good health on your part, or at least as good as one can expect. Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Adjuvent or Salvage Radiation?

Posts.Content: You were right to take time to enjoy the summer and ponder your choices. True, your predominantly G6 tumor(s) will grow slowly and likely present no problem. But the grade 4 core, though only 20%, can be quite aggressive. Furthermore, that core was located at the apex, where a positive surgical margin is more likely to occur in the event of extraprostatic extension. I'd say you can't afford to wait much longer. Also IMO, based on your age and assuming good health, you are an ideal candidate for robotic prostatectomy, and are most likely to enjoy a rapid and full recovery. Regarding radiation, often that is chosen for older men or those who are poor surgical candidates, and those whose cancer is much more advanced. Older in that the after effects of radiation may not show up for twenty years, and I believe that you would not want to find out in your seventies that perhaps you should have chosen surgery twenty years earlier. Just my opinions. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Half Way Through SRT

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by derbyrobert My brother recently had a prostatecomy and has never been the same since. I am a Clinical Psychologist and have noticed the significant changes... but these in no way account for this personalty change. The changes that result from prostate cancer and more importantly cancer treatment certainly changes ones outlook on life. However, I had an experience that began long before my diagnosis and treatment. I started having some troubling prostate symptoms nearly four years ago, and had a biopsy a few months later which was negative, but turned out later to be a false negative... in other words, the biopsy completely missed the tumor. That was the beginning of a very rough year, and for the next two years I was prone to episodes of crying and my wife frequently told me that I was depressed. I have never had any psych or emotional problems, but spoke with my doctor and he pretty much dismissed the symptoms that I presented to him. Two years later another biopsy identified the tumor and I had a prostatectomy, was started on Lupron and the antidepressant Effexor, had a urinary implant and underwent two months of radiation. My life has definitely changed as a result of the treatments, but mentally I feel far better off than I did two or three years ago. I believe now that during those two years between the negative biopsy and the positive one and subsequent treatments that I actually did have a tumor growing in me and that it affected my personality and my mental and emotional state, perhaps chemically. I have never heard anyone else mention this, but what I experienced was real. Perhaps your brother is obsessed with his new project as an item on his bucket list. But maybe the cancer growing in his prostate actually affected his personality by means of a physical process.

Posts.Title: prostate personality change

Posts.Content: Unless there is some laboratory inconsistencies, it probably means there is still some cancer in his prostate bed that was left behind during his RP. You do not mention his Gleason score or pathology staging. Sometimes cancer escapes the prostate for example along nerve pathways. If his PSA reaches 0.1 then two consecutive PSA tests will determine his doubling rate and give you an idea when he might need salvage radiation. At least that's what I understand how it works. Or it could just be nothing. That's always a possibility... but not likely.

Posts.Title: Life Expectancy Expected To Rise To 80 By 2030

Posts.Content: Mike - Sorry to hear the news, but I just gotta say... you're breaking the news in someone else's thread (unless you are Kim's husband, then I'm sorry, I misunderstood). If so the moderator should move your post to its own thread. So about the cancer, your G8 is higher than most of the guys here. Typically G7's are when guys come here asking about options. For G8 things are a bit further along than you'd like. There is a possibility that it has already spread outside the prostate. Just a possibility. There are a few of us here with that. Generally the option most often chosen is surgery, with the primary reason being that if the surgery does not get all the cancer out, then you can have radiation afterwards (referred to as salvage radiation) to clean up the abdominal bed. If radiation is performed first, the tissues become deformed and follow up surgery if needed is far less likely to be successful. If you're thinking traditional chemotherapy, that is unlikely for PCa at your stage. Typically that is reserved for G9 or G10, where the cancer has already left the prostate bed and spread throughout the body. There are probably more guys here at that stage than at yours and mine... that is, assuming your scans don't reveal something worse then your G8 rating and moderate PSA level would indicate. Good luck, Mike. Keep us informed.

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosis

Posts.Content: Hi Jay, and welcome to cancer forums dot net. You know me from the chatroom, so no introductions needed. Read the sticky on HT at the top of the forum list if you haven't already. Yeah, I'm on Lupron, about halfway thru my course. Next and hopefully final six month shot will be in January. Worst things about it for me are the hot flashes and mood swings. I fought to get a Rx for Venlafaxine which has made the hot flashes tolerable and the mood swings bearable. I'd say it has reduced the frequency, intensity and duration of both, but I keep a fan by my Sheldon seat on the sofa and one at my bedside. I bought an external on/off switch to make it easier generally it's on only a minute or so. Good luck Jay and see you in chat! One Day More!

Posts.Title: Sweating Bullets

Posts.Content: Congrats on your consistently low PSA level Hammer, and here's hoping that continues for you (and for me... next PSA is in two weeks). Regarding the balloon, Rooster strongly recommended it and I asked my RO about it twice. He told me that about half of G/U RO's use the balloon and half do not, and he does not. That was that. The treatment facility is right around the corner from my home so I wasn't about to drive an hour away every day just to get to experience a rectal balloon (as much as I may have wanted to ). They were however quite adamant about the full bladder thing, and several times, especially when I was sick, warned me that they wouldn't treat me the next day if it wasn't full. The treatments were about ten minutes each, and generally I was seen on time or even a little early. One of the tech's informed me that the alignment, pre-scan and treatment takes about seven minutes, plus a few for getting the pt on and off the table. This was using fairly new equipment. I'd imagine some older machines required more time on the table and therefore the balloon is necessitated. I can only imagine the delay that it's insertion, filling and removal would introduce, plus time allowance for any "accidents". So I did not have the balloon, and that's all I can add to this discussion. I did however experience persistent diarrhea, gas and frequent BM's... several per day, starting the second week of RT and extended several months afterwards. The RO did not warn me in advance and I only knew about the possibility of bowel distress by reading forums. There are of course other forums where everyone would have us believe that radiation has zero side effects. When I was really sick with the diarrhea was when the tech's would warn me about my bladder not being full. No one seemed to be very concerned about the GI SE's. The RO instructed me to eat Activia 2X daily. Additionally I found there were foods even beyond the extensive list they had given me that I had to eliminate from my diet during RT and on Dr's orders for several weeks afterwards. Good luck going forward, brothers.

Posts.Title: Hubby just diagnosed

Posts.Content: My AUS was finally turned on last Friday. Life with the AUS is certainly better than without it. Yesterday we went to the beach and it was only the second time in the past year that I was able to wear a swimsuit. It was great... lounging on the beach, swim in the gulf, pool, hot tub, shower... all without feeling that I had to hide something or eventually go back into some awkward, inconvenient plumbing or soaking thru my clothes. All is not totally dry however. The swimsuit was not a problem as it is typically wet anyway. But by the end of each day the thin pad I wear inside my shorts has numerous stains... just spots, nothing soaked. Now and then I can feel a bit of a surge, a sensation that were it not for the AUS would have been a squirt. Typically bending or lifting a certain way. I do already have fairly good control of my natural sphincter and it takes some getting used to it knowing how to squeeze the pump and then release my natural sphincter to pee normally. So I find sitting is slightly more convenient than standing. I suppose that if I had waited long enough, eventually I might regain something close to full control. However the matter of radiation pretty much meant that I had to proceed with having the AUS implanted. First off, my SRT had already been delayed too long, now approaching a full year since RP. It was necessary to be able to hold a full bladder in order to proceed with IMRT. It could not wait another six months for me to regain full control. Secondly, I have heard speaking with others who have undergone SRT that the radiation actually worsened their urinary control. So they ended up less continent than they were going into it. All that plus the fact that my Urologist told me early on that it was better to have it implanted before receiving radiation rather than after. The only cases of totally failed AUS implants that I know of were guys who had it put in after having radiation. I did not want to be in that boat. But all is not perfect though. Somehow the revision surgery two weeks after the original implant left me with some sort of trigger nerve pain in my groin involving my upper thigh and my one remaining testicle. It feels somewhere between sciatica and a kick in the balls. I must be very careful getting in and out of the car, even walking. My original Uro said that maybe a nerve got hooked while my legs were in the stirrups. The prosthetic surgeon dismissed that as a possibility. The pain is so intense that even poking around in my groin to find the source of the pain is enough to cause it to hurt for several days. I suspect that it is the fitting on the side of the cuff where the tubing connects to the cuff. But there's nothing I can do about it now, and I would not want to further delay SRT while a re-revision would need to heal. Hopefully in another 8-10 years when the whole thing will need replacing that this problem will go away... assuming I am still alive at that point. Tomorrow I return to the RO for my mapping scans and get my marks. Then on Friday my wife is finally having her port removed. Her next CT scan will be in October, probably just after I finish SRT. I've heard that the next two months will go quickly. The dietary restrictions are inconvenient, but hopefully that will be the worst of it. Waiting anxiously for this crazy roller coaster ride to finally come to an end.

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosis

Posts.Content: Mike - Sorry to hear the news, but I just gotta say... you're breaking the news in someone else's thread (unless you are Kim's husband, then I'm sorry, I misunderstood). If so the moderator should move your post to its own thread. So about the cancer, your G8 is higher than most of the guys here. Typically G7's are when guys come here asking about options. For G8 things are a bit further along than you'd like. There is a possibility that it has already spread outside the prostate. Just a possibility. There are a few of us here with that. Generally the option most often chosen is surgery, with the primary reason being that if the surgery does not get all the cancer out, then you can have radiation afterwards (referred to as salvage radiation) to clean up the abdominal bed. If radiation is performed first, the tissues become deformed and follow up surgery if needed is far less likely to be successful. If you're thinking traditional chemotherapy, that is unlikely for PCa at your stage. Typically that is reserved for G9 or G10, where the cancer has already left the prostate bed and spread throughout the body. There are probably more guys here at that stage than at yours and mine... that is, assuming your scans don't reveal something worse then your G8 rating and moderate PSA level would indicate. Good luck, Mike. Keep us informed.

Posts.Content: Hey Sudds, sorry about your streak of bad luck, but you are not alone. I think one out of four RP's return a final Gleason higher than the biopsy, so it happens. Several other FB's here have had that happen. Fortunately yours was organ confined other than the possible surgical margin, which is not uncommon for a tumor at the apex. You're probably looking at a year or two on HT and two months of RT. I'm now in my seventh week with just nine treatments left (total 7000 rads). My tumor was also 25% volume, about the same as yours. So you're in good company here. We're all fighting for you and we're all behind you. Good luck going forward. Just keep your chin up and move ahead. Eventually this will all end and you will come out on top.

Posts.Content: Thank you BAB (and everyone else) for your thoughts. I should mention that surgery is now scheduled for Oct 29th. Next week I make the rounds once again with the surgeon and the hospital admissions dept to go over what has transpired in the past month. I'm trying to remain emotionally calm about this whole thing, but as most everyone here knows, that's really not possible. Just framing this as something inevitable and whatever comes of it, I'll address it at that time. Thanks again!
Posts.Title: Update on my other condition...

Posts.Content: Good luck with the continence. As I recall my doc said don't attempt sex (of any form) for about 3-4 weeks... probably about how long you are on lifting restrictions. Most guys other than those few who are fully continent right away start having dry nights around a month also, with most regaining full continence in 3-6 months. Most continence returns within 9-10 months, though some still see improvement during the second year.

Posts.Title: New Question - Decipher

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman ... on my way home from a 10 day trip to Baton Rouge, Orlando, and Lake Worth, Florida... I have to say, it was a great respite. I thought less about cancer. Which was nice, because lately it seems like cancer has occupied my thoughts more than any other topic. Which truly sucks. Anyone else feel this way? Hello, Captain! Glad you got away from the gloomy world of cancer. I know that the busy mind does not drift into darker thoughts. Sometimes when I'm researching something related to cancer I just get sick of it and shut down. We are in fact right now in Orlando for a week... actually Kissimmee... well actually my phone says Celebration. Anyway, we spent yesterday at Universal Studios and IOA. We decided to buy season passes this year, and are planning for some of our family to join us here around Thanksgiving.[/QUOTE] Anyway, my respite is about to end... I'll go for my blood draw for PSA. On top of that, my wife is having a CT Scan on Friday, 1st one since finishing chemo for ovarian cancer, 5 weeks ago. Oh the joys of being a "cancer couple" ... Next week Lori has her post-chemo PET/CT scans to see if the cancer is gone, or if she goes back on chemo for a couple more rounds. Then the following Monday I go under the knife for my implant. Yes, sweating bullets indeed! I remember when you lost your "<". How sad... I guess mainly because it generally does not go back down again. But you still have a lo-o-o-o-ong way to go before the .1 mark. I would think that after two years you probably have a lot of time before any continual rise would reach the point of requiring action. Perhaps you may join us in the wonderful world of Lupron. Good luck with you PSA, end especially good luck to your wife with her scans. And welcome back, Captain!

Posts.Content: Good points from Ed and Djin. My doc said ten lbs was the limit for 30 days, and I found out just how much a gallon of milk or a 12 pack really weighs. If in doubt, don't do it. About Mr Foley, I like most guys was worried about it's removal. In the end, the anticipation was far worse than the actual removal. In fact, it even tickled! I've had several Foleys since then and don't fear them nearly as much as my first time, about twelve years ago. It sounds like your husband is doing remarkably well, and here's hoping everything returns to normal in good time!

Posts.Title: Sweating Bullets

Posts.Content: Congratulations Dan on the improvement, even if it is only slight it is something, and may improve in the future. And also for making the right choice. With the apical margin and tert 5, it's better to treat now before the horses get too far away from to corral. I think these days they use .03 as the threshold for possible future recurrence. Good luck going forward. It takes a couple of week to get into the swing of things... when to drink and how much, what you can eat and a hint of what side effects may be ahead for you. Weeks 3-5 were pretty rough for me, and it seemed like it will never end... then the fatigue hits you all of a sudden at week 6. And then just as suddenly you're looking at only a few days left, and get really happy. At least I did. Same 39 Tx, 70 Grays. Hope all goes well for you!

Posts.Title: Validation of ART, I suppose

Posts.Content: Unless there is some laboratory inconsistencies, it probably means there is still some cancer in his prostate bed that was left behind during his RP. You do not mention his Gleason score or pathology staging. Sometimes cancer escapes the prostate for example along nerve pathways. If his PSA reaches 0.1 then two consecutive PSA tests will determine his doubling rate and give you an idea when he might need salvage radiation. At least that's what I understand how it works. Or it could just be nothing. That's always a possibility... but not likely.

Posts.Title: Udate and question

Posts.Content: My understanding is - and this is purely non-technical and non-medical, that positive margins mean that some cancer cells remain in the area of the prostate after the prostate itself has been removed. First one must realize that EVERYTHING in the body is squished together. Various "parts" are not distinct from each other as clearly as they are in drawings or in the plastic models we may have seen. When the surgeon gets in there, basically EVERYTHING is red, and all looks very much the same. Tissues have different textures and contours and the surgeon must distinguish them from each other by visual and tactile recognition. So I'm guessing that he/she must cut away just enough but not too much. Cutting too deep means they've cut into something else. My surgeon used a "broad cut" and he told me afterwards that he "removed a lot of tissue". This was because my cancer was more extensive than the scans had indicated, and when asked about nerve sparing, both my wife and I emphasized that eliminating the cancer was to be the highest priority. Consequently I lost much in the way of urinary and sexual functioning... But he proudly told me "negative nodes and negative margins". I have observed in these prostate forums that many of the men who experienced recurrence had a positive margin, sometimes at the bladder neck, but more often in the area of the apex where the prostate is anchored to the pelvic floor... even though they may have had a relatively low Gleason score and lesser pathological stage. The surgeon may have been focused on more conservative treatment to avoid cutting away too much of the surrounding tissue.

Posts.Title: First Ever PSA = 0.00 !

Posts.Content: Wow. I've been away from CFN for a few days, I come back in and there's like forty updated threads and seems like dozens of new names. I must apologize to my friends here as there is no way I will be able catch up on all these back threads (I'm still in a narcotic fog and can't even remember what I've said in which threads). Anyway, I had Foleys in for two weeks following the implant surgery, then had a cystoscopy Tuesday morning following the holiday weekend and was admitted for emergency surgery that night to revise the AUS. Procedure went well, or seems to anyway... much better than two weeks ago. Still have an abdominal drain tube that comes out tomorrow morning. I posted on HW for those who are there also. Not much else has changed, just hate that I have to go thru the whole constipation thing all over again, just when things seemed to have finally settled down. Interesting side effect... I can't pee standing now, and have to sit like a girl... not sure if this is still an issue with the AUS. Good news is I stay dry when on my feet (yay!). Dr assures me that the urethra will fully heal and that I haven't lost any time on the SRT schedule. June is a big month, marking the one year anniversary since the MRI that revealed my prostate tumor. Just thinking of all that's happened in the past year is mind boggling.

Posts.Title: Hey! I just realized that today was my two year surgery anniversary!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TinkerbellRM27 Regarding his Gleason score, the urologist said I shouldn't really read the report as 4 + 3 = 7 I should read it as 4 + 4 = 8; he said they had to document the 3 because they saw some but that it was predominately 4's. I need serious help determining how to forge ahead with a treatment plan and options. What is the difference for example between a radiation oncologist and a medical oncologist? Also his urologist yesterday when talking made a comment almost how we want to steer away from these oncologists who will pump full of even more toxins that will kill him instead... When you're talkin' 4+4 you're talkin 'bout me! Anyway, I'd say the RO is now you're Dad's doctor. The MO won't be needed unless the bone scan turns up mets. The RO does primary radiation treatment "of your choice" (IMRT, SBRT, "seeds") ... there's a baker's dozen when it comes to primary RT, which is often chosen if there are complicating medical conditions such as heart disease or diabetes. The RO may also come back into the picture if your dad has surgery, as often is the case of grade 4, the cancer has become "locally advanced" also known as stage 3, meaning the cancer had escaped the prostate capsule and become embedded in the pelvic floor. I'm guessing he will end up with radiation anyway, whether as primary treatment or as either adjuvant or salvage radiation following prostatectomy, if for no other reason because of his age and very high PSA.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Results Are In (in less than 24 hours)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TinkerbellRM27 ROBLEE: So when "shopping" for multiple opinions do I shop just among Radiation Oncologists which I assume is what RO stands for? Also, I was surprised his urologist said surgery/removal of the prostate was unlikely from his perspective, for now. Said wanted to wait for bone scan. His Urologist is saying he has "high grade, high risk, metastatic prostate cancer". I am not sure how he knows it has metastasized - he said even if the bone scan was negative there are many time cancer sells embedded missed. But I think he is assuming it has spread based on the PSA, DRE, and 21 of 21 all cancerous. Given his PSA I would not be surprised if it has indeed already metastasized, but I did not want to be too blunt about that just yet. But it sounds like the Urologist is on top of this, if I understand, steering you away from both surgery AND away from going straight to a medical oncologist. In my opinion, yes, a radiation oncologist, preferably one who exclusively does urologic radiation oncology, would be your best bet at this point. You are also right that the number of positive cores indicates that the cancer is pervasive throughout his prostate gland, and the solid G8 score would indicate that your dad will come out of this with a minimum of stage 3A, more likely stage 3B or stage 4, all of which are considered very high risk. If stage 4 he would go straight into hormone therapy (ADT) in order to shrink his prostate and alleviate the urinary symptoms, and also to prepare him for further treatment. Good luck. It certainly sounds like he has a very serious case and what happens over the next few weeks will be critical.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Results Are In (in less than 24 hours)

Posts.Content: For my friends, the surgery that had been scheduled for today was cancelled. Instead I spent most of last week at Moffitt cancer center for a variety of scans which in the end turned out to be inconclusive. So still the only way to determine if this mass in my abdomen is cancer or not will be to have it removed. There are a number of complicating factors involved, which cannot be fully appreciated by anyone who has never experienced them first hand. Let's just say it's a long story. So now I'm looking at maybe mid November... unfortunate as that is the start of the holidays. We had already booked a couple weeks in Orlando which will most likely be non-refundable. But my symptoms are worsening by the day, and despite being assured that this tumor is slow growing, I know I would be worried about it constantly... for it could at any moment develop into an emergency situation, and I certainly don't want that to happen. I know that everyone here has been in this type of very stressful situation , where you have to make potentially life altering decisions with very little information to go on and no useful guidance from others. Every situation is different, and what may have worked for one person may not necessarily work for another. This stuff just never lets up.

Posts.Title: quick update

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JJackson I had a Robotic Assisted Radical Prostatectomy on 9/26. My surgery was pretty uneventful. I was released to home the following day. Of course with a Foley cath, 5 puncture wounds (subcuticular stitches covered with Dermabond) and no JP or any other drain. I share the majority of experiences Ive read hereno issues with the catherter really, very sore lower abdomen and pain in the shoulders. But the discomfort lessened each and by Post Op Day 4 all was fine. I had my catherter removed Sept 2nd. My anxiety over the removal was much worse than the act itselfminimal discomfort that was over, done and gone in a few seconds. My cath was removed in my Surgeons office. He was able to spare both nerves and said the lymph nodes were clear. Originally Posted by Rich2.0 Hi Jamie, It looks like we both had our surgery on the same day! I am a bit behind schedule on the catheter removal. I'm scheduled to have mine removed first thing tomorrow morning. I know I'm going to leak like a sieve the first day but getting rid of this ball and chain will be quite liberating. I don't have any pearls of wisdom to share at this point -just some words of encouragement. Hang in there and please post back often. I will be following this thread closely. Hello guys - I'm just a week behind you two, so I will be referring back to this thread often to check on your progress. Unfortunately I did not have much time to practice Kegels pre-op, but have also read that it has limited value until afterwards. My surgery was pretty much uneventful, much like JJackson's. My cath comes out in two days. Others I have spoken with mention six months as most common time to regain full control over continence. Good luck everyone!

Would like to talk to somebody who had the same surgery and ask questions regarding the results, good and bad.... I had the AUS implanted in May. Posts.Title: Need advice on artificial sphincter

Posts.Content: Very interesting thread... VERY interesting, probably one of the best I've found here. ASA, nice clear stratification of treatment choices vs Gleason score. Denis, I've watched your decision process on multiple forums from the very beginning. James, you hit the nail on the head... salvage radiation vs salvage surgery sealed the deal. Plus a bit of input from Ed and Another... not to omit anyone else (sorry). My brain is a bit foggy from a year on Lupron, so please bear with me. I started having serious problems right around the same time that my wife and I were planning our retirements and ultimate move to Florida... literally the same month. It was just an annoyance. I had been seeing my Urologist for twenty years. He never mentioned the C word. He did a biopsy, which was negative. DRE's were always 'normal'. He frequently told me that my PSA was high, but he never told me what that meant. So I went about with my life... retirement and relocation. When he ultimately retired and I had to find a new doctor, it was a relief when I was finally told that I have cancer. By this time, it was just one more thing I had to deal with (read my blog for more insight). It appeared surgery would the quickest and most efficient means of accomplishing an end. Some radiation options required too much time, others I was not even eligible for due to pathology. The issue of possible salvage sealed the deal. I was told following surgery that I would require radiation. And now I've had both. With surgery I pretty much knew what might happen and when... and in most cases, it did. I can accept that. After radiation, I have no idea what's next. I'm still dealing with bowel issues since the second week of radiation. It was a surprise and it is scary. When I mention it in forums some guys say, yeah, that can happen. Why was I not told about this beforehand? So with regard to surgery, I knew the risks going in and a year later I know which ones became an issue and which ones have not. But with radiation, I just don't know. My final meeting with the RO he told me that I wouldn't know for at least a year whether or not it worked. I would be very concerned if I had chosen primary radiation monotherapy and have no idea whether or not it had cured me, and that I had no further options. And I should add, what other surprises are in store? Will I someday hear that I have colorectal cancer and wonder whether or not it was caused by the radiation? I already have to wait another four months before I can even have a colonoscopy, because of the radiation. Again, it's all a big unknown. I'm just rolling with the punches here. Life throws me a curve ball and I deal with it the best I can.

Posts.Title: Results are in

Posts.Content: Gary-e replied in the incontinence pad experience thread, but I felt it might be better to start a new thread in case anyone else might be interested. Original thread: https://www.cancerforums.net/threads/54632-Incontinence-pad-experience Originally Posted by Gary e Hi roblee. I was always curious about the AUS. Did you have jitters having it installed the first time. My Uro doc said one Con he fears is that I will not know when to pee which may risk bladder infection. So what is it like if you don't mind telling. Thx Gary e Certainly, glad to help in any way I can. Not knowing your condition, I'd say that your doctor's concern should not be a problem, unless there is some reason such as a neurological condition that might cause you to not be able to feel when your bladder is full. Bladder sensations are normal with the AUS, in fact, my natural sphincter still works to some extent but is unreliable. I can tell when my bladder needs to be emptied, and when in front of the urinal or toilet must remember to both manually release the AUS as well as tell my natural sphincter to open up. There is sometimes some pressure buildup and it squirts at first, so it's a bit tricky getting everything right. Regarding the jitters, yes, this was probably one of the most difficult decisions of my life. I was extremely stressed at the time. I knew immediately following the prostatectomy that I would require salvage radiation (called adjuvant radiation) within six months, and that the RT would require holding a full bladder every day long enough for the radiation treatment, about two hours. As mentioned, my sphincter worked but I had little control and would leak copiously at times. Getting the implant I've had a number of other surgeries in my life (the AUS and its revision were numbers 11 and 12 as best I can recount). All had been life and death type situations. The AUS was an elective surgery, not entirely necessary, but would be required to proceed with the radiation in a timely manner. The clock was ticking, and the cancer was growing. Furthermore there are required delays for healing following any surgery and a window of several months before and after radiation. And furthermore getting the AUS would change the way I would have to do something that I do all day every day for the rest of my life! I thought I did everything right. I got literature from the manufacturer. I attended what was basically a sales presentation by a urologist and a RN representative of the manufacturer. I interviewed several urologists and discussed the procedure and recovery. There is a fairly high rate of failure, about 25%, which would further delay getting the radiation underway. I had everything mapped out in a spreadsheet. I had already been thru several months of Kegel coaching with physical therapist. Additionally, to add to my stress level, my wife was undergoing five months of chemotherapy plus a spinal infusion every few weeks. Finally the day came. I was to be the first surgery of the day. By noon I noticed that everyone who had come in after me had already been taken in. Like much of my experience in restaurants, when everyone who came in after me already had there food and I hadn't been served yet. Around noon they told me that the doctor would be late (DUH!) I hadn't had anything to eat or drink all morning and became, uh, emotional. At 2PM they finally took me in and gave me some drugs. I never saw the doctor. I woke up around 6PM and they asked me to pee. I couldn't. The surgeon came in around 8 and inserted a foley catheter after squeezing my nuts to make sure everything was in place. Very painful. For some reason I have never heard of anyone else having such an experience with the AUS. Most say they got the quick and simple procedure that I had been promised. I don't mean to discourage you, because normally this doesn't happen. Apparently. It's Murphy's Law... if anything can possibly go wrong, it will happen to you! For two weeks following the surgery I had a Foley. Everything down there was dark red and purple. Twice the cath was removed and I still couldn't pee. Finally the urologist did a cystoscopy and I was rushed to the hospital for emergency surgery and the AUS was replaced... which seemed to go fairly well. The AUS is left turned off for six weeks afterwards to let things heal. It was good to be rid of the cath, but I started having pains in my left thigh, something I described as being somewhere between sciatica and a kick in the balls. The urologist attributed it to swelling. Sitting is still uncomfortable now after nearly a year I don't worry about the pain (it couldn't be anything too serious, and is not as severe as it was the first month). Again, I've never read of anyone else experiencing this. Living with the implant Life with the AUS is certainly better than being totally incontinent. I wore a leg bag and condom cath for nearly a year before the AUS was finally turned on. The AUS leaks a bit. My natural sphincter is still unreliable. I can feel the AUS cuff in my groin between my butt cheeks. Sitting on hard surfaces I can feel it getting pressured. Sitting in a car for long trips I still feel the pains at the top of my thigh. Again, not normal. But stuff like squirting when sitting and occasional drips requiring wearing a light pad seem to be fairly common. Those who ride bikes require a special seat that is split down the middle. Many guys say they lost what continence they had after radiation. Mine stayed about the same, though it was never very good to start with. I seem to have less nighttime continence than I did before the AUS. Previously I could sleep "dry" with confidence. Nowadays I have to sleep with a dry washcloth in my crotch. I bought a bunch of yellow ones to differentiate between the ones my wife uses on her face. I wear a medical ID bracelet anytime I am in the car or away from home, in the pool etc. It says I should only be cathed by a urologist, someone who knows how to cath past the AUS. Many doctors, nurses and paramedics I know have never heard of an artificial sphincter implant. I understand that the AUS cuff gradually erodes the urethra and must be periodically relocated, at which time they just replace everything. Typically it's every seven years, though some go as long as ten. The dripping is an issue especially in a dry swim suit. Once everything is wet, no problem. There is no maintenance required, other than needing constant backup protection, even when in loungewear. Remembering that it may squirt when first squeezed. Knowing ahead of time how weak or strong the stream may be. It's better than incontinence, but it is not total continence. Some guys report having no problems. I guess they're lucky. I guess I shouldn't be surprised. There was a one in twenty chance that RP would leave me incontinent. I was one of the unlucky 5%. There was a one in four chance that the AUS would require revision. I was one of the unlucky 25%. And I don't know what the odds are of still having issues long term after the implant activation. Same thing with RT. Most guys say they had no problem. I developed diarrhea the second week which persisted beyond the end of treatments. Just one lucky guy I guess, wink.

Posts.Title: Extraprostatic extension (EPE) and Adjuvant Radiation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD My thinking is I'd rather go through it sooner rather than later. Get this behind me which is why I choose surgery in the first place - over with quicker. Now I just need to get the go ahead from the docs and get into an RO sooner than I could myself. Then , of course, will insurance cover it at this point? Like I said, I thought I was done with this and all the decisions that go with it, but not yet. Yeah, tell me about it! ... I often wonder if and when it is finally "over." Your RO should be able to make the case to your insurance company if he is fully committed to your treatment. So maybe you may need to see several RO's before finding one who is willing go to bat for you. Just be sure you have the pre-auth from your insurance before proceeding. It is always better to get this going before it gets out of hand. I'd say you have six months to complete your quest and have a treatment plan in place... maybe just enough time for those three consecutive PSA rises, depending on how well your RO is willing to accept your PSA's so far. He may want to use a specific lab before relying on the numbers. Also you may start HT before RT and possibly chemo soon afterwards. There is a lot more emphasis these days on treating early and hitting hard, but I think the majority are still old school and want to just wait and see.

Posts.Content: Dave, in my opinion you should consider yourself well on the way to BCR and looking into SRT. I remember seeing the same report mentioned by Prato that urologists tend to recommend SRT much later than RO's do. The same website also has a report that starting SRT before 21 months post-op has far better outcomes than waiting until the .2 threshold is crossed. This is what has led the the current thinking that three consecutive rises above .03 should trigger SRT (I'm generalizing here). With your positive surgical margin and small secondary grade 4 pathology I believe that should be considered sufficient adverse pathology to at least consider initiating SRT. Remember that grade 4 is the type that spreads, and essentially there is no grade 1 or 2 in this scoring method. The philosophy behind early SRT (eSRT) is to zap any remaining cancer cells that may have escaped (+SM) while they are still localized and before they leave the prostate bed and move on to other areas of the body... which is probably what Prato is facing right now. Even a small number of grade 4 cells could have easily been missed in pathology but are enough to set up residence. Please realize that I have no medical training and my opinions are often refuted because I don't cite specific studies and such, but I've seen enough and been thru enough that I recognize a duck when I see a duck. At this stage, one year post-op, you are playing a game of odds. Your condition may progress or it may not... there is no way to know now what the future will hold. I think you have made the right decision having your PSA re-evaluated and recognized that you are not in Kansas anymore. When it is your life that you are betting on, it becomes an entirely different game than the one your doctors are facing. Let's say it's like a bacon and eggs breakfast... a chicken was involved, but the pig was committed. Your urologist was involved, but you are committed. Any possibility of BCR means to your Uro that his surgery failed, and he may be reluctant to consider that as a possibility. But it is your future and your life that is on the line. You want to do all you can now, and not allow the beast to gain the upper hand. Good luck!
