Posts.Title: One year Result, no man's land follow up.

Posts.Content: Sorry to read about your problems, and all I can say is we all have them. Read the last line of my signature below. I'll tell you a bit about our problems and try to weave them into yours. Anyway, we've been married for 36 years and our problems began around fifteen years ago when little Peter couldn't perform the way he used to. We had both been sexually active, totally monogamous and very satisfied until around the time that I turned 50. Turns out I had a strangled cord on one testicle. I had surgery, but by then my wife had become bitter that I "didn't love her anymore"... which couldn't be further from the truth. She was also less sexual but blamed it on menopause. None of this helped our situation. About five years ago the testicle was removed and I had pretty much given up on mutual sex. Even going solo had become curiously painful. My PSA was rising but my Urologist just kept putting me on longer and longer courses of antibiotic. Our relationship had become strained and I began having long episodes of crying. I asked my GP but he was no help. I was hoping we might be referred to counseling or something. Finally I changed doctors and was given an MRI and diagnosed with prostate cancer. Good news, right? At least after three years I finally had something to work with. Well, the cancer was worse than expected, and I resented the time that had been lost. Then a few months after surgery my wife was complaining of severe back pain. Several doctors dismissed it and just gave her more and more pain meds. Sounded familiar to me, so we paid cash for an MRI, which revealed a tumor on her spine, and ultimately turned out to be lymphoma. All this was last December and she finally got out of the hospital very late at night the night before Christmas eve. Merry Christmas! So for the next few months I drove her to her chemotherapy and also to the spinal infusions three days after each chemo. Lots of scans etc in there also. My own treatment for the PCa was also ongoing and as soon as she finished chemo I had two surgeries to implant an artificial urinary sphincter because I was still leaking like crazy and needed to get started on follow up radiation for my own cancer. That finally ended just two months ago, and we had a wonderful Thanksgiving with our sons and their families. Because we both have suffered thru each others' cancers, we now realize that what we have left is nothing like what we had before but have are fortunate to be alive and that we still have each other, which has brought us much closer to each other. I am still on hormone blockade... chemical castration to starve the remaining cancer, and sex is totally out of the realm of possibility. But after what we have been thru together we are looking forward to hopefully a "normal" Christmas this year. So I guess for your case I have to say that if your leaking is an issue you can look into the AUS. If that is appropriate for you, it's the same company that makes the penile implant, which can be put in during the same surgery. I suspect that at your age (and not knowing how old your new bride may be) you probably can't expect to ever be the virile young man you used to be. But tackle each problem one at a time. This past year I also started taking antidepressants, also for the first time ever in my life for something like that, but I feel it has saved my sanity as well as my marriage. Look into that as well, and perhaps also into counseling. Depression and despair can become crippling. I know sometimes it seems there's no way to climb out of the dark hole. And cancer can strike anyone at any time. It sounds like in your case you emerged the victor, for now. Relish the time you have together. Hopefully your wife can be understanding and appreciate what you have been thru. Let her know that you are doing the best you can. Sometimes it takes a brush with death to make one realize just how frail we truly are.

Posts.Title: Rare forms of metastatic cancer / Low PSA production

Posts.Content: You're right that if the cancer has spread to the bones then it is stage 4. Hormone therapy not only makes him moody and irritable but can also cause weight gain as well as calcium loss. Unless you can get more info from him or his doctor, that is all you can go on for now. Stubborn men who are secretive about their health, and those who love them are fairly common. Others will surely chime in here.

Posts.Title: Fodder for the pro-PSA test argument

Posts.Content: I just wanted to let everyone know that we just returned from the hospital and my wife's oncologist said she is in complete remission. The PET scan from earlier this week was clear and all the tumors have disappeared. She asked why she was still having so much pain and he said it was because the cancer had eaten away at her bones, and now that it is gone, her bones are filling in again... so she is experiencing "growing pains". He said she has a 70% likelihood of remaining in remission for the rest of her life and "of the other 30% we usually can save about half"... so right around 85%, which is what I had read when I first began to research her PBL back in December. Now she is in surveillance and is supposed to get CT scans every six months, starting in October... which is right around when I hope to finish SRT, assuming everything goes well with the AUS on Monday.

Posts.Title: Wife in full remission

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by derbyrobert My brother recently had a prostatecomy and has never been the same since. I am a Clinical Psychologist and have noticed the significant changes... but these in no way account for this personalty change. The changes that result from prostate cancer and more importantly cancer treatment certainly changes ones outlook on life. However, I had an experience that began long before my diagnosis and treatment. I started having some troubling prostate symptoms nearly four years ago, and had a biopsy a few months later which was negative, but turned out later to be a false negative... in other words, the biopsy completely missed the tumor. That was the beginning of a very rough year, and for the next two years I was prone to episodes of crying and my wife frequently told me that I was depressed. I have never had any psych or emotional problems, but spoke with my doctor and he pretty much dismissed the symptoms that I presented to him. Two years later another biopsy identified the tumor and I had a prostatectomy, was started on Lupron and the antidepressant Effexor, had a urinary implant and underwent two months of radiation. My life has definitely changed as a result of the treatments, but mentally I feel far better off than I did two or three years ago. I believe now that during those two years between the negative biopsy and the positive one and subsequent treatments that I actually did have a tumor growing in me and that it affected my personality and my mental and emotional state, perhaps chemically. I have never heard anyone else mention this, but what I experienced was real. Perhaps your brother is obsessed with his new project as an item on his bucket list. But maybe the cancer growing in his prostate actually affected his personality by means of a physical process.

It was a way to update everyone at once without repeating the same thing over and over on the phone. Seems to have worked well. Hope to be seeing you on the other side. Only 12 more treatments to go for me!

Posts.Title: Do you have a Facebook Group?

Posts.Content: The ultrasound guided biopsy is the traditional first approach to a suspicious prostate. Sometimes it misses existing cancer because it is random in nature. The ultrasound merely guides the needles to the prostate, not to a suspected tumor. Twelve to 15 cores is also the normal sample size. The MRI guided is more accurate but sometimes it is not covered by insurance unless there has been an ultrasound biopsy performed first. Also most doctors are not alarmed by a gradually rising PSA over a period of years, but take action when it approaches 10 or if it suddenly shoots up unexpectedly. Given your history it is possible that there is cancer in your prostate, but there is nothing that can be done until it has been identified and evaluated. So far everything you have described sounds like a textbook case, and everything is proceeding normally and as would be expected. One thing to consider, assuming that a tumor is present, is that you will likely face a choice between surgery or radiation treatment. Your current age and general state of your health will also be a factor in evaluating various alternative treatments. EDIT: Removed singular mention of hormone injections.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another SVI may be an indicator it's too late for localized treatment success in that direction. The location of the extension can be an indicator of risk recurrence and treatment success. Cancer at the base is higher risk in general. It may be more difficult to reach effectively without unacceptable side effects. SVs extend up and behind the bladder. Early detection and treatment may still be a gold standard. Ugh, guess I didn't really want to hear that. Now I won't be able to sleep. Would have loved some of that early treatment. Thanks for the info though.

Posts.Title: Zytiga

Posts.Content: Thank you to those who have already contacted me personally. We are in northern Pinellas county and until just recently it looked like we were going to be directly in the storm's path. Recent landfall at Marco Island and it's current northern track will put the storm just east of Tampa when it passes us overnight tonight. The outermost rain bands passed us about five hours ago and spawned some tornadoes further inland. We have had light rain and gusty winds until right around 4PM. The winds are now picking up and our power has flickered a few times. Our biggest fear is losing power, possibly for several days. They now say on the news that this storm has already sucked most of the water right out of Tampa bay... bad news is the water will return later, with a surge. As much as I would like to see that personally, I'm happy to be indoors right now. Our place is sturdy and I feel safe and on the top floor. Big question was whether or not to move our cars away from trees. I'd hate to move one out into the open and get struck by some other projectile. We had to take in a relative whose home is right on the water. She is not sure what will be left afterwards. We have plenty of food, water and batteries, thank goodness. As far as we know, no one living in our immediate community has had to evacuate. My RO's office called and cancelled treatments for both Monday and Tuesday, which is good news, as I will have a few more days to recover from the SE's... which have been more difficult than expected. Bowel disruptions. Nineteen treatments completed, twenty more to go. Best of luck to the others here in Florida and those to the north who will be affected by this storm. I will try to update more later, assuming we keep our service.

Posts.Title: Hurricane Irma

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tybeeman I think I am more nervous about this then my RP. Understood. I was more apprehensive about the AUS implant surgery than about the RP. Difference is the RP was necessary, and the AUS is elective. Also, once in, the implant would change how I use the bathroom for the rest of my life. Think about how much you take that for granted. Oh, also the AUS was necessary so that I can proceed with salvage radiation to get the rest of the cancer, or so I hope. You are fortunate that this has not been an issue for you. ... find someone that will help you with depression. It can be tough on some of us. Important indeed. I understand that the loss of sexual function can undermine a man's sense of identity and purpose. Genuine depression can result from the uncertainty of how many years you have left. Many doctors don't get that. They see cancer every day, but for you and me it is a "big deal". When it happens to YOU, it's very personal.

Posts.Title: 16 months Post OP, I give up

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tim5965 ... my surgeon says I have a high probability of recurrence. Diagnosed 18 months ago with Gleason 9, 11/12 biopsy cores >50%, PSA 23. Some seminal vessical invasion and extraprostatic extension. Had six months of Lupron and Zytiga, PSA immediately came down to .3 and then to .2, Radical Prostatectomy on March 1. 24 lymph nodes clear and negative margins. PSA of zero at 30 days and zero again at 5 months. My testosterone is only 12 after 5 months so I guess that could be keeping my PSA at zero but that it’s likely to reappear as testosterone recovers. Does that sound right? Sounds like you are actually doing very well. I'm curious if your G9 is (4+5) or (5+4)... I'm assuming 4+5 as I've noticed that in cases with a grade 5 primary component (if known from biopsy) surgeons are less likely to operate and instead prefer move the patient on to an RO+MO. Our cases are not dissimilar... I was solid 4+4, extensive EPE and bilateral SVI, and like you, neg margins and neg nodes. My last PSA five months pre-op was 25. Post-op it was around .02-.03 and was put on Lupron. My first three PSA's after completing adjuvant radiation have been 0.0 Of course, none of us will know just which way this will go until all the treatments have worn off a couple of years from now. My doc says my PSA may go up to "one" (I'm hoping he means .01). OTOH I know an 82 year old who had RP+RT fifteen years ago and his PSA is zero. Originally Posted by G24 I understand that you are having ADT now. Since you are high risk, it is correct to combine the radiation with ADT. Here is a trial that shows how long high risk patients will live if they had two years of ADT after surgery. Most of them well over ten years. G24, thanks for the link. It was interesting that the MP arm of the study (Mitoxantrone** plus Prednisone) had a higher incidence of other cancers and only slightly better increase in PCa specific survival. Most interesting is: "Conclusion MP did not improve OS and increased deaths from other malignancies. The DFS and 10-year OS in these patients treated with 2 years of ADT were encouraging compared with historical estimates..."

Posts.Content: Interesting story... I can't say that I've run across a similar situation anywhere, at least in the past year. But this type of scenario may become more common today with so much genetic testing available (I recently did an Ancestry DNA myself). I believe you were smart to decide NOT to pass on the family curse, and I think - if I understand correctly - that your question is if anyone here agrees that you should pursue having preventative prostatectomy before you become stricken as have your ancestors. I would say, if Angelina Joley can have bilateral mastectomies based solely on genetic testing, then go for it. You may have some difficulty with the national healthcare system balking at circumventing protocol, but you may be able to find someone to champion your case. Good luck in your efforts. It sounds like you have really been on top of this so far and willing to move forward into uncharted territory.

Posts.Title: genome tested, lots of badness

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 58andscared DRE always reveals normal prostate so far. My concern is that in spite of these frequent PSAs and DREs, I might end up with an aggressive form that gets out of the capsule between exams - which are not conclusive anyway AFAIK. Which is exactly what happened to me, as well as a very small number of others here. I don't know about the Canadian healthcare system, but apparently here in the US, the only thing that will get you treated right away is a DRE, which is often the last thing to show up. Afterwards, I learned from my most recent urologist that at the base of the prostate is nearly impossible to detect tumors by DRE or TRUS. So dividing the prostate into three parts, apex, mid and base, it is not hard to see why approximately one third of TRUS biopsies are falsely negative. I have said it here often that doctors today are more concerned about overtreating than they are about curing.

Posts.Title: 9-year survival differences: aggressive vs. conservative treatment for advanced PC

Posts.Content: Welcome jjkap to the forum and the club that no one wants to be a member of. Like you I live in Florida. I am in the Tampa bay area. MichiganMan and I are G8's with T3B and SVI, which is just one step behind you. I for one consider myself fortunate to have caught it when I did. I do remember reading bio's of some guys here who had G9 and metastatic PCa even though their PSA's were not that high. I have not seen them on the forum in recent months though (I do remember their screen names so could track them down.. hoping they may jump in). I would imagine they are quite busy with their treatments or are out living their lives... I won't go any further into it than that. Whatever comes I wish you the best of luck in dealing with this terrible disease.

Posts.Title: I have metastatic prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe Is it the surgery that scares you. Are you afraid you will die on table or the side effects... I suppose the first few are scary. After a dozen or so it's just another surgery. Yes, there are risks. And stuff can happen. And the more surgeries you have, the narrower your odds become. Usually everything goes just fine. The thing that scares me most is "intraoperative recall".

Posts.Title: I have metastatic prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks guys... The hospital called and my ETA is 8:30AM, so I guess I'll be going under around 10 or so. Gary, this is at Morton Plant hospital (that's the factory where they make salt, right?). It's the main hospital in the Baycare chain that owns most of the medical facilities in Pinellas county... Clearwater/St Pete. It's a nice building right on the intercoastal waterway. It would be nice if I "luck out" like I did with my RP back in Ohio. Someone must have recognized my wife's name and I was put in the executive suite... private room with a sofa, conference table and a panoramic view of our city of seven hills. But hopefully I will remember to inquire about paying the upcharge to get a private room... if I can think of it Monday morning. The surgeon said two days if he can do it laproscopically, and five days if he has to open me up (one in three possibility of that). Don't let the forum fall apart while I'm gone MF Hopefully I'll be online over the weekend, and if I remember to take my tablet, feel up to posting from the hospital.
Posts.Title: Wish me luck... Please!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 Rob... LVI and lymph node involvement are two different things. His pelvic LN taken during surgery were negative. That's NO. LVI being positive is saying that the tumor violated the lymph system, another way for it to spread. Same as me. Thanks MM.... still not sure I understand the difference between lymph nodes and lymph system, but glad it didn't affect mine (and sorry yours were). Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 HT combined with SRT produce results 50% better than either one alone. Early ADT kills local and stray cells, before they get out of hand. My RO told me the same thing yesterday and ordered HT before I start RT.... I get my first Lupron shot tomorrow - whoopee!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Moonshadow His doctor seems insistent that he shouldn't have the pain and symptoms he's having right now on the Lupron. Yes, us callous and uncooperative patients continuously and deliberately refusing to respond to doctors' treatments the way they expect that we should.
Posts.Title: Possible castrate resistance in newly diagnosed father

Posts.Content: My Urologist had me taking saw palmetto for years, in fact it must have been a couple of decades. I will say that I seemed to do better with it than without it. I bought the whole herb supplement at first, but later bought only the extract form. Look at the label to see the concentration, as it varies widely. I would normally take it once in the morning with something like buttered toast to transport the fat plus buffer the digestive acids. It can be very hard on your stomach or could be ineffective if not taken with food. The SP was a curse as well as a blessing. It seemed to help with my urinary problems, and as my Urologist had recommended it, I trusted that it was safe and effective. Over the years, other than asking me if I was still taking it, he did little else other than prescribing the occasional antibiotic... even when it turned out that I actually had cancer. I'm not sure who I blame more for the outcome, him or my own belief in him. If you find yourself in a similar situation, I would say it wouldn't hurt to use it if it helps, but if your problems persist then you should look beyond OTC supplements.

Posts.Title: Saw Palmetto

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tybeeman Boy that is a long post LOL. I am a bad reader and a worst writer so pardon my bad writing skills. ... with any radiation you will almost always have some type of recurrence in 20 years. that make you 87. At 56 I would be 76. My dad was 95 when he died and my mother is still alive at 93. I did want to deal with it at 76. Tybee - one bad reader to another, I'm guessing that you do NOT want to deal with it at 76... and I'm in the same boat as you. Called a "slow reader" or "problem reader" in high school, ended up not surprisingly with low verbal and high math SAT's... engineering material for sure. Today they call it mild dyslexia. I can read but have to repeatedly start over and over to finish a sentence, especially if someone has used internet jargon "u r", or when they use the wrong their there or the wrong wear where. Another - I am always impressed with the depth of your knowledge and your mastery of language. I am jealous. In light of what I've said in the previous paragraph, perhaps you understand why. Also perhaps you can appreciate the amount of effort that I must conjure up to respond to posts here on cancer forums. People ask what I do in my retirement... this is what I do. It takes a lot of my time. In the months and years ahead when one or the both of us have moved on I will miss reading your insights... as well as that of many other forum brother here. Tybee - is your PSA rising? Are you doing anything about it? Sorry if I missed something, but your numbers and your timeline look awful (no offense please).

Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: All I can say is thank goodness for GP's because my Uro did do anything. I've told the story here before, but will repeat it again. My GP was concerned about my rising PSA, so I went to the Urologist I had been seeing for more than a decade. He said he was not concerned. I requested a DRE which he said was normal. A year later I experienced persistent urethral burning. He tested my PSA and it was 9.5 so he did a biopsy, which was negative. He put me on Cipro which alleviated the burning, and so for the next two years I kept going on longer and longer courses of Cipro, until we moved and I had to find a new doctor. My new GP found two bumps on the right side of my prostate and asked if I'd had an MRI. My PSA was 25. I returned to my Uro and told him about the bumps. He dismissed that and called them "concretions." When I asked him about the MRI he said he does not do MRI's. Then he said he was retiring and his partner would take over my case. Suddenly I was flooded with calls to setup appointments for all kinds of tests. Two months later my prostate was removed. Had I known then what I know now, I would have sought out another urologist years earlier.

Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: Because you will be going every day, convenience will be very important. I start radiation in August also, and had to choose between a local clinic or drive to Tampa to a large cancer center. You'll be driving there and back five days a week for 6-8 weeks, and you probably don't want a six hour daily commute.

Posts.Title: Who to choose for radiation?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F The "Club Zero" membership committee has fast tracked your application. You are IN! May 2018 be the year that PCa has been put into the past. I like that! And thanks for the "HUGE" welcome, and yes, 2018 is looking much better already! Admittedly I'm still in a bit of shock over this. I wasn't expecting it at all. Eventually it will sink in.
Posts.Title: First Ever PSA = 0.00 !

Posts.Content: I started eating more rice and bananas, and had to cut down on berries, as much as I love them. Too many caused me problems. Also I started having Activia yogurt daily at my RO's recommendation. For me, the whole plant based diet thing has never worked. I gotta have meat, but because of other GI issues can no longer eat fatty meats like barbecue or anything deep fried. So I stick with grilled chicken breast and lean cuts of beef. There is a brief PDF on radiation colitis from PCLPath (the url is very long) if you Google "patient diagnosis resource for radiation colitis".
Posts.Title: Bowel movements after RT

Posts.Content: If I were you Mike I'd plan on staying in a nearby motel for a few night and let your nurse/wife bring in food. You will be working on your "bowel program" for a while also... could make for a very uncomfortable drive. Maybe THEN spend a day or two living on broccoli and quinoa. Just sayin'. You'll be glad you did.

Posts.Title: The Drive Home

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tom182 I went over the results with my urologist and he recommended salvage radiation in the near future. He thought I should wait ... to give my body more time to heal since it's only been a little over a year from my surgery. I'm guessing the radiation oncologist would want to start immediately. Tom, sorry you got the not-so-good news. Presumably the rising PSA is attributable to your positive margin, as I don't see any other extraprostatic extension mentioned in your sig. But I see that you are using only 1 pad per day. I can't imagine just what kind of "healing" your uro expects to occur by waiting longer. If your PSA is in fact doubling, you probably want to get SRT underway asap. I was originally scheduled to begin SRT this month, but the RO hopes that my incontinence might improve by waiting a few months... currently 8-10 pads/day. You have that one licked. What would you be waiting for? Originally Posted by Another Newer information just posted recently on these threads may indicate sooner rather than later. Even as soon as .03. Not sure this is mainstream yet, but something to ask the oncologist. I don't recall reading that, but I do believe it could be true. Currently mine is hovering just below .03, and RO wants to proceed as soon as possible. Current plan is to have the AMS800 implant and begin SRT as soon as that heals up. (I've posted a few times here seeking opinions on that but have had zero replies). If I were down to one pad per day, SRT would begin tomorrow.

Posts.Title: Not Again......

Posts.Content: Michael - You were fortunate to not have any incontinence following surgery, but reading your bio I am wondering why you are staged as T3a even though there is seminal vesicle invasion. From what I've read SVI is staged as T3b. Your sig also mentions lymphatic invasion, but you are staged at N0... again, I thought LNI would be N1.... just curious.

Posts.Title: PSA after both prostate removal and radiation going up 2016

Posts.Content: I've been getting colonoscopies every three years and was due for one just before starting radiation, but my RO said that if I had it done that I would have to postpone the start of radiation (again!) so I dlayed the colo until six months after the end of RT. This was a joint decision between my RO and my gastro, as I had also developed radiation colitis during the ART. I think the only requirement of the colo with regard to RT is that there be six months of healing between one and the another. It's probably a good idea to have your colon checked for damage. Two years on Lupron for me. I was not put on Casodex as my PSA was still fairly low following RP. But the Lupron keeps hanging on, and I'm getting really fed up after two years of hot flashes and brain fog.

Posts.Title: New to forum and to diagnosis of prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 58andscared DRE always reveals normal prostate so far. My concern is that in spite of these frequent PSAs and DREs, I might end up with an aggressive form that gets out of the capsule between exams - which are not conclusive anyway AFAIK. Which is exactly what happened to me, as well as a very small number of others here. I don't know about the Canadian healthcare system, but apparently here in the US, the only thing that will get you treated right away is a DRE, which is often the last thing to show up. Afterwards, I learned from my most recent urologist that at the base of the prostate is nearly impossible to detect tumors by DRE or TRUS. So dividing the prostate into three parts, apex, mid and base, it is not hard to see why approximately one third of TRUS biopsies are falsely negative. I have said it here often that doctors today are more concerned about overtreating than they are about curing.

Posts.Title: genome tested, lots of badness

Posts.Content: Nick - If you truly have seminal vesicle involvement then you are already in the high risk group, where you join MM and me. MM knows what he's talking about. And Jim's remark about the professor's mental state should also be considered. My PCa appeared three and a half years ago, yet my Urologist took his time dealing with it. Later it turned out he had health problems of his own and mine was not addressed seriously until he retired. By then it had already begun to spread... as has yours. Our cases are different, but given your mention of SVI then you are also (for lack of a signature) stage pT3B. Next stage is bone metastasis, which becomes MUCH more difficult to treat. None of us are medical professionals, but it's obvious to all of us (I think) that you should at least be on HT now... and that only buys time. You do NOT want to allow this to progress any further! The window typically closes after 18-24 months. Good luck!

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: If I were you Mike I'd plan on staying in a nearby motel for a few night and let your nurse/wife bring in food. You will be working on your "bowel program" for a while also... could make for a very uncomfortable drive. Maybe THEN spend a day or two living on broccoli and quinoa. Just sayin'. You'll be glad you did.

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic The chances of missing existing cancer go down very fast with repeat biopsies. Except in your case, Djin. And in any case where the Uro intends to keep poking at the same area of the prostate, hoping for a lucky strike, without considering any alternative approach. Originally Posted by Ready2Fight Yes for us. First biopsy came back negative and my husband was ready to celebrate... not so fast Mr. MRI guided biopsy found it in the hard to reach anterior and there was plenty of it. Pathology later revealed that 35% of his prostate was cancerous all while his first biopsy came back showing none. I'm sorry that your husband had to go thru the same ordeal that I did. At least his appears to be relatively low grade and without extraprostatic tissue invasion. And he had you in his corner. And possibly the urologist. True, many would see a negative biopsy as good news. But to me it was disturbing because I had so many symptoms and my urologist wasn't doing anything to help me. I'm sorry everyone. I've been really down all day and it shows in my posts.

Posts.Title: Question about biopsy changes

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Men diagnosed with locally advanced (cT3-T4 or N+ and M0) ... For men with advanced, nonmetastatic prostate cancer, conservative treatment alone was associated with a 4 times higher likelihood of prostate cancer mortality compared with men treated with surgery... the results of the current study did affirm advantages in the setting of locally advanced disease. Thanks for the info DJin. I breathe a massive sigh of relief every time I read something like this, confirming that I was right to throw everything at this disease, and consider myself so very fortunate that it was caught just in the nick of time, before advancing to the next stage.

Posts.Title: 9-year survival differences: aggressive vs. conservative treatment for advanced PC

Posts.Content: Surgical removal of the tumor in my small bowel is scheduled for Monday. I know the board tends to slow down on weekends, and I'm not sure how much time I'll have to post before Monday morning. The hospital is supposed to call with an arrival time by the end of the day today. It may be a successful laparoscopic excision of a (hopefully) benign tumor and I'll just lose a few feet of bowel... maybe even lose some weight. But naturally I've also considered several other worse outcomes, though I would rather not give them voice. I've been in surgical prep mode for a few weeks now... tapering off certain meds, getting clearance from other doctors. I've had to discontinue all supplements that might cause bleeding, and also all narcotics, COX2 and NSAIDS, so my legs are killing me. Starting last night I must shower with surgical scrub, wear only freshly clean clothes and sleep on clean sheets... a newer protocol intended to minimize the possibility of infection. Sunday will be clear liquids only (ugh). My blog has been updated somewhat. As of a few weeks ago I was getting pretty sick of reading about cancer. And re-living a few painful memories. This is the fourth cancer that I've had to get up to speed on in a short time since our retirement three years ago. Looking back, it seems that each life change has served to toughen us up for the next one yet to come. Frankly I'm a bit scared. I know worrying won't help, and so far I seem to have been cruising along, feeling that I'm handling this well... then stop and think about it. My mind drifts away for a few moments, and suddenly realize just how scary this is. I trust the surgeon. He appears confident. But from the start this whole thing has been full of mixed messages. I pray that it turns out to be as simple as he believes it will be.

Posts.Title: The Drive Home

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 Rob... LVI and lymph node involvement are two different things. His pelvic LN taken during surgery were negative. That's NO. LVI being positive is saying that the tumor violated the lymph system, another way for it to spread. Same as me. Thanks MM.... still not sure I understand the difference between lymph nodes and lymph system, but glad it didn't affect mine (and sorry yours were). Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 HT combined with SRT produce results 50% better than either one alone. Early ADT kills local and stray cells, before they get out of hand. My RO told me the same thing yesterday and ordered HT before I start RT.... I get my first Lupron shot tomorrow - whoopee!
Posts.Title: PSA after both prostate removal and radiation going up 2016

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tom182 I went over the results with my urologist and he recommended salvage radiation in the near future. He thought I should wait ... to give my body more time to heal since it's only been a little over a year from my surgery. I'm guessing the radiation oncologist would want to start immediately. Tom, sorry you got the not-so-good news. Presumably the rising PSA is attributable to your positive margin, as I don't see any other extraprostatic extension mentioned in your sig. But I see that you are using only 1 pad per day. I can't imagine just what kind of "healing" your uro expects to occur by waiting longer. If your PSA is in fact doubling, you probably want to get SRT underway asap. I was originally scheduled to begin SRT this month, but the RO hopes that my incontinence might improve by waiting a few months... currently 8-10 pads/day. You have that one licked. What would you be waiting for? Originally Posted by Another Newer information just posted recently on these threads may indicate sooner rather than later. Even as soon as .03. Not sure this is mainstream yet, but something to ask the oncologist. I don't recall reading that, but I do believe it could be true. Currently mine is hovering just below .03, and RO wants to proceed as soon as possible. Current plan is to have the AMS800 implant and begin SRT as soon as that heals up. (I've posted a few times here seeking opinions on that but have had zero replies). If I were down to one pad per day, SRT would begin tomorrow.

Posts.Title: Not Again......

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I really don't see how the risk of overtreatment we read about is an argument against PSA screening... If by overtreatment they are talking about biopsies, better screening tests should be here very soon--until then, docs should explain to the patient their PSA level and trend, what that means, and the pros and cons of doing a biopsy. Amen. IMO there is not enough education of prostate patients by their urologists. My original Uro never said more than a dozen words to me, and at that only when I asked questions. I have informed both of my sons, now in their thirties, that their father had high risk, advanced prostate cancer, that his (my) grandfather died from it, and that they should insist on PSA tests when they are in their forties. Furthermore, I will once again get on my soap box and extol the importance of getting an MRI when there is ANY suspicion of potential prostate problems. ANY, whether from PSA or symptoms or otherwise. It is a relative simple, inexpensive and painless procedure that can identify trouble spots without poking needles thru the bowel and into this critical piece of anatomy that is intricately tied into many body systems and that is well known to eventually develop problems with age. Why an insurance company would risk paying out hundreds of thousands of dollars for adjuvant and salvage therapies for late stage prostate cancer rather than invest a few hundred dollars into reliable early detection of prostate tumors is just beyond me. Penny wise and pound foolish I tell you. In effect, decades of successful prostate cancer screening and treatment have been wiped out in five years since the 2012 USPTF decision. A remarkable change in events that has no parallel in public health history. It was buffoonery of the highest order in 2012; today marks a terse shift back to normalcy. Public health students will be studying this debacle for decades. American men will be dying from it for years. The significance of this final paragraph cannot be overstated. What a pity that so many of us got snared by this political snafu... a typically disastrous side effect of governmental overreach. Read each sentence carefully. Meditate to it in second level. And memorize its implications. Consider yourself fortunate if you were diagnosed early, and pity those of us who screamed from the rooftops for years before anyone would listen. */Rant off/*

Posts.Title: New to forum and to diagnosis of prostate cancer

Posts.Content: That is possible, but unlikely. I'm no expert, but what I've read is that the Lupron is effective for several weeks after the timed release has expired. I assume it was a six month shot. I too am due for my next 6-mo Lupron shot next week but the nurse said she had to make it one week later (now two weeks from today) so that the insurance would not be nit picky over the date. It is probably more likely that his cancer is becoming castrate resistant. His MO has several other avenues to pursue as this is not uncommon. In many cases Lupron does become ineffective after 2 or 3 years. I'm sure others with more experience will contribute more info here. Good luck!

Posts.Title: PSA testing change 2017

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ketoman If the SV have tumours, does that automatically mean the SVs are cancerous? I don't know whether or not tumors actually grow inside the SV's, but cancer cells from tumors in the prostate do migrate into the SV's. So even if there is no tumor in the SV, there can be cancerous cells in there. That's what pathologists look for in the SV's to determine if SV invasion exists... which is the difference between stage T3a and T3b.

Posts.Title: One year ago

Posts.Content: Definitely get a MRI guided Fusion biopsy, or perhaps a saturation biopsy. After three negative "blind" TRUS biopsy you are probably concerned that there is a tumor in there that they just haven't found yet. The fusion biopsy requires special training, and if your Uro is not experienced doing this then find someone else who is. In my case, a false negative biopsy led to an eventual locally advanced very high risk prostate cancer diagnosis following a fusion biopsy. In many cases, insurance policies mandate which tests can be performed when, but one would think that three negative biopsies despite steadily rising PSA should raise some red flags.

Posts.Title: Seminal vesicles spread

Posts.Content: Age 83 is the typical lifespan for males. Some live into their nineties, but that is far more common for women than men. Surely you realize that this is an end of life scenario. Hopefully you have addressed this with him and you know his feelings on this. I feel so sorry for you, having watched my own father and mother wither away. My Dad, himself a physician, chose to let himself deteriorate eventually die at home, where he was comfortable. My mother went thru several care facilities, but watched all of her friends go before her and felt terribly alone. You must ask yourself, and your father, how much longer you expect him to live, and what will his final years be like? Good luck with your decision. This is never easy.
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Small cell

Posts.Content: This message board, as much as I love it, needs a big red flag to indicate when there is a new PM. The small notification at the top of the screen too often goes unnoticed.
Posts.Title: Att: Rob Lee

Posts.Content: You were right to take time to enjoy the summer and ponder your choices. True, your predominantly G6 tumor(s) will grow slowly and likely present no problem. But the grade 4 core, though only 20%, can be quite aggressive. Furthermore, that core was located at the apex, where a positive surgical margin is more likely to occur in the event of extraprostatic extension. I'd say you can't afford to wait much longer. Also IMO, based on your age and assuming good health, you are an ideal candidate for robotic prostatectomy, and are most likely to enjoy a rapid and full recovery. Regarding radiation, often that is chosen for older men or those who are poor surgical candidates, and those whose cancer is much more advanced. Older in that the after effects of radiation may not show up for twenty years, and I believe that you would not want to find out in your seventies that perhaps you should have chosen surgery twenty years earlier. Just my opinions. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Att: Rob Lee

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another The majority of PC is 3+3 and 3+4. You have 4+3. It is not slow growing and it is not like 3+4. To underscore this, 3+3 is grade group 1, 3+4 jumps to group 2, and 4+3 is group 3. Put into a list: 3+3=1 3+4=2 4+3=3 4+4=4 4+5 or 5+4 = group 5, essentially terminal You do not want to be halfway up the totem pole. That's how narrow the dividing line really is. Originally Posted by Another Worst case scenario is that of a good friend of mine with 4+3 and 57. Surgery missed a significant portion. The suspicion is they were to go wide on the right and went wide on the left instead. Follow up radiation was not very effective, and he is now looking at hormone therapy from this point forward. All side effects are present. Not a happy camper. Sorry about your friend, Ano. FWIW my surgeon used a broad cut, and in his words, removed a lot of tissue. Hence the permanent ED and as you know, persistent incontinence. Now we won't know the true outcome until after RT ends and HT wears off, but I would much rather be in my shoes than your friend's. Again, to the OP, that's how fine a line we walk with this disease.
Posts.Title: New and trying to come up with a plan

Posts.Content: One thing that gets repeated often here in the forum is that PSA is not a test for cancer, but for prostate inflammation. As Southsider pointed out, you've had a lot of procedures that can irritate the prostate and cause inflammation. DRE is another. The lump may be suspicious and justify investigation, but in the event the biopsy turns up negative it is no guarantee that there is NOT cancer in your prostate. False negatives are common. As I mentioned in your earlier thread, most insurance requires a negative ultrasound biopsy before they will authorize an MRI guided biopsy, so most likely it is still a good idea to get the first one out of the way. It won't necessarily resolve your urinary problem. As Southsider also mentioned, your PSA isn't all that high for a man your age. But you will at least have a baseline for moving forward with future investigation.

John, when is your AUS to be activated?

Posts.Title: One year post Lupron, T = 11

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jeffjackson Unfortunately the pathology report was not as good as I had hoped for. The prostate weighed 49 grams which was a good bit bigger than expected. My Gleason increased from a 3+3 to a 3+4 with 27% of the prostate involved (22% right lobe and 32% left lobe). Unfortunately the cancer had also escaped the prostate with perineural and right seminal vesicle invasion. All not news I wanted to hear. The best news is negative margins on all biopsied tissues so maybe everything was gotten... My urologist mentioned he would likely want to do radiation regardless of the PSA level. I'm not jumping on that bandwagon until I see the numbers and can do some more radiation research. My father ultimately developed and died from bladder cancer and I believe that prostate cancer radiation he received years earlier was a part of the source of that problem. I'll proceed with caution as far as radiation is concerned. Post surgical recovery is going well... I went through a half dozen pads in my first afternoon/evening of freedom. Jeff, I think I've read that post-op pathology is upgraded in about a third of cases and downgraded in another third, which if true would mean that less than half are "spot on" with the pre-op biopsy results. Your case is similar to my own but is in many ways better. Same scenario with MM. All three of us (and a few other guys) are members of the "horses have left the barn" gang, and learning soon after surgery that adjuvant radiation is recommended "regardless" is very common. You can look up the NCCN stages and grades sometime, but you probably do not want to see that just now. Your prostate size was about the same as mine, which was 53g and the RO told me that is "larger than normal but not terribly large". So don't fret that. Also as your grade 4 component, the type that spreads, was secondary... but due to the large number of cores involved is probably the cause of the extracapsular extension despite your relatively low PSA's. In other words, you had a lot of cancer, but it wasn't all that bad. I'd gladly trade places with you. Don't worry about the continence. In all likelihood you will return to full continence in around 3-6 months. Only 5% of RP patients end up incontinent. And the radiation would not commence until you have regained sufficient continence. Typically it is recommended in six months. Your concerns about radiation are understandable, but the recommendations are based on a lot of historical data. It is far better to zap any remaining cells existing in your prostate bed before they move on to greener pastures... in other words, before your PSA begins to rise.

I'll proceed with caution as far as radiation is concerned. Post surgical recovery is going well... I went through a half dozen pads in my first afternoon/evening of freedom. Jeff, I think I've read that post-op pathology is upgraded in about a third of cases and downgraded in another third, which if true would mean that less than half are "spot on" with the pre-op biopsy results. Your case is similar to my own but is in many ways better. Same scenario with MM. All three of us (and a few other guys) are members of the "horses have left the barn" gang, and learning soon after surgery that adjuvant radiation is recommended "regardless" is very common. You can look up the NCCN stages and grades sometime, but you probably do not want to see that just now. Your prostate size was about the same as mine, which was 53g and the RO told me that is "larger than normal but not terribly large". So don't fret that. Also as your grade 4 component, the type that spreads, was secondary... but due to the large number of cores involved is probably the cause of the extracapsular extension despite your relatively low PSA's. In other words, you had a lot of cancer, but it wasn't all that bad. I'd gladly trade places with you. Don't worry about the continence. In all likelihood you will return to full continence in around 3-6 months. Only 5% of RP patients end up incontinent. And the radiation would not commence until you have regained sufficient continence. Typically it is recommended in six months. Your concerns about radiation are understandable, but the recommendations are based on a lot of historical data. It is far better to zap any remaining cells existing in your prostate bed before they move on to greener pastures... in other words, before your PSA begins to rise.

Posts.Title: Day 11, post RALP with pathologic data

Posts.Content: Statistics prove that when you stop testing for a disease, the reported number of cases will decline. BTW I recently got into a rant about about the USPSTF and overtreatment vs undertreatment on another message board and have stopped posting there. I received supportive messages from some other FB's, but bearing in mind that we come here for support, not harassment, concluded that it is an uncomfortable environment. I still read but am reluctant to reply. That may change at some time in the future, but for now you guys are stuck with me here.
Posts.Title: PSA testing change 2017

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I really don't see how the risk of overtreatment we read about is an argument against PSA screening... If by overtreatment they are talking about biopsies, better screening tests should be here very soon--until then, docs should explain to the patient their PSA level and trend, what that means, and the pros and cons of doing a biopsy. Amen. IMO there is not enough education of prostate patients by their urologists. My original Uro never said more than a dozen words to me, and at that only when I asked questions. I have informed both of my sons, now in their thirties, that their father had high risk, advanced prostate cancer, that his (my) grandfather died from it, and that they should insist on PSA tests when they are in their forties. Furthermore, I will once again get on my soap box and extol the importance of getting an MRI when there is ANY suspicion of potential prostate problems. ANY, whether from PSA or symptoms or otherwise. It is a relative simple, inexpensive and painless procedure that can identify trouble spots without poking needles thru the bowel and into this critical piece of anatomy that is intricately tied into many body systems and that is well known to eventually develop problems with age. Why an insurance company would risk paying out hundreds of thousands of dollars for adjuvant and salvage therapies for late stage prostate cancer rather than invest a few hundred dollars into reliable early detection of prostate tumors is just beyond me. Penny wise and pound foolish I tell you. In effect, decades of successful prostate cancer screening and treatment have been wiped out in five years since the 2012 USPTF decision. A remarkable change in events that has no parallel in public health history. It was buffoonery of the highest order in 2012; today marks a terse shift back to normalcy. Public health students will be studying this debacle for decades. American men will be dying from it for years. The significance of this final paragraph cannot be overstated. What a pity that so many of us got snared by this political snafu... a typically disastrous side effect of governmental overreach. Read each sentence carefully. Meditate to it in second level. And memorize its implications. Consider yourself fortunate if you were diagnosed early, and pity those of us who screamed from the rooftops for years before anyone would listen. */Rant off/*

Posts.Title: PSA testing change 2017

Posts.Content: Nick - If you truly have seminal vesicle involvement then you are already in the high risk group, where you join MM and me. MM knows what he's talking about. And Jim's remark about the professor's mental state should also be considered. My PCa appeared three and a half years ago, yet my Urologist took his time dealing with it. Later it turned out he had health problems of his own and mine was not addressed seriously until he retired. By then it had already begun to spread... as has yours. Our cases are different, but given your mention of SVI then you are also (for lack of a signature) stage pT3B. Next stage is bone metastasis, which becomes MUCH more difficult to treat. None of us are medical professionals, but it's obvious to all of us (I think) that you should at least be on HT now... and that only buys time. You do NOT want to allow this to progress any further! The window typically closes after 18-24 months. Good luck!

Posts.Title: New MRI Results - MY PCa is Regressing

Posts.Content: If by "mesh" you are referring to a sling procedure, then yes there are a number of men who experienced problems or the device was ineffective. Most continence returns within 9 months post-op but some experience additional healing between 12-24 months, but I'm guessing that if you have a problem now then you likely always will. After several months of PT with a Kegel coach, my Uro informed me that I was not a candidate for the sling, and referred me to a surgeon to implant an AUS. That process had its own complications, and now 18 months later I am still as incontinent as you are even with the AUS, but that is far better than the 8-12 pads I used to go thru in a day. And now I sleep commando with a dry washcloth tucked in my crotch for nighttime dripping, as just a few drops of wetness on my thigh is enough to wake me up. The AUS is a more drastic surgery than the sling, but I do know of several guys who had their sling removed and an AUS implanted because the sling just didn't work well enough, or even made matters worse.

Posts.Title: Hi guys

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 https://www.newsmax.com/health/healt.../18/id/861242/..... Several researchers found that eating fish regularly reduced the risk of death from prostate cancer while other studies showed no association. On the other hand, some studies showed that men who had high levels of omega 3 fatty acids from eating fish regularly actually were at increased risk of being diagnosed with prostate cancer. Curiously, it was when I was taking Omega 3 fish oil supplements as recommended by my ophthalmologist for dry eye (after Restasis failed) that I started having constant burning in my urethra. I stopped the supplements but the burning persisted. Within a few months my PSA was found to be 9.5 and I had a false negative prostate biopsy. The PSA kept rising. That, plus a broken crown and some antibiotics is basically how my story began, back in late 2013. Except that my GP had sent me to a urologist a year earlier (2012) because my PSA had hit the magic number 4. The urologist was unconcerned. I later learned about the USPSTF recommendations published that same year. I had always eaten a lot of nuts and drank lots of coffee, but ended up with cancer anyway... The other stuff, my wife makes me eat, because "it's good for you".

Posts.Title: FOOD for thought

Posts.Content: This is not yet the end for your father. Several men here went into surgery with Gleason scores of 7 or 8 and came out with a path report indicating a more aggressive cancer. It is apparent that you have done your homework as you have already mentioned bone mets and clinical trials. Castrate resistance typically develops after 2-3 years on the standard first line hormone therapies. Perhaps you could provide a little more information, such as your father's age and full post-op path report if available. Also in what part of the country is he located? Are you near a major cancer center? If your father is still in good general health other than the cancer and its ravages, he could still qualify for further treatments that could add months or years to his life. To be honest, this message board is not the best place to obtain detailed information on advanced metastatic cancer. There are a couple of other message boards which you can find using the same google search you probably used to find this one. Good luck to both you and your father.

Posts.Title: Must Casodex be given before a Lupron shot?

Posts.Content: Thanks guys... The hospital called and my ETA is 8:30AM, so I guess I'll be going under around 10 or so. Gary, this is at Morton Plant hospital (that's the factory where they make salt, right?). It's the main hospital in the Baycare chain that owns most of the medical facilities in Pinellas county... Clearwater/St Pete. It's a nice building right on the intercoastal waterway. It would be nice if I "luck out" like I did with my RP back in Ohio. Someone must have recognized my wife's name and I was put in the executive suite... private room with a sofa, conference table and a panoramic view of our city of seven hills. But hopefully I will remember to inquire about paying the upcharge to get a private room... if I can think of it Monday morning. The surgeon said two days if he can do it laproscopically, and five days if he has to open me up (one in three possibility of that). Don't let the forum fall apart while I'm gone MF Hopefully I'll be online over the weekend, and if I remember to take my tablet, feel up to posting from the hospital.
Posts.Title: Wish me luck... Please!

Posts.Content: Thanks, Rich, for the excellent list. Kozmic - yes, AZ is Amazon (I was trying to avoid advertising... but then they don't really need it, do they?) I saw Depends shields for $15 at CVS. The same package was $12 at Target and $10 from Amazon. Moral of the story: shop around. BTW one of my nurses said her husband prefers Tena as they are not as "noisy" as Depends. I also tried Depends Flex Fit briefs, but they have so much elastic that disposal becomes a problem. They fill the trash can too fast. For pad/shield/diaper disposal I use quart size zipper plastic bags. $6 for a box of 100, and I can fit two pads in each baggie. Keeps the bath/bedroom from smelling like urine. Personally I do not like shields, at least not at this point in my recovery. I haven't found one with enough of a "pouch" in front. Most of them are flat or nearly flat and tend to squish my poor penis too much. And for the first few days after cath removal, rubbing against the pads was too irritating. I've found that I like "belted shields". These are unisex pads that button in front and back. They come with a pair of elastic straps with a button on each end. They ride low on the hips and do not irritate my incision sites as they do not have a waist band. Initially I bought them at CVS because my wife had a 30% off extra care coupon, but I found the same shields available on AZ under the name Prevail.

Posts.Title: Post-op Continence Concerns & Suggestions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tybeeman Boy that is a long post LOL. I am a bad reader and a worst writer so pardon my bad writing skills. ... with any radiation you will almost always have some type of recurrence in 20 years. that make you 87. At 56 I would be 76. My dad was 95 when he died and my mother is still alive at 93. I did want to deal with it at 76. Tybee - one bad reader to another, I'm guessing that you do NOT want to deal with it at 76... and I'm in the same boat as you. Called a "slow reader" or "problem reader" in high school, ended up not surprisingly with low verbal and high math SAT's... engineering material for sure. Today they call it mild dyslexia. I can read but have to repeatedly start over and over to finish a sentence, especially if someone has used internet jargon "u r", or when they use the wrong their there or the wrong wear where. Another - I am always impressed with the depth of your knowledge and your mastery of language. I am jealous. In light of what I've said in the previous paragraph, perhaps you understand why. Also perhaps you can appreciate the amount of effort that I must conjure up to respond to posts here on cancer forums. People ask what I do in my retirement... this is what I do. It takes a lot of my time. In the months and years ahead when one or the both of us have moved on I will miss reading your insights... as well as that of many other forum brother here. Tybee - is your PSA rising? Are you doing anything about it? Sorry if I missed something, but your numbers and your timeline look awful (no offense please).

My dad was 95 when he died and my mother is still alive at 93. I did want to deal with it at 76. Tybee - one bad reader to another, I'm guessing that you do NOT want to deal with it at 76... and I'm in the same boat as you. Called a "slow reader" or "problem reader" in high school, ended up not surprisingly with low verbal and high math SAT's... engineering material for sure. Today they call it mild dyslexia. I can read but have to repeatedly start over and over to finish a sentence, especially if someone has used internet jargon "u r", or when they use the wrong their there or the wrong wear where. Another - I am always impressed with the depth of your knowledge and your mastery of language. I am jealous. In light of what I've said in the previous paragraph, perhaps you understand why. Also perhaps you can appreciate the amount of effort that I must conjure up to respond to posts here on cancer forums. People ask what I do in my retirement... this is what I do. It takes a lot of my time. In the months and years ahead when one or the both of us have moved on I will miss reading your insights... as well as that of many other forum brother here. Tybee - is your PSA rising? Are you doing anything about it? Sorry if I missed something, but your numbers and your timeline look awful (no offense please).

Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: Thanks, Rich, for the excellent list. Kozmic - yes, AZ is Amazon (I was trying to avoid advertising... but then they don't really need it, do they?) I saw Depends shields for $15 at CVS. The same package was $12 at Target and $10 from Amazon. Moral of the story: shop around. BTW one of my nurses said her husband prefers Tena as they are not as "noisy" as Depends. I also tried Depends Flex Fit briefs, but they have so much elastic that disposal becomes a problem. They fill the trash can too fast. For pad/shield/diaper disposal I use quart size zipper plastic bags. $6 for a box of 100, and I can fit two pads in each baggie. Keeps the bath/bedroom from smelling like urine. Personally I do not like shields, at least not at this point in my recovery. I haven't found one with enough of a "pouch" in front. Most of them are flat or nearly flat and tend to squish my poor penis too much. And for the first few days after cath removal, rubbing against the pads was too irritating. I've found that I like "belted shields". These are unisex pads that button in front and back. They come with a pair of elastic straps with a button on each end. They ride low on the hips and do not irritate my incision sites as they do not have a waist band. Initially I bought them at CVS because my wife had a 30% off extra care coupon, but I found the same shields available on AZ under the name Prevail.

Posts.Title: Post-op Continence Concerns & Suggestions

Posts.Content: Age 83 is the typical lifespan for males. Some live into their nineties, but that is far more common for women than men. Surely you realize that this is an end of life scenario. Hopefully you have addressed this with him and you know his feelings on this. I feel so sorry for you, having watched my own father and mother wither away. My Dad, himself a physician, chose to let himself deteriorate eventually die at home, where he was comfortable. My mother went thru several care facilities, but watched all of her friends go before her and felt terribly alone. You must ask yourself, and your father, how much longer you expect him to live, and what will his final years be like? Good luck with your decision. This is never easy.
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Small cell

Posts.Content: It's time to address the elephant in the room. What elephant? Post-op incontinence following prostatectomy. Some of us who are in our first month post-op have been posting remarks about leakage, Kegels, and other such matters in JJackson's "Post-op Day 10" thread... read it here: (http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...Post-op-Day-10 Jamie, Rich and I ("the three caballeros") are all in our first month post-op and struggling with these issues. There has already been a lot of info put forward in that thread, but he/we discussed starting a properly titled thread on the topic. So here it is. I just wanted to get this up and running so we can add our thoughts and experiences here rather than there (as Day 10 has long passed!) Personally I have been experimenting with various pads, shields, diapers (ok, I'm going to call them that) as well as some "external plumbing" devices. I hope to post my thoughts and opinions here on various products in the days ahead. AZ has been a terrific resource, offering testimonials as well as decent prices, better than you might find in a drug store or superstore. For any newbies (and yes, we are all newbies at this, if not now, we were only recently) what I've read and been told is that typically we should not expect to have much control for the first two months, with full control over urinary continence being attained between six and twelve months. As usual, your mileage may vary. Some report better control early on and others still having accidents more than a year out. So don't worry if you don't fit some standard. There is none. Good luck everyone! We've already taken the greatest step on this journey.

Posts.Title: Post-op Continence Concerns & Suggestions

Posts.Content: One thing that gets repeated often here in the forum is that PSA is not a test for cancer, but for prostate inflammation. As Southsider pointed out, you've had a lot of procedures that can irritate the prostate and cause inflammation. DRE is another. The lump may be suspicious and justify investigation, but in the event the biopsy turns up negative it is no guarantee that there is NOT cancer in your prostate. False negatives are common. As I mentioned in your earlier thread, most insurance requires a negative ultrasound biopsy before they will authorize an MRI guided biopsy, so most likely it is still a good idea to get the first one out of the way. It won't necessarily resolve your urinary problem. As Southsider also mentioned, your PSA isn't all that high for a man your age. But you will at least have a baseline for moving forward with future investigation.
Posts.Title: Do I really need a ultrasound guided prostate biopsy

Posts.Content: Good luck, Jack. Certainly this was not an easy decision, but with a Gleason 9 you made the right choice to stop this thing in its track. Hopefully they will find everything else in there (margins, lymph nodes, seminary vesicles) are negative and the cancer has not spread. What you need to do now is prepare for your post-op recovery. When you wake up from surgery you will have an indwelling catheter and a drainage bag. In a way, it is a kind of convenience... you don't have to pee. I remember I kept thinking I had to get up to go to the bathroom, only to realize there's nothing I could do in there except maybe empty the bag. But you do need to tend to he cath and bag. Have a supply of rubbing alcohol, tissues, and some antibiotic ointment. And get a new large bucket... this was a tip I read here before my surgery and it was quite handy to keep the drainage bag in the bucket by your bed overnight. During the day you can just carry around the bucket, so you always have a place to hold your bag when doing stuff around the house. Also buy a pack of waterproof pads for your bed and your easy chair (you have one of those, right?) There may be some leakage around the cath... not a lot, but it can stain clean sheets. The greatest difficulty post-op is getting in and out of bed. Many guys spend the first few nights sleeping in a recliner. Your stomach will have about a half dozen small cuts that don't really hurt that much, but the muscles underneath are also cut and it makes it painful to bend or twist your abdomen. You will be sleeping flat on your back for a few days, wishing there was a trapeze over your bed... but your flexibility will return gradually. I remember I could lay on my left side after a few days and it took a couple weeks before I could turn onto my right side. In another thread here someone told me the cut on the far right is where they pulled out the prostate. Post-op you will need to eat stuff that is easy to digest. It will be difficult to bear down to poop, so you don't want to make that any more difficult than it already is! Also you will have weight lifting restrictions for about a month post-op. For me it was ten pounds... some guys say theirs was 15 or maybe twenty. So that means you will not be allowed to lift more than XX pounds for 4 weeks. Ten pounds is about the size of a small suitcase or a bag of groceries if there are liquids, meat or canned goods. So plan ahead and try to anticipate getting at things you will need around the house when you are unable to bend or lift. The cath will come out after about ten days. You will need a supply of incontinence pads. Wear one on your cath removal day and take a spare with you. There is a thread we started here on incontinence questions. The cath removal is totally painless (for me it tickled a little). The incontinence goes on for several months, but gradually improves. It is a tremendous annoyance and inconvenience but everyone goes through it. Good luck next month. Know that most guys pull through this with zero issues. And this is something you had to do. You probably just added twenty years to your life.

Posts.Title: Surgery Date Confirmed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MRJ RAD-- Just for clarity, let's separate two terms: orgasm and erection, as either can be accomplished independent of the other. You asked about orgasms. You should be able to achieve orgasms now. It's more difficult without an erection but it should be manageable manually or with a little help from electronics. Exactly. I waited four weeks post-op before attempting to masturbate. I figured if they say to wait that long before lifting anything, then it should be safe. And by then I was so horny and in need of some relief. I was able to accomplish it without using any electronics... well, other than porn (who gets their porn on paper these days?) Of course after RALP there is no ejaculate, but there is definitely an orgasm. I refer to it as a pelvic orgasm, and was able to enjoy them for several months post-op. Then came the Lupron. I wasn't given Casodex beforehand, so I experienced the full blown "Lupron flare" for about ten days after the shot. I think I spent more time "in the bathroom" than since I was a teenager for those first few days. Since the Lupron kicked in, however, about three months ago, just once, and that wasn't very satisfying. More like it was something I felt I had to do, something to take care of. Oddly enough, last night I woke up with an erection. It seemed so real. But now that I am actually awake I realize that it must have been a dream. It was fun while it lasted. I remember how surprised I felt... and proud. But then I really woke up. Texas cath, leg bag and two feet of tubing. That's my ball and chain that I take to bed with me most nights. The past week has largely been sleepless due to changing meds... it must have been the first night I slept long enough to actually have a dream.

Posts.Title: Hubby just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tybeeman It has been 10 months since my robotic radical prostatectomy. I have had my consistency back since the 3rd month, with just a little leakage, mainly when I drink. Now no problem at all. Have not had an erection yet but I am taking Cialis daily and triple dose twice a week. Last night I woke up with a nocturnal erection. Was wondering if anyone else has experience this and could this be a sign that I will be getting my erections back. It is a long process and I am sure most of you know I am very anxious. Five months ago today for me, and have not had an erection of any kind since before the surgery. At my age I don't worry about it. I am able to work myself to a pelvic orgasm with much effort, but since the Lupron kicked in don't have much urge to do so. My greatest concern is that my RO said he has never seen any improvement in urinary continence after ten months, and I am halfway there now. I am dry all night, but have to get up once or twice to pee, and also do well when siting down. But when standing or walking I leak like a garden hose, going thru 8-12 pads a day pretty consistently. I've weighed them at around a half pound each. I am not even aware that I am leaking, just that the pads get heavy and very wet. My penis sometimes develop a rash from the moisture. My uro has had me in therapy for a couple months now. The therapist wants me to hold the Kegels for fifteen seconds and it just wears me out. Very hard to maintain. I guess the "good" news is I still have another five months before the RO has to proceed with SRT and hopefully I won't be leaking so much by then because it will stop any further improvement in continence.

Posts.Title: 10 months after 2 questions

Posts.Content: This morning I looked up the results of my blood draw from last Wednesday. PSA=0.00 and testosterone=18.7. This was my first PSA since completing adjuvant radiation in October. The testosterone had gone down from 30 before RT, but I was expecting there to be a little bounce in my PSA, as it was being artificially held down to .03 for the past year while on Lupron. Why am I not elated to see 0.00 for the first time in my life? The skeptic in me is suspicious that there must be something wrong. After all, I believed my first biopsy four years ago when it came back negative. At the end of treatment my RO told me that the radiation would continue to kill cancer cells for another six months or so. And as I understand it, dying cancer cells spew out PSA. And the Lupron only suppresses testosterone production. So why was there no bounce? Could the radiation have actually killed all the stray cells so quickly? While I should be popping open the champagne, instead I'm wondering how could this be? And does this mean that I could skip next week's Lupron shot? Hopefully I will know more after I discuss the results with my Uro on Wednesday. But while I would be overjoyed if I could just blindly accept these results, instead I only find myself with more questions. Still, I'd like to submit my application to Club Zero for my first time ever... and here's hoping I can stay there!

Posts.Title: First Ever PSA = 0.00 !

Posts.Content: Ken, I know you've been fretting over this for a long time... at least as long as I have been here and you were concerned over having lost your "<"... I don't remember seeing any or at least "that many" guys have PSA trend upwards following RP only to go back down, though I suppose it could be possible. Unfortunately there are no black and white answers. We've all been thru it to some extent. At least you are only considering legitimate treatment choices, as you already eat well and really know your stuff. I would think that Medicare should cover this fully, assuming that you have standard Medicare part B and a decent supplement. Your RO should have your back on that one. RT was no picnic... not difficult, but I got sick early on and now six months later still have radiation colitis, not unlike Dan. But would I change anything? Unlikely. You don't get any do-overs in this game. So take a while and decide exactly how you're going to approach this, but I agree that doing nothing is not a viable option. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Early Salvage Radiation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis I have cancer in my body and my job is to keep it out of my spirit! The shock of cancer can only be understood by those who have it ... The first impact of cancer was a profound loneliness and a gut level of fear that I have never experienced ... Cancer is a lonely disease. Support groups, forums and the like take the edge off and there are just times that the Dis-Ease sets in in your heart and drags you down. The other force which makes it so difficult is the slowness of treatment decisions and how the medical system moves. Denis, even though it has only been a few months since you first posted, I can see that you obviously 'get it'. What you wrote is all very well said and exhibits great insight to what all of us are going thru. Soon after my wife was discharged from the hospital, we were talking about our cancers and she said "it's the loneliest place you'll ever know". You mentioned that several times, so you obviously understand. Just last night, I was troubled by memories of her calling me in the middle of the night saying "I am so scared!" ... I often worry that I was not supportive enough for her during that time. There was a LOT going on then. It was a very uncomfortable time. This being October marks five years since that visit to a Urologist that started everything for me. What followed was three and a half years of being mishandled by the medical system, confounded by my own ignorance of the situation and perhaps reluctance to even consider the possibility of cancer. (Despite numerous prior surgeries, this was my very first cancer). Unfortunately I apparently let it get to me. I recognize that it has affected my spirit and my attitude about just about everything. Once you have cancer, everything else becomes much less important. When you and your life mate both have cancer, everything changes. You have the benefit of an early diagnosis and it sounds like you have a good medical team working for you. Hopefully you will be able to enjoy 'smooth sailing' throughout your journey. And keep your head above water.
