Posts.Title: How cancer effects me!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by derbyrobert My brother recently had a prostatecomy and has never been the same since. I am a Clinical Psychologist and have noticed the significant changes... but these in no way account for this personalty change. The changes that result from prostate cancer and more importantly cancer treatment certainly changes ones outlook on life. However, I had an experience that began long before my diagnosis and treatment. I started having some troubling prostate symptoms nearly four years ago, and had a biopsy a few months later which was negative, but turned out later to be a false negative... in other words, the biopsy completely missed the tumor. That was the beginning of a very rough year, and for the next two years I was prone to episodes of crying and my wife frequently told me that I was depressed. I have never had any psych or emotional problems, but spoke with my doctor and he pretty much dismissed the symptoms that I presented to him. Two years later another biopsy identified the tumor and I had a prostatectomy, was started on Lupron and the antidepressant Effexor, had a urinary implant and underwent two months of radiation. My life has definitely changed as a result of the treatments, but mentally I feel far better off than I did two or three years ago. I believe now that during those two years between the negative biopsy and the positive one and subsequent treatments that I actually did have a tumor growing in me and that it affected my personality and my mental and emotional state, perhaps chemically. I have never heard anyone else mention this, but what I experienced was real. Perhaps your brother is obsessed with his new project as an item on his bucket list. But maybe the cancer growing in his prostate actually affected his personality by means of a physical process.
Posts.Title: prostate personality change

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JJackson I had a Robotic Assisted Radical Prostatectomy on 9/26. My surgery was pretty uneventful. I was released to home the following day. Of course with a Foley cath, 5 puncture wounds (subcuticular stitches covered with Dermabond) and no JP or any other drain. I share the majority of experiences Ive read hereno issues with the catherter really, very sore lower abdomen and pain in the shoulders. But the discomfort lessened each and by Post Op Day 4 all was fine. I had my catherter removed Sept 2nd. My anxiety over the removal was much worse than the act itselfminimal discomfort that was over, done and gone in a few seconds. My cath was removed in my Surgeons office. He was able to spare both nerves and said the lymph nodes were clear. Originally Posted by Rich2.0 Hi Jamie, It looks like we both had our surgery on the same day! I am a bit behind schedule on the catheter removal. I'm scheduled to have mine removed first thing tomorrow morning. I know I'm going to leak like a sieve the first day but getting rid of this ball and chain will be quite liberating. I don't have any pearls of wisdom to share at this point -just some words of encouragement. Hang in there and please post back often. I will be following this thread closely. Hello guys - I'm just a week behind you two, so I will be referring back to this thread often to check on your progress. Unfortunately I did not have much time to practice Kegels pre-op, but have also read that it has limited value until afterwards. My surgery was pretty much uneventful, much like JJackson's. My cath comes out in two days. Others I have spoken with mention six months as most common time to regain full control over continence. Good luck everyone!

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosis

Posts.Content: Mike - Sorry to hear the news, but I just gotta say... you're breaking the news in someone else's thread (unless you are Kim's husband, then I'm sorry, I misunderstood). If so the moderator should move your post to its own thread. So about the cancer, your G8 is higher than most of the guys here. Typically G7's are when guys come here asking about options. For G8 things are a bit further along than you'd like. There is a possibility that it has already spread outside the prostate. Just a possibility. There are a few of us here with that. Generally the option most often chosen is surgery, with the primary reason being that if the surgery does not get all the cancer out, then you can have radiation afterwards (referred to as salvage radiation) to clean up the abdominal bed. If radiation is performed first, the tissues become deformed and follow up surgery if needed is far less likely to be successful. If you're thinking traditional chemotherapy, that is unlikely for PCa at your stage. Typically that is reserved for G9 or G10, where the cancer has already left the prostate bed and spread throughout the body. There are probably more guys here at that stage than at yours and mine... that is, assuming your scans don't reveal something worse then your G8 rating and moderate PSA level would indicate. Good luck, Mike. Keep us informed.

Posts.Title: Question about recurrence post RP

Posts.Content: It is difficult to tell exactly when the end will be. From the information you presented, it seems he has not been on any form of hormone deprivation therapy (ADT or HT) that might have arrested the progression of his bone mets. Or he may have been on HT as part of the radiation... But I am guessing that the radiation was spot treatment to his bone mets to reduce his pain. Traditionally, chemo had been reserved as a "last resort" but more recently is administered following radiation in order to take out micromets. It sounds like your husband was probably already beyond that before his treatment started. He will continue to hve good days and bad days, as both the cancer and its treatments saps all stamina from its victims. You can't necessarily blame it on doing too much on a good day. It is unfortunate that no one here was able to provide you with more information, but this particular message board is generally frequented by guys (and their wives or children) who have been recently diagnosed and/or currently undergoing treatment for a cure. Your husband's case is far beyond that. There are two other message boards where you will find men with more advanced cases... stage 4, metastatic cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tybeeman I think I am more nervous about this then my RP. Understood. I was more apprehensive about the AUS implant surgery than about the RP. Difference is the RP was necessary, and the AUS is elective. Also, once in, the implant would change how I use the bathroom for the rest of my life. Think about how much you take that for granted. Oh, also the AUS was necessary so that I can proceed with salvage radiation to get the rest of the cancer, or so I hope. You are fortunate that this has not been an issue for you. ... find someone that will help you with depression. It can be tough on some of us. Important indeed. I understand that the loss of sexual function can undermine a man's sense of identity and purpose. Genuine depression can result from the uncertainty of how many years you have left. Many doctors don't get that. They see cancer every day, but for you and me it is a "big deal". When it happens to YOU, it's very personal.

Posts.Title: 16 months Post OP, I give up

Posts.Content: The 4+4 core is also aggressive, but the 5+4 is very serious as the primary grade is 5, which is the highest. Naturally the kidney is the highest priority. At your age that may be a difficult recovery. Whether or not you could possibly face another surgery for your prostate is questionable. It could be treated with radiation depending on a few other stats, such as the size of your prostate. One treatment that does not involve intervention per se would be to start HT... androgen deprivation therapy as soon as you have recovered from your surgery, and remain on it for the rest of your life. Basically this would be a shot twice a year. There are side effects, but this form of therapy is common for those with advanced prostate cancer. The shots would prevent your cancer from progressing any further. At some point your cancer may become resistant to the HT, but there are new treatments being developed all the time. Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Incontinence and AUS experience

Posts.Content: Steve - Thanks so much for the info on this. I fully intend to bring this up with my RO next meeting, as I will be jumping thru all kinds of hoops to fulfill the full bladder requirement for IMRT... all this knowing that what residual cancer remaining in my SV bed may be so minute that broad radiation may well miss it, thereby potentially causing more harm than good. Checking the Axumin website it appears that some portions of the cost may be approved for medicare. After shelling out upwards of $10K for my wife's chemo deductible, I believe it may be well worth the additional cost of this approach if it can possibly target the radiation more accurately, and thereby offer a greater chance of success and hopefully eliminate any possibility of recurrence.

Posts.Title: Sweating Bullets

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman ... on my way home from a 10 day trip to Baton Rouge, Orlando, and Lake Worth, Florida... I have to say, it was a great respite. I thought less about cancer. Which was nice, because lately it seems like cancer has occupied my thoughts more than any other topic. Which truly sucks. Anyone else feel this way? Hello, Captain! Glad you got away from the gloomy world of cancer. I know that the busy mind does not drift into darker thoughts. Sometimes when I'm researching something related to cancer I just get sick of it and shut down. We are in fact right now in Orlando for a week... actually Kissimmee... well actually my phone says Celebration. Anyway, we spent yesterday at Universal Studios and IOA. We decided to buy season passes this year, and are planning for some of our family to join us here around Thanksgiving.[/QUOTE] Anyway, my respite is about to end... I'll go for my blood draw for PSA. On top of that, my wife is having a CT Scan on Friday, 1st one since finishing chemo for ovarian cancer, 5 weeks ago. Oh the joys of being a "cancer couple" ... Next week Lori has her post-chemo PET/CT scans to see if the cancer is gone, or if she goes back on chemo for a couple more rounds. Then the following Monday I go under the knife for my implant. Yes, sweating bullets indeed! I remember when you lost your "<". How sad... I guess mainly because it generally does not go back down again. But you still have a lo-o-o-o-ong way to go before the .1 mark. I would think that after two years you probably have a lot of time before any continual rise would reach the point of requiring action. Perhaps you may join us in the wonderful world of Lupron. Good luck with you PSA, end especially good luck to your wife with her scans. And welcome back, Captain!

Posts.Title: Sweating Bullets

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman ... on my way home from a 10 day trip to Baton Rouge, Orlando, and Lake Worth, Florida... I have to say, it was a great respite. I thought less about cancer. Which was nice, because lately it seems like cancer has occupied my thoughts more than any other topic. Which truly sucks. Anyone else feel this way? Hello, Captain! Glad you got away from the gloomy world of cancer. I know that the busy mind does not drift into darker thoughts. Sometimes when I'm researching something related to cancer I just get sick of it and shut down. We are in fact right now in Orlando for a week... actually Kissimmee... well actually my phone says Celebration. Anyway, we spent yesterday at Universal Studios and IOA. We decided to buy season passes this year, and are planning for some of our family to join us here around Thanksgiving.[/QUOTE] Anyway, my respite is about to end... I'll go for my blood draw for PSA. On top of that, my wife is having a CT Scan on Friday, 1st one since finishing chemo for ovarian cancer, 5 weeks ago. Oh the joys of being a "cancer couple" ... Next week Lori has her post-chemo PET/CT scans to see if the cancer is gone, or if she goes back on chemo for a couple more rounds. Then the following Monday I go under the knife for my implant. Yes, sweating bullets indeed! I remember when you lost your "<". How sad... I guess mainly because it generally does not go back down again. But you still have a lo-o-o-o-ong way to go before the .1 mark. I would think that after two years you probably have a lot of time before any continual rise would reach the point of requiring action. Perhaps you may join us in the wonderful world of Lupron. Good luck with you PSA, end especially good luck to your wife with her scans. And welcome back, Captain!

Posts.Title: Sweating Bullets

Posts.Content: Hey Sudds, sorry about your streak of bad luck, but you are not alone. I think one out of four RP's return a final Gleason higher than the biopsy, so it happens. Several other FB's here have had that happen. Fortunately yours was organ confined other than the possible surgical margin, which is not uncommon for a tumor at the apex. You're probably looking at a year or two on HT and two months of RT. I'm now in my seventh week with just nine treatments left (total 7000 rads). My tumor was also 25% volume, about the same as yours. So you're in good company here. We're all fighting for you and we're all behind you. Good luck going forward. Just keep your chin up and move ahead. Eventually this will all end and you will come out on top.

Posts.Title: Got my Path final report back, not good

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider Thanks, men. I completed the test, it wasn't a problem although sort of disorientated. Got a little faint when the gal put in the IV for the contrast, but it wasn't uncomfortable getting the test done. Although at UPMC Presbyterian, its quite a maze figuring out where to go and where my car was parked. The hospital is built on a steep slope- appropriately called "Cardiac Hill", and although they do have elevators, you're on a different floor every time you move from building to building. My wife worked in a hospital like that, built on a hillside. Eventually they "standardized" the floors so at least the floor numbers stayed the same. Still quite weird. You entered on the sixth floor. What's worse, there were at least a dozen different groups of elevators, none of which could get you to every floor. So the elevator you get on might not even stop on the eighth floor because it was the psych ward and restricted access, or the surgical floor floor for example. I think since most hospitals were pieced together over the years, like Tetris, they all seem to have different shaped buildings and floors stuck together based on what funding was available at the time for each expansion. And the parking garages never make any sense... at least four of them, half of which are for staff only. I had quite a few procedures done in that hospital, and each time I went back it seemed they had moved everything around. Reminded me of the "House that Jack Built" episode of the Avengers, if anyone remembers that show (who could forget Emma Peel and John Steed). Also had a few MRI's of various body parts over the years, mostly with contrast. They eventually become de rigeur, but admittedly I still feel a bit apprehensive being trapped in that machine for an hour or so.

Posts.Title: Hubby just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Welcome to the other side Rick, and I hope everything went well with your surgery and your recovery so far. First off, do not be apprehensive about the catheter removal, it is painless, and for me even tickled a little. It seems much more scary than it actually is. About your question, there are two different matters here: erections and orgasms. When erections might return depends a lot on how much nerve tissue was spared during the surgery. Sometimes there is extensive nerve invasion and a lot of it has to be removed by the surgeon to be sure that all the cancer was eliminated. Erectile function is probably the last or final normal function to return. Your greatest concern in the months ahead will be regaining full continence or bladder control after the Foley catheter has been removed. You will need to do Kegel exercises as was probably directed by your urologist, or you can find instructions in one of the stickies at the top of this forum. The other matter is orgasms, which will return surprisingly soon. If you masturbate or are stimulated by your partner you will probably experience a "pelvic" orgasm, but there will be no ejaculation. There is no ejaculate because all the glands that produced semen were removed. There will likely be some urine shoot out though. Many guys experience this for some time. Just be prepared. The most important matter though is that you survived the surgery, hopefully without complications, and second to that, that the surgery hopefully removed all of the cancer. This will not be known until you get your pathology report from your urologist. In the weeks ahead, the first sign of urinary continence will be the ability to not leak while sleeping, called "dry nights". Then comes full control while sitting. Standing up from sitting comes next, then holding it while walking. Eventually for most men the ability to hold their urine without thinking about it takes anywhere from three to nine months. Good luck Rick!

Posts.Title: just had devinci prostate removed on 4th day waiting to remove cathoid

Posts.Content: This morning I looked up the results of my blood draw from last Wednesday. PSA=0.00 and testosterone=18.7. This was my first PSA since completing adjuvant radiation in October. The testosterone had gone down from 30 before RT, but I was expecting there to be a little bounce in my PSA, as it was being artificially held down to .03 for the past year while on Lupron. Why am I not elated to see 0.00 for the first time in my life? The skeptic in me is suspicious that there must be something wrong. After all, I believed my first biopsy four years ago when it came back negative. At the end of treatment my RO told me that the radiation would continue to kill cancer cells for another six months or so. And as I understand it, dying cancer cells spew out PSA. And the Lupron only suppresses testosterone production. So why was there no bounce? Could the radiation have actually killed all the stray cells so quickly? While I should be popping open the champagne, instead I'm wondering how could this be? And does this mean that I could skip next week's Lupron shot? Hopefully I will know more after I discuss the results with my Uro on Wednesday. But while I would be overjoyed if I could just blindly accept these results, instead I only find myself with more questions. Still, I'd like to submit my application to Club Zero for my first time ever... and here's hoping I can stay there!

Posts.Title: First Ever PSA = 0.00 !

Posts.Content: Ken, I know you've been fretting over this for a long time... at least as long as I have been here and you were concerned over having lost your "<"... I don't remember seeing any or at least "that many" guys have PSA trend upwards following RP only to go back down, though I suppose it could be possible. Unfortunately there are no black and white answers. We've all been thru it to some extent. At least you are only considering legitimate treatment choices, as you already eat well and really know your stuff. I would think that Medicare should cover this fully, assuming that you have standard Medicare part B and a decent supplement. Your RO should have your back on that one. RT was no picnic... not difficult, but I got sick early on and now six months later still have radiation colitis, not unlike Dan. But would I change anything? Unlikely. You don't get any do-overs in this game. So take a while and decide exactly how you're going to approach this, but I agree that doing nothing is not a viable option. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Early Salvage Radiation

Posts.Content: Thanks, Rich, for the excellent list. Kozmic - yes, AZ is Amazon (I was trying to avoid advertising... but then they don't really need it, do they?) I saw Depends shields for $15 at CVS. The same package was $12 at Target and $10 from Amazon. Moral of the story: shop around. BTW one of my nurses said her husband prefers Tena as they are not as "noisy" as Depends. I also tried Depends Flex Fit briefs, but they have so much elastic that disposal becomes a problem. They fill the trash can too fast. For pad/shield/diaper disposal I use quart size zipper plastic bags. $6 for a box of 100, and I can fit two pads in each baggie. Keeps the bath/bedroom from smelling like urine. Personally I do not like shields, at least not at this point in my recovery. I haven't found one with enough of a "pouch" in front. Most of them are flat or nearly flat and tend to squish my poor penis too much. And for the first few days after cath removal, rubbing against the pads was too irritating. I've found that I like "belted shields". These are unisex pads that button in front and back. They come with a pair of elastic straps with a button on each end. They ride low on the hips and do not irritate my incision sites as they do not have a waist band. Initially I bought them at CVS because my wife had a 30% off extra care coupon, but I found the same shields available on AZ under the name Prevail.

Posts.Title: Post-op Continence Concerns & Suggestions

Posts.Content: It's time to address the elephant in the room. What elephant? Post-op incontinence following prostatectomy. Some of us who are in our first month post-op have been posting remarks about leakage, Kegels, and other such matters in JJackson's "Post-op Day 10" thread... read it here: (http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...Post-op-Day-10 Jamie, Rich and I ("the three caballeros") are all in our first month post-op and struggling with these issues. There has already been a lot of info put forward in that thread, but he/we discussed starting a properly titled thread on the topic. So here it is. I just wanted to get this up and running so we can add our thoughts and experiences here rather than there (as Day 10 has long passed!) Personally I have been experimenting with various pads, shields, diapers (ok, I'm going to call them that) as well as some "external plumbing" devices. I hope to post my thoughts and opinions here on various products in the days ahead. AZ has been a terrific resource, offering testimonials as well as decent prices, better than you might find in a drug store or superstore. For any newbies (and yes, we are all newbies at this, if not now, we were only recently) what I've read and been told is that typically we should not expect to have much control for the first two months, with full control over urinary continence being attained between six and twelve months. As usual, your mileage may vary. Some report better control early on and others still having accidents more than a year out. So don't worry if you don't fit some standard. There is none. Good luck everyone! We've already taken the greatest step on this journey.

Posts.Content: Wise decision Mr Ed. We finally lost total power after midnight. Today just breezy. Appears to be no real damage here. I hear Jacksonville was hit hard. Prayers for all.
Posts.Title: Hurricane Irma

Posts.Content: Thank you to those who have already contacted me personally. We are in northern Pinellas county and until just recently it looked like we were going to be directly in the storm's path. Recent landfall at Marco Island and it's current northern track will put the storm just east of Tampa when it passes us overnight tonight. The outermost rain bands passed us about five hours ago and spawned some tornadoes further inland. We have had light rain and gusty winds until right around 4PM. The winds are now picking up and our power has flickered a few times. Our biggest fear is losing power, possibly for several days. They now say on the news that this storm has already sucked most of the water right out of Tampa bay... bad news is the water will return later, with a surge. As much as I would like to see that personally, I'm happy to be indoors right now. Our place is sturdy and I feel safe and on the top floor. Big question was whether or not to move our cars away from trees. I'd hate to move one out into the open and get struck by some other projectile. We had to take in a relative whose home is right on the water. She is not sure what will be left afterwards. We have plenty of food, water and batteries, thank goodness. As far as we know, no one living in our immediate community has had to evacuate. My RO's office called and cancelled treatments for both Monday and Tuesday, which is good news, as I will have a few more days to recover from the SE's... which have been more difficult than expected. Bowel disruptions. Nineteen treatments completed, twenty more to go. Best of luck to the others here in Florida and those to the north who will be affected by this storm. I will try to update more later, assuming we keep our service.

There has already been a lot of info put forward in that thread, but he/we discussed starting a properly titled thread on the topic. So here it is. I just wanted to get this up and running so we can add our thoughts and experiences here rather than there (as Day 10 has long passed!) Personally I have been experimenting with various pads, shields, diapers (ok, I'm going to call them that) as well as some "external plumbing" devices. I hope to post my thoughts and opinions here on various products in the days ahead. AZ has been a terrific resource, offering testimonials as well as decent prices, better than you might find in a drug store or superstore. For any newbies (and yes, we are all newbies at this, if not now, we were only recently) what I've read and been told is that typically we should not expect to have much control for the first two months, with full control over urinary continence being attained between six and twelve months. As usual, your mileage may vary. Some report better control early on and others still having accidents more than a year out. So don't worry if you don't fit some standard. There is none. Good luck everyone! We've already taken the greatest step on this journey.

Posts.Title: Post-op Continence Concerns & Suggestions

Posts.Content: Thanks, Rich, for the excellent list. Kozmic - yes, AZ is Amazon (I was trying to avoid advertising... but then they don't really need it, do they?) I saw Depends shields for $15 at CVS. The same package was $12 at Target and $10 from Amazon. Moral of the story: shop around. BTW one of my nurses said her husband prefers Tena as they are not as "noisy" as Depends. I also tried Depends Flex Fit briefs, but they have so much elastic that disposal becomes a problem. They fill the trash can too fast. For pad/shield/diaper disposal I use quart size zipper plastic bags. $6 for a box of 100, and I can fit two pads in each baggie. Keeps the bath/bedroom from smelling like urine. Personally I do not like shields, at least not at this point in my recovery. I haven't found one with enough of a "pouch" in front. Most of them are flat or nearly flat and tend to squish my poor penis too much. And for the first few days after cath removal, rubbing against the pads was too irritating. I've found that I like "belted shields". These are unisex pads that button in front and back. They come with a pair of elastic straps with a button on each end. They ride low on the hips and do not irritate my incision sites as they do not have a waist band. Initially I bought them at CVS because my wife had a 30% off extra care coupon, but I found the same shields available on AZ under the name Prevail.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by G24 With your Gleason 9, seminal vesicle involvement, multiple positive margins and Stage T3b you should really start ADT after radiation. See this review. They report that ADT is beneficial for high risk patients. Thanks for another interesting link G24. Of particular note in this article is the following graph, fig 3, which can be found in section 3.2, Benefits of adjunctive hormone therapy to SRT may not be universal, which seems to indicate that the benefits of neoadjuvant ADT combined with SRT continue to be realized throughout years 5 thru 8 after RT, where the RT-only arm flattens out and the ADT+RT arm continues to decline. As this is a direct link to an image, the board may not allow linking to it directly. But you should be able to copy and past the link here: https://www.europeanurology.com/cms/...26/gr3_lrg.jpg

Posts.Title: Sore bottom still, 2-1/2 wks post RALP?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider Thanks, men. I completed the test, it wasn't a problem although sort of disorientated. Got a little faint when the gal put in the IV for the contrast, but it wasn't uncomfortable getting the test done. Although at UPMC Presbyterian, its quite a maze figuring out where to go and where my car was parked. The hospital is built on a steep slope- appropriately called "Cardiac Hill", and although they do have elevators, you're on a different floor every time you move from building to building. My wife worked in a hospital like that, built on a hillside. Eventually they "standardized" the floors so at least the floor numbers stayed the same. Still quite weird. You entered on the sixth floor. What's worse, there were at least a dozen different groups of elevators, none of which could get you to every floor. So the elevator you get on might not even stop on the eighth floor because it was the psych ward and restricted access, or the surgical floor floor for example. I think since most hospitals were pieced together over the years, like Tetris, they all seem to have different shaped buildings and floors stuck together based on what funding was available at the time for each expansion. And the parking garages never make any sense... at least four of them, half of which are for staff only. I had quite a few procedures done in that hospital, and each time I went back it seemed they had moved everything around. Reminded me of the "House that Jack Built" episode of the Avengers, if anyone remembers that show (who could forget Emma Peel and John Steed). Also had a few MRI's of various body parts over the years, mostly with contrast. They eventually become de rigeur, but admittedly I still feel a bit apprehensive being trapped in that machine for an hour or so.

Posts.Title: 1 Year Anniversary of Surgery & Thoughts

Posts.Content: Indeed... the quoted text is almost an advertisement against choosing RT as the first option. Technically challenging, few qualified to do the procedure, immediately surrounding tissues, ten years survival "or more". The stats for RP followed by SRT are far more promising. That was my secondary reason for choosing surgery first. The primary reason was because we were already in the process of moving from our home a thousand miles away and I frankly did not have time to shop around, or to dedicate the next eight weeks to daily treatments. A close friend of mine had cyberknife (I think he said) ten years ago, but said he was lucky that it was caught early and was well contained. He said he wanted to avoid the possibility of ED after surgery. Seems like backward thinking to me, but he's him and I'm me. My tumor was already known to be high grade and possibly advanced, and now requires SRT. I have no regrets whatsoever choosing surgery first. BTW good luck in your treatment, whichever path you choose. I hope all goes well for you and I wish you a full recovery.

I really, really want to take my time and leave you a detailed reply to your post, however, my wife and I are about to hit the road and I can't take the time to do that now. I promise I will take time to write this weekend as I believe we have much to discuss. In the meantime, have a great weekend!

Posts.Title: Update on incontinence recommendations

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by oshguy I had my annual checkup at the Cleveland Clinic on Thursday and discussed my continuing incontinence with my surgeon. I explained to him that I'm mostly dry, but after standing for 15-20 minutes or more, leaning forward for more than 30 seconds or so, lifting heavy items, etc., I start to leak slightly. I can feel it coming on, and nothing I do seems to be able to stop it. I've Kegeled more, less, none at all, and no frequency seems to help. The total volume of urine that I leak in a 24 hour period is usually actually quite small, anywhere from 5-6 ml to a maximum of 20 ml. While that doesn't seem like a lot, it can be bothersome. My surgeon suggests that I have a mesh sling implanted, as it is likely that my incontinence will not improve at this point. He all but guaranteed that I would be very happy with the result. That sounds good, but the thought of recovering from a gash right behind my scrotum is not very appealing. Has anyone here had this done? If so, how painful was the recovery period? Side effects? Was it successful? As my surgeon pointed out, there is no rush to do this, so I can take all the time I want to reach a decision whether to undergo the procedure or not. On the plus side, he considers the surgery a success and thinks that the cancer is permanently gone. And my erections are as good as pre-surgery, which is a testament to his nerve-sparing skill. Osh - it sounds like you have classic stress incontinence. You have reached the point where the majority of the 5% left with some incontinence ultimately reach, that is, you leak a little now and then, especially upon exertion. Most guys get by with absorbency products... pads, shields, liners. There's an amazing number of guys in your situation. It is never discussed, but the male adult product market is some billions of dollars annually (can't remember if it was four or forty... it's in my notes somewhere.) Another guy came into this forum a few months inquiring about the sling. To be honest, I have found that this is not the forum to obtain first hand recommendations on obscure topics. If you do more searching you will find other forums frequented by guys with lets say more esoteric issues resulting from PCa. The cancer survivors network is one very good resource. This forum (cancer forums dot net) is a warm, friendly place where guys can feel comfortable discussing their problems, but a lot of what goes on here is congratulating each other on low PSA's. I don't mean to diss anyone, but questions about slings and AUS's largely go unanswered here. Anyway, something you need to keep in mind is that when a surgeon - and most urologists are surgeons - recommends an implant, he is in fact trying to sell you something. It may actually be for your better interest, but many many more guys opt for pads rather than surgery. We all have other, better things to do with our time and money. Personally I have no experience with the sling, only that my Uro said that I am definitely NOT a candidate for that device. As far as the surgery goes, I've had two scrotal surgeries related to the removal of my right testicle, and will be facing yet another one to implant the AUS in a couple weeks. I know what to expect. Some pain - mainly stinging rather than throbbing, lots of discoloration and maybe some swelling. Plan on spending a week or two with a bag of frozen peas on your groin. Not the worst experience. The decision is entirely yours, as to whether some discomfort - and the very real possibility that it does not completely resolve your problem - is worth the time and "suffering". And congratulations on the successes you've experienced since your RP. Good luck with whatever you choose.

Posts.Title: Update on incontinence recommendations

Posts.Content: Dave, in my opinion you should consider yourself well on the way to BCR and looking into SRT. I remember seeing the same report mentioned by Prato that urologists tend to recommend SRT much later than RO's do. The same website also has a report that starting SRT before 21 months post-op has far better outcomes than waiting until the .2 threshold is crossed. This is what has led the the current thinking that three consecutive rises above .03 should trigger SRT (I'm generalizing here). With your positive surgical margin and small secondary grade 4 pathology I believe that should be considered sufficient adverse pathology to at least consider initiating SRT. Remember that grade 4 is the type that spreads, and essentially there is no grade 1 or 2 in this scoring method. The philosophy behind early SRT (eSRT) is to zap any remaining cancer cells that may have escaped (+SM) while they are still localized and before they leave the prostate bed and move on to other areas of the body... which is probably what Prato is facing right now. Even a small number of grade 4 cells could have easily been missed in pathology but are enough to set up residence. Please realize that I have no medical training and my opinions are often refuted because I don't cite specific studies and such, but I've seen enough and been thru enough that I recognize a duck when I see a duck. At this stage, one year post-op, you are playing a game of odds. Your condition may progress or it may not... there is no way to know now what the future will hold. I think you have made the right decision having your PSA re-evaluated and recognized that you are not in Kansas anymore. When it is your life that you are betting on, it becomes an entirely different game than the one your doctors are facing. Let's say it's like a bacon and eggs breakfast... a chicken was involved, but the pig was committed. Your urologist was involved, but you are committed. Any possibility of BCR means to your Uro that his surgery failed, and he may be reluctant to consider that as a possibility. But it is your future and your life that is on the line. You want to do all you can now, and not allow the beast to gain the upper hand. Good luck!

Posts.Title: One year Result, no man's land follow up.

Posts.Content: Chuck, sorry to hear about your cousin's situation, but of course the good news is that it apparently was caught fairly early before the horses have left the barn. Unfortunate that it is 4+3 and PSA in the teens, but he does have many options available... granted, complicated by the blood thinner which seems to be universal these days. Most likely, traditional IMRT would be the best course to follow, probably 44 Tx for ~80 Gy. Lots of guys in their mid 70's were getting that protocol when I was in ART. The addition of Lupron would be a more aggressive approach if there were indeed more serious pathology. As I understand it, the advantage is 5-10% in addition to RT, but that stat is I believe for aSRT, not primary radiation. Some RO's would include Casodex in more advanced cases, and a few even recommend Casodex monotherapy where there is the risk of disease progression during RT. (My summation of what I've read... and I am certainly not an authority on this). Presumably Jerry is on Medicare, which if traditional A+B+supplemental, covers the cost of all Lupron injections. I do not believe it is the gold mine that many cancer patients believe to be driving the pharmaceutical industry. They use what works and has been proven safe and effective. Best wishes for your cousin's treatment, and for your family's concerns during this period.

Posts.Title: My Cousin has Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: I just wanted to let everyone know that we just returned from the hospital and my wife's oncologist said she is in complete remission. The PET scan from earlier this week was clear and all the tumors have disappeared. She asked why she was still having so much pain and he said it was because the cancer had eaten away at her bones, and now that it is gone, her bones are filling in again... so she is experiencing "growing pains". He said she has a 70% likelihood of remaining in remission for the rest of her life and "of the other 30% we usually can save about half"... so right around 85%, which is what I had read when I first began to research her PBL back in December. Now she is in surveillance and is supposed to get CT scans every six months, starting in October... which is right around when I hope to finish SRT, assuming everything goes well with the AUS on Monday.

Posts.Title: Wife in full remission

Posts.Content: Post prostatectomy adjuvant or salvage radiation is typically 38-40 sessions. Some have reported as little as 35. Some newer technologies allow 25 sessions, but the vast majority are around 39. And it is every weekday for eight weeks. Once you start, it is recommended to never miss a day. Radiation works by killing cells, all cells. Healthy cells recover overnight but cancer cells are further weakened with every treatment. By contrast, primary radiation is usually 44 treatments. Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Frequency & number of salvage radiation sessions

Posts.Content: Welcome to the 5% club MRJ. One in 20 RALP patients never regain continence, or at least not down to single pad status. In my case, it became apparent at seven months that I would not be able to hold a full bladder long enough to undergo adjuvant radiation. I was in a bit of a time crunch due to adverse pathology and was told that most significant continence returns within the first nine months. I hate to say you've missed that boat. Certainly by 18 months you won't be healing much further. I've had the AUS for a full year now. It did not go well and I blame it all on the surgeon. Most other guys had a simple procedure... everything that my surgeon promised me, but what I experienced was anything but simple. So I don't mean to discourage you. I had the Kegel coach with the anal probe and everything before going ahead with the AUS. But one thing is certain... life with the AUS is far better than life without it. The surgery was supposed to be a quick 45 minute outpatient procedure and there would be no catheter. Well I was at the hospital for twelve hours before going home with a Foley which I had for two weeks before the AUS was finally replaced. I developed severe pelvic pain following the second surgery, but the device works and my radiation proceeded but was delayed by a month. I still drip and squirt unexpectedly and typically go thru one pad a day. What I have now is an inconvenience, a nuisance and an annoyance, but it's one I can deal with. I wore a leg bag for a year before last July and this is so-o-o-o much better. But it is still a life altering decision. There is a bit of a learning curve and the device has a limited lifespan and must be replaced periodically. AFAIK there are not many other AUS recipients on this msg board but I have found a few others. Also I had done a LOT of research into the AUS before going ahead with it, but that didn't help much. The surgeon said he has never had this happen to him before (note... I'm the one it happened to!) Also he is not the same surgeon as the one who did my RP. Anyway, I'd say you've done all you possibly can already and this is the final alternative... either get the AUS or spend your life with pads in your pants. If you want to discuss this any further I'd be happy to help in any way I can. Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Frequency & number of salvage radiation sessions

Posts.Content: Red - This "why are you on Zytiga" has been asked frequently ever since you first came to this forum. MM and ASA are correct, this is not a first line treatment for your grade of cancer. Zytiga with concomitant prednisone is typically reserved for stage 4 metastatic castration-resistant PCa, and then only after a variety of hormone therapies have failed. Let's say it is not for for casual use. All though your pathological stage is not listed in your sig, you do mention SVI so you are presumably pT3bN0Mx. Have you had a bone scan? How has Emory determined that you have metastatic cancer? This is important information for you to provide if you expect to garner appropriate replies when you post such questions here. How would anyone here know whether the combination with RT is safe when no one has ever even heard of that unusual pairing?

Posts.Title: Zytiga and Radiation, safe?

Posts.Content: CB, I too had RP followed by RT and was T3b with SVI, but I was G8 and my PSA was higher than yours. Do you know what your PSA was before starting RT? Any hormone therapy? You do have an advantage in that your biopsy was 4+5 not your post-op 5+4, otherwise you might not have even had the RP. My doc tells me that RP+RT has better disease specific survival than either RP or RT alone.

Posts.Title: Fodder for the pro-PSA test argument

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Great find PCASpouse Agreed! Originally Posted by Michael F A key takeaway in the Discussion is: "this trial showed that when clinicians limited themselves to the use of MRI-targeted biopsies only, the rates of detection of clinically significant cancer were higher than those seen with the standard of care. Furthermore, because systematic biopsy was avoided, clinically insignificant cancer was detected in fewer men, which may have a substantial benefit in reducing the overtreatment of men with prostate cancer." I believe that the true key takeaway would be the greater number of men who were or would have previously been undertreated because their tumors were located high up, away from the small portion of the gland that is accessible using the standard TRUS biopsy. It's about time for the bureaucrats to finally come to their senses on this one!

Posts.Title: NEJM new paper favors MRI guided bx as standard of care

Posts.Content: My RO said that in two studies, one using six months of ADT and the other with two years of ADT, indicated improved outcome when ADT is combined with RT. I don't know the names of the studies, but my RO doesn't believe everything he reads. I brought up other studies and he was familiar with them but said they didn't apply and gave me specific reasons for him thinking so. It surprised me actually, that he could remember having read them and recall their particulars. After RP I heard everything from six months to three years regarding the length of ADT. I could have gotten off six months ago but after much research and discussion opted for 18 months of ADT based on recent reports. HT is rough, but you get used to it, sort of like being in the military. By the way, AFAIK IMRT is a form of EBRT. I guess it depends on the machine being used. But I think External Beam RT is maybe the oldest, followed by Intensity Modulated RT, then Image Guided RT, at least as near as I can figure.

Posts.Title: 9-year survival differences: aggressive vs. conservative treatment for advanced PC

Posts.Content: Yes my initial biopsy was totally negative... no sign of cancer. The fusion biopsy two years later showed that 25% of my prostate was grade 4, Gleason 8. How did that happen? Without an MRI and a fusion biopsy, the urologist can only access less than one half of the prostate. In other words, my original urologist - in my opinion, didn't even look. It's like opening the closet door and saying nothing in here but clothes, without bothering to at least look around. By the time I was on my third urologist, I remarked on a graphic he had hanging in his office which showed that the top half of the prostate (the "base") is entirely hidden behind the pubic bone. I said "no wonder my other urologist couldn't find my cancer" and he said "yeah, you can never find them up there." So how could one's cancer progress from non-existent to very high risk and locally advanced in just two years? By a urologist who was not entirely honest with the patient. He made no attempt whatsoever to INFORM me of the possibility of a false negative biopsy. He only told me that my biopsy was negative and that my prostate was normal. In my mind, performing a biopsy that completely missed a sizable tumor should be grounds for a lawsuit. But of course that would likely be a futile effort and would just make me feel worse. And so because two years were lost, I am basically now an incontinent eunuch with major depressive disorder. I certainly hope you don't end up that way. I always assumed that a doctor would know what he's doing and that he would act only in the patient's best interest. Not so.

Posts.Title: Question about biopsy changes

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tybeeman Boy that is a long post LOL. I am a bad reader and a worst writer so pardon my bad writing skills. ... with any radiation you will almost always have some type of recurrence in 20 years. that make you 87. At 56 I would be 76. My dad was 95 when he died and my mother is still alive at 93. I did want to deal with it at 76. Tybee - one bad reader to another, I'm guessing that you do NOT want to deal with it at 76... and I'm in the same boat as you. Called a "slow reader" or "problem reader" in high school, ended up not surprisingly with low verbal and high math SAT's... engineering material for sure. Today they call it mild dyslexia. I can read but have to repeatedly start over and over to finish a sentence, especially if someone has used internet jargon "u r", or when they use the wrong their there or the wrong wear where. Another - I am always impressed with the depth of your knowledge and your mastery of language. I am jealous. In light of what I've said in the previous paragraph, perhaps you understand why. Also perhaps you can appreciate the amount of effort that I must conjure up to respond to posts here on cancer forums. People ask what I do in my retirement... this is what I do. It takes a lot of my time. In the months and years ahead when one or the both of us have moved on I will miss reading your insights... as well as that of many other forum brother here. Tybee - is your PSA rising? Are you doing anything about it? Sorry if I missed something, but your numbers and your timeline look awful (no offense please).

Posts.Content: Michael - You were fortunate to not have any incontinence following surgery, but reading your bio I am wondering why you are staged as T3a even though there is seminal vesicle invasion. From what I've read SVI is staged as T3b. Your sig also mentions lymphatic invasion, but you are staged at N0... again, I thought LNI would be N1.... just curious.

Posts.Title: PSA after both prostate removal and radiation going up 2016

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by fxoptions I forgot to ask , do antibiotics effect a PSA test results. I was on 10 days of Ciprofloxacin and Moxifloxacin for diverticulitis, two days later I had blood test for PSA. I did not tell my Urologist this ( a mistake). some say this may lower the PSA results. Is this true? FWIW my PSA shot up just after I had been on two different antibiotics for a stubborn infection in my jaw. The Dr was not sure if the PSA reading was false and possibly caused by the infection (but not the antibiotics). Then after the infection had been cured the PSA continued to rise. So in other words, infections may cause an elevated PSA but not necessarily antibiotics. Cipro was later prescribed after my first biopsy when the Uro wasn't sure if maybe the increased PSA may have been caused by another infection or perhaps prostatitis.

Posts.Title: CT scan and DRE shows issue with my prostate, confused

Posts.Content: Have you had a colonoscopy since your RT? Mine determined what I had suspected, that there was damage to the colon from the RT. While proctitis is more common than colitis, both can cause frequent BM's for months or years following RT. BTW I've had to eliminate some foods that I found caused bowel problems, onions and beans, and also had to limit consumption of fruits and vegetables. Currently I sometimes have as many as four BM's per day (sorry if this is TMI for some). Fortunately it's not like that every day, but often enough to be inconvenient.

Posts.Title: Bowel movements after RT

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic The chances of missing existing cancer go down very fast with repeat biopsies. Except in your case, Djin. And in any case where the Uro intends to keep poking at the same area of the prostate, hoping for a lucky strike, without considering any alternative approach. Originally Posted by Ready2Fight Yes for us. First biopsy came back negative and my husband was ready to celebrate... not so fast Mr. MRI guided biopsy found it in the hard to reach anterior and there was plenty of it. Pathology later revealed that 35% of his prostate was cancerous all while his first biopsy came back showing none. I'm sorry that your husband had to go thru the same ordeal that I did. At least his appears to be relatively low grade and without extraprostatic tissue invasion. And he had you in his corner. And possibly the urologist. True, many would see a negative biopsy as good news. But to me it was disturbing because I had so many symptoms and my urologist wasn't doing anything to help me. I'm sorry everyone. I've been really down all day and it shows in my posts.

Posts.Title: New to forum and to diagnosis of prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Yes J, and tennisplayer, surgery does come with risks, and I've had my share. But reading others' stories here I realize that it also happens to others and we are all fortunate that it does not happen more often then it does. In your case, I'm not sure you would have been any better off if you had waited a couple months and were one of your original surgeon's first surgical patient following his "recovery"... or that your cancer would not have progressed further, with the accompanying added complications. In my case, the prostatectomy was a stellar experience (other than learning that there was still some cancer left behind) and when I needed a urinary implant in order to proceed with treatment, that THAT surgery would require immediate revision, and that the revision would leave me with chronic pain. Sometimes it just works out that way. At least we are being treated for our cancers and the we are fighting the good fight, with the hope that we will come out on top. Good luck going forward, J. Stop back sometime later on and please tell us some more about your cancer.

Posts.Title: High-Risk Prostate Cancer: Classification and Therapy (a 2014 paper)

Posts.Content: The ultrasound guided biopsy is the traditional first approach to a suspicious prostate. Sometimes it misses existing cancer because it is random in nature. The ultrasound merely guides the needles to the prostate, not to a suspected tumor. Twelve to 15 cores is also the normal sample size. The MRI guided is more accurate but sometimes it is not covered by insurance unless there has been an ultrasound biopsy performed first. Also most doctors are not alarmed by a gradually rising PSA over a period of years, but take action when it approaches 10 or if it suddenly shoots up unexpectedly. Given your history it is possible that there is cancer in your prostate, but there is nothing that can be done until it has been identified and evaluated. So far everything you have described sounds like a textbook case, and everything is proceeding normally and as would be expected. One thing to consider, assuming that a tumor is present, is that you will likely face a choice between surgery or radiation treatment. Your current age and general state of your health will also be a factor in evaluating various alternative treatments. EDIT: Removed singular mention of hormone injections.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe Is it the surgery that scares you. Are you afraid you will die on table or the side effects... I suppose the first few are scary. After a dozen or so it's just another surgery. Yes, there are risks. And stuff can happen. And the more surgeries you have, the narrower your odds become. Usually everything goes just fine. The thing that scares me most is "intraoperative recall".

Posts.Title: 65 Years Old Male PSA 12, DRE feels hardness on the right side, waiting for biopsy

Posts.Content: Yeah Nick, you're pretty normal. I was on Lupron for eight months before RT. My body and limb hair had become fine and wispy. Zero libido, and as George said, don't really care about that. In fact I can't believe how much time and attention I used to devote to things sexual in nature. I've had very little problem with weight gain and no manboobs, though appear more flabby because of muscle loss. I've become somewhat of a weakling too. Now with both muscle and bones weaker I need to be careful as it is easy to overestimate my strength (i.e., it's shocking how weak I've actually become). Greatest SE's are hot flashes and brain fog. My wife tells me I've become a dumb blonde. I keep a fan by the sofa, by my bed and in the bathroom door, and bought a remote control on Amazon for $20 that controls three appliances (Elekcity Zap). I generally only need the fan for a minute or two. What hair was left on my abdomen disappeared during RT. Also the mild weakness caused by the Lupron was far overshadowed by the fatigue from RT. Last month was the first month that I "would have" had another Lupron shot but did not. Now it's just a matter of waiting for the slow recovery of my T-level. As I understand it, that won't happen until 2020, and it will never be what it was before. I still spend a lot of time just laying around listening to music, though I do get involved in a few projects and get out now and then... but not much passion for anything. No "drive". I don't really miss the body hair or the obsession with sex. But I do miss having clarity of mind. And the hot flashes are annoying and inconvenient to say the least. Fortunately it won't last forever, but how much recovery I will experience and when when still remains to be seen.

Posts.Title: One year on Lupron

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Men diagnosed with locally advanced (cT3-T4 or N+ and M0) ... For men with advanced, nonmetastatic prostate cancer, conservative treatment alone was associated with a 4 times higher likelihood of prostate cancer mortality compared with men treated with surgery... the results of the current study did affirm advantages in the setting of locally advanced disease. Thanks for the info DJin. I breathe a massive sigh of relief every time I read something like this, confirming that I was right to throw everything at this disease, and consider myself so very fortunate that it was caught just in the nick of time, before advancing to the next stage.

Posts.Title: 9-year survival differences: aggressive vs. conservative treatment for advanced PC

Posts.Content: Interesting story... I can't say that I've run across a similar situation anywhere, at least in the past year. But this type of scenario may become more common today with so much genetic testing available (I recently did an Ancestry DNA myself). I believe you were smart to decide NOT to pass on the family curse, and I think - if I understand correctly - that your question is if anyone here agrees that you should pursue having preventative prostatectomy before you become stricken as have your ancestors. I would say, if Angelina Joley can have bilateral mastectomies based solely on genetic testing, then go for it. You may have some difficulty with the national healthcare system balking at circumventing protocol, but you may be able to find someone to champion your case. Good luck in your efforts. It sounds like you have really been on top of this so far and willing to move forward into uncharted territory.

Posts.Title: genome tested, lots of badness

Posts.Content: Nick - If you truly have seminal vesicle involvement then you are already in the high risk group, where you join MM and me. MM knows what he's talking about. And Jim's remark about the professor's mental state should also be considered. My PCa appeared three and a half years ago, yet my Urologist took his time dealing with it. Later it turned out he had health problems of his own and mine was not addressed seriously until he retired. By then it had already begun to spread... as has yours. Our cases are different, but given your mention of SVI then you are also (for lack of a signature) stage pT3B. Next stage is bone metastasis, which becomes MUCH more difficult to treat. None of us are medical professionals, but it's obvious to all of us (I think) that you should at least be on HT now... and that only buys time. You do NOT want to allow this to progress any further! The window typically closes after 18-24 months. Good luck!

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tybeeman Boy that is a long post LOL. I am a bad reader and a worst writer so pardon my bad writing skills. ... with any radiation you will almost always have some type of recurrence in 20 years. that make you 87. At 56 I would be 76. My dad was 95 when he died and my mother is still alive at 93. I did want to deal with it at 76. Tybee - one bad reader to another, I'm guessing that you do NOT want to deal with it at 76... and I'm in the same boat as you. Called a "slow reader" or "problem reader" in high school, ended up not surprisingly with low verbal and high math SAT's... engineering material for sure. Today they call it mild dyslexia. I can read but have to repeatedly start over and over to finish a sentence, especially if someone has used internet jargon "u r", or when they use the wrong their there or the wrong wear where. Another - I am always impressed with the depth of your knowledge and your mastery of language. I am jealous. In light of what I've said in the previous paragraph, perhaps you understand why. Also perhaps you can appreciate the amount of effort that I must conjure up to respond to posts here on cancer forums. People ask what I do in my retirement... this is what I do. It takes a lot of my time. In the months and years ahead when one or the both of us have moved on I will miss reading your insights... as well as that of many other forum brother here. Tybee - is your PSA rising? Are you doing anything about it? Sorry if I missed something, but your numbers and your timeline look awful (no offense please).

Our cases are different, but given your mention of SVI then you are also (for lack of a signature) stage pT3B. Next stage is bone metastasis, which becomes MUCH more difficult to treat. None of us are medical professionals, but it's obvious to all of us (I think) that you should at least be on HT now... and that only buys time. You do NOT want to allow this to progress any further! The window typically closes after 18-24 months. Good luck!

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Surgical removal of the tumor in my small bowel is scheduled for Monday. I know the board tends to slow down on weekends, and I'm not sure how much time I'll have to post before Monday morning. The hospital is supposed to call with an arrival time by the end of the day today. It may be a successful laparoscopic excision of a (hopefully) benign tumor and I'll just lose a few feet of bowel... maybe even lose some weight. But naturally I've also considered several other worse outcomes, though I would rather not give them voice. I've been in surgical prep mode for a few weeks now... tapering off certain meds, getting clearance from other doctors. I've had to discontinue all supplements that might cause bleeding, and also all narcotics, COX2 and NSAIDS, so my legs are killing me. Starting last night I must shower with surgical scrub, wear only freshly clean clothes and sleep on clean sheets... a newer protocol intended to minimize the possibility of infection. Sunday will be clear liquids only (ugh). My blog has been updated somewhat. As of a few weeks ago I was getting pretty sick of reading about cancer. And re-living a few painful memories. This is the fourth cancer that I've had to get up to speed on in a short time since our retirement three years ago. Looking back, it seems that each life change has served to toughen us up for the next one yet to come. Frankly I'm a bit scared. I know worrying won't help, and so far I seem to have been cruising along, feeling that I'm handling this well... then stop and think about it. My mind drifts away for a few moments, and suddenly realize just how scary this is. I trust the surgeon. He appears confident. But from the start this whole thing has been full of mixed messages. I pray that it turns out to be as simple as he believes it will be.

Posts.Title: Wish me luck... Please!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gary e I am 2 months into firmagon. And just under 3weeks with IMRT. I am developing diarrhea problems. Will the Onc doctor prescribe a drug to firm me up. I don't want to be over drugged if possible Gary e Gary, I had diarrhea and frequent loose bowel issues starting my second week of IMRT. My radiation oncologist recommended that I have Activia yogurt 2X daily. No drugs. My RT ended two months ago and I still sometimes have proctitis... the urge to poop several times a day. This isn't discussed much anywhere online. You can read some of my recount of this in the RT sticky at the top of the forum list. It would be the last or next to last page. During RT I had to give up most fresh fruits and veggies. A small salad with dinner is all I could eat without problems. I found that the BRAT diet helped... Bananas, Rice, Apples and Toast. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Lower GI issues

Posts.Content: Thanks guys... The hospital called and my ETA is 8:30AM, so I guess I'll be going under around 10 or so. Gary, this is at Morton Plant hospital (that's the factory where they make salt, right?). It's the main hospital in the Baycare chain that owns most of the medical facilities in Pinellas county... Clearwater/St Pete. It's a nice building right on the intercoastal waterway. It would be nice if I "luck out" like I did with my RP back in Ohio. Someone must have recognized my wife's name and I was put in the executive suite... private room with a sofa, conference table and a panoramic view of our city of seven hills. But hopefully I will remember to inquire about paying the upcharge to get a private room... if I can think of it Monday morning. The surgeon said two days if he can do it laproscopically, and five days if he has to open me up (one in three possibility of that). Don't let the forum fall apart while I'm gone MF Hopefully I'll be online over the weekend, and if I remember to take my tablet, feel up to posting from the hospital.

Posts.Title: Sarasota/Bradenton, FL Doctors

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Photopassion He's now 66 and was diagnosed about 2.5 years ago. He had a Gleason score of 8 and a PSA of 22. The surgeon didn't really want to do surgery because the tumor was so large... If it is any consolation, those figures are nearly identical to mine. I am 66 and had a G8 and PSA 25. So your father's surgeon did what he should have done going into the surgery. But your dad should have been referred to a radiation oncologist immediately after surgery if there was adverse post-op pathology (as I was), or certainly when his PSA began to rise. MM, MF and Chuck have provided excellent recommendations. There are new hormone therapies and gene specific treatments available today that have appeared on the scene only within the past couple of years. It is unfortunate that appropriate action was not taken sooner, but it is certainly not too late for him, as I had stated in my initial reply to your post. There are many other guys on this and other message boards with far worse pathologies who have survived for years, so please don't be discouraged so soon. Your dad likely still has a long way to go if proper action is taken very soon.

Posts.Title: Honest Thoughts about Advanced Disease

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tybeeman Boy that is a long post LOL. I am a bad reader and a worst writer so pardon my bad writing skills. ... with any radiation you will almost always have some type of recurrence in 20 years. that make you 87. At 56 I would be 76. My dad was 95 when he died and my mother is still alive at 93. I did want to deal with it at 76. Tybee - one bad reader to another, I'm guessing that you do NOT want to deal with it at 76... and I'm in the same boat as you. Called a "slow reader" or "problem reader" in high school, ended up not surprisingly with low verbal and high math SAT's... engineering material for sure. Today they call it mild dyslexia. I can read but have to repeatedly start over and over to finish a sentence, especially if someone has used internet jargon "u r", or when they use the wrong their there or the wrong wear where. Another - I am always impressed with the depth of your knowledge and your mastery of language. I am jealous. In light of what I've said in the previous paragraph, perhaps you understand why. Also perhaps you can appreciate the amount of effort that I must conjure up to respond to posts here on cancer forums. People ask what I do in my retirement... this is what I do. It takes a lot of my time. In the months and years ahead when one or the both of us have moved on I will miss reading your insights... as well as that of many other forum brother here. Tybee - is your PSA rising? Are you doing anything about it? Sorry if I missed something, but your numbers and your timeline look awful (no offense please).

Posts.Title: What does your Gleason score actually mean?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rmotacek1 I am 3 .5 years post davinci & 3 years post radiation. I have been having regular dull ache in my stomach lately just above my navel. Anyone else experience this? Could it be from the old davinci incision? I am kind of worried it could be stomach cancer but my PSA has been really good lately. Just always worried about the cancer coming back some day I guess. Probably not cancer, probably not your stomach, and most likely not related in any way to your prostatectomy. DO see a doctor about it, but do not present any of your "theories"... You may eventually get a CT or similar scan. Interesting that you mention your DaVinci incision. The largest of mine is a horizontal, a few inches long and just above the navel. For a couple of years it was my ugliest scar. Then the mesenteric surgery last fall put a 7" long vertical scar that crosses the RP scar, so I am forever branded with the sign of the cross. You gotta see it to fully appreciate it... And I'm not even catholic!

Posts.Title: Stomach Pain

Posts.Content: Age 83 is the typical lifespan for males. Some live into their nineties, but that is far more common for women than men. Surely you realize that this is an end of life scenario. Hopefully you have addressed this with him and you know his feelings on this. I feel so sorry for you, having watched my own father and mother wither away. My Dad, himself a physician, chose to let himself deteriorate eventually die at home, where he was comfortable. My mother went thru several care facilities, but watched all of her friends go before her and felt terribly alone. You must ask yourself, and your father, how much longer you expect him to live, and what will his final years be like? Good luck with your decision. This is never easy.
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Small cell

Posts.Content: Nick - If you truly have seminal vesicle involvement then you are already in the high risk group, where you join MM and me. MM knows what he's talking about. And Jim's remark about the professor's mental state should also be considered. My PCa appeared three and a half years ago, yet my Urologist took his time dealing with it. Later it turned out he had health problems of his own and mine was not addressed seriously until he retired. By then it had already begun to spread... as has yours. Our cases are different, but given your mention of SVI then you are also (for lack of a signature) stage pT3B. Next stage is bone metastasis, which becomes MUCH more difficult to treat. None of us are medical professionals, but it's obvious to all of us (I think) that you should at least be on HT now... and that only buys time. You do NOT want to allow this to progress any further! The window typically closes after 18-24 months. Good luck!

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Thanks Rooster. I had been reading that 18 months was the new normal, and a year ago I requested to end mine at 18 months. Originally I had heard everything from nine months to three years. So my last six month shot expired in July (two months ago), but I'm still waiting for my SE's to subside. I'm still having major hot flashes. What I've also read is that the six month shots take longer to wear off (have a longer half life due to the more "durable" depot agent), plus being on HT for a longer time as well as just being older, all mean that it will take longer to wear off. So I figure sometime in the year 2020 things will probably be about as good as they're going to get. Good luck Rooster. I hope things are going well for you.

Posts.Title: For those on long term hormone therapy (ADT)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tybeeman Boy that is a long post LOL. I am a bad reader and a worst writer so pardon my bad writing skills. ... with any radiation you will almost always have some type of recurrence in 20 years. that make you 87. At 56 I would be 76. My dad was 95 when he died and my mother is still alive at 93. I did want to deal with it at 76. Tybee - one bad reader to another, I'm guessing that you do NOT want to deal with it at 76... and I'm in the same boat as you. Called a "slow reader" or "problem reader" in high school, ended up not surprisingly with low verbal and high math SAT's... engineering material for sure. Today they call it mild dyslexia. I can read but have to repeatedly start over and over to finish a sentence, especially if someone has used internet jargon "u r", or when they use the wrong their there or the wrong wear where. Another - I am always impressed with the depth of your knowledge and your mastery of language. I am jealous. In light of what I've said in the previous paragraph, perhaps you understand why. Also perhaps you can appreciate the amount of effort that I must conjure up to respond to posts here on cancer forums. People ask what I do in my retirement... this is what I do. It takes a lot of my time. In the months and years ahead when one or the both of us have moved on I will miss reading your insights... as well as that of many other forum brother here. Tybee - is your PSA rising? Are you doing anything about it? Sorry if I missed something, but your numbers and your timeline look awful (no offense please).

Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: I would say that our immune systems never killed any cancer cells. In theory, cancer cells are actually our own cells, but mutated.
Posts.Title: Question about recurrence post RP

Posts.Content: Busby, you are a young man and your pathology was not that bad. It appears from your sig that the cause of your PSA is your positive margin and lymphoascular invasion. So there is likely some cancerous tissue remaining local to your prostate bed. My non-professional recommendation would be to treat it NOW before it leaves the pelvic area and moves on to other parts of your body. At that point it would become incurable, and you would be destined for lifelong HT, or a slow painful death. You are much too young for that. Hit this thing with everything available NOW to knock it out before it takes over. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Question on BCR - Using PSA to predict time until serious symptoms

Posts.Content: Depending on the results of the biopsy, he will probably be scheduled for a nuclear bone scan, and perhaps a PET scan and some more blood work. The bone scan is not as scary as it sounds. They inject a small amount of isotope and he comes back in a few hours and lies down on a table while a scanner takes some pictures. He will be given a card stating that he has this isotope in him for a period of weeks or months which will be very important to have if and when he travels by air. The scans are necessary if he has advanced PCa (which it sounds like he might have, based on his PSA) to determine if any cancer has spread to other parts of his body, where and how much.

Posts.Content: I'm three months into my first round of Lupron and it looks like I'll be on it for the rest of the year at least. Fortunately the side effects have been tolerable. However after reading about bone loss I mentioned to my RO that I am already osteopenic and also on PPI's so might already be at high risk of bone fractures. His LPN called today about scheduling a Prolia shot and I ran it past my PCP who said it's "probably" approved for men by Medicare, but I need to be sure as I know it is very expensive. Has anyone here had Prolia or any other osteoporosis injection while on long term ADT, and if so was it covered by your insurance (or in particular, Medicare?) ... I know I tend to come here asking about issues that most of the constituency has never faced, so I guess I'm asking the guys who have more advanced conditions. Thanks.

Posts.Title: Any experience with Prolia on Lupron HT?

Posts.Content: As I understand, it is not necessary, but probably depends on the stage of prostate cancer. Those who are G9/10 or already stage 4 are generally started on a couple weeks of Casodex to prevent the surge of testosterone known as "Lupron flare" when Lupron is first administered. I was not given Casodex beforehand and was climbing the walls for about ten days following my first Lupron shot. I think the surge would likely be detrimental to patients who already have metastatic PCa. Those who are stage 3 like me probably not so much. At least that's my guess as why some guys get it and some don't.
