Posts.Title: Must Casodex be given before a Lupron shot?

Posts.Content: Very well laid out and informative reply ASA! ... I have have held back so far on posting in this thread as I tend to be the "poster boy" for incontinence (see other recent incontinence thread: Looking for Information) ... Regarding RP, the statistic I see most often is that 5% or one in twenty RP patients will have not regained full continence within 18 months. For most it occurs between 3-6 months and generally 90% of healing is completed by 9 months. Therefore adjuvant radiation, if needed, is typically scheduled for 6-8 months after RP... though most likely not applicable to the OP's situation. Even after the first two years some are left with an occasional infrequent "accident" during exertion (SUI). Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Radiation advocates will claim that "incontinence is almost non-existent" following RT. They are only partially correct, as that may mostly be true for avoiding full loss of control following primary RT, but there are still urinary issues for some men. Rarely mentioned, especially by the advocates of RT over RP. Often omitted is the fact that many victims of PCa have already had years of urinary issues and likely other treatments and/or medications for urinary frequency, urgency, difficulty starting/stopping flow, incomplete voiding and urethral burning sensations. So the fact that they may be left with WORSE urinary symptoms after RT doesn't make headlines. Being left incontinent by a surgeon's scalpel definitely does. And it sells books! Originally Posted by ASAdvocate So, take your time and investigate your options. One piece of advice would be not to take the opinions of a specialist in one area about other treatments, as they often don't know much about the other, and tend to promote their own. True words of wisdom. This tends to be the little secret within the medical community... favoring their own specialty over any others... presenting "best case" outcomes and rarely making mention of adverse effects (not unlike the drug commercials on TV, where the SE's like "may cause death" are rushed thru near the end of the ad).

Posts.Title: incontinence almost inevitable with normal treatment?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis I have cancer in my body and my job is to keep it out of my spirit! The shock of cancer can only be understood by those who have it ... The first impact of cancer was a profound loneliness and a gut level of fear that I have never experienced ... Cancer is a lonely disease. Support groups, forums and the like take the edge off and there are just times that the Dis-Ease sets in in your heart and drags you down. The other force which makes it so difficult is the slowness of treatment decisions and how the medical system moves. Denis, even though it has only been a few months since you first posted, I can see that you obviously 'get it'. What you wrote is all very well said and exhibits great insight to what all of us are going thru. Soon after my wife was discharged from the hospital, we were talking about our cancers and she said "it's the loneliest place you'll ever know". You mentioned that several times, so you obviously understand. Just last night, I was troubled by memories of her calling me in the middle of the night saying "I am so scared!" ... I often worry that I was not supportive enough for her during that time. There was a LOT going on then. It was a very uncomfortable time. This being October marks five years since that visit to a Urologist that started everything for me. What followed was three and a half years of being mishandled by the medical system, confounded by my own ignorance of the situation and perhaps reluctance to even consider the possibility of cancer. (Despite numerous prior surgeries, this was my very first cancer). Unfortunately I apparently let it get to me. I recognize that it has affected my spirit and my attitude about just about everything. Once you have cancer, everything else becomes much less important. When you and your life mate both have cancer, everything changes. You have the benefit of an early diagnosis and it sounds like you have a good medical team working for you. Hopefully you will be able to enjoy 'smooth sailing' throughout your journey. And keep your head above water.

Posts.Title: How cancer effects me!

Posts.Content: Red, good luck with the radiation. Do you know what your total dosage will be? I just completed adjuvant RT two weeks ago, and diarrhea started midway thru the second week. I've always had a somewhat sensitive digestive system, but this persisted all the way thru my eight weeks... not always diarrhea, but frequent urgency and still now two weeks later will sometimes have two or three very normal looking bowel movements throughout the day. One very important thing to remember is never trust a fart! ... It was very inconvenient to have to find a toilet whenever I felt the urge to expel (and it seemed to be much more often than previously or since) but keeping that rule probably saved me a few embarrassing situations. The gas was a puzzle. The RO had me on a reduced diet already... no beans, cruciferous veggies or peanut products, no carbonated drinks and no spicy food (easy for me!) and yet had frequent explosive gas. The doctor simply said that 'some bowel disruption is to be expected' but no one even mentioned that this might happen. I ended up severely limiting fruits and veggies... a banana was okay, but no more bowls of blueberries or squash. Around week six I was suddenly hit with tremendous fatigue. It lasted for anther week after Tx ended, but just now getting back to normal. I've been told everything should be back to normal in a few weeks and that the radiation will continue to kill cancer cells for another 8-9 months.

Posts.Content: I know that recent Forum Brothers MikeA and now Brownie have mentioned they are ex-military. This got me wondering just how many other vets are now members of the prostate cancer brotherhood, now that most guys who were draft age in the 1960's are now prime age for prostate cancer. After about six months in the British Isles, I spent the remaining three years living in a bomb shelter on the Czech border in Bavaria. It was among the best times of my life, and the GI bill was instrumental in letting me get my degree. How about you? Anything you care to share?

Posts.Title: Surgery Date Confirmed

Posts.Content: Following RP two years ago I went thru the usual stages of recovery, starting with dry nights at around one month. I could even walk to the bathroom in the mornings without leaking. But by midday I had very little control and would dribble all day until bedtime, when I would again be dry all thru the night. I was told right after surgery that I would need radiation at around six months, but my continence never improved. I went thru PT with a Kegel coach and the anal probe but my daytime leaking wasn't improving fast enough. After seven months I decided to get the AMS800 implant so that radiation could get underway. There were some problems with the implant but it was good enough to start RT at around the one year mark. But one of the after effects of the radiation is that I am no longer dry at night. I have to sleep with a dry washcloth tucked in between my legs. Even just turning over in bed I always drip a little onto the sheets or on my thigh... a sensation that causes one to wake up immediately. I think it's a reflex... memories of early childhood there. I suspect that the radiation damages the nerves and muscles involved in the bladder and sphincter and seems to take a long time to heal... years perhaps, or eventually, I'm hoping. But it is real. I've read other guys report their continence worsening after post-op radiation. As MM said, you are not alone. And MM... good luck with your AUS surgery.

Posts.Title: Sarasota/Bradenton, FL Doctors

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis I have cancer in my body and my job is to keep it out of my spirit! The shock of cancer can only be understood by those who have it ... The first impact of cancer was a profound loneliness and a gut level of fear that I have never experienced ... Cancer is a lonely disease. Support groups, forums and the like take the edge off and there are just times that the Dis-Ease sets in in your heart and drags you down. The other force which makes it so difficult is the slowness of treatment decisions and how the medical system moves. Denis, even though it has only been a few months since you first posted, I can see that you obviously 'get it'. What you wrote is all very well said and exhibits great insight to what all of us are going thru. Soon after my wife was discharged from the hospital, we were talking about our cancers and she said "it's the loneliest place you'll ever know". You mentioned that several times, so you obviously understand. Just last night, I was troubled by memories of her calling me in the middle of the night saying "I am so scared!" ... I often worry that I was not supportive enough for her during that time. There was a LOT going on then. It was a very uncomfortable time. This being October marks five years since that visit to a Urologist that started everything for me. What followed was three and a half years of being mishandled by the medical system, confounded by my own ignorance of the situation and perhaps reluctance to even consider the possibility of cancer. (Despite numerous prior surgeries, this was my very first cancer). Unfortunately I apparently let it get to me. I recognize that it has affected my spirit and my attitude about just about everything. Once you have cancer, everything else becomes much less important. When you and your life mate both have cancer, everything changes. You have the benefit of an early diagnosis and it sounds like you have a good medical team working for you. Hopefully you will be able to enjoy 'smooth sailing' throughout your journey. And keep your head above water.

Posts.Content: Very well laid out and informative reply ASA! ... I have have held back so far on posting in this thread as I tend to be the "poster boy" for incontinence (see other recent incontinence thread: Looking for Information) ... Regarding RP, the statistic I see most often is that 5% or one in twenty RP patients will have not regained full continence within 18 months. For most it occurs between 3-6 months and generally 90% of healing is completed by 9 months. Therefore adjuvant radiation, if needed, is typically scheduled for 6-8 months after RP... though most likely not applicable to the OP's situation. Even after the first two years some are left with an occasional infrequent "accident" during exertion (SUI). Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Radiation advocates will claim that "incontinence is almost non-existent" following RT. They are only partially correct, as that may mostly be true for avoiding full loss of control following primary RT, but there are still urinary issues for some men. Rarely mentioned, especially by the advocates of RT over RP. Often omitted is the fact that many victims of PCa have already had years of urinary issues and likely other treatments and/or medications for urinary frequency, urgency, difficulty starting/stopping flow, incomplete voiding and urethral burning sensations. So the fact that they may be left with WORSE urinary symptoms after RT doesn't make headlines. Being left incontinent by a surgeon's scalpel definitely does. And it sells books! Originally Posted by ASAdvocate So, take your time and investigate your options. One piece of advice would be not to take the opinions of a specialist in one area about other treatments, as they often don't know much about the other, and tend to promote their own. True words of wisdom. This tends to be the little secret within the medical community... favoring their own specialty over any others... presenting "best case" outcomes and rarely making mention of adverse effects (not unlike the drug commercials on TV, where the SE's like "may cause death" are rushed thru near the end of the ad).

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD Mainly I was wondering from those who have gone through external beam radiation, whether you were advised to go on some modified diet or whether you maintained your current diet and modified as necessary to limit bowel side effects. I was given a list by my RO of foods to avoid, and I ended up even having to add to it. I had to give up granola for breakfast. I also stopped most supplements and took only a bare minimum daily multivitamin (generic Centrum). And in addition to eliminating all the rich and spicy foods on the list, I had to severely restrict fresh fruits (berries) and vegetables (salads). I tried to eat fairly "normally" but had tremendous gas and diarrhea if I ate fruits and veggies as I used to. My RO recommended that I continue that diet for several weeks after the end of RT and now a year later I still have bowel issues from radiation colitis. But I have not had any weight gain issues other than from some meds I had to take for other medical problems... which I was later able to lose again. You might want to read the last few pages of the "EBRT" stickie on the main page. I remember that I posted there several times during RT, as did a few other guys going thru around the same time. Good luck to you! They say it is a marathon, not a sprint, especially with HT added.

Posts.Title: incontinence almost inevitable with normal treatment?

Posts.Content: Unfortunately I don't believe there is any magic sauce. Fatigue will most likely creep up on you later on during radiation, around six weeks in. Good news is that the time you most want to take a nap is just after each treatment, so if you get zapped on your way home from work, you'll likely go right to bed. Bad news is the HT will probably keep you from resting well due to night sweats. Some guys claim they never got the RT fatigue, but most do. And it lingers for a few weeks after your 40 has ended. Last Nov we had the grandkids down for a week at Universal Studios just a month after completing RT. My energy held up surprisingly well. But I'm not sure how well maintaining contractor's hours will work out. Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Full bladder

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RTS Curious if anyone has an opinion on leftover prostate tissue after surgery causing a psa rise? I just can’t see how with my pathology report that cancer could have gotten out of my prostate. Your post sugery psa of .11 july 2017, two and a half years after RP, qualifies as persistent PSA. I didn't see any other PSA's listed during that time period. Presumably you were indeed tested and just left it out or I just missed it. At .25 this month you are now in the territory of BCR and should be considering salvage radiation. There is a slight possibility that it is from benign prostate tissue left behind, but I would say that is most likely wishful thinking. You should also seriously consider adjuvant hormone therapy. How it escaped is at this point not the real question, but what you will be doing about it, and when. Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Full bladder

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KarlEmagne So I'm very likely a candidate for RP at age 53 and am wondering what others on this forum having undergone the procedure, especially with less than ideal outcomes, experienced afterwards in terms of mood swings. Has RP been triggering severely depressive episodes for anyone? I've already had several despite good physical health and am worried I'll be plunging into the next hole soon. I have unfortunately been unable to get help with this in our public health care system despite repeated attempts. The attitude seems to be one of total indifference towards male individuals over 50 who are working and paying taxes. To complicate matters, I had very adverse side effects from an SSRI anti-depressant which I tried decades ago. Advice? Coping strategies? Medications taken? My cancer experience sent me to very dark and unfamiliar place. I'd had no experience whatsoever with emotional or mental health issues in my past, but unfortunately my misdiagnosis occurred at a time in my life already filled with stress and anxiety, including retirement and relocation and following the deaths of several close friends and family members, all within a period of just a few years. I found myself crying all the time and prone to emotional outbursts. My family doctor was no help whatsoever, and my urologist's unwillingness to provide me with any information was most frustrating. Eventually I changed doctors and got the news that my "prostatitis" was actually cancer and it was far worse than had been suspected. And within two months of my prostatectomy we sold our home of 33 years and moved to Florida, where my wife was immediately diagnosed with advanced non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, again within just two months. On top of all that, I never regained urinary continence, was started on Lupron injections (which is another emotional roller coaster in itself) and had to postpone adjuvant radiation while I drove my wife to her chemotherapy treatments. I felt that I had no one in my corner... no one to help me or guide me. Some of the others here on this board may recall what an emotional mess I had become. Fortunately a few encouraged me to "get some help" (if only it were that easy). The radiation oncologist who ordered the Lupron was no help whatsoever... even dismissive of what I was going thru. Eventually thru my own research I learned about venlafaxine or Effexor, an SNRI, and outright asked my GP for a prescription. Suddenly things started to improve. I have now been on it for nearly two years, have had to go up and down in dosage a few times but am fairly certain that I will be taking it for the rest of my life. The emotional stability it has brought far outweighs the side effects. I should also mention the effects of general anesthesia. It sticks with you for a few weeks and can be very depressing... not to mention the stress of surgery and the emotions that go along with it. I am a veteran of over a dozen surgeries and have experienced this every time. Here again the Effexor has kept me from going off the rails when dark thoughts try to re-emerge. There's not a whole lot of joy to be experienced anymore. The SNRI just keeps me from swaying too far from the even keel so to speak. But just knowing this stability plus the positive outcomes of both my cancer and my wife's has brought some peace into my chaotic life. Coping strategies? I have none. I try to just go with the flow. I've had two other "close calls" with cancer since all of this happened. Long stories there. It can be scary, but I seem to be able to handle it all. I can't really help you much but maybe my story will help you feel not so alone in your struggle.

On top of all that, I never regained urinary continence, was started on Lupron injections (which is another emotional roller coaster in itself) and had to postpone adjuvant radiation while I drove my wife to her chemotherapy treatments. I felt that I had no one in my corner... no one to help me or guide me. Some of the others here on this board may recall what an emotional mess I had become. Fortunately a few encouraged me to "get some help" (if only it were that easy). The radiation oncologist who ordered the Lupron was no help whatsoever... even dismissive of what I was going thru. Eventually thru my own research I learned about venlafaxine or Effexor, an SNRI, and outright asked my GP for a prescription. Suddenly things started to improve. I have now been on it for nearly two years, have had to go up and down in dosage a few times but am fairly certain that I will be taking it for the rest of my life. The emotional stability it has brought far outweighs the side effects. I should also mention the effects of general anesthesia. It sticks with you for a few weeks and can be very depressing... not to mention the stress of surgery and the emotions that go along with it. I am a veteran of over a dozen surgeries and have experienced this every time. Here again the Effexor has kept me from going off the rails when dark thoughts try to re-emerge. There's not a whole lot of joy to be experienced anymore. The SNRI just keeps me from swaying too far from the even keel so to speak. But just knowing this stability plus the positive outcomes of both my cancer and my wife's has brought some peace into my chaotic life. Coping strategies? I have none. I try to just go with the flow. I've had two other "close calls" with cancer since all of this happened. Long stories there. It can be scary, but I seem to be able to handle it all. I can't really help you much but maybe my story will help you feel not so alone in your struggle.

Posts.Title: how long after radiation can I go back to roughage?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mostth Extraprostatic extension: The lesions more so on the left have broad based areas of capsular contact with extracapsular extension difficult to exclude towards and into left seminal vesicle. As I recall my MRI said something similar, giving the impression that my cancer was "close" but still contained within the prostate. Apparently a biopsy generally is not able confirm that. As it turned out following RP, the cancer had in fact exited the prostate in three areas and had invaded the seminal vesicles, which meant that I had to have Lupron and radiation soon after the prostatectomy. While I hate to say it, just be prepared for your case to possibly turn out to be worse than expected. It happens in about 30% of prostatectomies. There's nothing quite like waking up from surgery and hearing "we got MOST of the cancer".

Posts.Title: Help please

Posts.Content: Very well laid out and informative reply ASA! ... I have have held back so far on posting in this thread as I tend to be the "poster boy" for incontinence (see other recent incontinence thread: Looking for Information) ... Regarding RP, the statistic I see most often is that 5% or one in twenty RP patients will have not regained full continence within 18 months. For most it occurs between 3-6 months and generally 90% of healing is completed by 9 months. Therefore adjuvant radiation, if needed, is typically scheduled for 6-8 months after RP... though most likely not applicable to the OP's situation. Even after the first two years some are left with an occasional infrequent "accident" during exertion (SUI). Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Radiation advocates will claim that "incontinence is almost non-existent" following RT. They are only partially correct, as that may mostly be true for avoiding full loss of control following primary RT, but there are still urinary issues for some men. Rarely mentioned, especially by the advocates of RT over RP. Often omitted is the fact that many victims of PCa have already had years of urinary issues and likely other treatments and/or medications for urinary frequency, urgency, difficulty starting/stopping flow, incomplete voiding and urethral burning sensations. So the fact that they may be left with WORSE urinary symptoms after RT doesn't make headlines. Being left incontinent by a surgeon's scalpel definitely does. And it sells books! Originally Posted by ASAdvocate So, take your time and investigate your options. One piece of advice would be not to take the opinions of a specialist in one area about other treatments, as they often don't know much about the other, and tend to promote their own. True words of wisdom. This tends to be the little secret within the medical community... favoring their own specialty over any others... presenting "best case" outcomes and rarely making mention of adverse effects (not unlike the drug commercials on TV, where the SE's like "may cause death" are rushed thru near the end of the ad).

Posts.Title: incontinence almost inevitable with normal treatment?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mikesimm My Radiologist doc says she won't start adjunctive radiation after surgery until my pee skills "max out". She says once radiation is started, the pee skills are "fixed" at that point, so she wants me to be at my max. Anyone with experience on this? I think she won't go any longer than 2-3 months, regardless. Hoping I can get my skills honed by then. Yes, too much experience LOL! Just after surgery I was told I would need ART at around six months. At four months I was still largely incontinent so my Urologist put me into PT with a Kegel coach, which really didn't help much. At six months I could hold it as long as necessary as long as I was focused on it... totally dry nights, getting up from sitting, etc but walking around and DOING STUFF as soon as I lost focus on holding it I'd leak copiously. I was still unable to start RT for several reasons, one being the incontinence (the other being my wife's chemo schedule). At that point I had to decide whether or not to have an artificial sphincter implanted, which also carried with it a six week healing requirement plus a 1 in 4 chance of requiring revision surgery. Yes, you WILL be required to hold a full bladder for RT. I don't think I've heard anybody say they were spared that requirement. And yes, RT will 'freeze' the healing of everything in your pelvis and lower abdomen. Routine medical procedures such as colonoscopies must be worked around a three month window on either side of the two month RT. Personally I used an Excel spreadsheet to keep track of our schedules for both my wife and I... odd for a retired couple. But it really has been that complicated. Forgive me if I'm repeating myself. I don't know of anyone else on this board who has faced this decision. However several other guys who said they went into RT with good continence lost some of that by the time RT ended. So in other words, my continence would get no better and quite likely would become worse. Fast forward to today, with just ten more doses of RT left (two more weeks). The AUS is uncomfortable, sometimes painful... long story there. But it does its job. Additionally my natural sphincter still has decent control, so I need to release both my bladder sphincter plus squeeze the implant in order to pee. I do feel that my natural sphincter has continued to improve (heal) over the past six months, and perhaps the AUS might not have been an absolute necessity. But I did not know that six months ago. Much crystal ball gazing was required to get all these pieces to come together. Again, good luck Mike.

Posts.Title: Checking In

Posts.Content: Unfortunately I don't believe there is any magic sauce. Fatigue will most likely creep up on you later on during radiation, around six weeks in. Good news is that the time you most want to take a nap is just after each treatment, so if you get zapped on your way home from work, you'll likely go right to bed. Bad news is the HT will probably keep you from resting well due to night sweats. Some guys claim they never got the RT fatigue, but most do. And it lingers for a few weeks after your 40 has ended. Last Nov we had the grandkids down for a week at Universal Studios just a month after completing RT. My energy held up surprisingly well. But I'm not sure how well maintaining contractor's hours will work out. Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Starting Hormone Therapy and 8 weeks of Radiation-How to deal with fatigue

Posts.Content: I'll try to answer you here rather than on that other message board, where so far your thread has zero replies. I know that in the past we have joked about spending too much time in cancer forums. Well, just last night I discovered yet another one (that makes four for me, not counting several I checked out but where I never bothered to register). And I can only speak for my own case, but yours is not so dissimilar. You fear that it may be unhealthy, but for me it is a necessity. We both have a spouse who has also been thru cancer, and in some ways are still going thru it. In my case, it dropped in my lap right in the midst of my own cancer struggle. You have the additional burden of your CAD and I consider myself fortunate to be without additional co-morbidities. But at this time my struggle with PCa is ongoing and is starting to look like I'm still stuck at first base. But I learn new things every day. Yes, I do grow weary of reading about cancer and people who have cancer and am prone to just shut sown my laptop because I always find myself gravitating back to this forum and a couple others or father Google with some new search idea. BTW I used to watch news all the time, now I rarely ever do. The TV stays off most of the time. I have the complete Seinfeld DVD set, still in shrinkwrap. But then I'm on Lupron, so I spend a lot of time just doing nothing. Part of my research was into anti-depressants, as you probably know, and that has been a big help for me emotionally... considering all that's gone south recently on this end, and I'm not talking about Florida. You have hobbies and see friends. I don't do much of either. We do go out to dinner with others we meet here in our community. Seems everyone here has cancer or has had cancer. But for me I never stop learning about it. And I have to. This coming week marks the one year anniversary of my fusion biopsy. That and the DaVinci a couple months later are I feel the only times that I've been treated properly. We are traveling back to Ohio for the fourth and I made an appointment to see the surgeon who did my RP, and I intend to tell him how I feel. I also hope to get his opinion on the disaster that has been my AUS implant. My introduction to Florida medical care has led me to believe that the patient must be the one with all the medical knowledge because the doctors here don't do anything unless you ask them about it. So I would recommend that you continue to learn as much as you can. I know that you worry about your PSA and given what we have seen here with guys who have a fairly decent profile but end up in BCR anyway, it may only be a matter of time before you find yourself in those shoes... not to be a pessimist, but I've always believed it's better to be prepared rather than being left with your pants down.

Posts.Title: just started radiation

Posts.Content: I had a MRI of the head and neck about a year ago and they put me in this headgear to keep my head motionless and had an angled mirror something like a periscope in front of my eyes so that I was looking down at my feet and out into the room. Also took an Ativan beforehand. I think that was my fourth MRI, but have had many CT's which of course go much faster fortunately. Three just this year, including a brain scan, plus an "octreoscan" radio isotope scan that took 90 minutes in the machine with my arms over my head... twice! My arms were shaking like a leaf by the end of it.

Posts.Title: What Should i Expect

Posts.Content: I know that recent Forum Brothers MikeA and now Brownie have mentioned they are ex-military. This got me wondering just how many other vets are now members of the prostate cancer brotherhood, now that most guys who were draft age in the 1960's are now prime age for prostate cancer. After about six months in the British Isles, I spent the remaining three years living in a bomb shelter on the Czech border in Bavaria. It was among the best times of my life, and the GI bill was instrumental in letting me get my degree. How about you? Anything you care to share?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tybeeman It has been 10 months since my robotic radical prostatectomy. I have had my consistency back since the 3rd month, with just a little leakage, mainly when I drink. Now no problem at all. Have not had an erection yet but I am taking Cialis daily and triple dose twice a week. Last night I woke up with a nocturnal erection. Was wondering if anyone else has experience this and could this be a sign that I will be getting my erections back. It is a long process and I am sure most of you know I am very anxious. Five months ago today for me, and have not had an erection of any kind since before the surgery. At my age I don't worry about it. I am able to work myself to a pelvic orgasm with much effort, but since the Lupron kicked in don't have much urge to do so. My greatest concern is that my RO said he has never seen any improvement in urinary continence after ten months, and I am halfway there now. I am dry all night, but have to get up once or twice to pee, and also do well when siting down. But when standing or walking I leak like a garden hose, going thru 8-12 pads a day pretty consistently. I've weighed them at around a half pound each. I am not even aware that I am leaking, just that the pads get heavy and very wet. My penis sometimes develop a rash from the moisture. My uro has had me in therapy for a couple months now. The therapist wants me to hold the Kegels for fifteen seconds and it just wears me out. Very hard to maintain. I guess the "good" news is I still have another five months before the RO has to proceed with SRT and hopefully I won't be leaking so much by then because it will stop any further improvement in continence.

Posts.Title: 10 months after 2 questions

Posts.Content: If you read my blog (or have otherwise followed our story) then you know that my biopsy and RP were basically a brief roadside stop on the course of our move to Florida, and Lori's cancer was totally unexpected. As it turned out she got excellent care - though it was not without issues. If I had this to do all over again, I would have put the skids on our move and probably setup camp outside the Cleveland Clinic til everything was over with. And why didn't I do that initially, back in 2014? Because I didn't know enough about prostate cancer. In fact, at that point, no one had ever mentioned the word cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TinkerbellRM27 He then said "well he is T2C" but likely "T3B"...well I don't believe either of those are STAGE 4 from what I understand, no? T3B is the "last stop" before stage 4. Believe me, I've been jumping thru hoops for the past year hoping to avoid going over that edge. And I was cT1C before pT3B. Your Uro's stumbling over terminology is inexcusable. Quite possibly this guy's head is so clouded with higher level minutia that he can't be bothered with mundane stuff like scores and staging. Giving him the benefit of the doubt, he may actually be an excellent surgeon but with a frightening, off-putting demeanor. I have encountered this fairly often professionally... engineers with excellent analytical skills who present complex data so concisely that "mere mortals" (or Muggles) seem barely able to comprehend what is before them... and the job ends up going to a blowhard who sounds sweet but has little knowledge of actually getting things done.

Posts.Title: Brachytherapy instead of surgery?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by steve135 Thanks for the info. I just had a second PSA score of .006 on my three month testing. I am now one year on HT I'm guessing Triptorelin is a lot like Lupron and the HT is effectively keeping your PSA down. From NCBI "Triptorelin reduced testosterone concentrations less rapidly, but maintained castration as effectively as leuprolide." I've been on Lupron only, no Casodex for the past year and have never had a PSA test that goes out to three digits. But I do know that my PSA was around 0.03 last year before going thru RT and afterwards it was 0.00 What I don't know is whether or not that .03 was actually .035 and the 0.00 was actually 0.005 ... My Uro said my PSA "may" go up to .01, so if mine were the same as your .006, then it would have been rounded up to .01 My worry now is that from zero there's only one direction for the PSA to go... UP... So a year from now after the Lupron has worn off is when the real story will be told. Everyone says the PSA level post-RT is not as important as the direction. Same goes for your Triptorelin. As long as it's in your system, the actual PSA value will be unreliable. And as long as it is steady there isn't much to worry about, at this time anyway. Also your doc has probably told you the same thing mine did, that it will take a year or so before testosterone recovers, and after that length of time on HT it will probably never reach its pre-HT level.

Posts.Title: Full bladder

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RTS Curious if anyone has an opinion on leftover prostate tissue after surgery causing a psa rise? I just can’t see how with my pathology report that cancer could have gotten out of my prostate. Your post sugery psa of .11 july 2017, two and a half years after RP, qualifies as persistent PSA. I didn't see any other PSA's listed during that time period. Presumably you were indeed tested and just left it out or I just missed it. At .25 this month you are now in the territory of BCR and should be considering salvage radiation. There is a slight possibility that it is from benign prostate tissue left behind, but I would say that is most likely wishful thinking. You should also seriously consider adjuvant hormone therapy. How it escaped is at this point not the real question, but what you will be doing about it, and when. Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KarlEmagne So I'm very likely a candidate for RP at age 53 and am wondering what others on this forum having undergone the procedure, especially with less than ideal outcomes, experienced afterwards in terms of mood swings. Has RP been triggering severely depressive episodes for anyone? I've already had several despite good physical health and am worried I'll be plunging into the next hole soon. I have unfortunately been unable to get help with this in our public health care system despite repeated attempts. The attitude seems to be one of total indifference towards male individuals over 50 who are working and paying taxes. To complicate matters, I had very adverse side effects from an SSRI anti-depressant which I tried decades ago. Advice? Coping strategies? Medications taken? My cancer experience sent me to very dark and unfamiliar place. I'd had no experience whatsoever with emotional or mental health issues in my past, but unfortunately my misdiagnosis occurred at a time in my life already filled with stress and anxiety, including retirement and relocation and following the deaths of several close friends and family members, all within a period of just a few years. I found myself crying all the time and prone to emotional outbursts. My family doctor was no help whatsoever, and my urologist's unwillingness to provide me with any information was most frustrating. Eventually I changed doctors and got the news that my "prostatitis" was actually cancer and it was far worse than had been suspected. And within two months of my prostatectomy we sold our home of 33 years and moved to Florida, where my wife was immediately diagnosed with advanced non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, again within just two months. On top of all that, I never regained urinary continence, was started on Lupron injections (which is another emotional roller coaster in itself) and had to postpone adjuvant radiation while I drove my wife to her chemotherapy treatments. I felt that I had no one in my corner... no one to help me or guide me. Some of the others here on this board may recall what an emotional mess I had become. Fortunately a few encouraged me to "get some help" (if only it were that easy). The radiation oncologist who ordered the Lupron was no help whatsoever... even dismissive of what I was going thru. Eventually thru my own research I learned about venlafaxine or Effexor, an SNRI, and outright asked my GP for a prescription. Suddenly things started to improve. I have now been on it for nearly two years, have had to go up and down in dosage a few times but am fairly certain that I will be taking it for the rest of my life. The emotional stability it has brought far outweighs the side effects. I should also mention the effects of general anesthesia. It sticks with you for a few weeks and can be very depressing... not to mention the stress of surgery and the emotions that go along with it. I am a veteran of over a dozen surgeries and have experienced this every time. Here again the Effexor has kept me from going off the rails when dark thoughts try to re-emerge. There's not a whole lot of joy to be experienced anymore. The SNRI just keeps me from swaying too far from the even keel so to speak. But just knowing this stability plus the positive outcomes of both my cancer and my wife's has brought some peace into my chaotic life. Coping strategies? I have none. I try to just go with the flow. I've had two other "close calls" with cancer since all of this happened. Long stories there. It can be scary, but I seem to be able to handle it all. I can't really help you much but maybe my story will help you feel not so alone in your struggle.

I would guess that it's temporary, but that healing and recovery would probably be slower following RT than it was beforehand... and might take months or even years to recommence. Not a medical opinion, and may just be wishful thinking.

Posts.Content: I'll try to answer you here rather than on that other message board, where so far your thread has zero replies. I know that in the past we have joked about spending too much time in cancer forums. Well, just last night I discovered yet another one (that makes four for me, not counting several I checked out but where I never bothered to register). And I can only speak for my own case, but yours is not so dissimilar. You fear that it may be unhealthy, but for me it is a necessity. We both have a spouse who has also been thru cancer, and in some ways are still going thru it. In my case, it dropped in my lap right in the midst of my own cancer struggle. You have the additional burden of your CAD and I consider myself fortunate to be without additional co-morbidities. But at this time my struggle with PCa is ongoing and is starting to look like I'm still stuck at first base. But I learn new things every day. Yes, I do grow weary of reading about cancer and people who have cancer and am prone to just shut sown my laptop because I always find myself gravitating back to this forum and a couple others or father Google with some new search idea. BTW I used to watch news all the time, now I rarely ever do. The TV stays off most of the time. I have the complete Seinfeld DVD set, still in shrinkwrap. But then I'm on Lupron, so I spend a lot of time just doing nothing. Part of my research was into anti-depressants, as you probably know, and that has been a big help for me emotionally... considering all that's gone south recently on this end, and I'm not talking about Florida. You have hobbies and see friends. I don't do much of either. We do go out to dinner with others we meet here in our community. Seems everyone here has cancer or has had cancer. But for me I never stop learning about it. And I have to. This coming week marks the one year anniversary of my fusion biopsy. That and the DaVinci a couple months later are I feel the only times that I've been treated properly. We are traveling back to Ohio for the fourth and I made an appointment to see the surgeon who did my RP, and I intend to tell him how I feel. I also hope to get his opinion on the disaster that has been my AUS implant. My introduction to Florida medical care has led me to believe that the patient must be the one with all the medical knowledge because the doctors here don't do anything unless you ask them about it. So I would recommend that you continue to learn as much as you can. I know that you worry about your PSA and given what we have seen here with guys who have a fairly decent profile but end up in BCR anyway, it may only be a matter of time before you find yourself in those shoes... not to be a pessimist, but I've always believed it's better to be prepared rather than being left with your pants down.

Posts.Title: With apologies....

Posts.Content: I'll try to answer you here rather than on that other message board, where so far your thread has zero replies. I know that in the past we have joked about spending too much time in cancer forums. Well, just last night I discovered yet another one (that makes four for me, not counting several I checked out but where I never bothered to register). And I can only speak for my own case, but yours is not so dissimilar. You fear that it may be unhealthy, but for me it is a necessity. We both have a spouse who has also been thru cancer, and in some ways are still going thru it. In my case, it dropped in my lap right in the midst of my own cancer struggle. You have the additional burden of your CAD and I consider myself fortunate to be without additional co-morbidities. But at this time my struggle with PCa is ongoing and is starting to look like I'm still stuck at first base. But I learn new things every day. Yes, I do grow weary of reading about cancer and people who have cancer and am prone to just shut sown my laptop because I always find myself gravitating back to this forum and a couple others or father Google with some new search idea. BTW I used to watch news all the time, now I rarely ever do. The TV stays off most of the time. I have the complete Seinfeld DVD set, still in shrinkwrap. But then I'm on Lupron, so I spend a lot of time just doing nothing. Part of my research was into anti-depressants, as you probably know, and that has been a big help for me emotionally... considering all that's gone south recently on this end, and I'm not talking about Florida. You have hobbies and see friends. I don't do much of either. We do go out to dinner with others we meet here in our community. Seems everyone here has cancer or has had cancer. But for me I never stop learning about it. And I have to. This coming week marks the one year anniversary of my fusion biopsy. That and the DaVinci a couple months later are I feel the only times that I've been treated properly. We are traveling back to Ohio for the fourth and I made an appointment to see the surgeon who did my RP, and I intend to tell him how I feel. I also hope to get his opinion on the disaster that has been my AUS implant. My introduction to Florida medical care has led me to believe that the patient must be the one with all the medical knowledge because the doctors here don't do anything unless you ask them about it. So I would recommend that you continue to learn as much as you can. I know that you worry about your PSA and given what we have seen here with guys who have a fairly decent profile but end up in BCR anyway, it may only be a matter of time before you find yourself in those shoes... not to be a pessimist, but I've always believed it's better to be prepared rather than being left with your pants down.

Posts.Title: With apologies....

Posts.Content: One more note regarding Medicare... coverage begins on the 1st day of the month that you turn 65, not on your birthday. Also, yes you should have the ball already rolling on that as it does take as much as 90 days for the paperwork to go thru. Start by establishing an account at SSA.gov if you haven't already.
Posts.Title: New to this Game

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TinkerbellRM27 He then said "well he is T2C" but likely "T3B"...well I don't believe either of those are STAGE 4 from what I understand, no? T3B is the "last stop" before stage 4. Believe me, I've been jumping thru hoops for the past year hoping to avoid going over that edge. And I was cT1C before pT3B. Your Uro's stumbling over terminology is inexcusable. Quite possibly this guy's head is so clouded with higher level minutia that he can't be bothered with mundane stuff like scores and staging. Giving him the benefit of the doubt, he may actually be an excellent surgeon but with a frightening, off-putting demeanor. I have encountered this fairly often professionally... engineers with excellent analytical skills who present complex data so concisely that "mere mortals" (or Muggles) seem barely able to comprehend what is before them... and the job ends up going to a blowhard who sounds sweet but has little knowledge of actually getting things done.

Posts.Title: Brachytherapy instead of surgery?

Posts.Content: Number 5 is the only one I can answer. Locally advanced is stage 3 and means the cancer has escaped the prostate and invaded local tissues, such as seminal vesicles and abdominal wall. Stage 4 is distant metastasis and means it has traveled to remote areas of the body, such as bones and organs. Typically the spine and pelvis are attacked first, then long bones like the femur.

Posts.Title: What Should i Expect

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RTS Curious if anyone has an opinion on leftover prostate tissue after surgery causing a psa rise? I just can’t see how with my pathology report that cancer could have gotten out of my prostate. Your post sugery psa of .11 july 2017, two and a half years after RP, qualifies as persistent PSA. I didn't see any other PSA's listed during that time period. Presumably you were indeed tested and just left it out or I just missed it. At .25 this month you are now in the territory of BCR and should be considering salvage radiation. There is a slight possibility that it is from benign prostate tissue left behind, but I would say that is most likely wishful thinking. You should also seriously consider adjuvant hormone therapy. How it escaped is at this point not the real question, but what you will be doing about it, and when. Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: What Should i Expect

Posts.Content: Red, good luck with the radiation. Do you know what your total dosage will be? I just completed adjuvant RT two weeks ago, and diarrhea started midway thru the second week. I've always had a somewhat sensitive digestive system, but this persisted all the way thru my eight weeks... not always diarrhea, but frequent urgency and still now two weeks later will sometimes have two or three very normal looking bowel movements throughout the day. One very important thing to remember is never trust a fart! ... It was very inconvenient to have to find a toilet whenever I felt the urge to expel (and it seemed to be much more often than previously or since) but keeping that rule probably saved me a few embarrassing situations. The gas was a puzzle. The RO had me on a reduced diet already... no beans, cruciferous veggies or peanut products, no carbonated drinks and no spicy food (easy for me!) and yet had frequent explosive gas. The doctor simply said that 'some bowel disruption is to be expected' but no one even mentioned that this might happen. I ended up severely limiting fruits and veggies... a banana was okay, but no more bowls of blueberries or squash. Around week six I was suddenly hit with tremendous fatigue. It lasted for anther week after Tx ended, but just now getting back to normal. I've been told everything should be back to normal in a few weeks and that the radiation will continue to kill cancer cells for another 8-9 months.

Posts.Title: just started radiation

Posts.Content: Gosh Red, I thought you were asking about suggestions for diarrhea early on during RT. Guess I was just wasting my time.
Posts.Title: just started radiation

Posts.Content: My cancer was a bit more aggressive and my PSA higher. The surgeon asked me beforehand about nerve sparing and I told him that getting all the cancer was more important, but if it were possible without compromising the mission, then by all means do so. My wife was with me and we had to admit that we had not had successful coitus for some time. I lost had a testicle ten years earlier (still looking for where I put that darn thing ). Post op I took longer to regain continence and went ahead with an AUS implant in order to proceed with ART. Also ED has been more or less permanent so far, but I'm sure a big part of that is due to the Lupron. Still not sure what the future will hold, but my surgeon did reaffirm using a 'broad cut' and removed a lot of nerve tissue, but the payoff was negative margins as well as negative nodes. Nerve sparing may be very important for some, but I say keep priorities straight. Dead men have no erections.

Posts.Title: Nerve Sparing Or Not Nerve Sparing That Is The Question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by cindy_hart He began EBRT treatments at the end of January and completed his daily therapy on April 2, 2018. As reported by others on this site he was required to follow a no-gas diet, taking Gas-X multiple times per day and taking a laxative daily. He also had to have a full bladder for the treatment. The daily laxative treatments kept him close to home with frequent and loose bowel movements. Except for the daily treatments, he rarely went out. Having to give up spicy foods, beer and all alcohol were his worst complaints until about week five when he began experiencing the fatigue. He is just now (two weeks post his last treatment) beginning to see an improvement in the fatigue but frequent and loose bowels (with very little warning) continue even without the daily laxative. He is now almost two weeks post treatment and is wondering how long this will last or if it will ever go away. I'm trying to get some anecdotal information for him. While I realize post side effects will vary from person to person, it might help him to know that it won't last forever. Is anyone willing to share if they had this post treatment side effect and how long it lasted? Any responses will be greatly appreciated. Thank you! Yes, I experienced considerable bowel disruption during IMRT/EBRT which still persists to some extend today, six months after the end of treatment. I was not required to take a laxative and when I asked my RO about Gas-X he said that simethicone would be ineffective and Beano would be preferred (I ended up using neither one). Starting midway thru the second week I began to experience frequent urgency and occasional diarrhea, the latter at least 2-3 days a week and the urgency most days, including explosive gas. I wrote about this in the EBRT sticky on the main page of this forum. I think it was around page 10, but could be wrong. It should be easy to find. Most guys say they had no side effects from radiation Tx but it certainly walloped me. I was due for a colonoscopy last year before starting radiation, but because I had so much else going on it was cancelled and rescheduled several times, but eventually postponed until after radiation. Friday I finally get that colonoscopy (start the prep tomorrow), and I am somewhat apprehensive about what the gastroenterologist might find in there as far as radiation damage. I have never had any sort of bowel problems and am typically quite regular... two cups of coffee and five minutes on the throne and I'm done for the day. But ever since the pelvic radiation I often have 2-3 BM's per day, and many mornings a foot long (sorry for the details). The colonoscopy would have required three months of healing before starting RT and after RT I had to wait six months before getting the colo, so it will be good to finally have this out of the way. Whether or not my doctor may find something that might explain the continued SE's and whether or not this condition will continue or may improve with time is something I really don't know. Everything I did for the first year following my surgery was in preparation for starting adjuvant radiation, and it seemed like everything was getting in my way. Good luck to your husband for continued improvement. Hopefully I have not discouraged either of you.

Posts.Title: Post EBRT side effects

Posts.Content: I had a MRI of the head and neck about a year ago and they put me in this headgear to keep my head motionless and had an angled mirror something like a periscope in front of my eyes so that I was looking down at my feet and out into the room. Also took an Ativan beforehand. I think that was my fourth MRI, but have had many CT's which of course go much faster fortunately. Three just this year, including a brain scan, plus an "octreoscan" radio isotope scan that took 90 minutes in the machine with my arms over my head... twice! My arms were shaking like a leaf by the end of it.

Posts.Content: One more note regarding Medicare... coverage begins on the 1st day of the month that you turn 65, not on your birthday. Also, yes you should have the ball already rolling on that as it does take as much as 90 days for the paperwork to go thru. Start by establishing an account at SSA.gov if you haven't already.

Posts.Title: What Should i Expect

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Denver Colorado I'm 64 with T2a. Gleason left - 6(3+3) in 2/6 cores 10%, right - 7(4+3) in 4/7 cores 10% ... PSA scores 12.83 on 6/1/17 14.42 on 6/8/17 16.9 on 7/13/17 ... I turn 65 in October so I can move into the Medicare and supplemental insurance group in a couple of months. Your indecision is understandable. I've edited your PSA's to make them tabular for perspective. Also the G7(4+3) is the one you need to be concerned about. Since your biopsy was only last month, you would need to wait until next month (August) at the earliest if you were to elect surgery... which at your age, I would recommend assuming you enjoy overall good health other then the PCa. You can expect to live into your 80's and you don't want a half-baked prostate remaining in there (okay, I know I'll hear form others on that one!) Your PSA is rising, but that can be arrested and even reduced by going on ADT, which might even be necessitated if any of that grade 4 tumor has escaped the prostate. You will need the entire pathology report and even then there could still be surprises waiting for you once they remove your prostate. It happens fairly often. So basically you're looking at a potential delay from August til October in order to have complete freedom to have whatever you want, wherever you want fully paid by Medicare plus your choice of supplemental insurance (unless you get locked into an "advantage" plan, which after being with Kaiser, you are probably wise enough to avoid). Bottom line, wait for 65, ask about whether or not ADT might be a good idea, then go for the surgery. Often in cases where the Gleason is higher than (3+4) radiation + ADT becomes necessary after surgery anyway. Some may say that is a reason for just going with primary RT in the first place, to which I can only say be sure to evaluate all of your alternatives.

Posts.Title: What Should i Expect

Posts.Content: My cancer was a bit more aggressive and my PSA higher. The surgeon asked me beforehand about nerve sparing and I told him that getting all the cancer was more important, but if it were possible without compromising the mission, then by all means do so. My wife was with me and we had to admit that we had not had successful coitus for some time. I lost had a testicle ten years earlier (still looking for where I put that darn thing ). Post op I took longer to regain continence and went ahead with an AUS implant in order to proceed with ART. Also ED has been more or less permanent so far, but I'm sure a big part of that is due to the Lupron. Still not sure what the future will hold, but my surgeon did reaffirm using a 'broad cut' and removed a lot of nerve tissue, but the payoff was negative margins as well as negative nodes. Nerve sparing may be very important for some, but I say keep priorities straight. Dead men have no erections.

Posts.Title: New to this Game

Posts.Content: The first Sunday in June is National Cancer Survivor's Day. Anyone who has or has had cancer and is still living is a survivor. If you go to the NCSD Facebook page it becomes apparent that only women get cancer, or at least only women survive cancer... or so that is the impression one would get from their FB page. Every photo is of women. One photo shows half of one man's face (fortunately he is NOT wearing pink, for Pete's sake). In a recent thread on that other forum site a number of guys vented on the discrepancies in how men and women with cancer are treated. I have posted about it here on CFN and ended up deleting the post. I know everyone loves boobs and make jokes about prostates (or refer to them as 'prostrates') but come on there is more than one type of cancer. Even my wife gets fed up with how many people assume that she had breast cancer. Isn't it time for the world to come to the realization that both genders can be cancer victims - and survivors?

Posts.Title: Happy National Cancer Survivor's Day!

Posts.Content: Much of your decision making will depend on your father's general health. At 69 he is right on the cusp of the surgery/no surgery dividing line. If he is expected to live more than 20 years (if his family has a history of living into their nineties) then you should perhaps be concerned about the long term effects of radiation. Of course, those who chose rad recently will say they have not concerns (they are still fairly young). Surgery of course has consequences. He's probably not concerned about ED, but incontinence can be a definite life changer. The doctors and facilities you have chosen are all excellent. With a dominant grade 4 his cancer is aggressive, but the HT will keep it in check for a while. I do not know which order you plan to see the RO's and the Moffitt team, nor do I know which order I would recommend. Depends on which tests he has already had and when they were, and whether any retests would reflect progression or regression. Focus your questions on optimum and worst case timelines, possible outcomes of treatments and likelihood of success, and if not, overall survivability and quality of life.

Posts.Title: Ugh, but not overly concerned

Posts.Content: Gleason score of 6 is moderate... some may say he is a candidate for non-surgical treatment. Also he is relatively young, unless there are other medical conditions (diabetes etc). Off hand I would say his outlook should be good... but sometimes the Gleason may later be elevated if the prostate is removed and evaluated in dissection. His PSA is startlingly high, but could be caused by other factors. I'd guess if there is any metastasis that it would be from another source. Typically bone scans and possibly an MRI will be conducted. (My wife just went thru a spinal tumor, which was originally believed to be a back strain so I'm a little scared when people mention metastasis... I am not a medical pro so take what I say here with a small grain of salt). Good luck to you and your father!

Posts.Title: Starting off the new year with my father's new diagnosis :-(

Posts.Content: Fin - As Chuck mentioned above PNI is cancerous invasion of the nerves INSIDE THE PROSTATE... It just means that as the tumor grew within the prostate it also grew into the nerve tissue that is in there. Almost everyone has PNI. Another "scary" term some people have is "High Grade PIN" which sends men and their spouses into a tailspin, "OMG I have High Grade PIN"... but it really does not affect the outcome. What's more, your only grade 4 component was secondary and probably small in volume. Grade 4 is the kind of cancer that can escape the prostate and spread. As some background, the prostate is full of nerve tissue but with very little blood supply. That's why the first line of attack is rarely if ever chemo, because the chemo would not reach the tumor. Furthermore your tumors were in the lateral lobes, not near the base which might involve the bladder, and not near the apex, where positive margins are more likely to occur. Also your lymph nodes were all negative, which is no guarantee, but is definitely to your benefit. All in all I would say, DON'T WORRY. Most likely this was nipped in the bud. Many guys would trade anything to have a pathology report like yours. Enjoy your freedom. And congratulations on having excellent continence so far!

Posts.Content: You still have a long way to go before your PSA would reach alarming levels. Mine shot up from 4 to 9 in just one year, and continued to multiply. I did the Cipro thing for several years before it started to look more like cancer than prostatitis. I'd say you have a good chance this is just prostatitis or perhaps an infection, and not cancer. Good luck

Posts.Title: Comparison of operative and margin outcomes from surgeon learning curves in RARP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I think you're pretty spot on, Prato. Chuck, that was Jim, not Prato. I know we all start looking alike after a while Don't fret.. just ribbing you. I know you are a VERY busy man.
Posts.Title: Ugh, but not overly concerned

Posts.Content: Surgery is often chosen by those who are on the younger side and in generally good health, with less aggressive PCa (lower Gleason scores), where radiation tends to be chosen by older men who may have a problem with surgery, such as other health problems. Each case is different and there are ARDENT supporters and haters of both surgery and radiation. If you were twenty years older then either radiation or simply doing nothing would be an obvious choice. Side effects from surgery generally are experienced right away and improve over time. SE's from radiation often do not appear until years later. The main advantage of surgery is that the doctor actually examines the prostate and surrounding tissues. Radiation is administered based on external scans, which I call "shooting in the dark". I had a more aggressive prostate cancer, had surgery followed by radiation a year later. I have suffered what are probably the worst side effects of both, but if I could go back I would not change my choice. I'm assuming you had R-CHOP for your NHL. Be aware that in the case of PCa, chemo is generally reserved for advanced metastatic PCa and is in effect one of the "last resort" treatments. Good luck in what comes. Be sure that you speak with or correspond with several older men who had radiation ten years or so ago before choosing. Opponents of surgery usually speak of the "advances" in radiation over the past decade, but still there are NO men who survived twenty or more years after having had radiation within the past ten years. That's just my way of saying there is little to go by in the way of a track record.

Posts.Title: Just got the bad news....40 years old

Posts.Content: Good news is yours are all 3+4, which is better than 4+3. (3+3 is often a case of "maybe" treat, maybe not... though at your age, probably treat). Bad news is you have a lot of positive cores, but all on the left side, so I'm guessing the right side was negative. Looks like the higher concentrations are lateral and less medial. I'm not sure what that means. Also I don't know how to interpret the Partin tables. BTW the difference between 3+4 and 4+3 is the first number is the "dominant" pathology or most pervasive, the second number is the grade found to be less common.

Posts.Title: Ugh, but not overly concerned

Posts.Content: Keith - I agree that you should TRY to get your surgery moved up a few weeks. It COULD make a difference. Chuck mentioned the veteran's choice program. I don't know if your case would be eligible for outside treatment. I too was 4+4 and understood that I had to wait eight weeks after the biopsy before having the surgery. It turned out that the cancer had progressed beyond what the MRI had shown, which led to additional treatments that lasted basically for two years. I will never know how much it had progressed during those two months, but chances are it was already outside of the prostate and well on its way. But at present it appears that I beat the cancer by throwing everything available at it. Congratulations on defeating your CLL. I lost my brother eight years ago to complications from treatment for CLL.

Posts.Title: Orgasms after surgery?

Posts.Content: Thanks... this is all very reassuring, as I too did not have nerve sparing. Currently I am mostly concerned about incontinence, but I have heard that 8 weeks is typical and up to as much as a full year. So far, I have not had any interest in sex.... just no interest there. That alone seems strange to me. But my wife and I have not had traditional coitus for several years. The PCa made orgasms painful and I basically "took things into my own hands" about once a month just to keep from going crazy. Posts.Title: In U.S. 11% of payers cover MRI in biopsy-naive patients; rest require a neg. biopsy

Posts.Content: Gleason score of 6 is moderate... some may say he is a candidate for non-surgical treatment. Also he is relatively young, unless there are other medical conditions (diabetes etc). Off hand I would say his outlook should be good... but sometimes the Gleason may later be elevated if the prostate is removed and evaluated in dissection. His PSA is startlingly high, but could be caused by other factors. I'd guess if there is any metastasis that it would be from another source. Typically bone scans and possibly an MRI will be conducted. (My wife just went thru a spinal tumor, which was originally believed to be a back strain so I'm a little scared when people mention metastasis... I am not a medical pro so take what I say here with a small grain of salt). Good luck to you and your father!

I live in one where the doctors assume the patient is comfortable being poked and prodded, but they don't want him to be awake when it happens.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ubetternoit Had prostate surgery and bladder doesn't empty all the way just a little at a time and I was thinking of the Advance Male Sling for incontinence. Does anyone know if that be dangerous seeing that I have to put a catheter in again with the procedure? Has your urologist recommended the sling for you? It would likely do nothing for your retention problem. It sounds like something else, perhaps nerve damage from the surgery. I too started having a problem with incomplete voiding starting just this past summer, mentioned it to my uro who pretty much dismissed it and I didn't pursue it due to having more pressing matters... But I will certainly bring it up again at my next checkup. As far as "how soon" you can have a cath, I had a Foley for several weeks in 2017, a year after RP, and for a couple of days just last week for another surgery. There should not be any problem for you if you need to have one put in.

Posts.Title: Orgasms after surgery?

Posts.Content: Keith - I agree that you should TRY to get your surgery moved up a few weeks. It COULD make a difference. Chuck mentioned the veteran's choice program. I don't know if your case would be eligible for outside treatment. I too was 4+4 and understood that I had to wait eight weeks after the biopsy before having the surgery. It turned out that the cancer had progressed beyond what the MRI had shown, which led to additional treatments that lasted basically for two years. I will never know how much it had progressed during those two months, but chances are it was already outside of the prostate and well on its way. But at present it appears that I beat the cancer by throwing everything available at it. Congratulations on defeating your CLL. I lost my brother eight years ago to complications from treatment for CLL.

Posts.Title: PSA INCREASE 2.8 in one year. Doc not alarmed.

Posts.Content: Presumably the 'laser' is HIFU or something like it, which is focused on individual tumors. The problem with PCa is it's like cockroaches... if you see one, you probably have many. You should probably avoid focused ablation and limit your treatment to surgery or 'some form' of radiation. Since you have a grade 4 component in your biopsy you should act within a matter of months. This would put you out of eligibility for active surveillance. Surgery has a long track record of success and has the advantage of removing the gland entirely, where it can be analyzed in a pathology lab. In many cases a 3+4 is upstaged to 4+3 or even worse. There is a strong possibility of genitourinary side effects. Six months or so of incontinence is typical but usually heals entirely within a year with few complications. ED is more common. For men in their sixties, that's usually not a big deal. For radiation, eight weeks of intensity modulated external beam radiation is the traditional standard treatment. There are possible late term side effects which may appear years later due to radiation toxicity. IMRT is administered based on external scans. There are some strong vocal advocates of RT over surgery. Newer forms of radiation seek to reduce the length of time and number of treatments required. HDRBT is one that looks promising but as with many of the newer forms of treatment, there is not a very long track record to go by. Your choice depends on your willingness to accept risks. Many on this message board chose surgery in order to "be done with it." In some of those cases, adjuvant or salvage radiation plus possible hormone therapy following surgery may be necessary, typically those with Gleason 8 or those who were upstaged from G7 based on the pathology results discovered during surgery. Welcome to the board, and sorry you have to be here, but the people here know a lot because we've been thru it ourselves. Good luck going forward!

Posts.Title: Trying to make decision.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nhlsir54 Yes I did R-CHOP... I thought having been through this that I would be prepared for the psychological part, but that has not been the case. I do know I had several people tell me not to do chemo. That it would kill me, not the cancer. I am trying to do as much research as possible but then it gets to be too much and I get discouraged. I also know from previous cancer how important a positive outlook is, and I believe you can make yourself sicker by your thoughts. I have learned a lot from time spent on this forum. I guess we are all scared of the unknown. Hi Jeff, I'm sorry that you have to go thru this again, but you have your head on straight and your wife is on board with you, so you are already way ahead of most others going into this. A good sense of humor, a good support network, and the self confidence of having previously survived another cancer will all make your journey thru prostate cancer much easier. As others have noted, yours is currently a rather innocuous form of PCa, and you certainly do have time to wait and see if it progresses any further. I know that once you've had cancer, anything that hurts sends your mind into the "is it coming back" tailspin. So the best I can say at this point is, don't worry too much about it. But beware of taking it too lightly. My Urologist kept me in the dark for several years, during which time my cancer progressed to the point where it became "very high risk" and required multiple follow up procedures over the past eighteen months. In a significant number of cases, once the prostate has been removed and examined in the pathology lab, additional tumors are found, and in some cases worse or much worse. Fortunately your PSA is relatively low, though a bit on the high side given your age. BTW my wife was diagnosed with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma one year ago just before Christmas. It was a crazy time for us both, and very stressful for me as this happened right in the midst of my own cancer treatment. Additionally I became very concerned while she underwent R-CHOP as she started watching toxic online videos about how (as you mentioned) chemo would kill her rather than the cancer. We are both still bombarded by anecdotal tales of miracle cures and how we not only caused our own cancers by eating wrong, but can cured be by eating differently. In the end, she also required only six of eight infusions, plus - as she had spinal tumors, also had a radiation boost and needed spinal injections following each infusion. If you have the time you may want to read our blog linked at the bottom of my sig, or at least the first and last chapters. Yes, you can drive yourself nuts doing TOO much online research. Both my wife and I have really had to dial it back lately. If anything, our cancers have brought my wife and I even closer than ever. You are very fortunate to have a head start on your PCa and a very understanding wife. You are a champ for what you have been thru already and I'm sure you will breeze thru this one with flying colors. Good luck!

Posts.Title: New prostate cancer diagnosis for lymphoma survivor

Posts.Content: Good news is yours are all 3+4, which is better than 4+3. (3+3 is often a case of "maybe" treat, maybe not... though at your age, probably treat). Bad news is you have a lot of positive cores, but all on the left side, so I'm guessing the right side was negative. Looks like the higher concentrations are lateral and less medial. I'm not sure what that means. Also I don't know how to interpret the Partin tables. BTW the difference between 3+4 and 4+3 is the first number is the "dominant" pathology or most pervasive, the second number is the grade found to be less common.

Posts.Title: Just got the bad news....40 years old

Posts.Content: Keith - I agree that you should TRY to get your surgery moved up a few weeks. It COULD make a difference. Chuck mentioned the veteran's choice program. I don't know if your case would be eligible for outside treatment. I too was 4+4 and understood that I had to wait eight weeks after the biopsy before having the surgery. It turned out that the cancer had progressed beyond what the MRI had shown, which led to additional treatments that lasted basically for two years. I will never know how much it had progressed during those two months, but chances are it was already outside of the prostate and well on its way. But at present it appears that I beat the cancer by throwing everything available at it. Congratulations on defeating your CLL. I lost my brother eight years ago to complications from treatment for CLL.
