Posts.Title: Just got the bad news....40 years old

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by redbelly7 I've just about had enough of the emotions. I'm sure it's the Lupron... I think I'm ready for something to help and would like suggestions from you guys. Xanax? I'm not much on these types of Rx's, but need relief. My emotional rollercoaster started after the first negative biopsy. I suspect the cancer itself was affecting my hormones, but my emotions were definitely a mess. The Lupron only exacerbated conditions. In addition to the hot flashes and night sweats I was extremely volatile... not violent, but explosive and fits of anxiety followed by brooding and extended crying spells. I read in this and other forums that some guys were taking Venlafaxine for the hot flashes and it also helped with the moodiness. I hinted to my RO about the problem but he was no help. Finally I asked my GP for Venlafaxine, which is the generic name for the antidepressant Effexor. I have never taken anything like this before... no Valium or Prozac, nothing. I started the Effexor a little over a year ago and it has made a tremendous difference. I've had to make some adjustments but now I couldn't imagine life without it. Xanax probably wouldn't do much for you, though it might help to settle down some of the hyperness caused by your prednisone. I do also have some Ativan (wiich is similar) for the tight chest, can't breathe, Alien chest burster feeling I still get sometimes when I get worked up, usually when talking about how screwed up my PCa treatment had been, but TBH what the Ativan does is make me very sleepy much earlier than usual and I sleep thru movies or miss our favorite TV shows. Xanax and Ativan can be habit forming so I use that only very rarely, but the Effexor must be taken every day. Once I was sick for a day and couldn't take it and started having withdrawal symptoms, so once you start taking it you're stuck with it for a while and it must eventually be tapered off. But it really has helped. It took a while to start working as it should, but has made me a much more pleasant person to be around.

Posts.Title: Just got the bad news....40 years old

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nhlsir54 Yes I did R-CHOP... I thought having been through this that I would be prepared for the psychological part, but that has not been the case. I do know I had several people tell me not to do chemo. That it would kill me, not the cancer. I am trying to do as much research as possible but then it gets to be too much and I get discouraged. I also know from previous cancer how important a positive outlook is, and I believe you can make yourself sicker by your thoughts. I have learned a lot from time spent on this forum. I guess we are all scared of the unknown. Hi Jeff, I'm sorry that you have to go thru this again, but you have your head on straight and your wife is on board with you, so you are already way ahead of most others going into this. A good sense of humor, a good support network, and the self confidence of having previously survived another cancer will all make your journey thru prostate cancer much easier. As others have noted, yours is currently a rather innocuous form of PCa, and you certainly do have time to wait and see if it progresses any further. I know that once you've had cancer, anything that hurts sends your mind into the "is it coming back" tailspin. So the best I can say at this point is, don't worry too much about it. But beware of taking it too lightly. My Urologist kept me in the dark for several years, during which time my cancer progressed to the point where it became "very high risk" and required multiple follow up procedures over the past eighteen months. In a significant number of cases, once the prostate has been removed and examined in the pathology lab, additional tumors are found, and in some cases worse or much worse. Fortunately your PSA is relatively low, though a bit on the high side given your age. BTW my wife was diagnosed with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma one year ago just before Christmas. It was a crazy time for us both, and very stressful for me as this happened right in the midst of my own cancer treatment. Additionally I became very concerned while she underwent R-CHOP as she started watching toxic online videos about how (as you mentioned) chemo would kill her rather than the cancer. We are both still bombarded by anecdotal tales of miracle cures and how we not only caused our own cancers by eating wrong, but can cured be by eating differently. In the end, she also required only six of eight infusions, plus - as she had spinal tumors, also had a radiation boost and needed spinal injections following each infusion. If you have the time you may want to read our blog linked at the bottom of my sig, or at least the first and last chapters. Yes, you can drive yourself nuts doing TOO much online research. Both my wife and I have really had to dial it back lately. If anything, our cancers have brought my wife and I even closer than ever. You are very fortunate to have a head start on your PCa and a very understanding wife. You are a champ for what you have been thru already and I'm sure you will breeze thru this one with flying colors. Good luck!

Posts.Title: New prostate cancer diagnosis for lymphoma survivor

Posts.Content: Do not despair. I was G8 also, but with six positive cores - two of them 100%, and my PSA was 25, five months before surgery. Currently there is no evidence of disease, though I cannot be sure until after the HT has worn off in a couple of years. It has been a struggle, but it can be beaten. The scans will not eliminate the possibility of spread, as they are not that sensitive. But they will pick up if your case is seriously advanced. But I believe you are probably safe. Good luck with your path results.

Posts.Title: How Bad is 9-10 has now some very discouraging results.

Posts.Content: Keto, you are now right on the precipice of metastasis. The next step after stage 3B is stage 4, distant metastasis. As you know, stage 3B means that the cancer has spread outside the prostate and their first stop is the seminal vesicles. This is referred to as "locally advanced". From the SV's, the cancer cells typically travel into the lymphatic system and spread to distant areas of the body, or they grow into the nearby pelvic bones, spine and thigh bones. At that point there is basically no treatment to halt the cancer's progress into vital organs and eventual death. Hormone therapy (ADT) does not kill cancer cells. It deprives the cancer of the testosterone that it feeds on and slows it's growth. Additionally it weakens the cancer and makes it more susceptible to cell death by radiation. Radiation kills cancer cells. HT does not. It just keeps it from growing. Once cancer has left the prostate bed and begun to spread into other areas of the body, the only treatment is cytoxic chemotherapy. As I understand it, it's the worst. And again, it does not stop the cancer, but just slows it down. Basically, if you are stage T3B and do not proceed with salvage or adjuvant radiation, your cancer will likely continue to grow. It is not a certainty, but is highly likely. I just recently finished radiation, had prostatectomy sixteen months ago and have been on HT for a year. I was one of the lucky ones. My latest PSA came back at 0.00, primarily due to my two months of daily radiation. Radiation is the only treatment that actually kills prostate cancer cells, as far as I know. The prospect of eventually developing bone metastasis really, really scared me. I think that you should throw every treatment possible at your cancer. Beat it while it's down, and knock it out for good.

Posts.Title: Bone metastasis

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Your original (well-intended, innocent) statement did state "non-aggressive". That's where the challenge came from. Now that I go back and read what I just posted, I probably did overdo the whole "innocent" thing. Overly dramatic. Damn... wish I wasn't such a gurl. And I really wasn't thinking "non-aggressive" as a type of cancer, just early stage. I'm not very good with terminology. Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 when did your cancer become metastatic? In all your previous posts, u list yourself as pT3b NO? True, a G8 is aggressive... And it looks like I did the same thing with metastatic. I mean it has spread. I thought that's what it meant. Again, my bad. Foot in mouth. Guess I should keep a medical dictionary at hand when I post. Or just become a lurker. Or stick to talking about incontinence... that's something I'm getting to know very well. Again, sorry, no ill will intended. I really do appreciate the interaction with everyone here, but the last few days it seems there must be a disturbance in the force or something. I will try to avoid throwing around words I don't really know the exact meaning of (of which I do not know the exact meaning?)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic What I find of great interest is their use of 0.03ng/ml ( measured about 3 months post RP) as a prognostically useful demarcation of biochemical persistence (BCP). .... [*]Those with G7, intermediate and high-risk PCa, especially with adverse path-report findings, would do well to request a uPSA at about 100 days RP if their initial 6-8 week values is the "standard <0.1" (as mine was). If your PSA is at a later time found to be going up, it may be useful to know just what your nadir value was and when it occurred, and whether there was biochemical persistence from the outset. This could help in treatment decisions regarding ART and SRT. This is also in line with the advice brothers have been getting from ROs about using values of 0.1 or lower as a threshold for starting RT. BTW, based on the detection rate of positive lymph nodes in the above study, I wonder how many guys with LN- on their RP path report are harboring micro-lesions in a LN left behind. It may be that the regional positive nodes that are detected after BCR actually began before, and not after, the RP. Interesting notes and thank you for your usual extensive research and interpretation Djin. I had mentioned the .03 threshold in a recent post, and I guess I am vindicated seeing it again here. My initial post-RP PSA was (like yours) declared undetectable at <.1 ... and from there went to .02, .03, so who knows if there was actually a nadir. Your final remark might actually be a bit disturbing. After what I experienced from 2012 to 2016 I don't even want to read what the USPSTF now has to say.

Posts.Title: Muscle spasms

Posts.Content: Surgery is often chosen by those who are on the younger side and in generally good health, with less aggressive PCa (lower Gleason scores), where radiation tends to be chosen by older men who may have a problem with surgery, such as other health problems. Each case is different and there are ARDENT supporters and haters of both surgery and radiation. If you were twenty years older then either radiation or simply doing nothing would be an obvious choice. Side effects from surgery generally are experienced right away and improve over time. SE's from radiation often do not appear until years later. The main advantage of surgery is that the doctor actually examines the prostate and surrounding tissues. Radiation is administered based on external scans, which I call "shooting in the dark". I had a more aggressive prostate cancer, had surgery followed by radiation a year later. I have suffered what are probably the worst side effects of both, but if I could go back I would not change my choice. I'm assuming you had R-CHOP for your NHL. Be aware that in the case of PCa, chemo is generally reserved for advanced metastatic PCa and is in effect one of the "last resort" treatments. Good luck in what comes. Be sure that you speak with or correspond with several older men who had radiation ten years or so ago before choosing. Opponents of surgery usually speak of the "advances" in radiation over the past decade, but still there are NO men who survived twenty or more years after having had radiation within the past ten years. That's just my way of saying there is little to go by in the way of a track record.

Posts.Title: New prostate cancer diagnosis for lymphoma survivor

Posts.Content: Recently I made a simple remark regarding HT in another thread. Then another user asked that I cite "specific research" to support my statement. But since my remark was based only on personal experience, I have no such research. And since I do not wish to further hijack the original thread I will continue the story here in a new thread. It is a long story which I still do not fully understand. Several years ago it was discovered that my PSA had jumped from 4 to 9. DRE's were negative as was the first biopsy, but the PSA continued to rise. When I asked the doctor what was next he said another biopsy. I asked "and if that is also negative then what" and he said medicine. I asked what kind of medicine and he said a series of injections to lower my PSA. Although there was no mention of hormones in general or ADT in particular, in retrospect it now sounds to me a lot like HT. From that experience I was under the impression that HT could possibly be used as a first line of defense. Jump to the present. The second biopsy revealed what was characterized as aggressive prostate cancer, and the choices I was given were surgery or radiation and possibly both. Last Friday night, a newbie posted a couple questions as he was facing his first biopsy. I replied with a paragraph about my biopsy and added a couple lines that he may face surgery or radiation, and that some cancers can be treated with hormone injections. Again, all based solely on assumptions from my own personal experiences. So the next morning, this other user states that he has consulted with top experts and had never heard of such a thing. He seemed to be demanding that I cite references to back up my claim. I felt like a school kid being told to "show your work". Now please realize that I am a simple man who has been thrown into this whole PCa thing seemingly over night. I reacted emotionally. I certainly have no research behind my innocent comment, only supposition. But what he then said seemed to contradict my only experience. He said that HT is used only to treat advanced cancer that is beyond surgery or radiation... if I am recalling this correctly, that it is essentially the last line of defense. But I had been told by my Uro that my early cancer could have been treated with a series of injections before it was discovered to be both aggressive and metastatic, but now it can only be treated with a combination of both surgery and radiation. I have since apologized to the other poster by PM. I have also read thru the HT sticky and found that many there have had HT following surgery and/or radiation to lower their PSA. I am aware of the drastic side effects of HT and do not intend to diminish that. I also realize that since my post op PSA so far is undetectable, HT would not be of any benefit at this stage. As much as I just want to put this whole thing behind me, I am curious and need to ask those in the know... is HT only for end stage PC which cannot be treated by surgery or radiation, or can it also be used in the early stages of cancer prior to surgery or RT? Or is it something else? Thanks for any input. My story is even longer but I've tried to keep it relatively short here. Please forgive my naivety if I may have unwittingly stepped on any toes.

Posts.Title: New prostate cancer diagnosis for lymphoma survivor

Posts.Content: I noticed the common Tewari link as well. As mentioned in other threads, it's usually the top surgeons who get the most difficult cases. Not that these cases appeared to be all that complicated at the outset... But I have noticed, reading various forums, that it seems to be the guys who had a good prognosis going in who seem to be more likely to develop BR some years later. And as I've mentioned elsewhere, I (and guys like me) had the advantage going into treatment that I was high risk with known adverse pathology and would require further treatment. I didn't know what all would be involved, but all the docs agreed that surgery would most likely be the beginning rather than the end of my treatments. Originally Posted by Another I picked surgery so I have the opportunity of treating recurrence with radiation. Yuppers. The fact that surgery left me impotent and incontinent are but minor casualties in the battle against a potentially devastating disease. On that other forum, guys are often asked "why surgery? why not just go straight with primary radiation? Go Brachy! Go HDR! Rah rah proton and SBRT!" Why, is because I plan to live another ten or twenty years, and already have enough bowel and bladder problems. I have a friend fifteen years my senior who had RP+RT when he was my age and his PSA is zero. He hit it with everything possible, and I am doing the same. If doc tells me someday that I need chemo, then I'm doing chemo. No hesitation.

Posts.Title: Observation, Statistics, Coincidences?

Posts.Content: You will need a pack of urinary shields (Depends or similar) as you will be incontinent for several months. Stool softener... you will likely be plugged up for a few days after surgery. Some polysporin antibiotic ointment to dab around the tip of your penis to keep the catheter moist or it will irritate the skin. Many guys used a bucket by the bedside to hold the urinary discharge bag overnight... a trash can will work, but you can use the bucket handle during the day to carry around the bag. Stock up on drinks and snacks as you won't feel like going out for a while. There's probably more, but that's all I can think of right now. Good luck with your procedure and your recovery!

Posts.Title: Is HT possible in early stage?

Posts.Content: Okay, I just googled cancer stages and found the TMB scale, and I see that stage 4 is called distant metastasis (thank goodness for spell check... I misspell it every time). Stage 3 is "spread to local tissues". That's what I have, and I did not intend to make it anything more than that. Not to throw out the newbie thing again, but I have pretty much had to figure this stuff out myself. I had the original pathology report from the biopsy that had the percents and cores, but after that I've been on my own to find out what I can. It has been just five months since my first diagnosis. Then just before we moved (the last time I saw my Urologist) he mentioned that I will need radiation in six months because the cancer had spread into both seminal vesicles and I am T3B. I added the N0 myself after reading up on SVI. That's when I learned that means I have an 80% chance of surviving ten years. I try to not let that get me down... that's a one in five chance of never seeing 75. Okay, I'm getting dramatic again. Anyway, the whole HT thing came about because all the time that my previous Urologist was watchfully waiting or whatever, the cancer was growing inside me, and I am more than just a little pissed about that. Hopefully I haven't said "too much" once again... like Trump's midnight tweets.
Posts.Title: Is HT possible in early stage?

Posts.Content: Thanks MM... the "clinical" is the only piece of paper I have, or had. When we moved to Florida a lot of papers got stashed in boxes or shredded and heaven only knows WHERE they might be today. But my Uro did tell me lymph nodes and margins were clear, but was concerned that both SV were affected (there was supposed to be more lab analysis on that but that fell by the wayside). All that from the post-op pathology is pretty much what's in my sig. Then the last thing he said was about the radiation because I am T2B. You know how quickly time flies during a Dr appointment. I just found a new Uro here in Fla but he did not have my records yet. There's so much going on with my family and other stresses that I don't even want to get into that. But I think everyone here has stuff like that on their shoulders. That's life. I do consider myself more fortunate than many others here on the board and that is a blessing. EDIT: This is the most informative article I've read on SVI. It's from 2011. Again, I do not know HOW extensive the SVI is... maybe when my new Uro gets my records. http://myprostatedoc.blogspot.com/20...g-seminal.html
Posts.Title: Is HT possible in early stage?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Your original (well-intended, innocent) statement did state "non-aggressive". That's where the challenge came from. Now that I go back and read what I just posted, I probably did overdo the whole "innocent" thing. Overly dramatic. Damn... wish I wasn't such a gurl. And I really wasn't thinking "non-aggressive" as a type of cancer, just early stage. I'm not very good with terminology. Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 when did your cancer become metastatic? In all your previous posts, u list yourself as pT3b NO? True, a G8 is aggressive... And it looks like I did the same thing with metastatic. I mean it has spread. I thought that's what it meant. Again, my bad. Foot in mouth. Guess I should keep a medical dictionary at hand when I post. Or just become a lurker. Or stick to talking about incontinence... that's something I'm getting to know very well. Again, sorry, no ill will intended. I really do appreciate the interaction with everyone here, but the last few days it seems there must be a disturbance in the force or something. I will try to avoid throwing around words I don't really know the exact meaning of (of which I do not know the exact meaning?)

Posts.Title: Is HT possible in early stage?

Posts.Content: Thanks MM... the "clinical" is the only piece of paper I have, or had. When we moved to Florida a lot of papers got stashed in boxes or shredded and heaven only knows WHERE they might be today. But my Uro did tell me lymph nodes and margins were clear, but was concerned that both SV were affected (there was supposed to be more lab analysis on that but that fell by the wayside). All that from the post-op pathology is pretty much what's in my sig. Then the last thing he said was about the radiation because I am T2B. You know how quickly time flies during a Dr appointment. I just found a new Uro here in Fla but he did not have my records yet. There's so much going on with my family and other stresses that I don't even want to get into that. But I think everyone here has stuff like that on their shoulders. That's life. I do consider myself more fortunate than many others here on the board and that is a blessing. EDIT: This is the most informative article I've read on SVI. It's from 2011. Again, I do not know HOW extensive the SVI is... maybe when my new Uro gets my records. http://myprostatedoc.blogspot.com/20...g-seminal.html
Posts.Title: Is HT possible in early stage?

Posts.Content: Thank you, and I am more than happy to bury the hatchet. I am somewhat embarrassed by my actions, but I'm sure everyone understands (we are all under stress). I had assumed that my early cancer started out non-aggressive and later became that way... I don't know. As you say, without that qualifier, the statement was probably valid. Well, it is after all the same old internet that we all know and hate

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic What I find of great interest is their use of 0.03ng/ml ( measured about 3 months post RP) as a prognostically useful demarcation of biochemical persistence (BCP). .... [*]Those with G7, intermediate and high-risk PCa, especially with adverse path-report findings, would do well to request a uPSA at about 100 days RP if their initial 6-8 week values is the "standard <0.1" (as mine was). If your PSA is at a later time found to be going up, it may be useful to know just what your nadir value was and when it occurred, and whether there was biochemical persistence from the outset. This could help in treatment decisions regarding ART and SRT. This is also in line with the advice brothers have been getting from ROs about using values of 0.1 or lower as a threshold for starting RT. BTW, based on the detection rate of positive lymph nodes in the above study, I wonder how many guys with LN- on their RP path report are harboring micro-lesions in a LN left behind. It may be that the regional positive nodes that are detected after BCR actually began before, and not after, the RP. Interesting notes and thank you for your usual extensive research and interpretation Djin. I had mentioned the .03 threshold in a recent post, and I guess I am vindicated seeing it again here. My initial post-RP PSA was (like yours) declared undetectable at <.1 ... and from there went to .02, .03, so who knows if there was actually a nadir. Your final remark might actually be a bit disturbing. After what I experienced from 2012 to 2016 I don't even want to read what the USPSTF now has to say.

Posts.Content: Do not despair. I was G8 also, but with six positive cores - two of them 100%, and my PSA was 25, five months before surgery. Currently there is no evidence of disease, though I cannot be sure until after the HT has worn off in a couple of years. It has been a struggle, but it can be beaten. The scans will not eliminate the possibility of spread, as they are not that sensitive. But they will pick up if your case is seriously advanced. But I believe you are probably safe. Good luck with your path results.

Posts.Title: Muscle spasms

Posts.Content: I am sorry for your loss. He was fortunate to have you with him to the very end. I fully understand many of the questions you are now asking yourself about what you perhaps could or should have done differently. That is part of grieving. Do not allow yourself to feel guilty about anything. You did the best you could at each stage, making decisions that you felt were in his best interest, hoping that perhaps you could keep him with you for a little longer. I went thru the same thing with my mother five years ago. Should we have subjected her to so many treatments, and did that just increase her suffering? In the end, it came down to the fact that we were not aware just how fast she was going. Had we known it was only a matter of months, we probably would have spared her the pain of trying to keep her alive. No one knows. But we cannot go back and change any of it. And I am certain that she knew we were in a difficult situation also. Thirty years ago, it was my father. I did not realize until much later that he had been trying to say goodbye to me. I totally missed it. Two weeks later, he was gone. And your dad also likely knew that you were trying to spare yourself the agony of losing him. It's only natural. Hopefully in his final moments he could feel all the love you had given him.

Posts.Title: 7 months post surgery , still in the zero club

Posts.Content: Just when I thought I was beginning to understand the answers, they change the questions. Following RP my Urologist informed me that I was T3b because the cancer had invaded both seminal vesicles. Examining the path report myself I noticed mention of 6mm extraprostatic extension (about 1/4 inch). I was researching the difference (if any) between extraprostatic and extracapsular extension, when I stumbled upon the following listed for stage 3 PCa: T3a: The tumor has extended outside of the prostate on one side. T3b: The tumor has extended outside of the prostate on both sides. T3c: The tumor has invaded one or both of the seminal vesicles, which are small bag-like organs near the bladder. Now, I had never heard of T3c before. The website seems targeted more for patients and less for MD's or pathologists (which I would trust more but understand less) so I'm guessing it's just inaccurate. The link is here: cancerconnect.com/stage-iii-c-prostate-cancer ... or is this something new? BTW and FWIW I think I suffered my first restless sleep/night sweats/hot flashes last night since the six month Lupron injection exactly three weeks ago. I was up every hour to pee (nighttime is the only break I get from constantly wearing either padding or plumbing) so that too was unusual. Most nights I only get up once, if at all, to void. Very unusual. I'm hoping it had more to do with yesterday's Chinese dinner rather than the Lupron. Hang in there everyone. Remember, I'm pulling for you. We're all in this together!

Posts.Title: Will the real T3B please stand up

Posts.Content: I don't know about the free psa, but for a long time I had a burning sensation in my urethra, but not when urinating. The burning would keep me awake at night. Cipro helped, but required longer and longer courses, and my psa kept rising. My urologist kept telling me that all my tests were negative. Only a biopsy can determine if you have cancer, but a MRI may be needed to locate it. Good luck.

Posts.Title: PSA confusion

Posts.Content: Thanks Jamie. Just today I was trying to remember when my last PSA blood draw was, which seemed like it was just a few weeks ago. Then I realized that the entire month of December was missing from my total recall. It's no wonder. From my wife's first order for an MRI on the 2nd to her emergency eye surgery on the 28th, I spent most of the month of December driving her back and forth to various medical facilities. I barely had time to post in this forum, other than an occasional mention of the latest news on her status. We did nothing for New Years, just split some champagne. Our older son just returned from Iraq and is spending a few days with us. This morning I actually had time to leave notes in a couple threads here, then today we finally saw Rogue One together... I instinctively ordered 3D tickets then realized that my wife would be unable to see half of what was going on (still enjoyed it in 2D). Monday I see the R/O about my SRT and Tuesday my wife has her second round of chemo. We've already been shopping for caps and wigs. Wednesday back to the eye Dr... then maybe a chance to catch my breath!
Posts.Title: Goodbye 2016 - the year my wife and I BOTH fought cancer

Posts.Content: The USPSTF recommendations published in 2012 apparently led to many men developing advanced prostate cancer which could have been successfully treated early on, because they exhibited steadily rising PSA's but showed no other symptoms... myself being one of them. Oddly enough, had my tumor been located a bit lower in the prostate it might have presented to a DRE and all would have been good. However, because only about one third of the prostate can be approached by DRE or by TRUS biopsy, a significant number of cancers went undetected over the past five years. This was recently discussed here in another thread... https://www.cancerforums.net/threads/54538-PSA-testing-change-2017. Bottom line, when doctors stop testing for a certain disease, then the number of reported cases will decline. And that's exactly what happened, thereby legitimizing that panel's recommendations. The blowback is that there are now even more men with advanced and in some cases untreatable cancer. It's a good thing you got that "accidental" PSA test, which probably saved your life. This eats away at me every time I think about it, and it has been difficult to accept what happened. It still burns me up when I read about the alleged "overtreatment" of prostate cancer. Personally I would rather be free of cancer rather than being told that it was better to just live with it. Apparently there was a very vocal group who felt they had been somehow wronged by doctors who they believed had performed unnecessary surgery. At some point I gotta stop posting in threads like this. It ain't helping. Maybe a Xanax will.

I wonder what they've been up to in the past fifteen years?

Posts.Title: Will the real T3B please stand up

Posts.Content: Recently I made a simple remark regarding HT in another thread. Then another user asked that I cite "specific research" to support my statement. But since my remark was based only on personal experience, I have no such research. And since I do not wish to further hijack the original thread I will continue the story here in a new thread. It is a long story which I still do not fully understand. Several years ago it was discovered that my PSA had jumped from 4 to 9. DRE's were negative as was the first biopsy, but the PSA continued to rise. When I asked the doctor what was next he said another biopsy. I asked "and if that is also negative then what" and he said medicine. I asked what kind of medicine and he said a series of injections to lower my PSA. Although there was no mention of hormones in general or ADT in particular, in retrospect it now sounds to me a lot like HT. From that experience I was under the impression that HT could possibly be used as a first line of defense. Jump to the present. The second biopsy revealed what was characterized as aggressive prostate cancer, and the choices I was given were surgery or radiation and possibly both. Last Friday night, a newbie posted a couple questions as he was facing his first biopsy. I replied with a paragraph about my biopsy and added a couple lines that he may face surgery or radiation, and that some cancers can be treated with hormone injections. Again, all based solely on assumptions from my own personal experiences. So the next morning, this other user states that he has consulted with top experts and had never heard of such a thing. He seemed to be demanding that I cite references to back up my claim. I felt like a school kid being told to "show your work". Now please realize that I am a simple man who has been thrown into this whole PCa thing seemingly over night. I reacted emotionally. I certainly have no research behind my innocent comment, only supposition. But what he then said seemed to contradict my only experience. He said that HT is used only to treat advanced cancer that is beyond surgery or radiation... if I am recalling this correctly, that it is essentially the last line of defense. But I had been told by my Uro that my early cancer could have been treated with a series of injections before it was discovered to be both aggressive and metastatic, but now it can only be treated with a combination of both surgery and radiation. I have since apologized to the other poster by PM. I have also read thru the HT sticky and found that many there have had HT following surgery and/or radiation to lower their PSA. I am aware of the drastic side effects of HT and do not intend to diminish that. I also realize that since my post op PSA so far is undetectable, HT would not be of any benefit at this stage. As much as I just want to put this whole thing behind me, I am curious and need to ask those in the know... is HT only for end stage PC which cannot be treated by surgery or radiation, or can it also be used in the early stages of cancer prior to surgery or RT? Or is it something else? Thanks for any input. My story is even longer but I've tried to keep it relatively short here. Please forgive my naivety if I may have unwittingly stepped on any toes.

Posts.Title: Is HT possible in early stage?

Posts.Content: Okay, I just googled cancer stages and found the TMB scale, and I see that stage 4 is called distant metastasis (thank goodness for spell check... I misspell it every time). Stage 3 is "spread to local tissues". That's what I have, and I did not intend to make it anything more than that. Not to throw out the newbie thing again, but I have pretty much had to figure this stuff out myself. I had the original pathology report from the biopsy that had the percents and cores, but after that I've been on my own to find out what I can. It has been just five months since my first diagnosis. Then just before we moved (the last time I saw my Urologist) he mentioned that I will need radiation in six months because the cancer had spread into both seminal vesicles and I am T3B. I added the N0 myself after reading up on SVI. That's when I learned that means I have an 80% chance of surviving ten years. I try to not let that get me down... that's a one in five chance of never seeing 75. Okay, I'm getting dramatic again. Anyway, the whole HT thing came about because all the time that my previous Urologist was watchfully waiting or whatever, the cancer was growing inside me, and I am more than just a little pissed about that. Hopefully I haven't said "too much" once again... like Trump's midnight tweets.
Posts.Title: Is HT possible in early stage?

Posts.Content: Congratulations on the undetectable post-op PSA. That's very important. But I know the lingering incontinence can be a big concern. I've been told six to twelve months. Ugh! Sounds like your progress in that dept is much better than mine. Hang in there! As long as there is improvement month to month you probably have nothing to worry about. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Decision made, and PSA result

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MrEd I am married, grown kids and just retired on Monday, Been planned for 6 months. Welcome Ed to the club that no one wants to be a member of. The advantages of surgery are that the entire prostate can be dissected and analyzed after removal, and if extraprostatic extension is identified you have the backup option of radiation. My PCa hit me also just as my wife and I were in the midst of fulfilling our retirement plans. In fact, one of the big reasons for going with surgery rather than radiation (in addition to those above) is that I did not have two months to undergo daily radiation. Yes, it could have been worked in, but was not practical. In fact, my RALP was right after we had driven a large Uhaul to Florida, unpacked and flew back to Ohio the very weekend before surgery. Less than two months later, it was no longer our home and we were back in Florida. Like yours, when my PSA hit 12 was when I became very concerned. Plus I had a couple of (4+3) cores that were later elevated to G8 post-op. I'm telling you this because it is not uncommon for the grade of cancer in the prostate to be higher than was indicated in the biopsy, so don't be surprised. There are a few of us here with a similar experience. Good luck in your treatment and recovery!

Posts.Title: Hi, new member

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kim McComas Dr said my husbands PSA levels was 95.3 and that's sky high... He has a lot of test coming up. I'm worried I was reading with levels that high it possibly spread. Yes, that is sky high, probably too high to be caused by an infection or anything other than cancer. You have every reason to be worried... However, it is most likely still treatable. The tests will include a bone scan to determine if it has spread to his bones (worst case) and an MRI to identify the size and location of his tumor, which will most likely lead to a biopsy. Most if not all of us here (those of us who are cancer patients, not relatives of a patient such as yourself) started with out with the biopsy. Then the urologist will offer recommendations depending on the extent of your husband's disease, his age and his general health... surgery, radiation, chemo. Some PSA's have been measured in the hundreds... guys who are alive and posting here regularly, so do not be alarmed. The road ahead will be rough on both of you, but in all likelihood there is a favorable outcome in the end. Good luck, and keep us posted. The more information you can provide, the better support we - those of us here, will be able to provide.

Posts.Title: Prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: I am sorry for your loss. He was fortunate to have you with him to the very end. I fully understand many of the questions you are now asking yourself about what you perhaps could or should have done differently. That is part of grieving. Do not allow yourself to feel guilty about anything. You did the best you could at each stage, making decisions that you felt were in his best interest, hoping that perhaps you could keep him with you for a little longer. I went thru the same thing with my mother five years ago. Should we have subjected her to so many treatments, and did that just increase her suffering? In the end, it came down to the fact that we were not aware just how fast she was going. Had we known it was only a matter of months, we probably would have spared her the pain of trying to keep her alive. No one knows. But we cannot go back and change any of it. And I am certain that she knew we were in a difficult situation also. Thirty years ago, it was my father. I did not realize until much later that he had been trying to say goodbye to me. I totally missed it. Two weeks later, he was gone. And your dad also likely knew that you were trying to spare yourself the agony of losing him. It's only natural. Hopefully in his final moments he could feel all the love you had given him.

Posts.Content: I don't know about the free psa, but for a long time I had a burning sensation in my urethra, but not when urinating. The burning would keep me awake at night. Cipro helped, but required longer and longer courses, and my psa kept rising. My urologist kept telling me that all my tests were negative. Only a biopsy can determine if you have cancer, but a MRI may be needed to locate it. Good luck.

Posts.Title: PSA confusion

Posts.Content: The year in review (pardon maybe a little tipsy right now): New Years 2016 - we'd been in Florida for about a month and healthy for all we know Easter - a few days afterwards, we flew back to Ohio to clear out and sell our house Memorial Day - Urologist said he is retiring next month but his partner can take over my case. Fourth of July - had the MRI and biopsy in June and got the bad new on July 5th. August - okay, no holiday, but my wife and I drove a Uhaul full of stuff back to Florida. Labor Day - flew back to Ohio three days before the RALP surgery Halloween - two months post op, the house is sold and we drive back to Florida, and by the way, I'll need SRT Thanksgiving - wife's back pain getting much worse. Got an MRI the following week. December - all hell breaks lose. Tumor on her spine. Admitted to hospital. Final Dx lymphoma (DLCBL) Christmas - radiation and first chemo done, back home late night before Xmas eve, slept like a log! Day after Christmas - she noticed visual changes, rush to ophthalmologist, emergency eye surgery on Wed New Year Eve - what a month. Wife getting eye drops 4X daily, eye patch, now she looks like a pirate. 2017 - already know she has more chemo and I will probably have radiation BUT IT HAS GOT TO BE BETTER! Happy New Year Everyone!

Posts.Title: Goodbye 2016 - the year my wife and I BOTH fought cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ready2Fight My prayers for the best possible health for both you and your wife in 2017! Thank you for helping others by contributing so much to this forum even while dealing with these serious health issues. Hang in there, you're truly an inspiration! Thank you so much for your kind words. Some people always know just the right thing to say, though I am not so fortunate. But one thing I learned about ten years ago after a serious leg injury is that visiting forums such as this and reading about other peoples' problems make one realize that our own problems are relatively small. What I mean is no matter how bad our situation is, there are always others who have it much worse. So therefore I generally feel that, if you have to have something wrong, may it be something that is commonly known and readily treatable. Sometimes stuff happens to us that is just nature's way of letting us know it's time to slow down or just to remind us that we are not invulnerable. Reading about others who have SERIOUS health issues can make us realize just how fortunate we are.

Posts.Title: Goodbye 2016 - the year my wife and I BOTH fought cancer

Posts.Content: Two months post op myself. I seem to have good control at night, but during the day have no control whatsoever. I wake up several times a night to pee. I can hold it until I can get to the bathroom, and then have a good stream. Sounds good right? Well, during the day time when I'm standing or sometimes if I stand up from sitting, the pee just runs out of me and soaks whatever pad I am wearing. I don't even feel it until several seconds into the stream. When I'm sitting I feel like I have to pee, so I go into the bathroom but can't go. So as soon as I pull up my underpants, I squirt. It drives me nuts. But I have read some others have similar sensations so I don't worry. My Uro said it's typically 6-12 months to regain control. I just remember how far I've gone since the weeks immediately following surgery.

Posts.Title: Adjuvant or Salvage radiation treatment?

Posts.Content: The USPSTF recommendations published in 2012 apparently led to many men developing advanced prostate cancer which could have been successfully treated early on, because they exhibited steadily rising PSA's but showed no other symptoms... myself being one of them. Oddly enough, had my tumor been located a bit lower in the prostate it might have presented to a DRE and all would have been good. However, because only about one third of the prostate can be approached by DRE or by TRUS biopsy, a significant number of cancers went undetected over the past five years. This was recently discussed here in another thread... https://www.cancerforums.net/threads/54538-PSA-testing-change-2017. Bottom line, when doctors stop testing for a certain disease, then the number of reported cases will decline. And that's exactly what happened, thereby legitimizing that panel's recommendations. The blowback is that there are now even more men with advanced and in some cases untreatable cancer. It's a good thing you got that "accidental" PSA test, which probably saved your life. This eats away at me every time I think about it, and it has been difficult to accept what happened. It still burns me up when I read about the alleged "overtreatment" of prostate cancer. Personally I would rather be free of cancer rather than being told that it was better to just live with it. Apparently there was a very vocal group who felt they had been somehow wronged by doctors who they believed had performed unnecessary surgery. At some point I gotta stop posting in threads like this. It ain't helping. Maybe a Xanax will.

Posts.Title: Alternative to PSA?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind Radiation will stop the healing and recovery process right where it is so unless the need is compelling, I would wait as long as necessary to fully recover from the surgery before beginning the RT. I just learned about this myself recently, and as I still have only partial bladder control and have had zero erections since surgery ten weeks ago, I definitely hope to postpone RT until those issues have improved, at least the incontinence. Try to find a RO who has access to a newer LINAC, the machine that will be used to deliver the radiation..The newer equipment has made big advances over the older machines and they do a much better job especially when it comes to avoiding damage to healthy tissue...I would insist on a Varian Rapid-Arc or newer....it costs no more... Thanks for the info on this. I have my first consult with a RO coming soon and will try to remember to inquire about the equipment he has in his arsenal.

Posts.Title: Adjuvant or Salvage radiation treatment?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mikesimm I had surgery Oct. 23... with a tumor located extensively in the apex and base. Invasion of both seminal vesicals, perivesicular soft tissue, and microscopic bladder neck invasion. Clear margins. No lymph node or other involvement. Staged at pT3b. Considering the extent of all that, I was fully expecting to go in and learn about my future treatment plan (radiation, hormone therapy, etc.). Turns out, my PSA on that same day was "undetectable". So the news was... "come back in six months". I was kinda shocked, but thrilled, of course. I asked him about the ultra-sensitive PSA testing - he's not a fan, saying it just causes unnecessary worry... Congrats on getting thru the surgery and your first follow up, and though your abdominal pain is unfortunate, it sounds like that is clearing up with time. So set your mind at ease for now and relax during your recovery and focus on regaining your continence. But I must say (doing my best Ed Grimley impersonation) that your initial expectations are probably accurate, given that SVI and your T3B staging always qualify as 'adverse pathology' and automatically justify adjuvant radiation and probably also hormone deprivation therapy within your first year post-op and preferably as soon as you have regained continence. My surgeon was also "not a fan" of ultra sensitive PSA and informed me on my first post-op that my PSA was "undetectable", but he also informed me immediately after surgery of the implications of SVI and the need for RT in about six months post-op. I suspect that your surgeon will likely be more forthcoming with this information at your next follow up in six months. Given your relatively low pre-op PSA there is probably little reason to be concerned at this point, and likely no cause to jump into early RT. But your Uro would be wise to proceed with ART before your PSA begins to rise, as opposed to waiting for some threshold to trigger salvage radiation. SVI is serious business and T3B is considered "very high risk" and is the final stage before bone metastasis, at which point PCa evolves into an entirely different disease. Again, good luck in your continued recovery, but don't let the wild horses get away from you. Just sayin'.

Posts.Title: Pathology Report seems OK or maybe not so OK

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 "But will Medicare make me wait till it hits .2, which is the AUA guideline? " ... On the other hand, Medicare has rarely posed any authorization problems over the last ten years for me and my wife. I find it hard to believe that a program run by the Federal Government works so smoothly, for the most part. Originally Posted by Pratoman Jim I've been on Medicare for a year and a half and I too am amazed how well it's worked so far. Just hoping it's there when I really need it. If I ever do. For SRT I am 100% satisfied... no, pleased, with Medicare and with my Aetna supplemental. I've never had to pay a dime for anything, except a few prescriptions (and with GoodRx, those cost far less than I would pay monthly for any Rx drug plan). I was on Medicare for 8 months when the MRI and biopsy identified my tumor. Lori has commercial BCBS and we had $10K out of pocket last year for her lymphoma. We've had a terrible experience with them, but mostly that was the TOTALLY TERRIBLE billing department at the hospital where she was treated. This year she goes on Medicare, no medical questions are asked of new enrollees. Here's hoping the worst is behind us!
Posts.Title: Post SRT PSA decline

Posts.Content: Ken, sorry to hear the news, but then again it wasn't totally unexpected. This is the moment you've been anticipating for about as long as I've known you on this forum. Whatever the rate of rise might be, it's definitely rising, and there's no two ways about that. At this low level it's probably better that you forego ADT anyway for the sake of your own comfort as well as not introducing yet another delay into your SRT schedule, as they generally like two months of HT before starting RT. Also this way you'll be saving HT as an extra round in the clip to pull out if you need more heavy armaments later on. Remember that the RT will continue killing cancer cells for eight months or so after treatment ends, so it will be a while before you'll get an accurate PSA again. And good for you for rejecting getting involved in any trendy RT delivery techniques. Stick with what works. And good luck!

Posts.Title: Post SRT PSA decline

Posts.Content: Last week had my third uPSA since completing ART and was thrilled (no, shocked) that all three came back as 0.0 ... Per another thread that was Quest so I wonder if that was actually "<0.02"?? ... But I won't be looking this gift horse in the mouth! So now we move to six month testing, but since my testosterone is only nine (yes, that's 009) my Uro said that it's unlikely much will have changed by then. And with this being my 999th post on this forum, what could be more fitting than rolling the odometer over to three zeroes in a row? Hopefully as the Lupron wears off I may regain some semblance of brain power once again. But I'm pretty sure that my little head (you know, the second head that controls us guys) is probably down for the count. But where one door closes, another opens. Last October after completing RT I had an MRI that was inconclusive after an ENT had found a mass in my throat. One thing led to another and I had nasopharyngeal surgery in April, after which he said he "couldn't get to it" (this just keeps getting better). So as mentioned in another forum I started prednisone yesterday and am having a CT tomorrow. Not sure where this may lead but it's fairly safe to assume it's NOT cancer. I do appreciate the well wishes I've had from everyone. At least I won't be worrying about PCa for a long while.

Posts.Title: Three consecutive 0.0 PSA's ... No More Lupron, WooHoo!

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club BH. Your PSA of 9 is high, and 14 is very high, especially for a man your age. Had you had any previous PSA tests? I know they usually don't bother until around age 50. Note the PSA measures prostate inflammation, and is not a cancer test. It is possible, though unlikely, that your PSA is elevated due to an infection or perhaps sexual activity or strenuous exercise. But it is good that you are getting the biopsy. But there's one thing you need to be aware of, and depending on your doctor, your urologist may never tell you this (mine didn't). If your biopsy is 'negative', it does NOT mean that you do NOT have cancer. The biopsy is a flawed test where the urologist essentially closes his eyes and pokes needles into you, hoping to hit something if it's in there. So you will need to be your own advocate if your urologist seems to be unconcerned about your condition. Feel free to some back here and ask questions anytime. And good luck to you!

Posts.Title: New Member and Scared!

Posts.Content: Just noticed in your quote of my post that I had mistakenly omitted the word "not"... at 4+ your PSA is NOT terribly high. My GP sent me to a Uro when mine went over 4, but it was several years before the cancer was discovered. As I understand it, tumors at the BASE of the prostate - the area closest to the bladder (the TOP of the prostate... it is viewed upside down) ... tumors at the base are difficult to find via DRE or by ultrasound biopsy. The good news is that if you do have a tumor at the base, it is least likely to leave a "positive surgical margin" post-op, which is a frequent cause of recurrence. Welcome back, by the way.

Posts.Title: Hi, new member

Posts.Content: Ice, looks like your PSA is rising, but you probably need a few more to be sure it is up, up, up. At 4.+ it's not terribly high, but when it hits ten, there's no doubt you got something going on in there. Mine kept going up, but my biopsy was negative and all my DRE's were normal. I wasn't able to get the MRI guided fusion biopsy until I changed Uro's. It was quite a struggle. As much as I hope that you do not have cancer, a negative biopsy is not proof of that... unfortunately.

Posts.Content: Merry Christmas to all, and God bless us every one! ... And Holiday greetings where appropriate, or Happy Festivus. This is our second Christmas in the tropical south, surrounded by palm trees and 80+ degree temperatures, but our first Christmas without a home to return to in the great white north. And this is our first Christmas as cancer survivors for both my wife and I, with several months of therapy for us both in the coming New Year. But we ARE survivors, with much to be thankful for. May your days be merry and bright!

Posts.Content: Ken, sorry to hear the news, but then again it wasn't totally unexpected. This is the moment you've been anticipating for about as long as I've known you on this forum. Whatever the rate of rise might be, it's definitely rising, and there's no two ways about that. At this low level it's probably better that you forego ADT anyway for the sake of your own comfort as well as not introducing yet another delay into your SRT schedule, as they generally like two months of HT before starting RT. Also this way you'll be saving HT as an extra round in the clip to pull out if you need more heavy armaments later on. Remember that the RT will continue killing cancer cells for eight months or so after treatment ends, so it will be a while before you'll get an accurate PSA again. And good for you for rejecting getting involved in any trendy RT delivery techniques. Stick with what works. And good luck!

Posts.Content: Charles Krauthammer died late this afternoon from cancer at age 68; what kind of cancer has not been declared. For anyone who does not know his name you owe it to yourself to find out. He was a brilliant, witty, humble man, who could debate without arguing, and influence without offending. We normally do not bring up politics here, but Doctor Krauthammer transcended earthly politics. Spending most of his life in a wheelchair, he worked for Jimmy Carter and Walter Mondale, Ronald Reagan and eventually Fox news. Many were unaware of his disability, People said of him that when he spoke, everyone listened. One of his recent quotes spoke of "the catastrophe that awaits everyone". Perhaps it was his comprehension of death that made him appreciate and enjoy life so much. Most of us here have survived at least one life altering event. Hopefully we have come out of it stronger and wiser. He always made the best of every situation. His final words: my fight is over. Rest in peace.
Posts.Title: RIP Charles Krauthammer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by leach234 Couldn't stand the guy. ... and he would have respected your opinion.

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club BH. Your PSA of 9 is high, and 14 is very high, especially for a man your age. Had you had any previous PSA tests? I know they usually don't bother until around age 50. Note the PSA measures prostate inflammation, and is not a cancer test. It is possible, though unlikely, that your PSA is elevated due to an infection or perhaps sexual activity or strenuous exercise. But it is good that you are getting the biopsy. But there's one thing you need to be aware of, and depending on your doctor, your urologist may never tell you this (mine didn't). If your biopsy is 'negative', it does NOT mean that you do NOT have cancer. The biopsy is a flawed test where the urologist essentially closes his eyes and pokes needles into you, hoping to hit something if it's in there. So you will need to be your own advocate if your urologist seems to be unconcerned about your condition. Feel free to some back here and ask questions anytime. And good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH The main thing to keep in mind is that the only current test that can officially diagnose prostate cancer is a biopsy. And, as you noted, even a biopsy can miss a tumor if the needle happens to shoot past it. This happens in over 20% of standard 12-core biopsies. That's what happened. My cancer probably could have been caught two years earlier. Originally Posted by IM Fletcher He wanted me to get a biopsy but I started asking more questions and he seemed concerned about possible infection due to my daily antibiotic, so he ordered an MRI (which was a fiasco due to insurance balking several times because, apparently, the "protocol" is to get one after a positive biopsy. Makes no sense to me ... First approach always seems to be infection. Apparently insurance will not pay for an MRI until after there has been a biopsy, even a negative one, I guess. In my wife's case, we paid CASH for the MRI that revealed her spinal tumor, bypassing the insurance, for expediency. Having that MRI in hand was indispensable when it came to getting treatment for her lymphoma. Originally Posted by IM Fletcher Bottom line, I'm learning, is that the prostate is one puzzling piece of work. There doesn't seem to be a definitive anything. Even a biopsy could miss cancer. Then, if you have cancer, there is no definitive on whether to treat or not. It's extremely frustrating. 'nuff said. Secondary question is about the three months. I know what I've read here and abound, but it goes against my rational thought to sit on things for three months. Why not check the PSA next week and see where it is? If (the big IF) I were to have it, couldn't it get worse or leave the prostate in three months time? At some point there has to be a line of demarcation in regards to metastasis, but there doesn't seem to be any sort of urgency when it comes to PC I think it's because any test is expensive, even a PSA test. Mine is checked every five weeks, but then I still have cancer. PCa does grow slowly. Some less common forms can progress rapidly, but for the more typical PCa, not much difference between a few weeks and a few months... imo, afaik. Unfortunate. Given how common PCa is, especially over age 60, you'd think there would be better screening.
